The Treasury was scheduled to sell $10.5 billion in three-year notes Tuesday, the first leg of its three-part, $30.5 billion quarterly refunding. ``The dollar is unlikely to keep rising because sooner or later investors will start selling it for profit-taking,'' said Akiyoshi Sakai, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The mood on the stock market was basically optimistic for the short term, according to Chris Schreiber, a broker with New Japan Securities Co. ``There's a general feeling that the currency is pretty stable. Interest rates also seem stable, so short-term conditions look pretty sound.'' But he added that a 0.05 percentage point reduction in brokerage commissions that took effect Tuesday was encouraging small investors to take profits. ``The lower commission makes it easier for individual investors to meet their profit targets,'' Schreiber said. Investors who trade small lots pay higher commissions, now a maximum of 1.15 percent, under Tokyo's fixed-rate system. In bond dealings, the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond strengthened. As of 3 p.m. it was listed at 86.43 points, up from 86.36 points Monday. The yield dropped to 7.280 points from Monday's or 7.295 percent. 10-year Japanese government bond weakened to 86.29 from 86.36 Monday. That boosted the yield to 7.31 percent from 7.295 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bandits Oil Street to Rob Occupants of Stalled Cars
DOC.TEXT: In a slick new twist to street crime, hoods have been oiling down an intersection and attacking motorists who spin out on the goo. No serious injuries have been reported in the attacks over the past month by the oilcan bandits wielding clubs, bottles and guns, police said Monday. City cleanup crews have repeatedly spread sand on the slick but now work only with a police escort after Molotov cocktails were thrown at them, authorities said. On Monday, a TV news crew was pelted with rocks and bottles. The L-shaped intersection in the Mission District abuts the rundown, graffiti-scarred Bernal Housing Project, a multi-story complex covering two blocks. The oil catches drivers stopped at lights, police said. ``With the oil on the streets, the tires can't get a grip, and the victims can't get away,'' said Lt. Al Casciato. ``They're just helpless.'' ``What we figure is happening is people going there to buy drugs are being ripped off,'' he said. By the time officers arrive, the victims have fled, he said. Police have arrested one suspect. One robbery has been directly linked to the oil slick, but Casciato said residents call frequently to report assaults at the slippery intersection. Early Saturday, Casciato watched a group of men drag a driver out of a spun-out car and rob him. Officers chased the suspects into the housing project, where they escaped, Casciato said. On Monday, a sandy stain remained on the street around a corner where police say dealers openly sell crack and marijuana. One block away, well-tended Victorian homes stand out against the bleak projects. Sgt. Gile Pursley said Saturday's slick was as wide as two cars and about 70 feet long. At least 15 gallons of goo too slick to walk on covered the road, he said. The outline of a human figure was spray-painted by locals on the asphalt next to the slogan ``211 victom (sic),'' a reference to the penal code number for robbery. Since April 24, eight robberies have been reported in the area, and three attempted robberies have been reported since May 1, one of which was definitely grease-related, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Accord Is History Repeating Itself
DOC.TEXT: An arrangement under which more than 13,000 Contra rebels are to disarm and be given land to work parallels in some ways an earlier episode in 20th-century Nicaraguan history. In 1932, a newly elected civilian government uneasily co-existing with a strong military struck a peace pact with recalcitrant guerrillas. In exchange for laying down their weapons, the rebels of the 1920s and 30s were promised a huge cooperative where they could farm and live among their own. Augusto Cesar Sandino, the ``general of free men'' who fought against the U.S. occupation of Nicaragua for five years, had cut a deal with the elected government of President Juan Bautista Sacasa. Sandino and his army of peasants were granted about a fourth of the country to farm. Resentful of the pact and suspicious of the rebel general's intentions, Gen. Anastasio Somoza, who headed the National Guard created by the United States, had Sandino killed on Feb. 21, 1934. Less than two years later, Somoza seized power, starting a 43-year dynasty that ended on July 19, 1979, when the guerrillas of the Sandinista National Liberation Front _ named after Sandino _ seized control of a popular uprising and ousted Somoza's son, also named Anastasio. Now the U.S.-backed Contra rebels have cut a deal with the new government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in exchange for giving up their arms in a process that was to begin today. Mrs. Chamorro, elected Feb. 25 and inaugurated last month, is struggling to bring peace to a country that has seen nine years of war between the Contras and the leftist Sandinistas, who continue to control the army. In exchange for disarming, the Contras, most of whom are peasants, are to receive land in southern Nicaragua where they can settle. The Contras had refused to fulfill a previous accord to lay down their arms, saying they wanted Gen. Humberto Ortega, brother of former President Daniel Ortega and a leader of the Sandinista revolution, removed as commander in chief of the armed forces. The latest accord, reached last Friday, makes no mention of that demand. Mrs. Chamorro's government, in a transition of power agreement signed in March, allowed the Sandinistas to keep control of the army in exchange for de-politicizing the body. She has said Gen. Ortega will keep his post only temporarily. In a gesture designed to show the civilian government's ultimate control of the armed forces, Mrs. Chamorro took over the post of defense minister herself. Contras and Sandinistas, both of whom understand military power far better than political accommodation, remain suspicious of each other. Since Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration, the Contras have been gathering in security zones established on a rough north-south line through central Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Racketeering Charge Dismissed Against Federal Judge
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have dropped the first-ever charge of racketeering against a federal judge, but Robert Aguilar still faces retrial on five charges. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle on Monday granted dismissal of the racketeering charge and another count against Aguilar. Aguilar, 59, remains charged with leaking a wiretap, trying to deceive the grand jury and the FBI and conspiring to influence a fellow judge to grant favorable treatment to a felon. The charges carry up to 25 years in prison. Bechtle also granted a defense request to delay the retrial from June 4 to August because of a foot injury incurred by Aquilar's chief attorney, Patrick Halliman. Halliman needs medication that could affect his concentration. Bechtle did not rule on a defense request seeking government documents to support Aguilar's claim he is being prosecuted for his liberal rulings. The jury at Aguilar's first trial acquitted the U.S. District Court judge March 19 of trying to influence a colleague in a felony case, and deadlocked on seven other charges, including use of his judgeship as a racketeering enterprise. The Justice Department then moved to dismiss the racketeering charge, saying the one charge on which Aguilar was acquitted might have left a fatal gap in the ``pattern of racketeering activity'' alleged in the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Up, Stocks Also Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up in Tokyo today after a three-day decline, while the stock market extended its rally to a fifth day with a marginal gain. The dollar closed at 158.05 yen, up 0.25 yen from Monday's close of 157.80 yen. After opening at 158.15 yen, it ranged between 157.95 yen and 158.25 yen. The dollar had fallen 1.28 yen in the three previous trading days. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed above 31,000 points briefly but closed at 30,970.58, up just 14.31 points, or 0.046 percent, from Monday's close. The Nikkei gained 782.63 points Monday. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond strengthened. As of 4 p.m. it was listed at 86.43 points, up from 86.36 on Monday. The yield dropped to 7.280 from Monday's 7.295 percent. ``Yen-dollar trading was quiet as market participants are awaiting the start of (the U.S. Treasury bond) auction tonight,'' said Mamoru Tabata, a currency dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``The dollar stayed in an extremely narrow range.'' Masafumi Koyama, chief customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo, said there was not much interest in yen-dollar deals among either buyers or sellers. Trading against European currencies occupied center stage, he said. ``Cross-trading against the (West German) mark, Swiss franc and even the sterling pound will continue'' overnight, Koyama said. If the dollar weakens against those currencies, it will advance no further than the lower 159-yen range against the yen, he predicted . The stock market, meanwhile, is aiming at the 31,600 mark, where it would recoup one-third of its losses this year, said Chris Schreiber, a broker with New Japan Securities Co. But in today's trading, he added, ``every time it got up there around 31,000, there was selling pressure.'' He questioned whether the rally could be sustained, noting that only the ``externals'' _ interest rates and currency stability _ were positive. Purchases centered on bargain hunting for stocks with latent value in land holdings rather than profitability, he said. ``The market's negative factors are still out there,'' he said, citing a large number of margin purchases that will be dumped on the market by June to make settlement deadlines. Some traders said that brokerages, not investors, were the main buyers behind the rally. ``Brokers are trying to rescue issues from December,'' said Julian Jones, a broker at W.I. Carr. The Nikkei peaked at the end of December before beginning a slide of more than 25 percent. The slump apparently bottomed out April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Family Donates $20 Million to Yale
DOC.TEXT: The Bass family of Texas has donated $20 million to Yale University to study the environment and says its largesse won't end there. The gift will establish the Yale Institute of Biospheric Studies, which will take a broad interdisciplinary approach to studying the biosphere _ that zone of the earth, from crust to atmosphere, that contains living organisms. The donation is the biggest Yale has received since Paul Mellon, a 1929 graduate, contributed more than $12 million in 1966-67 to construct the Yale Center for British Art and an art collection worth an estimated $35 million. ``This institute is an idea whose time has come,'' said Edward Bass, a 1968 Yale graduate involved in a number of ecological issues worldwide. He said his family will make several additional gifts over the next 12 to 15 months to other areas of the university. He would not disclose the sum. The gift will pay for laboratory and classroom renovations, research, conferences, exhibitions and endowments. The gift also provides a $2 million endowment for the directorship of Yale's Peabody Museum of Natural History. Bass is chairman and chief executive of a venture and investment capital company, and has numerous other business interests. Fortune magazine in September placed the value of the Bass family fortune at $5 billion. Outside Tucson, Ariz., his Space Biospheres Ventures has been developing Biosphere II, a 2{-acre greenhouse-like, closed ecological system designed to test applications for living in space. Bass' father and three brothers are also Yale graduates. Sid Richardson Bass, a brother, is a Yale trustee. Previous gifts from the family included $1 million to establish an expository writing program. The institute will draw largely on the resources of the departments of biology, geology and geophysics, along with the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, said Yale President Benno C. Schmidt Jr.

DOC.HEAD: National Safety Council Calls for Lower Blood-Alcohol Limit
DOC.TEXT: The National Safety Council is calling on all states to lower their blood-alcohol limit for driving to 0.08 percent. Most states have a limit of 0.1 percent; at least four states _ California, Maine, Oregon and Utah _ already have 0.08 percent limits. A uniform standard among states would improve police handling of drunken driving cases and would increase public awareness of the problem, the council's board of directors said Monday in adopting the policy. More than 23,000 people die and about 350,000 are seriously injured each year in alcohol-related traffic accidents, the council said.

DOC.HEAD: Black Schools Chief Whose Dimissal Sparked Protests Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Selma's first black school superintendent, whose ouster sparked student boycotts and marches, has accepted an undisclosed amount to leave early and drop his $10 million lawsuit against the school board. Norward Roussell said Monday that the amount of the settlement was close to what he would have received if his three-year, $69,500-a-year contract had been renewed. The contract was to have run out June 30. He said the settlement would be effective ``when I get the money.'' In announcing his resignation, he cited the stress of the turmoil since the white-majority board voted in December not to renew his contract. The move sparked near-continuous protests by blacks, including a 5{-week sit-in at City Hall. Roussell had sued the city and the board, claiming racial discrimination. The board said it dismissed him because of a dictatorial management style. ``People are protesting because they want quality education for their children,'' Roussell said in a telephone interview. ``This protest has never been about me. It is not something I asked people to do.'' A leader of the continuing protests, Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, said Roussell's resignation wouldn't affect the demonstrations. ``We call them the Roussell wars and his situation was merely one battle,'' Varner said. ``We're just as concerned about tracking and other issues as his situation.'' Critics said ``tracking'' had been used by school officials to guide black students into lower-level classes regardless of their ability. In his lawsuit, Roussell said his attempt to revise the tracking system prompted his removal. School board member Dick Bean, who is white, said Roussell's resignation could allow the board's racial split to begin healing. Selma's schools have about 6,000 students, 70 percent of them black.

DOC.HEAD: Miss West Virginia's Attacker Given Probation
DOC.TEXT: A woman who kicked out the window of Miss West Virginia Lisa Bittinger's car and pulled the beauty queen's hair in a roadside tussle has been placed on two years' probation. Tammy Boyce, 24, was convicted of battery, destruction of property and reckless driving in the incident Nov. 7. She was sentenced Monday. Bittinger, 21, was charged with brandishing a pistol in the brawl but was acquitted.

DOC.HEAD: Lahad Says No Release of Shiites for Western Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Shiites imprisoned by an Israeli-backed militia in Lebanon will not be traded for Western hostages unless efforts are made to include freedom for militiamen and Israeli soldiers in the deal, the militia's commander says. The remarks by Gen. Antoine Lahad of the South Lebanon Army come as Washington steps up pressure on Israel to free Arab detainees to help win freedom for six Americans and 10 other Westerners held by Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon. Lahad's remarks Monday appeared to reflect a hard line by Israel toward any deal that excluded its own captives. ``I want to make clear ... that I cannot release anybody ... just because of the foreigners,'' Lahad said in an interview on Middle East Television. ``There is no way I can release (my prisoners) unless there are negotiations to release SLA and Israeli captives.'' Lahad holds 300 Arab detainees, most of them Shiite Moslems, at a jail two miles southeast of his headquarters in Marjayoun. Shiite extremist groups have demanded the release of detainees held by Lahad and Israel. An Iranian newspaper suggested last week that good will gestures by Israel would encourage the release of additional Western hostages. Two Americans were freed last month. Lahad also told the television network that he has temporarily stopped freeing prisoners for Moslem holidays to quell rumors that such moves were part of a package deal to release Western hostages. When the publicity dies down, Lahad will resume the customary prisoner release on Moslem holidays, the network quoted him as saying. Sources close to Lahad's 2,500-member South Lebanon Army, which gets training and supplies from Israel, said eight of his fighters are held by Shiite groups. Israel, meanwhile, reiterated that it is not opposed to a swap in principle, but that such an exchange should include three Israeli servicemen captured in Lebanon in 1986 and believed held by radical Shiites linked to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia. ``It is our stated policy that we are ready to contemplate an exchange for the Israeli prisoners who are held by those organizations,'' said Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. He denied there was any direct U.S. pressure on Israel to make prisoner releases exclusively on behalf of Western hostages. Israel's most prominent prisoner is Sheikh Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Shiite Moslem cleric. Obeid and two assistants were abducted by Israel in July. Israel also holds 9,986 Palestinians detained during the 29-month uprising against the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Of the Western hostages in Lebanon, the one held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Cambridge Names Commissioner of Laboratory Animals
DOC.TEXT: This university town has named a commissioner to oversee the welfare of some 60,000 animals used in experiments here each year. Dr. Stuart Wiles was named Monday to the position of commissioner of laboratory animals established by the City Council in June as part of the nation's first city ordinance to protect animals used for research. Wiles, a veterinarian, will monitor Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and about a dozen other academic and private firms that do about some $100 million per year in animal research. ``This will keep scientists honest,'' said Gul Agha, who initiated the legislation four years ago when he was a researcher at MIT. ``It's an excellent precedent because we have two of the most prestigious institutions in the country accepting accountability to the public,'' Agha, who teaches computer science at the University of Chicago at Urbana, said in a telephone interview. The ordinance, which covers all non-human vertebrates, defines an experiment as any procedure a research institution conducts on a live animal. Institutions covered include schools, colleges and diagnostic laboratories. Federal law covers dogs, cats and monkeys but not reptiles, amphibians, mice, rats and rabbits. Wiles' job will be to ensure that researchers provide proper ventilation, nourishment and other care to lab animals. The commissioner has the right to make unannounced visits to research sites, report infractions to the city manager, conduct hearings and impose fines of $300 per day per violation. ``There are a great many people concerned about the welfare of animals,'' Wiles said. ``But it's important to regulate _ not over-regulate or place an unfair burden on the researchers.''

DOC.HEAD: North Texas Nudists Bracing for Mosquitoes in Wake of Flooding
With PM-Flood Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The news from biologists that record flooding over the past two weeks is likely to produce a bumper crop of mosquitoes has been particularly unsettling to one group of Texans _ nudists. Claudia Adcock, manager of the Ponderosa Ranch nudist colony near Wills Point, said her camp is putting up bird houses to lure purple martins, which eat mosquitos ``like nobody's business.'' Officials said pests such as mosquitoes, fleas and fire ants will be plentiful because of the moisture this spring from the worst flooding since 1908. Spring is a particularly tough time for nudists anyway because many people are venturing out into the sun for the first time all year. To protect novice nudists, Ponderosa keeps an ample supply of insect repellent, sunburn ointment, poison-ivy lotion and other skin-injury remedies. ``Sunburn is our biggest problem with newcomers,'' Ms. Adcock said. ``If your butt ain't seen daylight before, you don't have any idea how quickly it's going to burn.''

DOC.HEAD: Beach Boy Wilson's Cousin Seeks to Take Over His Affairs
DOC.TEXT: Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys crashed a news conference called by cousin Stanley Love as Love was about to announce his intention to become legal overseer of the musician's estate and life. Wilson, 48, took the microphone at the Greater Los Angeles Press Club on Monday and declared he was fit to handle his own affairs. He dismissed allegations that therapist Eugene Landy controls his every move. ``I have heard of the charges by Stan Love, and I think they're outrageous,'' said Wilson. Wilson had just been served with a petition to appear at a June 22 conservatorship hearing in Superior Court, said Love's spokesman, Warren Duffy. Love, brother of Beach Boy Mike Love, said Landy abused his role as therapist by taking control of Wilson's finances and other aspects of the singer's life. Landy generated controversy and lost his psychology license after beginning a 24-hour treatment program for Wilson. Wilson has credited Landy with helping him beat his drug and alcohol addiction, slim down from more than 300 pounds and return to a music career that featured the release of an acclaimed solo record last year. Love, though, said he had taken care of Wilson for four years in the late 1970s and believes Landy has improperly treated Wilson. He said Wilson suffers from schizophrenia and an ``adaptive disorder.'' ``If Brian went to the store and gave the checker a $100 bill for a $2 item and the checker said, `May I keep the 98 bucks?' Brian would say, `Sure.' That's Brian's problem the whole time, whether it's the high level of LA or whether it's just a clerk at the store,'' said Love, a former Los Angeles Laker. Wilson, who is producing his second solo album, denied he is some sort of puppet. ``I see who I want to see when I want to see them. And I am totally in charge of my whole life,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Outlines Colombian $6 Million Drugs-for-Weapons Plot
DOC.TEXT: Two Colombians claiming to represent the Medellin cartel offered $6 million in cocaine proceeds for Stinger missiles and other weapons for use against aircraft carrying Colombian officials, the FBI says. The two defendants ordered 120 of the shoulder-fired ground-to-air missiles, FBI agent Charles A. Salemme testified at a hearing Monday. The men, who claimed to work for reputed cartel kingpin Pablo Escobar, told undercover agents they were willing to pay $5 million from the sale of a half-ton or more of cocaine for the missiles, 50 automatic rifles and a plane to carry them, Salemme said. An additional $1 million would be paid to those who would steal the weapons from the military, Salemme told U.S. Magistrate Thomas Wilson in Tampa. Instead of getting the Stingers, the men were arrested. Alfredo Antonio Ramos-Tinoco, 47, and Luis Fernando Arcila-Giraldo, 28, were ordered held without bail on charges of conspiracy to receive stolen property and export arms illegally. They were also charged with drug trafficking. No cash or weapons ever changed hands in the deal, the latest of several attempts by drug traffickers to obtain Stingers, authorities said. Federal officials say none of the earlier negotiations had gone as far as the deal foiled Saturday. The Colombians said the weapons were intended to show the Colombian government it was getting too close to the drug cartel, officials said. They planned to use the missiles to shoot down government helicopters in Colombia, investigators said. FBI officials said a Stinger on the legitimate arms market costs about $14,000. The 4-foot, 35-pound missile uses an infrared homing device to target the heat generated by the engine of a plane or helicopter. Allen McCreight, head of the FBI's Tampa office, said it was not known whether the negotiations for the weapons were directed by Escobar. Violence linked to Colombia's drug lords has claimed the lives of three presidential candidates in that country in the past year.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Blasts North Plains; Mild Over Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: A blast of cold descended over the northern Plains early today, while much of the rest of the nation enjoyed mild weather. A thunderstorn rumbled through North Platte, Neb., and temperatures dropped into the 30s and 40s in the Dakotas, Nebraska, Montana, Wyoming and Idaho. Rain fell in Albany, N.Y., and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., and winds buffeted Kansas City, Kan., Oklahoma City, Las Vegas and Key West, Fla. Today's forecast called for snow flurries in Idaho and Montana and showers over Wisconsin and southern Texas. Frost warnings were posted over Idaho and Oregon, and a hard freeze was possible in Idaho. On Monday, unseasonably high temperatures extended across the northern Plains. The high of 92 in St. Cloud, Minn., broke the record of 87 for the date, set in 1963. Flooding continued along the rain-swollen Trinity River south of Dallas. The high temperature in the nation Monday was 104 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: AP Cited in Three Foreign Reporting Categories
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press was cited for outstanding coverage of events in Romania, China and Iran, and three Pulitzer Prize winners also were honored by the Overseas Press Club. In awards announced Monday, the AP's two first-prize winners were Mort Rosenblum, for his reporting from Romania, and a photographer who covered the funeral of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini but who remains anonymous to avoid reprisals. A citation went to Jeff Widener for his photo of a Chinese man standing in front of a line of tanks. A newspaper reporting prize went to Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times for the China coverage that also won them a Pulitzer earlier this year. Another Pulitzer winner honored was David Turnley of the Detroit Free Press, cited by the press club for his photos from China and Romania. The club, at its annual banquet, also observed a minute's silence and announced it was sending cables of protest to the 18 nations where 76 journalists are imprisoned. The awards list: Hal Boyle Award for newspaper or news service reporting _ Rosenblum; Kristof and WuDunn. Bob Considine Award for newspaper or news service interpretation _ Jackson Diehl of The Washington Post, articles on Eastern Europe, with a citation to Claudia Rosset of The Wall Street Journal, on China. Robert Capa Gold Medal for photo reporting or interpretation requiring exceptional courage or enterprise _ Turnley; citations to Widener and to Christopher Morris of Black Star for Time magazine, for photos from Panama. Olivier Rebbot Award for photo reporting _ Peter Turnley, Newsweek, for the fall of Romanian President Nicolai Ceausecu, with citations to Bill Gentile for his book, ``Nicaragua,'' and James Nachtwey of Life magazine for ``Death Zone.'' Best newspaper or news service photo reporting _ AP anonymous photographer; with citation to Ron Jacques Haviv of Agence France-Presse from Panama. Ben Grauer Award for spot radio reporting _ Gary Matsumoto of NBC Radio, for stories on Eastern Europe, with citation to Steve Futterman, NBC-Mutual Radio, for reports on China. Lowell Thomas Award for radio interpretation or documentary _ CBS News Radio for ``Europe 1989,'' with citations to Duc Nguyen and Peter Breslow and National Public Radio for stories on Vietnam revisited. Television spot news _ Dan Rather and CBS News for ``The New Face of Communism,'' and Bernard Shaw of CNN for stories on China. Edward R. Murrow Award for TV interpretation or documentary _ Ted Koppel and Dorrance Smith, ABC News, for ``The Tragedy at Tiananmen, the Untold Story,'' with citations to Jackie Judd and Mark Lakasiewicz of ABC for ``Secrets of the Secret Police'' from Czechoslovakia and Diane Sawyer and Janet Tobias of ABC for ``Valley of the Shadows'' from Peru. Ed Cunningham Memorial Award for magazine writing _ Fred Shapiro, The New Yorker, for ``Letters from Beijing,'' with citation to John Kohan and Time magazine team for ``The New USSR.'' Hallie & Whit Burnett Award for general magazine article _ Joel Millman in The New York Times Magazine, for ``El Salvador's Army, A Force Unto Itself,'' with citations to Henry Trewhitt, Jeff Trimble and Robin Wright of U.S. News & World Report, for ``Soviet Military Power,'' and Trimble, Roger Rosenblatt, Douglas Stanglin and Dusko Doder of U.S. News & World Report for ``Revolution and Ruin.'' Best cartoon _ Mike Luckovitch of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, with citation to Dana J. Summers of The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel. Morton Frank Award for business or economic reporting _ Saul Hansell of Institutional Investor, for ``The Wild Wired World of Electronic Exchanges,'' with citation to Robert Neff, Paul Magnuson, William Holstein, Robert Dowling and Mark Vamos of Business Week, for ``Rethinking Japan.'' Forbes Magazine Award for newspaper or news service business or economic reporting _ Peter Gumbel of The Wall Street Journal, for reporting on reform in the Soviet Union, with citation to Ruth Youngblood of United Press International. Cornelius Ryan Award for best book _ Thomas L. Friedman for ``From Beirut to Jerusalem.'' Madeline Dane Ross Award for foreign correspondent showing concern for the human condition _ Jeremy Iggers of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul, for ``Feeding A Hungry Planet,'' with citation to Michael Hiltzik of the Los Angeles Times, for articles on East Africa. Eric and Amy Burger Award for reporting on human rights _ Katherine Ellison of the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The most important thing about going to Wannsee is what we are going to say there, which is: `Aside from how horrible you were, we lived.''' _ Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, on the reason for holding a ceremony at the Berlin villa where Nazi leaders plotted the ``Final Solution.''

``This is a way for people to see the more personal, human side of our presidents.'' _ Curator James Kratsas on a new exhibit on presidents and their pets at the Gerald R. Ford Museum in Grand Rapids, Mich.

``Sunburn is our biggest problem with newcomers. If your butt ain't seen daylight before, you don't have any idea how quickly it's going to burn.'' _ Claudia Adcock, manager of the Ponderosa Ranch nudist colony near Wills Point, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed In Beirut's Christian Battles
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with artillery through the night, setting hospitals on fire and killing seven people as up to 30 shells a minute rained down on residential areas, police said today. Buildings burned out of control, reddening the night sky, while howitzer and rocket salvos roared overhead. In addition to the battles in east Beirut, the two sides traded heavy shelling around the port of Jounieh, 12 miles to the north, police said. The barrages eased around 5 a.m. into mortar and machine-gun clashes between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia, led by Samir Geagea. Police said 14 people were wounded. In all, 19 people have been killed and 41 wounded since fighting broke out Monday after a two-week lull in the struggle between Aoun and the Lebanese Forces for control of the country's Christian enclave. Police said the fatalities included a family of five killed when a salvo hit their building in the Aoun-controlled town of Fanar in Metn province north of Beirut. A total of 941 people have been killed and 2,497 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea's forces. Most of the casualties have been civilians. The battles have been some of the worst between Christian forces since the Lebanese civil war broke out in April 1975. Most of the war has pitted Christians against Moslems. In today's fighting, Aoun's 130mm howitzers fired salvo after salvo into Geagea's strongholds in the city's Ashrafiyeh and Karantina neighborhoods, where the Lebanese Forces have their headquarters, police said. Geagea's forces unleashed barrages of 122mm rockets from 30-barrel truck-mounted launchers into the Aoun-held districts of Badaro and Furn el-Shubbak. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said a military hospital in Badaro controlled by Aoun was severely damaged by a rocket barrage that set it ablaze. Aoun's gunners hammered the Hospital de Notre Dame du Liban in Jounieh, which is controlled by Geagea's fighters. ``I was in my room when the shells started falling,'' said an unidentified patient in an interview on Geagea's Lebanese Broadcasting Corp. television station. ``Despite my wound, I left the bed and hid in the closet. I stayed there until nurses came and took me to the shelter on a stretcher,'' he said. The station showed the patient's room which, like most of the hospital, took several direct hits. The man's bed was shredded and there was a gaping hole in the ceiling. The bearded patient was interviewed in the seven-story hospital's underground bomb shelter. Upstairs, a carpet of debris and broken glass covered the corridors. Smoke shrouded several districts as apartment buildings and gas stations burned. Several trucks carrying food across the the capital's dividing Green Line were hit late Monday and set on fire. The fighting has caused damage estimated at $1 billion and forced 400,000 of the Christian enclave's 1 million people to flee. Civilians who had been trapped in their offices Monday, when the shelling escalated sharply, took advantage of the lull at dawn today to race home to check on their families.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Names Green Bay Prelate as New Detroit Archbishop
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has appointed Bishop Adam J. Maida of Green Bay, Wis., as the new archbishop of Detroit, the Vatican reported today. He succeeds Cardinal Edmund C. Szoka, who was named to a top financial post at the Vatican in January. The 60-year-old Maida, born in East Vandergrift, Pa., was promoted to the Green Bay post in November 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Incrementally Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained slightly against the Japanese yen today but declined against the West German mark. Gold prices edged higher. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 158.05 yen, up 0.25 yen from Monday's close of 157.80 yen. The dollar had fallen 1.28 yen in the three previous trading days. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 157.85 yen. ``Yen-dollar trading was quiet as market participants are awaiting the start of (the U.S. Treasury bond) auction tonight,'' said Mamoru Tabata, a currency dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``The dollar stayed in an extremely narrow range.'' Masafumi Koyama, chief customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo, said there was not much interest in yen-dollar deals among either buyers or sellers. Trading against European currencies occupied center stage, he said. ``Cross-trading against the (West German) mark, Swiss franc and even the sterling pound will continue'' overnight, Koyama said. If the dollar weakens against those currencies, it will advance no further than the lower 159-yen range against the yen, he predicted . Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: _1.6540 West German marks, down from 1.6550 _1.4315 Swiss francs, down from 1.4320 _5.5580 French francs, up from 5.5555 _1.8595 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8590 _1,214.25 Italian lire, up from 1,213.50 _1.1620 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1617 In London, the pound sterling was quoted at $1.6735 this morning, compared with $1.6710 late Monday in European trading. London markets were closed Monday for a national bank holiday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $372.10 per ounce this morning, up from $371.45 per troy ounce late Friday. In Zurich, gold traded at $372.00 per troy ounce, up from $371.70 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 32 cents an ounce today, to close at $373.42. Silver traded in London at $5.05 per troy ounce, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Attack on John Wayne's Daughter
DOC.TEXT: Jurors convicted a man of eight felony counts, including assault with a deadly weapon, in an attack on the daughter of the late John Wayne and her boyfriend. Jerrell Hintergardt, 38, who made a surprise confession in court last week, faces sentencing June 8. He was convicted Monday. The prosecution alleged that Hintergardt and private investigator Oded Daniel Gal were hired by Aissa Wayne's former husband, Dr. Thomas Gionis, to attack her and boyfriend Roger Luby in October 1988. Gionis allegedly arranged the beatings at Luby's Newport Beach home because of a custody dispute with Ms. Wayne over their daughter, Anastasia, then two years old. Gionis, who is awaiting trial, has pleaded innocent to charges of conspiracy and assault. Ms. Wayne and Luby were forced into the garage where they were tied up and beaten. They cut Luby's achilles tendon. Prosecutors allege that Gionis paid Gal $43,000 to arrange the attack and that Gal hired Hintergardt and Jeffrey Kendall Bouey to carry it out. Gal and Bouey still face charges and are free on bail. Gionis, a neurosurgeon, was divorced from Ms. Wayne in 1987, and the couple went to court in 1988 over who would get custody of Anastasia. The little girl has been kept by her mother, pending the outcome of Gionis' trial.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Vent Shuts Down, Flow Reaches Ocean
DOC.TEXT: The massive outpouring of molten rock from Kilauea Volcano has come to a temporary halt as a lava flow that has burned its way through much of this coastal community finally reached the ocean. Officials are keeping a close watch on acid formed when the lava hits the ocean. Hot lava mixing with salt water produces steam clouds, known as laze,that contain hydrochloric acid and other hazardous chemicals. Trade winds are blowing the gas out to sea, said Bruce Butts, deputy administrator of Hawaii County Civil Defense. The flow entered the ocean just west of Harry K. Brown State Park about a quarter-mile north of the town, Butts said. Before it stopped at noon Monday, the lava had been gushing from the Kupaianaha opening of the volcano at a rate of 650,000 cubic yards a day, feeding the 8-mile-long lava flow that has destroyed 61 homes in this community since April 4. Geologists said they do not know whether the halt in the lava flow signals the end of Kilauea's eruption that began Jan. 3, 1983. ``If it holds true to form, it'll be only a pause,'' said Reggie Okamura of the U.S. Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. Instruments monitoring the vent, or volcano opening, and the earlier primary Pu'i O'o vent show continued tremor, indicating molten rock is continuing to move in the vent system, Okamura said. Drainage from the flow is entering the ocean, and should do so for the next two or three days, Butts said. The flow has destroyed 139 homes in Kalapana since the eruption began more than seven years ago. Only 34 homes remained untouched, and most have been evacuated.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Oil Leak Appears to Disperse
DOC.TEXT: Texaco began skimming more than 37,000 gallons of oil that spilled into the Gulf of Mexico after it shut a pipeline suspected of leaking. The company sent a skimmer to clean the area and requested two more, although Texaco said it had not determined the cause or who was responsible for the leak. ``Let's just say there's oil in the Gulf. At this time we don't know if it's ours or not,'' said Texaco spokesman Max Hebert. Coast Guard Cmdr. Dave Beach said the leak was discovered Sunday morning near Eugene Island, about 100 miles off the Louisiana coast. By Monday afternoon the Coast Guard estimated that 37,800 gallons of oil had leaked into the Gulf. Initial indications were that the leak may have occurred in a pipeline serving 36 drilling platforms in the congested area, Texaco said. The pipeline is operated by Texaco and is owned by Marathon, Exxon, Mobil, Texaco, Chevron and Conoco. Divers were investigating the 20-inch pipeline to try to pinpoint the source of the leak. Seas were moderate in the area Monday and the oil was expected to disperse in the open Gulf, Texaco said. ``The latest report we got late Monday evening was that the three heaviest brown patches had decreased in size, mainly into three streaks covering an area roughly eight by 22 miles,'' Beach said. ``Basically, it's spreading out into a lighter sheen and there's a lot less heavy oil showing,'' he said. After testing all pipelines and platforms in the area, the Eugene Island Pipeline System was shut down at about 1 a.m. Monday, Texaco said. ``At this stage it's still in the minor category,'' said Beach. ``If everyone has shut down as requested, all you're going to get from now on is just a minor amount of oil coming from the line.'' Texaco had notified the companies using the oil line to suspend operation by Monday, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Demolishes School, Houses in Iran
DOC.TEXT: Two moderate earthquakes shook central Iran, demolishing a school and a number of houses in the village of Islamabad and surrounding areas, Tehran radio reported today. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, did not say whether there were any casualties. The stronger quake registered 4.8 on the Richter scale of ground motion, the radio said. The temblors shook the southern township of Semiran in central Isfahan province once at dawn and again at dusk Monday. The radio said southern villages have been shaken by earthquakes 57 times in the past month. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage in a populated area, and one of 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Seeks International Backing On Major European Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Departure time has not been announced; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk is seeking support from Western Europe for his white government's efforts to bring the black majority into the South African political system. De Klerk plans to leave today on a tour of nine nations in Western Europe, which South African officials call the most important foreign trip by a South African leader in decades. It also is an important test of South Africa's bid to end its international isolation. The government's hopes of improving its foreign standing after years of sanctions were boosted after it reached an agreement last week with the African National Congress, the leading anti-apartheid group, after their first talks. The two sides agreed to work together to end political violence and clear the way for full constitutional talks on ending white-minority rule. ``It is the accord reached ... last week which the world will see as progress towards a new democratic South Africa,'' said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity. In a sign of a new willingness to deal with South Africa, French President Francois Mitterrand, who has shunned South African leaders in the past, will now hold talks with de Klerk. De Klerk will also see British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, King Juan Carlos of Spain and many presidents and prime ministers. He begins his trip in France and then goes on to Belgium, Italy, West Germany, Britain, Spain, Switzerland, Greece and Portugal. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it is the most extensive trip by a South African head of state since the governing National Party came to power in 1948. South African political analysts say the most important aspect of the trip is de Klerk's hope of easing South Africa's diplomatic and political isolation. De Klerk, who has launched major reforms to end the apartheid system of racial separation, will explain his policies to European governments. De Klerk will also be looking for support for his political plans. West European nations have been an important source of aid and support for the African National Congress, which de Klerk hopes will help to control more radical black elements that oppose any peaceful agreement with the white government. De Klerk is also expected to ask European nations to ease or end sanctions imposed against his country to protest apartheid. Sanctions have hurt the South African economy. While de Klerk has little hope of persuading European nations to curtail sanctions, he may lay the groundwork for an easing of sanctions in the future.

DOC.HEAD: California Bank Turned Over to Philippines Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd to add newspaper report Marcoses gave $8.5 million to election officials and others in last days to retain power, picks up 4th graf pvs, `The transfer ...'; ADDS 5 grafs at end with further details of report.
DOC.TEXT: A Los Angeles bank that allegedly was used by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos to launder money stolen from their country has been turned over to the Philippine government. The bank, estimated by a defense attorney to be worth $20 million to $30 million, was transferred Monday in a significant victory for the government of President Corazon Aquino. The Philippines is trying to recover more than $220 million allegedly embezzled by the Marcoses from the country's treasury during Marcos' 20 years in power. A newspaper reported today that the Marcoses doled out about $8.5 million to politicians, reporters and others in the last 100 days of the Philippine dictator's regime in a desperate attempt to retain power. An accused political assassin who received about $50,000 was among dozens of cash recipients during the spending spree, according to a palace ledger the Los Angeles Times said it obtained a copy of. The transfer of all shares in the California Overseas Bank to the Manila government was part of a March 16 plea bargain in federal court, where Mrs. Marcos is on trial. The bank had pleaded guilty to wire fraud. The bank was owned by Robert S. Benedicto, a one-time Marcos crony whom prosecutors charged with conspiring to help Marcos shift stolen money to secret Swiss accounts and other personal uses. Mrs. Marcos is alleged to have participated with her husband in the embezzlement, using the money to live in luxury and invest in New York real estate. Co-defendant Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi financer, is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal ownership of the New York properties. Marcos was indicted with his wife but died in exile in Hawaii in September. Benedicto, also indicted and listed as a fugitive by the court, was dropped from the case as part of the plea bargain. Two former officials of the bank testified last week that Benedicto had said he bought the institution for $7 million in 1976 because Marcos ``needed the bank,'' and that he had personally managed several accounts whose owners were known only to himself. Prosecutors said the accounts belonged to the Marcoses and were used to launder money being funneled to other accounts, to buy a Manhattan office building and Mrs. Marcos' jewelry, and to provide two Marcos children with $10,000-a-month allowances. The register of cash expenses disclosed by the Los Angeles Times made no apparent reference to the expenses related to her trial in New York, but showed that Mrs. Marcos gave generous gifts to members of the national press corps during her husband's 1986 presidential campaign against Mrs. Aquino. Those gifts included watches and envelopes, each stuffed with the equivalent of about $250. Three days after the election but before results were announced, Mrs. Marcos was host of a dinner for employees of an agency that investigates election fraud in Manila, the ledger showed. At each of the 55 place settings was an envelope stuffed with the equivalent of about $500. The ledger also credits Arturo Pacificador, a Marcos associate and former member of Parliament, with receiving about $50,000 five days after the assassination of Evilio Javier, director of the 1986 Aquino campaign in Antique province. Pacificador was indicted in connection with the slaying and is a fugitive. The ledger was seized along with other palace documents by the new Philippine government after Marcos fled a popular revolt on Feb. 25, 1986 and Mrs. Aquino was installed as president.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Visit Stirs Emotions of American Legion Band Members
DOC.TEXT: Muscovites stopped on the street and some leaned out of windows to clap and try to sing along as an American Legion marching band played ``God Bless America'' outside a hotel near the Kremlin. ``Let me tell you, it was one of the most emotional times of my life,'' the band's leader, Dorothy Hill, said today. She said the two impromptu concerts Sunday and Monday proved that peace is possible between the superpowers. ``The people there watching and listening were shedding tears, we were shedding tears. I never saw such emotion in my life,'' said Mrs. Hill, a 74-year-old World War II Coast Guard veteran. ``It proved my point right there _ that reaction of your people and our people _ that peace is possible,'' she told reporters. Mrs. Hill charmed and plodded her way through the Soviet bureaucracy for three years to bring the 70-member, all-male American Legion band from Waltham, Mass., to Moscow on what she called a ``peace move.'' On Wednesday, it will march in Red Square in the Soviet Union's annual Victory Day parade celebrating the defeat of Nazi Germany. Mrs. Hill said Soviet officials have told her it will be the first American band to join the parade. But band members have already gotten an emotional charge from their two concerts outside the Hotel Rossiya, where they struck up ``God Bless America,'' as well as the Soviet and U.S. national anthems. Muscovites who had watched curiously soon began to sing along as best they could. Some people leaned out of the hotel windows, and began clapping. John ``Jake'' Comer of Quincy, Mass., past national commander of the American Legion, said the tears ``just came out of my eyes'' as the band played ``God Bless America'' and he held the Soviet and U.S. flags during the impromptu concerts. ``I've been to 18 countries, to Nicaragua, had an audience with the pope, visited the Oval Office with Presidents Reagan, Bush.'' he said. ``I've done everything. But nothing as moving as that.'' Mrs. Hill said she began planning the trip about three years ago after having a dream ``that we should never see another war.'' With no contacts in Moscow, she just stayed up through the early morning hours and dialed telephone operators in Moscow, trying to find out who to contact. After dialing night after night, she finally found one helpful telephone operator who put her in touch with the Soviet Peace Committee, ``and once we got them, the show was on the road.'' The Joseph P. Hill American Legion Band, named for Mrs. Hill's late husband, arrived Moscow on Saturday on a 10-day trip. Its members range in age from 17 to 82, and include veterans of wars in Europe, Japan, Korea and Vietnam. At a ceremony today at the headquarters of the Soviet Peace Committee, its chairman, Genrik Borovik, praised Mrs. Hill as a ``remarkable, wonderful woman.'' ``I'm happy that she broke American bureaucracy and Soviet bureaucracy just coming straight to ... the Soviet Peace Committee,'' he said. Borovik called the event unusual, because the American Legion ``always was considered as a very right-wing organization, which was always, let me say, not the best friend of the Soviet Union.'' Borovik is a television commentator who, in the years before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power, often critized U.S. foreign policy in his commentaries.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Takes Another Step Toward Indepedence
With PM-Soviet-Baltics
DOC.TEXT: Estonia today dropped the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from its name and adopted the republic's old tricolor flag in place of the red banner of socialism as it took another step toward independence. The Estonian parliament, without formally declaring independence, reinstituted several paragraphs from the Baltic republic's 1938 constitution, including an opening proclamation that Estonia is ``an independent republic, with the supreme state power vested in the people.'' Nationalist parliamentarians regard the move as another step in a phased march toward independence and not in itself a formal break with Moscow. The parliament also declared that the step, in large part symbolic, was intended as a show of solidarity with the sister Baltic republics of Lithuania and Latvia, which have declared full independence. All three republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The vote today was 73 in favor, 14 against, with two abstentions, eight members present but not voting, and eight absent. The measure passed with three votes more than the required two-thirds majority of the legislature's total membership. Minutes after the vote was taken in the Estonian Supreme Soviet, the red flag with its hammer and sickle was lowered from the roof of the ancient parliament building and a new flag with cornflower blue, black and white stripes was raised in its place. A small crowd gathered in the cobblestone square to see what would follow, but there was no immediate attempt to cover the giant hammer and sickle crest that has adorned the front of the building for five decades. Estonia, which in November 1988 became the first of the 15 Soviet republics to proclaim its sovereignty from Moscow, has taken repeated steps in recent months to establish a separate identity without provoking a confrontation with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev over the issue of independence. The nearby Baltic republic of Lithuania, which declared independence on March 11, is now the target of an economic blockade in which the Soviets have cut the flow of oil, natural gas and other critical raw materials. The third Baltic republic, Latvia, declared independence on May 4, and is now waiting to hear whether Gorbachev will impose sanctions similar to those he slapped on Lithuania. The Estonian parliament today adopted a resolution congratulating Latvia on declaring independence, and declaring Baltic solidarity. ``We congratulate the (Latvian) Supreme Soviet and the whole population of Latvia on the occasion of adopting the independence declaration of the Latvian republic,'' said the statement, which was broadcast on Radio Estonia and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in Britain. ``The path to our own statehood is not easy, but we are convinced that here, in the Baltics _ acting together _ will arrive at a restoration of our independent states more fruitfully than if each were to struggle on its own,'' the statement said. Tallinn deputy Mart Laar said Estonia already is feeling the effects of the Soviet oil and natural gas embargo against Lithuania, because a Lithuanian refinery processes 50 percent of Estonia's gasoline. The Estonians have been trying for weeks to start talks with the Kremlin leading toward eventual independence, but Moscow so far has refused. The Estonian Independent, an English-language weekly in the capital of Tallinn, reported in its most recent edition that Gorbachev adviser Alexander Yakovlev told Estonian Supreme Soviet chairman Arnold Ruutel that no negotiations could start unless the parliament suspended a March 30 ruling that invalidated the Soviet constitution on Estonian territory. The action today carried Estonia a step further and said that dropping of Soviet symbols was ``guided by the decision'' of March 30. The law adopted today made the offical name ``the Estonian Republic.'' Ethnic Estonians make of 64 percent of the overall population of 1.5 million. The ethnic Russian minority makes up 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Fears Western Hostage May Be Slain If Missing Iranians Dead
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader said today he believes no more Western hostages will be freed until the Israelis and their Lebanese militia allies release some 400 Lebanese Shiite and Palestinian captives. Hussein Musawi, leader of the fundamentalist Islamic Amal faction, also voiced fears that one of the Western hostages in Lebanon could be killed if four missing Iranians are found to have been slain by Christian militiamen. Musawi's remarks were seen as an effort to pressure Washington to make a conciliatory gesture toward Iran and the hostage-takers following last month's release of two American captives. Iran and its Lebanese Shiite allies have asked the United States to help determine the fate of the four missing Iranians who were seized eight years ago and pressure Israel and its militia allies in south Lebanon to release their prisoners. ``If the kidnappers' mind is sound and their religion is sound, they will not free any more hostages,'' said Musawi, the reputed mentor of some of the hostage takers. ``And I think they won't. ``If the Americans want to solve the hostage issue, they should solve the problem of the Moslems and the oppressed held by Israel and its surrogates,'' he added. But Musawi warned that if the four Iranians were found to have been slain, it could prompt a violent reaction by those holding the hostages. ``If the death of the four Iranians is ascertained, that will definitely affect the hostage issue. One of the kidnap groups might react by murdering a hostage,'' Musawi said. ``I don't have any concrete information on that. But they've done it before. What's there to stop them from doing it again?'' he told The Associated Press in a telephone interview from his headquarters in the ancient town of Baalbek in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Musawi's pro-Syrian faction is part of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be linked to the Shiite extremists holding most of the 16 remaining Western hostages, including six Americans. The longest held is American Terry Anderson, Chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in Beirut March 16, 1985. The four Iranians were seized by right-wing Lebanese Forces militiamen north of Beirut in July 1982. Iran has repeatedly demanded their release. But the four men are widely believed to have been killed either in civil war shelling or by their captors. Lebanese Forces commander Samir Geagea said in August 1988 that after he took over the militia two years earlier he found no trace of the missing Iranians. He blamed his predecessor, Elie Hobeika, for their disappearance and apparent slaying. Last October, Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said that if the men are dead, the militiamen can at least ``give us back their bodies or show us their graves.'' Musawi is the reputed mentor of the pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which holds American professors Alann Steen and Jesse Turner. The group freed American educator Robert Polhill, 55, on April 22 after he spent 39 months in captivity. The move was followed by the April 30 release of another American, Frank Reed, 57, who was held hostage for 42 months by a group calling itself the Organization of Islamic Dawn. President Bush has publicly thanked Iran and Syria for helping secure their freedom. Bush has said the United States could try to help determine the fate of the four missing Iranians. Israeli officials reiterated that they are not opposed to a prisoner swap in principle, but stressed that an exchange should include three Israeli servicemen captured in Lebanon in 1986 and believed held by radical Shiites linked to Hezbollah. ``It is our stated policy that we are ready to contemplate an exchange for the Israeli prisoners who are held by those organizations,'' said Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: Scrabble and Monopoly for Hostage Terry Anderson
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, bgng, Although Anderson... to raise fact that Anderson is AP's chief Middle East correspondent; edits 8th graf pvs, Anderson is ... to conform
DOC.TEXT: Terry Anderson, the longest held of the 16 Western hostages, helped fellow prisoners make Scrabble and Monopoly games to amuse themselves, according to a newly freed captive. His guards are giving him and other hostages plenty of diversions, according to an account given by former hostage Frank Reed to Anderson's sister, Peggy Say. ``They have a lot of things which was encouraging to me; at least they did at the time Frank was there,'' Mrs. Say said. These included boxes of books, writing materials and dominoes. Although Anderson, 42, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is in good physical condition from plenty of exercise, he is tired and needs dental care, Mrs. Say said. She said the hostages are blindfolded and chained in line with their preference. ``Frank preferred a chain on his wrist,'' she said. ``Terry preferred a chain on his ankle so that his arms are free to write and play cards.'' The closest she and Reed were able to calculate that he last saw Anderson was somewhere between a year and 18 months ago. Reed spent 20 months with Anderson and Thomas Sutherland in Lebanon. For a period of time, the three American hostages were together with two others, John McCarthy and Brian Keenan. Reed, the director of the private Lebanon International School, was freed April 30 after being held for 44 months. He is undergoing medical checkups at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland and met with Mrs. Say Monday night. Anderson is in his sixth year of captivity. Sutherland was a dean at the American University of Beirut. McCarthy is a British television journalist. Keenan, who is Irish, taught English at American University. ``He is still a vindictive hearts player,'' Mrs. Say said of her brother. Reed told her Anderson also reads voraciously, a book a day. Reed said Anderson could pick up some things in Arabic from the radio and have at least some idea of what he thought was going on in the world. But his guards have made a concerted effort to keep from him news of the deaths of his father and brother, both from cancer, within four months of each other in 1986. Mrs. Say said she believes that he still does not know. ``That's very difficult,'' she said. ``Part of you wants him to have known and dealt with it and part of you believes it might be too much for him if he found out in captivity.'' But with his mind still sharp, he thinks of new birthdays painfully uncelebrated for the two daughters he cares for so deeply. He is wracked with anguish at missing more than five years with them, unable to savor the passage of Gabrielle from child to woman. In Anderson's sixth year of captivity, Gabrielle turned 14 on April 26. He has never held Sulome, who was born three months after he was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut on March 16, 1985, by Islamic Jihad, a group loyal to Iran. She will be 5 on June 7. ``He was very verbal about his love of them and that was what he wanted when he got out, to see his daughters,'' Mrs. Say said. Unlike Reed, who said he was brutally beaten by his kidnappers for trying to escape twice, Anderson was left alone. Mrs. Say said Reed told her Anderson was not beaten. Reed told Mrs. Say that her brother was aware of her tireless campaign to free him and the other hostages. Mrs. Say, 49, shuttles between Washington and her home in Kentucky. She has made several trips to the Middle East seeking his release. She has met with President Bush, Pope John Paul II, the archbishop of Canterbury and PLO leader Yasser Arafat. She fields phone calls all hours of the day and night. ``The guards told him (Anderson) everytime I did something of major import,'' Mrs. Say said. ``Because it has been a criticism that I've heard, I said to him (Reed), `Does Terry think what I'm doing is making him be held longer?' And he said, `Absolutely not. That only gives him hope.'''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says Breslin Not Racist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Language in 8th graf may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo said Newsday columnist Jimmy Breslin is not a racist despite an expletive-filled outburst against a reporter of Korean descent who had criticized him. The governor on Monday called Breslin's comments about the reporter ``dumb and offensive,'' but said his longtime friend should not be judged solely on the ``outrageous'' way he chose to talk in the newsroom. ``He's certainly not racist, ethnic. He's been a champion of open-mindedness,'' Cuomo said. Cuomo spoke after six state legislators sent telegrams to Newsday editors Donald Forst and Anthony Marro urging them to suspend Breslin. Chiara Coletti, a Newsday spokeswoman, said the newspaper would have no response until after a meeting scheduled for tonight with Forst, Marro and the Asian-American editorial staff. On Sunday, three Asian-American groups called for Breslin's resignation after the outburst of sexual and racial slurs against staff reporter Ji-Yeon Mary Yuh, 25, who had sent him an internal computer message calling his May 3 column sexist. Breslin wrote in the column that his wife, City Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge, devoted too much time to government duties and not enough time to him or the home. In his Monday column, the 61-year-old Pulitzer Prize winner described the article as ``conscious humor.'' After receiving Yuh's message, Breslin called her ``a yellow cur'' and ``slant-eyed'' in a newsroom outburst, New York Newsday reported. In an apology sent to Newsday staff in an internal computer message, Breslin said: ``I am no good and once again I can prove it. ... I am sorry. I said things I shouldn't have said. The racial and sexual insults I spewed are never appropriate.'' The governor said Breslin ``wrote one of the most elegant and persuasive apologies I've ever read. How can you beat up on a guy who says, `I'm no good and I've proved it once again.''' On Monday, the New York Association of Black Journalists wrote to Marro, calling for Breslin's suspension. ``We recognize in the past Jimmy Breslin has been a champion of minorities and the disadvantaged, but these most recent comments cannot be excused or tolerated in any newsroom setting,'' the letter said. Breslin, who writes about New York City in hard-bitten, streetwise fashion, won a Pulitzer for commentary in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: British Plane Crashes During NATO Maneuver
DOC.TEXT: A British military jet participating in a NATO exercise crashed 20 miles southwest of Sardinia shortly before dawn today, officials said. Searchers found plane wreckage, but the pilot of the AV-8 Harrier was missing and presumed dead, said Nicholas Smith, spokesman for the British Ministry of Defense. Officials said the cause of the crash was not immediately known. The pilot's name was withheld. The vertical take-off and landing jet crashed into the sea 10 miles from the British aircraft carrier Invincible. The jet was taking part in ``Dragon Hammer,'' an annual NATO exercise in the central and western Mediterranean involving units from Italy, Turkey, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Boycott Classes in Anti-Government Protest
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of radical students boycotted classes and held rallies today after dissidents urged nationwide protests this week aimed at toppling President Roh Tae-woo's government. About 2,000 students armed with firebombs and rocks fought riot police at the gate of Seoul National University, shouting demands that Roh resign and dissolve the giant governing party formed by a three-party merger. Violent protests also were reported on at least seven other campuses in Seoul and two provincial cities, but no overall figures or details were available. The newspaper Chosun Ilbo reported anti-government rallies on 30 campuses across the nation. ``Destroy the ruling party!'' demonstrators shouted as their leaders urged students across the nation to join in protests aimed at forcing the Democratic Liberal Party to disband. Dissidents have planned anti-Roh protests in 17 cities beginning Wednesday, when the newly enlarged governing party holds its first national convention. Also today, taxi union leaders in Seoul decided to stage a street rally Thursday to press demands for a 17.3 percent wage increase. Union drivers planned to gather in southern Seoul in thousands of company taxis and, if police block them, to start street protests with honking horns. Roh, whose party had been losing popularity, secured a majority of seats in the National Assembly in January with a merger of his party with two minor opposition groups. Dissidents contend the merger was an attempt by conservatives to prolong their power. They also accused Roh of backpedaling from earlier promises of reforms. Roh warned South Koreans in a nationally televised speech Monday that the nation is at a crossroads where it can either be ``on a road toward progress or fall into a road toward chaos.'' Roh appealed for industrial and social peace to prevent chaos. But radicals accused him of using concern over the economy as a ploy to suppress labor activity and political dissent. In efforts to reinvigorate the economy, Roh's government ordered 49 major business groups today to sell excess real estate holdings or face unfavorable treatment in taxes and loans. The measure was intended to combat soaring housing prices and rampant land speculation. Government officials hope companies will invest more in export industries. South Korea's top 30 conglomerates are reported to own real estate worth at least $18 billion, although it is not known how much of the total is held for speculation. The government also barred the 49 business groups from buying new land and buildings until June 1991. Critics had accused Roh of favoring big companies and of incompetent policies that triggered inflation and economic difficulties.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle, Thatcher Laud Ike on 45th Anniversary of Allied Victory
DOC.TEXT: On the 45th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe, U.S. and British leaders paid tribute today to American soldier and statesman Dwight Eisenhower for his post-war vision of a free and united Europe. ``He foresaw the unification of Germany and foresaw that we should come to a stage when a divided Europe would be a thing of the past. That is what we're working for now,'' said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Vice President Dan Quayle, sitting across from Mrs. Thatcher in the room where Britain's wartime leader Winston Churchill often met with Eisenhower, said: ``He was a person of great vision and that vision has come true today.'' They spoke at a ceremony in the Cabinet Room at the prime minister's 10 Downing Street residence marking the 100th birthday of Eisenhower, the supreme commander of the Allied forces and later president of the United States. Quayle credited Mrs. Thatcher and Presidents Bush and Reagan for achieving Eisenhower's goal of ``peace and freedom'' in Europe. ``Now we must carry on with that victory,'' Quayle said. ``The future is going to be one that presents many challenges. There is no substitute for NATO. There is no substitute for peace and freedom.'' Mrs. Thatcher, sitting beside Churchill's grandson who bears the former prime minister's name, said Eisenhower ``shared our dark days and became an architect of our freedom. ... We counted him as one of us.'' In a speech Eisenhower made in Washington in 1953, Mrs. Thatcher said, he saw the United States striving from the firm foundation of NATO ``to foster a broader European community, conducive to the free movement of persons, of trade and of ideas.'' She said he foresaw ``a Europe that included a free and united Germany, with a government based on a free and secret ballot.'' She said he also envisioned this ``free community, and the full independence of the East European nations, spelling the end of the unnatural division of Europe.'' Susan Eisenhower, who attended the ceremony with her Russian husband, presented the prime minister with a pictorial history of her grandfather's life. ``I am of the generation that remembers a lot of it,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Quayle arrived in London Monday night from Rome on the second leg of a European tour commemorating Eisenhower. He flies to Paris tonight. The vice president, who was a dinner guest Monday night at Chequers, the prime minister's country residence, paid tribute to the ``special relationship'' between Britain and the United States. That relationship has been a preoccupation of political observers here as the focus of attention in Europe has shifted to Germany. He also praised Mrs. Thatcher at a time when her popularity has slumped and her Conservative Party is far behind the opposition Labor Party in opinion polls. ``She continues to have a very important special relationship with our president,'' Quayle said.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Motorist Accused of Murder Ruled Senile
DOC.TEXT: An 82-year-old ex-convict is mentally unfit to stand trial in the deaths of two sheriff's deputies who were shot while giving him a ride in their patrol car, a prosecutor says. ``He can't understand the charges against him or assist in his defense. If he is ever found competent to stand trial, we'll start the trial process right away. He won't be freed,'' District Attorney General Paul Summers said Monday. Ule Reynolds, a barber from Gary, Ind., is charged with shooting the two Lauderdale County deputies in January. Authorities say the deputies gave Reynolds a ride after finding him late at night in a disabled car. He had been driving to Tennessee to attend a cousin's funeral. Reynolds was armed with a .357-caliber Magnum revolver in a shoulder holster, but deputies Bobby Nolen, 55, and Kevan Ward, 31, apparently put him in the back seat of their car without searching him for weapons, authorities say. Reynolds has a criminal record dating from 1927. Summers said doctors at the Middle Tennessee Mental Health Institute in Nashville examined Reynolds and found him to be senile. A circuit judge accepted that finding Friday and ruled Reynolds incompetent to stand trial, Summers said. Prosecutors have asked that Reynolds be committed to a mental institution and the court is expected to review his status next month, Summers said. Reynolds has been in custody without bond since his arrest. Relatives and friends told authorities that Reynolds' mental ability has deteriorated in recent years. His wife, Minnie, said he told her after the shooting that he thought the deputies were taking him to jail. Reynolds was convicted of manslaughter in Tennessee in 1927 and served a two- to five-year prison sentence. He had several arrests on firearms charges over the years and was convicted in 1975 in Indiana on a weapons violations and with trying to tamper with a jury in a criminal case.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Warns East Europe of ``Ecological Armageddon''
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Charles today praised East Europeans for casting off communism but warned the region faces an ``ecological Armageddon.'' Speaking in the shadow of a statue of Karl Marx at a Budapest university that until recently bore the name of the father of communism, Charles was strident in his condemnation of Stalinism. ``In the name of Karl Marx, Lenin and Stalin charted a course that divided Russia from Europe and then, after the Second World War, forcibly removed Hungary from Western Europe, turning half of Europe into a form of Marxist prison camp,'' he said during his first visit to a Warsaw Pact country. Holding out hope that Russia ``may one day return to the west,'' Charles praised Hungary's role in the revolutions of 1989. ``One after another, the nations of Europe rejected an imposed system which had repressed, impoverished and stultified them, consistently failing to live up to its promises,'' he said. ``All of the re-emerging democracies of Europe owe Hungary a debt,'' Charles said, noting that Hungary was the first Warsaw Pact nation to break from the Iron Curtain. Hungary ``hammered the first hole in the Berlin Wall'' by allowing thousands of East Germans to flee West last summer, and it was a Hungarian pastor, Laszlo Toekes, whose persecution triggered the revolt that brought down Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu, he said. Europeans can now ``reshape the moral and political future of our continent,'' Charles said. But he warned the future is in danger from the grave ecological damage wrought by developed industry in the West and centralized planning in the East. ``Central Europe has itself been the victim of ideological experiment and the worst follies of a command economy,'' said Charles, who is known for his concern for the environment and traditional architecture. ``Its very landscape bears the dreadful scars and so do its children,'' he said. ``We are only just becoming aware of the terrible catastrophe you have been suffering. Somehow we must find a way to help reverse this apparent ecological Armageddon.'' After his 30-minute speech, the keynote pronouncement of his four-day visit to Hungary, Charles and his wife, Princess Diana, moved to a nearby fruit and vegetable market to meet shoppers. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher toured the same market when she visited Hungary in 1984. Britain's royal couple got an enthusiastic welcome from Hungarian vendors and customers alike, chatting with those who could speak English and admiring the rich assortment of traditional salami and other produce. The princess, elegant in a pink suit with purple trim, won universal admiration from the middle-aged Hungarian women straining to catch a glimpse of her. ``She's beautiful,'' cooed Jolan Varga after the princess left the market. Cries of ``Lady Di!'' rang out from children perched on a staircase above the market floor. The royal couple, who arrived in Hungary late Monday, made front-page news in all the national dailies today. State radio in the early morning read extracts from Prince Charles' writings on the ills of modern architecture. Later today, Charles was to meet Imre Makovecz, a Hungarian architect well known for combining traditional motifs with his modern designs. Diana attended a fashion show, and was later scheduled to visit a movie set, where Hungarians are making a film about the short-lived 1956 revolt crushed by Soviet troops.

DOC.HEAD: Tulane Doctor Who Founded Medical Facilities in Guatemala Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Carroll Dean Henry Behrhorst, a teacher at Tulane University who took medical care to poor, isolated Guatemalans, died Monday in that Central American nation of an apparent heart attack at the age of 67. Behrhorst, who founded the Behrhorst Clinic in Chimaltenango, Guatemala, moved his family to that mountain town of about 20,000 people in 1962 after hearing that doctors were needed. Since 1982, he had taught nine months of each year at Tulane's School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine, where he was an adjunct assistant professor.
