His specialty was providing health care in underdeveloped countries. Behrhorst also taught at the medical school of the University of San Carlos in Guatemala. Before moving to Guatemala, Behrhorst had a family medical practice in Winfield, Kan. In Chimaltenango, he not only treated people but also set up a program to teach villagers about health, nutrition, farming, child care and family planning. The clinic that Dr. Behrhorst started as a one-man, one-room operation evolved into a model rural hospital. The clinic also established a safe water system for the village. Survivors include his wife, Alicia, four sons and five daughters. Burial will be in Chimaltenango.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Committee Approves 50 Percent Quota Increase
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New, with editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A 50 percent increase in money available for loans to Eastern Europe and developing countries was approved today by the International Monetary Fund's policy-making committee. At the insistence of the United States, the IMF's Interim Committee linked the $60 billion increase to a plan to force substantial economic reforms from 11 poor countries, which are $4 billion behind on their loan payments. U.S. officials said Congress had demanded the link before approving the increase in the U.S. contribution, or quota. In exchange for the link, which many debtor countries opposed, the United States agreed to begin consideration of an additional increase in its contribution in 1993, two years earlier than originally planned. ``Despite reservations that a number of members had on certain individual elements of the package, we recognize this was a consensus. ... Everybody had to give in order to achieve a compromise,'' said Canadian Finance Minister Michael H. Wilson, chairman of the 22-member Interim Committee. The quota change, which must be approved before the end of 1991 by nations representing 85 percent of the fund's voting power, will raise the fund's resources to $180 billion from $120 billion. ``What you see ... is a package with features that are designed to strengthen the role of the International Monetary Fund as the central pillar of the international financial system,'' Wilson said. Delinquent countries that agree to adopt economic reforms would be eligible for money from a special IMF fund. However, nations in arrears could lose their voting rights. Also, the agency could sell 3 million ounces of gold, roughly equivalent to the members' original contributions, to meet the obligations of defaulting debtors. The 11 nations in arrears are the Sudan, Zambia, Peru, Costa Rica, Honduras, Guyana, Somalia, Sierra Leone, Cambodia, Vietnam and Panama. The Interim Committee also agreed to reorder the voting power within the fund, allowing Japan to vault from fifth place to second, behind the United States, in recognition of its growing financial power. West Germany will share the second position. Offiials said Great Britain, which had been No. 2, and France were close to an agreement to share the fourth spot, although that was not addressed in the Interim Committee's statement. The panel reached agreeement on the package Monday night after debating it most of the day in private sessions. It announced the pact in a communique released this morning. The plan had received an important boost Sunday with the endorsement by the Group of Seven major industrial nations: the United States, Japan, West Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada and Italy. On other subjects, the Interim Committee promised to support reforms in Eastern European countries emerging from four decades of communism, but not at the expense of developing countries. It welcomed applications for fund membership from Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria. Poland, Hungary, Yugoslavia and Romania are already members. The panel also pointed to progress under Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's 14-month-old program to reduce the crushing $1.3 trillion debt burden on Third World countries, noting that commercial banks have negotiated agreements with six countries: Mexico, the Philippines, Costa Rica, Venezuela, Chile and Morocco. Commenting on recent economic developments, the committee noted an upturn in inflation, saying, ``Recent price developments point to the need for continued vigilance and restraint in monetary policy.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Intend to Seek Additional Charges Against Barry
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs, The legal... to UPDATE with Barry reaction; DELETES last graf, Lurma Rackley... now outdated
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors intend to seek additional drug charges against Mayor Marion Barry, according to sources familiar with the investigation. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Monday that U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens wants a federal grand jury to return up to five additional misdemeanor drug possession charges against Barry. The legal action could come as early as today, the sources said. During a neighborhood walking tour today, Barry reacted to the report, saying, ``I don't lose any sleep over allegations. Justice is done in the courts. The best answer to a lie is the truth.'' The mayor already faces five misdemeanor cocaine-possession charges and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged drug use. Barry, arrested in an FBI sting operation Jan. 18, has pleaded innocent to all eight counts returned by a grand jury on Feb. 15. WRC-TV, also citing anonymous sources, reported Monday that the new charges would relate to alleged drug use by the mayor in the weeks before his January arrest. Judy Smith, a spokeswoman for Stephens, would not comment on the possibility of new charges against the 54-year-old Barry. When Barry was indicted on Feb. 15, Stephens said he was continuing to explore a ``broad range of allegations'' against the mayor. The grand jury that indicted Barry has met regularly since then, and several social companions of Barry's have testified before the panel. Also, court papers filed on Monday reported that hair samples taken from Barry on the night of his drug arrest showed that he had used cocaine repeatedly in the preceding weeks. In the filing, Stephens opposed a move by Barry's lawyer to suppress the hair test evidence. R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's attorney, argued in an earlier filing that because cocaine residue normally takes one to four days to reach a suspect's hair follicles, tests taken in the hours following Barry's Jan. 18 arrest would not be relevant to the case. The tests were administered after the mayor was arrested in a downtown Washington hotel room by undercover FBI agents, who officials say videotaped him smoking crack cocaine with a female companion who was cooperating with authorities. Stephens argued that the tests should be admitted at Barry's trial to help the government try to rebut any argument that the mayor was coerced into using drugs. ``It is hard evidence based upon the concrete results of a scientific test and it directly establishes that the defendant used cocaine in the weeks immediately preceding his arrest,'' Stephens wrote. In recent years, courts have increasingly relied on hair sample tests for information on past drug use. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has scheduled a pre-trial hearing for May 25 on various motions and counter-motions filed by Mundy and Stephens. The trial is scheduled to begin June 4.

DOC.HEAD: Workers' Group Calls for Strike Against Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with developments in other Baltic states; Picks up 11th graf, `It calls ...'; Edits thereafter to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: An organization representing non-Latvian workers today branded the Baltic republic's declaration of independence a ``state coup'' and appealed for a protest strike. In the neighboring republic of Estonia, parliament took another step toward independence by dropping the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's name and adopting the republic's old tricolor flag in place of the red Soviet flag. And in the third Baltic republic, Lithuania sought to cope with an economic blockade imposed by Moscow after its declaration of independence by reducing meat supplies to the Soviet Union by 10 percent while it seeks alternative markets, a spokesman for parliament said. The spokesman, Aidas Palubinskas, said the action was not a retaliatory measure. He said the idea is to establish direct trade with Soviet cities and regions, bypassing central authorities. ``Instead of using a worthless ruble, we'll be starting a market economy on a small scale,'' he said. In Latvia, an appeal printed on the front page of the republic's Communist Party newspaper said pro-independence leaders ``did not consider it necessary to ask the people: do they want a return to unemployment, lawlessness and oppression? Do they want hunger, cold and bankruptcy as in neighboring Lithuania?'' The appeal increased concern over how non-Latvians, who comprise up 46 percent of the population and most of the urban working class, would react to Friday's declaration of independence. Many non-Latvians oppose secession, especially the ethnic Russians that make up 33 percent of the republic's 2.6 million people. Latvia has pledged to go more slowly than neighboring Lithuania, which declared itself a sovereign state on March 11. But it is unclear whether Latvia's gradual approach, which includes honoring the Soviet Constitution for an unspecified transition period, will save it from the sort of economic blockade that Moscow imposed on Lithuania. In Estonia, parliament adopted several measures today intended as a show of solidarity with Lithuania and Latvia, which have declared full independence. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed all three Baltic republics in 1940. The parliament, without formally declaring independence, reinstituted several paragraph's from Estonia's 1938 constitution, including an opening proclamation that Estonia is ``an independent republic, with the supreme state power vested in the people.'' The deputies also voted to drop the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's name and adopt the old Estonian blue, black and white striped flag. Minutes after the vote was taken in the Estoniana Supreme Soviet, the red Soviet flag with its hammer and sickle was lowered from the roof of the parliament building and the new flag was raised in its place. Nationalist parliamentarians regard the moves as another step in a phased march toward independence and not in itself a formal break with Moscow. Estonia last month declared its intention to restore independence and called the Soviet Union an occupying power. But it set no date for secession and left the door open for negotiations with the Kremlin. Gorbachev has threatened Estonia, but taken no concrete actions against it. In Latvia, the appeal for a protest strike, printed in Sovietskaya Latvia, was from the republic's United Council of Work Collectives, which members say represents about 140,000 workers. Most of them are not ethnic Latvians. It calls the declaration of independence ``an anti-Soviet and anti-constitutional state coup'' and said the decision was made ``in spite of the wishes of many work collectives and without a general referendum, not taking into accont the opinion of a significant number of people's deputies.'' The appeal did not say when the strike should begin, but leaders have previously mentioned May 15. It asked all enterprises in Latvia to start organizing strike committees. Anatoly Alexeyev, head of the Interfront Movement that unites thousand of non-Latvians, said today that he expected a major anti-independence demonstration on Wednesday during Victory Day celebrations marking the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. Residents of Riga say they have already observed some panic buying by people who fear Moscow will impose a partial economic blockade, as it did against Lithuania. ``I don't know what's happened to everything _ now they have grabbed up all the salt,'' said a retiree who was walking along the streets of Riga's Old Town with an empty shopping bag. Latvian deputies awaited a response from Moscow to documents they sent the Kremlin on Monday explaining their declaration of independence and the transition period they envision. Deputy Prime Minister Ilmars Bisers, who helped draft the message, said there had been no response yet and ``we may have to go there.'' In a speech to a group of veterans on Monday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev condemned ``separatists.'' But the Tass news agency's report of that meeting did not say whether he mentioned Latvia directly. ``There are forces that would like to use the atmosphere of democracy, glasnost and freedom to implement their futile ambitious plans, including separatist plans,'' he said. Such a policy was ``irresponsible,'' Gorbachev said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, The democratically ..., with 5 grafs to UPDATE with details from Jewish leaders' East Berlin visit, pickup 8th graf pvs, The ceremony ...
DOC.TEXT: Mixing anger with grief, World Jewish Congress leaders today honored the memory of the 6 million Jewish victims of the Holocaust at the mansion where high-ranking Nazis plotted their ``Final Solution.'' ``I will not pray here, because I personally believe that God turned his face away from this place, as he did from Auschwitz,'' said congress President Edgar M. Bronfman. ``Neverthless something must be said.'' In Hebrew, German and English, participants read words penned by death camp survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel: ``What does a Jew today feel in this place, marked by evil and malediction? Fear and trembling, anger _ incommensurate anger, helplessness and grief, infinite grief.'' The ceremony at the Wannsee Villa came on the final day of the World Jewish Congress meeting in Berlin, the first time the organization has met on German soil. Some delegates from around the world stayed away from the meeting, saying the trip to the heart of Nazi tyranny would be too traumatic. After the ceremony, the congress leaders went to East Berlin for a meeting with East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. ``There has never been a Germany without Jews,'' de Maiziere told the Jewish leaders. ``There can only be a Germany with Jews, or there won't be any Germany. ``Yet, the shadow of Auschwitz hangs over us,'' he continued. The democratically elected East German parliament, in a dramatic gesture, last month accepted a share of responsibility for the Holocaust. For more than four decades, the now-ousted Communist authorities had denied any responsibility for the deaths of 6 million Jews. During his East Berlin visit, Bronfman urged that a memorial be built at the site of the now crumbling Berlin Wall to recall the dual significance of the date Nov. 9. On that day last year, the Berlin Wall was opened. On Nov. 9, 1938, Nazi thugs throughout Germany started ransacking Jewish stores and homes and killing dozens of Jews in what has been called Kristallnacht (Crystal Night), because of all the broken glass. The ceremony at the Wannsee Villa was held on the 45th anniversary of the Nazis' unconditional surrender, ending World War II in Europe. Under brilliant, sunny skies, the congress leaders gathered in front of the villa, where on Jan. 20, 1942, high-ranking officials of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich planned the extermination of the Jews. Wiesel's words called to mind some of the Jewish victims of the Holocaust: ``teachers and their pupils, brides and grooms, intellectuals and workers, rabbis and their disciples, young revolutionaries and old dreamers of Zion.'' Heather Harris, 23, read the statement in English before about 300 people, including the congress' leadership. Ms. Harris comes from San Francisco and now lives in Jerusalem, where she heads the World Union of Jewish Students. Heinz Galinski, head of West Germany's 35,000-member Jewish community, recalled the horror that the Nazis planned at Wannsee. He said the murder of the Jews ``stands alone in the history of mankind.'' ``If the Nazis had won, then all the people of the world would have been enslaved,'' said Galinski, like Wiesel a survivor of the Auschwitz death camp. Before the ceremony, Bronfman and other leaders of the group toured the inside of the villa, which is in disrepair. West Berlin plans to turn it into a Holocaust memorial. They stood in what is known as the ``Fireplace Room,'' where Nazi SS boss Reinhard Heydrich and his fellow Nazis planned the ``Final Solution.'' ``It's mind-boggling,'' Bronfman said. ``I'm sad and I'm angry too.'' Introducing the statement by Wiesel, Bronfman called the Wannsee decision ``the most despicable decision in the history of mankind.'' Wiesel himself did not attend the ceremony because of what were termed ``scheduling problems.'' In the villa 48 years ago, Heydrich detailed plans to use Jews as slave laborers and to build concentration camps, gas chambers and crematoria. He said that a total of 11 million Jews would be wiped out. Even before the Wannsee conference, Nazi troops had been slaughtering Jews in occupied Polish and Soviet territory. Outside the villa's high gates, a plaque reads: ``In this house in January 1942, the infamous Wannsee conference took place. To the memory of the fellow human beings slain by the Nazi tyranny.'' At a news conference Monday at the heavily guarded West Berlin Jewish Community headquarters, the Jewish congress leaders discussed their concerns about German reunification. ``The Jewish people have something to say to the new Germany that is going to be created in a short time,'' Bronfman said. He said Sunday that a unified Germany must ``forever teach'' about the Nazi Holocaust, ``the lowest point ever reached in man's inhumanity to man.'' In Jerusalem, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said it was Israel's duty to demand that ``in a united Germany there would be a perpetual educational effort, so that the generation growing up there would remember. In all parts of Germany, the government must wage a war against anti-Semitism.'' The Polish-born Shamir escaped the Holocaust, but his parents and two sisters were killed. Of the more than 600 participants at the meeting, 80 were from nations other than Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Deportees Sometimes Forcibly Sedated
DOC.TEXT: Deportees from Canada are sometimes forcibly sedated before being expelled to protect other travelers, the Canadian immigration minister said. Any deportee leaving Canada by plane, train, bus or boat who might be disruptive on the trip is liable to be drugged, Immigration Minister Barbara McDougall said Monday. ``In some cases we provide a medical attendant for some people who are being deported. Should there be any sedation, that is done by the medical attendant,'' she told reporters. She said under international agreements concerning airlines, ``we have to make sure people's behavior on an aircraft is appropriate and there's no danger to other passengers.'' The practice is ``not a violation of anything as far as I can tell,'' she said. But Steve Foster, a lawyer with the Jesuit Refugee Service in Toronto, said the government is abusing the rights of deportees by drugging them without consent. ``We've got a charter of rights that says you can't do this to people,'' Foster said in a telephone interview. ``To administer drugs for a non-medical reason is unethical. To administer drugs without a patient's consent is unethical.'' In the United States, the Immigration and Naturalization Service does not, ``as a matter of policy sedate deportable aliens,'' but INS officers accompany ``anyone that might be potentially violent or dangerous,'' spokesman Duke Austin said in Washington. On chartered flights, however, deportees have been sedated ``on a limited basis'' by the INS, said a source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The INS has used chartered flights or government planes to deport Cubans to their homeland. McDougall's comments about forced sedations came after questioning from Canadian member of parliament Dan Heap, who asked McDougall to halt the deportation of Mohammed Ahmed Said, a Kenyan. ``I don't believe there's anything in Canadian law which allows me to put a needle in you without your permission no matter what, unless you're mentally incompetent,'' Heap said outside the House of Commons. Said claims immigration officers threatened to sedate him if he made any trouble, Heap said. Said was being held in a detention center in Toronto pending deportation, which McDougall said she would not halt.

DOC.HEAD: President Congratulates South Africa, ANC on Meeting
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent letters congratulating Nelson Mandela and South African President F.W. de Klerk on their historic talks last week, their offices said today. The African National Congress, the most powerful black political organization in South Africa, released the contents of the letter it said was received today. De Klerk's office confirmed he had also received a letter from Bush, but did not make the contents public. ``Your brave struggle against apartheid and your commitment to peace and a political solution to South Africa's great problems have stirred the hopes of many,'' Bush said to Mandela, deputy president of the ANC. ``The American people respect this commitment and support your efforts to achieve a non-racial and democratic South Africa with equal opportunity for all,'' Bush said. The letter said the great energy shown by Mandela since de Klerk freed him from a life prison sentence in February had helped the country move closer to achieving those objectives. ``The joint commitment to a peaceful process of negotiations and efforts to resolve the existing climate of violence agreed to by the African National Congress and the government is a great step forward to this end,'' Bush said, adding he looked forward to discussing those issues with Mandela when they meet later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Existing Home Sales Declined 1.6 Percent During First Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 3rd graf, At the, making it 1st quarter 1990 over 1st quarter 1989 percentages and deleting reference to 4th quarter's $95,000.
DOC.TEXT: Existing home sales declined 1.6 percent during the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double-digits and prices in many areas continued to rise. The National Association of Realtors said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.81 million units during the January-March period, down from 3.87 million units during the fourth quarter and 3.90 million during the first quarter of 1989. At the same time, the Realtors survey showed the median price of existing homes rose 5.2 percent to $95,900, up from $91,200 during the same period of 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Mortgage rates moved up as well, ranging from 9.83 percent as the year began to 10.22 percent as the quarter ended, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association. The survey covered sales of existing single-family detached homes, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives. The Realtors said sales are expected to remain stable during the year. The survey showed 29 states with increased sales, led by South Dakota with a 49.1 percent gain, while Vermont was at the bottom of the list with a 24.8 percent decline. By region, the West posted a 3.0 percent sales increase to an annual rate of 680,000 units, followed by the South, up 0.7 percent to 1.46 million units. The Northeast has the largest decline, down 5.5 percent to 690,000 units. Sales were down 4.9 percent in the Midwest to 980,000 units. The West also experienced the sharpest gain in median prices, up 7.6 percent to $143,700. It was followed by the Midwest where costs rose 6.9 percent to $74,200. Prices advanced 2.0 percent each in the Northeast and South. The median price in the Northeast was $146,200, while it was $85,800 in the South. Five Western metropolitan areas continued to have the most expensive homes, led by Honolulu with a median price of $290,400. It was followed by the San Francisco Bay area, $262,200; Orange County, Calif., $243,600; Los Angeles, $211,500, and San Diego, $182,300. San Diego was tied with Boston. The least expensive homes were found in Peoria, Ill., where the median price was $48,000; Oklahoma City, $50,600; Spokane, Wash., $52,000; Mobile, Ala., $58,700, Louisville, Ky., $59,300.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills 1, Wounds 5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with one dead in bomb blast today, report of guerrillas killed Monday; Picks up 7th graf pvs, ``The drug ...'; Edits thereafter to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: A car packed with dynamite exploded today outside a government office building in western Colombia, killing one person and wounding five others, police said. The blast damaged the civil register's offices, along with several houses, stores and vehicles in Pereira, a city of 300,000 residents about 110 miles west of Bogota. No one claimed responsibility, but police said they captured one suspect who they believed had driven the car to the site. An army communique also reported today that 18 leftist guerillas and a soldier died in three battles Monday in different regions. It said the rebels belonged to the country's three main guerrilla groups _ the National Liberation Army, the People's Liberation Army and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. And in the latest terrifying twist in the drug war, a top police official said Monday that traffickers are buying up homes near police stations, intent on turning them into house bombs. ``The traffickers are willing to pay five or six times the value of the houses in order to fill them with dynamite and blow them up,'' said Col. Oscar Pelaez, chief of the country's investigative police. He told a news conference Monday that some of the homes involved are adjacent his agency's headquarters in southern Bogota. Drug traffickers have been carrying out a terrorist campaign of car bombings and other attacks in retaliation for a government crackdown on drugs. Authorities blame traffickers for the assassinations of three presidential candidates in the last eight months. The Medellin cocaine cartel has targeted police in particular. Most of the violence has been in the city of Medellin, where more than 30 police officers and several civilians have been killed the last two months. On Saturday, Medellin police defused an abandoned car packed with dynamite and ball-bearings. The drug lords have said in communiques that they are retaliating for alleged police torture and killing of detained cartel members. At Monday's news conference, the chief of police, Gen. Miguel Gomez, repeated an official denial of those charges. Pelaez said police were tipped off to the house-bomb plot by informers in the cartel. He said indiscriminate violence by the cartel had disenchanted some members. ``Many people are ready to collaborate in a common crime,'' Pelaez said in an interview after the news conference. ``They are willing to kill an individual. But when it comes to these collective massacres, they are sickened and they denounce the actions.'' He said police also had received cooperation from private citizens who live near houses that traffickers tried to buy. ``The people realize that their lives are threatened,'' he said. Meanwhile, authorities found the bodies of 13 people who they said had been massacred in southern Guaviare state. The state's governor, Wilfredo Ceron, said the killings had taken place Friday in dense jungle that prevented immediate confirmation. He told the RCN radio network the killings were apparently the result of a private feud.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Defends Saying Reagan Lied
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 3rd graf from end, bgng, Poindexter, questioned... to make it Reagan, sted Bush
DOC.TEXT: The lead prosecutor at John M. Poindexter's Iran-Contra coverup trial says he had ample evidence for telling jurors that President Reagan lied to the American people about trading arms for hostages. Dan K. Webb said in a court filing that his remark, made during final arguments, was supported by evidence that Reagan had, indeed, sold arms to Iran to try to secure the release of American hostages in Lebanon. Webb defended his comment in a brief that he and other trial prosecutors filed Monday in response to Poindexter's motion to set aside his five felony convictions. The former national security adviser was convicted April 7 of conspiracy, obstructing congressional inquiries and making false statements to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. In his summation to the jury, Webb said he couldn't criticize Reagan's decision to sell arms to Iran in an attempt to win the hostages' freedom. ``You make judgments as president and you carry them out, and maybe you're right and maybe you're wrong,'' Webb said. ``But you don't lie to the American public.'' The defense had previously charged that Webb's statement about Reagan was an improper expression of personal opinion that was ``clearly designed to inflame the members of the jury, to make them feel as if they themselves were victims of the alleged crime in this case.'' The prosecution responded Monday by saying Webb's statements were ``fully supported by the evidence and were relevant to the charges in this case.'' The evidence ``clearly established'' that a November 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran ``was intended as part of an exchange of arms for hostages,'' said the brief filed by prosecutors in the office of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. ``The evidence further establishes that on Nov. 13, 1986, President Reagan addressed the nation and denied to the American public the allegation that his administration had been involved in an arms-for-hostages deal,'' the prosecution filing said. Webb's comment was relevant because prosecutors were trying to show that Poindexter's motive for lying to lawmakers about the U.S. role in the missile shipment to Iran was to protect the president from political embarrassment. Poindexter, questioned by lawmakers within days of Reagan's speech, denied he knew anything about the shipment at the time it occurred. Poindexter also was convicted of lying to Congress by denying that National Security Council staff officer Oliver L. North was supervising a secret operation to arm the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress banned U.S. military aid. He is scheduled to be sentenced June 11 and could receive up to 25 years in prison and fined as much as $1.25 million.

DOC.HEAD: Planned Dialogue Between Government, Protesters Breaks Down
DOC.TEXT: Anti-Communist protesters stormed out of a meeting with Interim President Ion Iliescu today, dashing government hopes of a quick end to a marathon rally demanding his resignation. The meeting ended just minutes after it began when the government said the session could not be videotaped and the protesters' delegation refused a counter-offer of a stenographer recording the minutes. At downtown University Square, site of the anti-Iliescu protest, about 1,000 demonstrators had gathered by midday, loudly demanding Iliescu's resignation. They called his National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government, a party of ``neo-Communists.'' The demonstrators, part of a rally that began 17 days ago, vowed to continue their protest until Romania's first free national elections in more than 50 years are held May 20. Iliescu, a former Communist Party functionary, was relegated to lesser duties when he became an outspoken critic of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in the early 1970s. The Front was catapulted to prominence after Ceausescu was toppled in December. Iliescu and other former Communist officials within the Front publicly broke with their Marxist past and embraced democratic, free-market ideals. But critics accuse them of adhering to Communist ideals and seeking to reimpose totalitarian rule if they win the elections. Meanwhile, the National Liberal Party said its presidential candidate, Radu Campeanu, had canceled planned campaign stops in the northeastern region of Moldavia after being attacked Saturday by alleged Front supporters in Braila, 180 miles northeast of Bucharest. Liberal Party officials said Campeanu, who suffered facial cuts in the attack, was considering whether to cancel two other planned rallies out of concern for his safety. Both Campeanu and Ion Ratiu, candidate of the National Peasants' Party, recently have said they would boycott the balloting unless political violence by alleged Front supporters abated. Ratiu and his wife have claimed they also have been the targets of Front assaults.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Residents Evacuated as Flood Waters Roll South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with record crest in Ark., rain in Texas, picking up 4th graf pvs, `In Texas...'
DOC.TEXT: Rural Texans stubbornly stayed by their homes as the Trinity River _ swollen from the worst northern Texas flooding in more than 80 years _ rolled southward toward the Gulf of Mexico today. Elsewhere, a reservoir on the Oklahoma line began falling after hitting a record of more than 27 feet above normal, and snakebites were on the rise in Arkansas, where flooding has forced the evacuation of more than 300 homes and driven the reptiles from nesting areas. The Arkansas River hit a record 27.6 feet _ 3.6 feet above flood stage _ today at Little Rock. Thirteen deaths have been blamed on the weather in the past two weeks, one in Oklahoma and the rest in Texas. Northern Texas has had 22.06 inches of rainfall in the first four months of 1990, the most since 1922. The result: the worst flooding since 1908. Light rain fell today in eastern Texas and there was a chance of thunderstorms in the Dallas area Wednesday, but National Weather Service meteorologist John Cockrell said that should not compound the already severe flooding. In Texas, flood warnings for people and livestock were issued for today as the Trinity River engulfed homes, pastures and fields south of Dallas. At least 150 people were evacuated and main roads closed in Trinidad, 60 miles southeast of Dallas. Near Palestine, 90 miles below Dallas, about 50 homes were destroyed or severely damaged in the community of Long Lake, where the Trinity, usually a few hundred feet across, had bulged to about two miles. ``We can't tell exactly how many residences are affected yet, because we can't count underwater,'' said Bill Walters, manager of a Red Cross shelter set up in a campground. While about 80 people had been evacuated from Long Lake by late Monday, many were reluctant to leave, Walters said. ``These people are pretty stubborn, as all Texans are. They think they can stick it out, but they really can't do it,'' he said. As the flooding moved downstream, the Red Cross sent teams to prepare shelters. Many farm-to-market roads and some major highways were closed. Lake Texoma on the Oklahoma line fell half a foot Monday after cresting at a record 644.76 feet above sea level, the first time since 1957 that water flowed out the spillways. Mike McCoy of the Army Corps of Engineers said will take up to two months for the lake to return to a ``decent'' level as the Corps plans to lower i by 6 to 9 inches a day. A preliminary survey Sunday found 83 homes at least partially submerged in Oklahoma's Marshall County, which is partly cut off from the outside by the swollen lake. Highway flooding made life strange for Judy Peterson, who works in Madill, Okla. Instead of simply driving the 18 miles from her home on Sand Point to the office, she and her husband must take a boat a half-mile and then drive a circuitous 56-mile route around the northern edge of Lake Texoma and back to Madill. They'd been doing that for a week as of Monday. ``It's really getting old,'' she said. In central Arkansas, the rising waters of the Arkansas River have driven snakes from their homes. A hospital at Pine Bluff, which normally treats one snakbite victim a week, has treated eight in the last week. Spokesman Bill Cheatham said most were bitten by copperheads, but no one was seriously hurt. Water was reported up to 3{ feet deep in homes in the Pine Bluff area. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton added two more counties to last week's disaster declaration Monday, bringing the total to 29. An estimated 325 houses were evacuated in six counties, officials said. Officials said the flooding along the Arkansas River was the worst since a 1927 rampage that prompted construction of many of the levees along the river.

DOC.HEAD: Former W.Va. Governor Pleads Guilty to Five Felony Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf, `Moore, 67,' to UPDATE with prosecution comment.
DOC.TEXT: Former West Virginia Gov. Arch Moore today fulfilled an agreement with federal prosecutors by pleading guilty to a five-count corruption indictment. The maverick Republican, the only West Virginia governor to serve three four-year terms, entered his plea before U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman, brought in from Baltimore because federal judges in the state asked to be excused. Moore faces up to 36 years in prison and fines totaling $1.2 million. Sentencing was set for July 10. U.S. Attorney Michael Carey said the government agreed to make no sentencing recommendation. Moore, 67, agreed April 12 to plead guilty to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice after federal prosecutors revealed they had secretly recorded a meeting in which Moore allegedly admitted receiving illegal cash donations in his 1988 campaign. The recording also allegedly showed he planned to hide information from federal investigators. After the hearing, Carey said additional allegations against Moore will be detailed at the sentencing hearing. ``Mr. Moore use large sums outside the election process. It was a scheme to run the election outside the limit of the law,'' said John Campbell, an assistant U.S. attorney from the Justice Department's public integrity section. ``Any time the franchise of the voters is taken away from them is a serious offense,'' Carey said. The indictment accused Moore of committing acts relating to his 1984 campaign and his term as governor from 1985 to 1989. In addition, Moore was accused of blocking a federal grand jury's investigation of him last year and this year, Carey said. The indictment further alleged Moore used his public position to extort approximately $573,000 in 1985, Carey said. It also accused him of filing false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985, the official said. It further charged that he schemed to defraud the state of his salary and benefits by funneling about $100,000 in cash into his 1984 campaign fund, Carey said. It was the second time Moore was indicted for improprieties allegedly committed while in office. He and his 1972 campaign manager were indicted in December 1975 for allegedly extorting $25,000 from the president of a shaky financial holding company trying to get a state charter for a new bank. Moore was acquitted in 1976. Although registered as a Republican, Moore's politics were flexible in a state in which Democrats outnumber Republicans 2-to-1. He had friends and foes on both sides of the aisle. Moore served one term in the state House of Delegates from 1953 to 1954 and was in the U.S. House from 1957 to 1969. He won the governor's office in 1968 with a razor-thin election victory, and defied polls four years later to win re-election. The constitution barred him from a third consecutive term, but in 1984 he returned for a third, nonconsecutive term. Budget problems helped undo him in 1988, when voters turned him out in favor of political novice Gaston Caperton. He is the second West Virginia governor to encounter legal trouble with the federal government. Former Democratic Gov. W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, who served from 1961-65, and several of his associates were tried on bribery conspiracy charges in 1968. Barron was acquitted but later went to prison for bribing the foreman of the jury that acquitted him.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Suffer Sharp Setback In Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: Italian voters dealt the new-look Communist Party a sharp setback in regional and provincial elections, while groups seeking greater local autonomy made surprising gains, according to results released today. ``Earthquake at the polls,'' said the national daily La Repubblica after the Lega Lombarda, a regional political party in the Milan area, won 19 percent of the votes, outpolling the Communists in the wealthy industrial region. Results from the voting Sunday and Monday confirmed the early trends showing the Communists, who had come to the brink of power a decade ago, getting no more than 24 percent of the vote. The Communists, Italy's No. 2 party, won 30 percent of the vote in the last regional elections in 1985 and 27.8 percent in parliamentary voting in 1987. The Christian Democrats, who have led or dominated all national governments for four decades, suffered small losses and held on to about a third of the total votes. The Socialists, Italy's No. 3 party, advanced, but with 15 percent of the vote were still a long way from overtaking the Communists. Premier Giulio Andreotti, a Christian Democrat, warned during the campaign that major shifts in the voting could cause his coalition government to collapse. The coalition also includes the Socialists and three tiny parties: Republicans, Social Democrats and Liberals. But commentators said the results didn't appear to pose major risks for the coalition. However, the results were a disappointment for the Communists, who adopted a ``new course'' at an extraordinary congress in March in an effort to halt the party's steady electoral decline since the early 1980s and react to the democratic upheavals sweeping Communist parties from power in Eastern Europe. At their congress, the Communists gave party leader Achille Occhetto a mandate to restructure the party to try to unite Italy's fractured left. This would eventually entail changing the party's name and hammer-and-sickle symbol. The proposals were opposed by the party's old guard leaders, who saw them as a denial of the party's history and roots. ``The new course didn't stop the hemorrhage of votes that has gone on since 1984,'' said the leading Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera. The biggest gains were made by the Lega Lombarda and similar locally oriented groups in the north. These groups have been accused of prejudice toward Italians from the south and immigrants from the Third World who have come to the more prosperous north seeking work. But the Lega has denied the charge, saying its aim is to reduce the power of the central government in local matters. ``The racist leagues advance,'' headlined Rome's Il Messaggero. But Giorgio Bocca, a La Repubblica columnist, said the mainstream parties would be making a serious error to underplay the reasons for the success of the new groups. ``This is the reaction to a policy which has led to the bankruptcy of the public administration and handed large areas of the south to the underworld,'' Bocca wrote. Umberto Bossi, leader of the Lega Lombarda, said its success in becoming the second-largest party in Lombardy exceeded its expectations. ``This is the first step toward our final goal of federalism, to reduce the power of the central government.'' Up for election were 15 of 20 regional governments, 87 provincial governing councils and 6,374 city governments. City elections were not held in such major centers as Rome, Naples, Trieste, Catania and Bolzano.

DOC.HEAD: Men Say Aborted Drug Deal Led to Torture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add age.
DOC.TEXT: A man told police he was burned, tortured by electric shocks, put on a hot stove and had hot wax poured into his eyes after he and another man were abducted in a drug deal that went sour, police said today. Paul Breakwell, 20, said he and Jason Ingani, 19, both of Monroeville, were held by three men and assaulted for more than eight hours after the alleged deal broke down, Police Chief Donald Aubrecht said. Breakwell told police he was burned, shocked with electricity and put on a hot stove before he escaped and summoned police Saturday; the men said they caught Breakwell and Ingani trying to burglarize the house, Aubrecht said. John Bosack, 20, and John Fritzius, 21, who both lived in the home where the alleged assaults occurred, and Brian Teets, 19, of Monroeville were charged with unlawful restraint, terroristic threats, aggravated assault, reckless endangerment and drug possession, Aubrecht said. Police confiscated what appeared to be cocaine, along with pills, drug paraphernalia and $1,200 in cash. Breakwell was being treated at Forbes Regional Medical Center, but his family requested no information be released, hospital officials said. Ingani also was hospitalized after the abduction, but his whereabouts weren't known. The hospitalized men face drug charges when their hospital treatment is finished, Aubrecht said. They also could be charged with burglary if Bosack and Fritzius file a countercomplaint. Fritzius and Teets were released on $10,000 bond each. Bosack is being held in the Allegheny County Jail on $10,000 bond. The three men are scheduled to appear at a hearing Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Chaos in Gas Supplies Costs Job of Oil Company Director
DOC.TEXT: The Ministry of Industry has dismissed the director of the state-run oil monopoly, blaming him for a disruption in supplies that has led to long lines at gas stations, a ministry spokesman said today. Jerzy Szewczyk was fired from his post as director of the Central Oil Company for failing to predict a need to increase crude oil imports, said the spokesman, Jan Golab. For the last week, gas stations across Poland have been plagued by long lines reminiscent of the chronic shortages during the former Communist regime when gasoline had to be rationed. The lines dwindled after the market-oriented policies of the new Solidarity-led government reduced demand by raising gasoline prices dramatically to match world market prices more closely. Golab said that due to a shortage of funds, Szewczyk had kept a relatively low supply of gas in Poland and had not anticipated increased purchases last week as a result of two national holidays. Supplies to gas stations dried up, causing long lines to appear and requiring rapid imports, Golab said. The failure of the Soviet Union to meet its obligations in crude oil deliveries has also contributed to the disruption of gas supplies. Some Soviet gasoline bound for Poland is refined in Lithuania. Moscow has sharply reduced oil supplies to the Baltic republic as part of an economic blockade aimed at forcing the Lithuanians to back off their declaration of independence. The offical PAP news agency reported that deliveries from the Soviet Union dropped by 10,000 tons in April as a result of ``general problems in its economy and trade with Poland.'' Polish newspapers reported today that the situation is likely to improve in the short term because tankers with foreign oil were either already docked or on their way to the Baltic port of Gdansk.

DOC.HEAD: Spain Deports Palestinians Who Planned Bombing of Syrian Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Spain has pardoned and deported two Lebanese Palestinian terrorists arrested in 1985 while preparing a car-bomb attack on the Syrian Embassy in Madrid, a Justice Ministry spokeswoman said Tuesday. The government approved a pardon April 20 for Jihad Ibrahim Salami and Chassan Ibrahim. They were deported to Lebanon immediately afterward, said the spokeswoman, who was not identified in accordance with custom. The daily El Pais said Tuesday the pardons coincided with others granted recently in several Western countries. The newspaper did not identify the countries. It said the pardons were intended as goodwill gestures in response to the recent release of Western hostages held by radical groups in Lebanon. It was the second time since 1986 the government has pardoned and deported Lebanese citizens convicted of terrorist acts in Spain. The two men pardoned last month were arrested in July 1985 in a Madrid apartment where police found 26 of explosives. The Palestinians told police they planned to use a car bomb to blow up the Syrian Embassy in Madrid and assassinate the Syrian ambassador. Police said at the time they believed the men were members of Force 17, part of PLO leader Yasser Arafat's Fatah organization. Force 17 served originally as a special security group to protect Arafat and other senior PLO leaders. It later took up special operations against Israeli targets. In 1987, a court convicted both men on charges of illegal possession of arms, explosives and false identification papers and sentenced each to 10 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Rebels Claim Field Victory, Reports Fighting Closes on Luanda
DOC.TEXT: Angola's U.S.-backed rebels today claimed they had routed government forces after a three-day battle in southeast Angola, while Portuguese media reports said fighting could be closing on the capital Luanda. A statement released in the Portuguese capital said 139 government troopers were killed and remaining government forces fled trenches near Mavinga, 700 miles southeast of Luanda. The Portuguese news agency Lusa reported from Luanda that Gen. Antonio dos Santos N'dalu was nominated to command the Bengo-Cuanza front, indicating fighting was as close as 38 miles northeast of the capital. There was no confirmation from officials in Luanda that fighting was so close to the capital. Government troops launched an offensive last December against UNITA rebel positions in southeast Cuando Cubango province and claimed they captured the airstrip and a strategic UNITA base near Mavinga. In turn, the rebels stepped up bombing and sabotage attacks in the capital and other towns. UNITA never acknowledged defeat at Mavinga, and today's statement, signed by Chief of Staff Arlindo Pena, said recent fighting drove government troops from positions six miles north of the base. But Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos said last week government columns had advanced south of Mavinga and could soon be within artillery range of rebel headquarters at Jamba, some 125 miles further south. A Western diplomat following the Angolan conflict from Lisbon said today the UNITA claims seemed ``exaggerated,'' adding he had no reports of a major battle in the region. Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said any government withdrawal from Mavinga could be to reinforce units in the north, where UNITA rebels are said to have intensified offensives in small combat units. The reports of fighting came as diplomatic efforts continued to reach a peaceful end to the 15-year civil war. UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, has been fighting to force the Marxist Angolan government to share power since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Given in Racial Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: The accused ringleader in the Bensonhurst attack gathered a white gang armed with bats because he believed blacks were coming into their neighborhood to attack them, his attorney argued today. ``You might convict him of being a jerk. He is a jerk,'' Stephen Murphy, attorney for Keith Mondello, said in his closing statement. ``But it's no crime to be a jerk.'' Meanwhile, a separate jury deciding the fate of the accused triggerman, Joseph Fama, resumed deliberating today. They asked to review several pieces of evidence, including photographs of the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn and a photo collage containing pictures of the defendants. The jurors began deciding Fama's fate Monday without hearing that a key witness with a history of hallucinations wanted to recant. State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens refused to let Fama's defense lawyer reopen his case to put Franklin Tighe back on the witness stand to say he did not see the shooting. Tighe, 20, also a Bensonhurst resident, has a long record of psychological problems including visual hallucinations and severe depression. He was the only witness who said he saw Fama pull a pistol and shoot 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. Defense lawyer David DePetris said Monday that after testifying, Tighe contacted him and said he was not standing next to Fama when Hawkins was shot, as he told the jury. ``In plain, simple language, I smell a rat here,'' Assistant District Attorney Edward Boyar said. He objected to allowing DePetris to reopen his case, which he rested last week. In his summation Monday in Fama's case, Boyar was highly critical of ``silent Bensonhurst'' and its numerous residents who saw much or all of the Aug. 23 attack but refused to come forward. He spoke of door stoops ``where the brother and sisterhood of Bensonhurst sat, watching but not seeing, hearing but not listening'' when Hawkins was surrounded by a white mob and shot through the heart. ``When the mob turned that corner what did they know about Yusuf Hawkins?'' Boyar asked. ``They knew the color of his skin. That was the only thing they knew about Yusuf Hawkins.'' DePetris told the jury the prosecution witnesses were not believable and that Fama had not been proved guilty. He told the panel that Tighe believed what he was saying when he testified. But he said the stress of finding Hawkins dying on the street triggered hallucinations in the mentally unstable man.

DOC.HEAD: Chaos in Gas Supplies Costs Job of Oil Company Director
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to restore cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The Ministry of Industry has dismissed the director of the state-run oil monopoly, blaming him for a disruption in supplies that has led to long lines at gas stations, a ministry spokesman said today. Jerzy Szewczyk was fired from his post as director of the Central Oil Company for failing to predict a need to increase crude oil imports, said the spokesman, Jan Golab. For the last week, gas stations across Poland have been plagued by long lines reminiscent of the chronic shortages during the former Communist regime when gasoline had to be rationed. The lines dwindled after the market-oriented policies of the new Solidarity-led government reduced demand by raising gasoline prices dramatically to match world market prices more closely. Golab said that due to a shortage of funds, Szewczyk had kept a relatively low supply of gas in Poland and had not anticipated increased purchases last week as a result of two national holidays. Supplies to gas stations dried up, causing long lines to appear and requiring rapid imports, Golab said. The failure of the Soviet Union to meet its obligations in crude oil deliveries has also contributed to the disruption of gas supplies. Some Soviet gasoline bound for Poland is refined in Lithuania. Moscow has sharply reduced oil supplies to the Baltic republic as part of an economic blockade aimed at forcing the Lithuanians to back off their declaration of independence. The offical PAP news agency reported that deliveries from the Soviet Union dropped by 10,000 tons in April as a result of ``general problems in its economy and trade with Poland.'' Polish newspapers reported today that the situation is likely to improve in the short term because tankers with foreign oil were either already docked or on their way to the Baltic port of Gdansk.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Elizeth Cardoso Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Bossa nova and samba singer Elizeth Cardoso, who in her heyday was known as ``The Divine,'' has died of stomach cancer. She was 69. Ms. Cardoso died Monday at the Bambina medical center in Rio de Janeiro, a clinic spokesman said. Ms. Cardoso's career spanned 50 years. She started out as a singer in small clubs, and with the release in 1958 of ``Song of Too Much Love,'' her career took off. She recorded more than 60 records, the last in 1989. Composer Dorival Caymmi said Ms. Cardoso's death represented a ``loss in the category of artists that enchanted the night.'' Survivors include a son, Paulo Cesar Valdez, and a daughter, Tereza Cristina.

DOC.HEAD: Fashion Revolutionary of Britain's Swinging Sixties Dead
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Plunket Greene, who with his wife Mary Quant helped revolutionize the British fashion scene for young people in the 1960s, has died, his family announced. He died Friday at age 57, his family reported Monday. No cause of death was stated. Plunket Greene and Mary Quant met when they were both students at Goldsmiths' College of Art in southeast London, and they married in 1957. In 1955, Plunket Greene and a friend, Archie McNair, had opened a fashion boutique called Bazaar in the King's Road in west London's Chelsea district. Quant was initially the buyer for Bazaar. But with her husband's encouragement, she began to sell her own trend-setting designs. These included the miniskirt that became the symbol of Britain's swinging sixties. The influence of the couple turned the King's Road into the fashion mecca for young Britons. Crowded with clothes boutiques and chic restaurants, its sidewalks became a perpetual fashion show as young people flocked there to buy the latest styles and be seen wearing them. The styles were widely copied abroad. Bazaar became one of the first stores to cater almost exclusively to the new generation of affluent young. The couple opened a second store in the nearby Knightsbridge district of London in 1961, and Plunket Greene opened a restaurant in the basement of the original King's Road store. Tall, witty, elegant and sociable, Plunket Greene in 1963 expanded into the mass market with a new Mary Quant label, Ginger Group, and launched his wife's designs with considerable success in the United States. During the 1970s, he expanded the Mary Quant licences to include items such as bed linens, carpets, swim wear, hosiery and jewelry and secured a place in the Japanese market. He is survived by his wife and their 19-year-old son, Orlando.

DOC.HEAD: Lukens Underdog in Ohio; Democrats Seek Opponent for Helms in N.C.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Larrie in graf 17 bgng ``The goveronor'' and in next graf CORRECT that Hechler was congressman for 18 years.
DOC.TEXT: Ohio Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens asked voters to salvage his scandal-marred career and four North Carolina Democrats fought for a chance to challenge Sen. Jesse Helms, as five states held primary elections today. West Virginia's Democratic ballot featured Sen. Jay Rockefeller's shoo-in bid for nomination to a second term, and a campaign for state treasurer by Dee Caperton, whose divorce from Gov. Gaston Caperton last fall made headlines. The other states with balloting are Indiana, which has congressional primaries, and New Jersey, where impoverished Atlantic City and several other communities are choosing mayors. Senate candidate Harvey Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, N.C., was joined at the polls this morning by two first-time voters he could count on for support, his daughters Erika, 19, and Angela, 18. Here is a state-by-state rundown of the liveliest races: _ OHIO: Lukens, who represents a conservative, rural district in western Ohio, was disowned by the Republican Party after his conviction last year on a misdemeanor charge of having sex with a 16-year-old girl. The 59-year-old divorced Lukens says his actions were ``dumb'' but ``not evil.'' Over the weekend, The Columbus Dispatch reported the state Tax Department had certified him as delinquent because of $1,500 in unpaid personal income taxes. The leader among his three primary opponents is Thomas Kindness, who formerly held the seat. Three Democrats seek their party's nomination. Ohio also has a governor's race, with state Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. facing one little-known opponent for the Democratic nomination. George Voinovich, the former Cleveland mayor, is unopposed for GOP nomination. In Cuyahoga County, voters decide whether to raise taxes on liquor and cigarettes to finance a new stadium for baseball's Cleveland Indians. _ NORTH CAROLINA: Gantt, Charlotte's first black mayor, has emerged in recent polls as the front-runner in the Democratic Senate primary but appears unlikely to avoid a runoff by winning more than 40 percent of the vote. ``We are not going to win this World Series by dividing ourselves up in the league championship,'' Gantt said over the weekend in appealing to voters to unite behind him as the best hope of beating Helms. The three other leading candidates in a six-man field are John Ingram, a former state insurance commissioner; Michael Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney, and R.P. ``Bo'' Thomas, a former state senator. Helms himself faces two token challengers in the GOP primary. In the 3rd District, 100-year-old Henry Merritt Stenhouse, an eye doctor, is running in a GOP primary for the seat held by Democratic Rep. Martin Lancaster. Stenhouse, who campaigns against ``too damned much government'' faces businessman Don Davis, 60, and oil heater repairman Ken Brosman, 39. _WEST VIRGINIA: Rockefeller, an heir to one of America's biggest fortunes, faces two underfinanced rivals. Republican John Yoder, a lawyer and onetime aide to former Chief Justice Warren Burger, is unopposed for his party's nomination. Ms. Caperton has cited her management of her own $5 million portfolio in addition to an estimated $11 million she reportedly received from her divorce settlement as evidence she can handle the state's finances. Opponents have characterized her as a socialite ill-equipped to handle the state's books, which are awash in red ink. The governor has remained neutral as polls show his former wife in a close race with Larrie Bailey, a former state treasurer. Two others are also on the ballot. In the 4th District, Democratic Rep. Nick Joe Rahall Jr. is challenged by Ken Hechler, a congressman for 18 years until he gave up the office in 1976 to run for governor. Hechler, 75, calls on voters to elect ``a congressman with high moral standards again,'' a reference to Rahall's having faced drunken driving charges in California in 1988 and being sued in 1984 by a Las Vegas casino for gambling debts. _ INDIANA: A comeback effort is under way in the 1st District, where Democratic Rep. Peter Visclosky faces Katie Hall, whom he ousted in 1984. Ms. Hall, who served one term as the state's only black congresswoman, also lost to Visclosky in 1986. Two others are also seeking the Democratic nomination in the district, which includes Gary. Indiana has a Senate election this year but no primary. Republican Sen. Dan Coats, who was appointed to replace Vice President Dan Quayle, will face Democratic state Rep. Baron Hill in November. _NEW JERSEY: In Atlantic City, incumbent James L. Usry, the city's first black mayor who is under indictment for bribery, faces six challengers in a non-partisan primary. If no one gains a majority, the two front-runners will meet again June 12.

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Democrats Seek Senate Nominee as Five States Hold Primaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Larrie in graf 11th bgng ``West Virginia's.'' Will be topped after pollls close at 7:30 p.m. EDT in N.C., W.Va. and Ohio; material below dash should stand.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Six Democrats squared off Tuesday for a chance to oppose Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens sought to survive a sex scandal in Ohio, and a former West Virginia first lady tried to rejoin her ex-husband _ as state treasurer. In other highlights of the busiest day of primary voting so far this year, former Democratic Reps. Katie Hall of Indiana and Ken Hechler of West Virginia bid for comebacks in their old districts. Ms. Hall challenged Rep. Pete Visclosky and Hechler went up against Rep. Nick Joe Rahall Jr. In North Carolina, 100-year-old Henry Merritt Stenhouse ran in a Republican primary for Congress. And in Atlantic City, N.J., Mayor James L. Usry, the city's first black mayor who is under a bribery indictment, faced six challengers in a non-partisan primary. Sen. Jay Rockefeller faced two token Democratic challengers in West Virginia. Republican attorney John Yoder is the unopposed GOP candidate. Ohio Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. had one Democratic opponent in his drive for the nomination for governor. Former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich is the Republican nominee. The race that attracted most attention was North Carolina's Democratic Senate primary. Late polls showed Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, leading, but state law requires a June 5 runoff unless one candidate gets more than 40 percent of the total. ``We are not going to win this World Series by dividing ourselves up in the league championship,'' Gantt said in a last-minute appeal to voters to unite behind him as the best hope of denying the deeply conservative Helms a fourth term. The three other main contenders were John Ingram, a former state insurance commissioner; Michael Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney, and R.P. ``Bo'' Thomas, a former state senator. Helms himself had token opposition from two challengers in the GOP primary. West Virginia's Democratic primary for treasurer featured Dee Caperton, whose 23-year marriage to Gov. Gaston Caperton ended last fall in a highly publicized divorce. The governor has remained neutral as polls showed his former wife in a close race with Larrie Bailey, a former state treasurer. Two others also are on the ballot. In western Ohio, Lukens faced three GOP primary opponents, including Thomas Kindness, who formerly held the seat. At the other end of the state, voters in Cuyahoga County decided whether to raise taxes on liquor and cigarettes to finance a new stadium for baseball's Cleveland Indians.

Helms has always been a target of liberal and moderate Democrats because of his strongly conservative stands, including opposition to abortion and federal funding for art exhibits he considers obscene. In 1984, with President Reagan heading the GOP ticket, Helms turned back a strong challenge by former Gov. Jim Hunt by 52 percent to 48 percent. Indiana also has a Senate election this year but no primary. Republican Sen. Dan Coats, who was appointed to replace Vice President Dan Quayle, will face Democratic state Rep. Baron Hill in November. The Ohio governor's race is expected to be a heated contest this fall, as the GOP banks on the highly popular Voinovich to reclaim the post from the Democrats. Two-term incumbent Richard Celeste was barred by state law from seeking a third term. Lukens insisted on running despite party officials' call for his resignation after he was convicted last year on a misdemeanor charge of having sex with a 16-year-old girl. His troubles grew when The Columbus Dispatch reported that the state Tax Department had certified him as delinquent because of $1,500 in unpaid personal income taxes. Ms. Caperton cited her management of her own $5 million portfolio in addition to an estimated $11 million she reportedly received from her divorce settlement as evidence she could handle the state's finances. Opponents said the former beauty queen and socialite was ill-equipped to handle the state's troubled finances.

DOC.HEAD: First Soldiers Accused in Philippine Coup Bid Go on Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with defense lawyers walking out, comments, admission of suspect in killing of American, President Aquino confident if U.S. leaves bases; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA1
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for dissident soldiers accused of trying to overthrow President Corazon Aquino walked out of court today after military judges denied their motion questioning the legality of the tribunal. One of the civilian lawyers told the court he would not participate further in the trial and left the chamber, followed by the other defense lawyers. They were cheered by 21 officers accused of participating in the December coup attempt. The officers, including two generals, were the first soldiers to face court martial in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, the strongest and bloodiest of six bids to topple Mrs. Aquino since she took office four years ago in an uprising against the late Ferdinand Marcos. All 21 have been charged with mutiny, murder, attempted murder and conduct unbecoming an officer. They could receive life imprisonment if convicted of all charges. One of the accused, Brig. Gen. Jose Commendador, declared, ``This is worse than a kangaroo court,'' and said the defendants would not participate in the trial if they were not represented by their civilian lawyers. Commendador led rebel troops in occupying an air base in the central Philippines for nine days. During the opening session, defense lawyers filed several motions, including one challenging the authority of military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa to appoint the court. Defense lawyer Pablito Sanidad argued that de Villa should not personally have appointed the judges because he was in effect a ``co-accuser'' since his residence was bombed and destroyed in the coup attempt. The defense also argued that the order creating the court and appointing its members was not signed by de Villa, but the military judges ruled that the tribunal was ``duly constituted.'' ``I'm sorry I cannot stand in behalf of my client and could not be a willing instrument over this illegally assembled body,'' former Appellate Court Judge Alfredo Lazaro told the judges before leading the walkout of about a dozen lawyers. Lazaro represented Lt. Col. Romelino Gojo, a marine commander who led rebel troops in taking over the suburban Villamor Air base. A seven-member tribunal, led by Brig. Gen. Demetrio Camua, is hearing the case. The defendants cheered with raised fists when the judges entered the courtroom. Lozano said defense lawyers will ask the Supreme Court to halt the trial and rule on the validity of the military court's decision to go ahead with it. The court adjourned until next Tuesday, but government-appointed military defense lawyers said they were not in a position to lead the defense. Also in Manila, a suspect in the killing of a U.S. Marine said that he accidentally shot the American during a hold-up near the U.S.-run Subic Bay Naval Base last week, police said today. Renato Angeles, 38, one of two Filipinos arrested in the case, made the admission during a lie detector late Monday, police said. He is accused in the May 4 killing of Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette. President Corazon Aquino said today that the Philippines would be prepared if U.S. military bases here are closed when their lease expires in 1991, a Cabinet official said. Mrs. Aquino asked all government departments for suggestions on next year's budget to support base conversion plans, said Executive Secretary Catalino Macaraig, chairman of a presidential committee advising Filipino negotiators in talks with the United States the future of the facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Congress Remember Holocaust Victims
LaserPhotos BER1,BER2
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the World Jewish Congress stood outside the villa Tuesday where Nazi leaders plotted the Holocaust and recalled the 6 million dead, including brides and grooms, rabbis and students and ``dreamers of Zion.'' ``I will not pray here, because I personally believe that God turned his face away from this place, as he did from Auschwitz,'' said Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress. The solemn ceremony in front of the Wannsee Villa, where Nazi leaders in 1942 mapped out the ``Final Solution,'' was the most emotional part of the three-day World Jewish Congress in Berlin, which ended Tuesday. It was the first time the Congress had met on German soil, and some delegates refused to attend, saying their grief was still too great. Wannsee Villa is now in disrepair, with many of the inside walls ripped out and dusty scaffolding covering one part of the facade. West Berlin officials have promised to refurbish the villa and turn it into a Holocaust memorial. A tribute composed by Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, a concentration camp survivor, called to mind the Holocaust victims. It spoke of ``teachers and their pupils, brides and grooms, intellectuals and workers, rabbis and their disciples, young revolutionaries and old dreamers of Zion.'' ``All were doomed. Simply, solely as Jews,'' said the declaration, read on the 45th anniversary of the collapse of Nazi Germany in World War II. The declaration recalled how the Nazis ``in the name of their criminal leadership on behalf of their nation, condemned the entire Jewish people to death and oblivion.'' ``What does a Jew today feel in this place, marked by evil and malediction?'' said Wiesel's tribute. ``Fear and trembling, anger _incommensurate anger, helplessness and grief _ infinite grief.'' The statement was read in English, Hebrew and German. ``If only the walls could speak. If only the trees and clouds could testify,'' it said. ``We need to hear them, for most German men and women, in the past refused to speak, refuse to remember.'' Jewish leaders for years have said that older Germans especially have refused to face their past. West German President Richard von Weizsaecker has drawn acclaim at home and abroad for urging fellow citizens to frankly deal with the horrors of the Nazi legacy. As the two Germanys rush toward reunification, there have been fears of a growth of anti-Semitism. A top-ranking official from West Germany tried to allay these fears during a speech to the final session of the Congress. ``We will continue with all force the fight against right-wing extremism and anti-Semitism,'' Interior Minister Wolgang Schaeuble said. Before the ceremony, Bronfman and other leaders of the organization toured the inside of the villa. They stood in what is known as the ``Fireplace Room,'' the room that historians say is most likely the one used for the conference. There, Nazi SS boss Reinhard Heydrich and his co-conspirators planned the ``Final Solution,'' the extermination of European Jews. ``It's just absolutely mind-boggling, when you hear that Heydrich wanted to come here to a secluded spot because he wasn't sure his colleagues would go along with him,'' said Bronfman. ``He he was so happy they did, he took a glass of brandy and had a cigar. What kind of people were these?'' Later, Congress leaders traveled to East Berlin for a meeting with Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. ``There has never been a Germany without Jews,'' de Maiziere told the Jewish delegation. ``There can only be a Germany with Jews, or there won't be any Germany.'' The democratically elected East German government, in a dramatic gesture, last month accepted joint responsibility for the Holocaust. For more than four decades, the now-ousted Communist authorities had denied any responsibility. Bronfman, during the East Berlin visit, called for a memorial to be built at the site of the now crumbling Berlin Wall to recall the significance of Nov. 9, 1938, and Nov. 9, 1989. On the date last year, the Berlin Wall was opened. On Nov. 9, 1938, Nazi thugs throughout Germany started ransacking Jewish stores and homes and killing dozens of Jews in what has been called Kristallnacht, because of the masses of broken glass that littered the streets afterward.

DOC.HEAD: 184 in House Can Take the Money and Not Run
With BC-Easy Money-List
DOC.TEXT: The easiest way for Rep. Stephen Solarz to become a millionaire is to quit his job. Ditto for Rep. Dan Rostenkowski. Solarz and Rostenkowski, both Democrats, are among 184 lawmakers eligible to put leftover campaign cash to personal use if they retire from the House by January 1993. They can take the money and not run. Until 1979, members of Congress were allowed to convert leftover campaign funds to personal use when they retired. But Congress voted that year to halt the practice for lawmakers elected after January 1980. Last year, Congress voted to totally ban the practice. The measure, however, delayed the effective date of the prohibition to January 1993, giving those eligible more than two years to decide whether to retire and take the money. The Senate bars members from converting campaign funds, but all members of Congress are allowed to use their campaign accounts for political purposes after leaving office. House members may keep whatever campaign funds they had as of Nov. 30, 1989 _ about $40 million for the 184 House members covered by the clause. Sixty of the 184 members had at least $100,000 in their campaign accounts at the cutoff date; a handful had less than $5,000. One, Kentucky Democrat William Natcher, is eligible but reported a zero campaign balance a month after the cutoff date. Most House members are reluctant to discuss whether the deadline will affect their political plans for 1992, saying they are concentrating on legislative business and the 1990 elections. But the aging of many senior House members and redistricting as a result of the 1990 census has led to speculation that 1992 will be a high turnover year. ``Retirement in 1992 is going to be attractive to a lot of older members,'' said William Schneider, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute. Older incumbents who see their safe districts shaken up by redistricting may ``be tempted to just retire and keep their campaign money,'' Schneider said. ``Of course they'll come up with any number of other public reasons for deciding not to run.'' Solarz is among the those whose futures could be affected by redistricting. New York City probably will lose a congressional seat and Solarz could end up in a race against a fellow incumbent, perhaps Democrat Charles Schumer. But Solarz, who had a $1.5 million campaign war chest at the cutoff, repeatedly has said he has no plans to retire before 1993 and that he would not convert his campaign cash if defeated. Rostenkowski is unopposed this fall, and many of his colleagues think the Chicago lawmaker will retire after one more term. He had $1 million in campaign funds at the Nov. 30, 1989, cutoff and has been vague about his plans. ``We're focusing on this year's agenda and winning re-election in 1990 and then we'll worry about 1992,'' said Rostenkowski spokesman Jim Jaffe. Rostenkowski has not said whether he would take his campaign funds with him if he left office before the deadline, Jaffe said. ``But it's the law that members can convert, and he supports the law,'' Jaffe said. A handful of those retiring from Congress this year could convert their campaign funds to personal use. One retiring member, Kansas Republican Robert Whittaker, has said he would not use his $500,000-plus in excess campaign money for personal purposes. Georgia Democrat Doug Barnard, who says his next House term will be his last, has more than $500,000 and has said he might convert some for personal use. Retiring Rep. Bill Frenzel, a Minnesota Republican who has more than $300,000 left, plans to refund all 1989 and 1990 campaign contributions, pay bills and give the remainder to other candidates. Most of the others who are eligible avoid the subject. ``They don't like to advertise it because it just makes people angry,'' Schneider said. Once lawmakers retire, they don't have to worry about whether such criticism will cost them votes. Former Rep. Samuel Stratton of New York wrote himself a check for nearly $200,000 from campaign funds last year. Retired Ohio Republican Rep. Delbert Latta converted $123,000. Missouri Republican Gene Taylor closed his campaign account last year by giving $52,000 to charity and $345,000 to himself.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Rejects Soviet Unification Idea; East Germans Skeptical
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with reaction by Kohl and East Germans to Shevardnadze suggestion; Picks up 13th graf, `The Netherlands ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-NATO, Bjt
