DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected Moscow's suggestion that the two Germanys could unite and decide later which military alliances they will join, and East Germany said it was also skeptical. Speaking to reporters, Kohl said the matter of a united Germany's military allegiances must be cleared up before the two German nations are formally merged. Kohl said the Germans ``need no singularization,'' meaning that a united Germany should have its sovereignty. The chancellor was referring to a suggestion by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at last week's unification talks in Bonn that formal unity could occur before ``external'' aspects of the merger process are cleared up. East Germany also reacted negatively to Shevardnadze's weekend proposals. Government officials in East Berlin are ``skeptical'' of delaying a settlement on the ``external'' aspects of unification, said the East German news agency ADN, and want ``a quick continuation'' of the six-nation talks. During Saturday's meeting of the two Germanys and the four World War II victors, Shevardnadze also suggested a ``transition period'' during which the four wartime allies would retain postwar rights even after German unity. Shevardnadze's remarks had initially triggered jubilation among some West German politicians, who sensed the pace of unification was rapidly picking up. But by today that had changed into concern about delaying settlement of the international aspects of German unification. There had even been talk among some politicians of canceling West Germany's Dec. 2 federal balloting in favor of elections for a united Germany's parliament. But Kohl said today ``without question'' the Dec. 2 elections will still occur. The United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain jointly control many matters in the former German capital of Berlin. They also have special rights outside Berlin, many involving the status of the troops they maintain in what once were their post-war military occupation zones. Vernon A. Walters, U.S. ambassador to West Germany, said today that Washington supports a united Germany with unrestricted sovereignty and without special rights for any of the World War II allied victors. The question of a united Germany's military attachments has been one of the greatest obstacles to quick reunification. The Soviet Union rejects a unified Germany as a member the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but the NATO allies insist the new Germany belong to the Western alliance. At the weekend meetings, Shevardnadze said he envisions the four World War II victors keeping troops on German soil for a few years after unification until the issue of a united Germany's military allegiance is settled. The Bonn talks were attended by the foreign ministers of the two Germanys, France, Britain and the Soviet Union as well as U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The Netherlands, a NATO member, expressed doubts Monday about the latest Soviet idea. ``I clearly see complications if there is a de-coupling of German unification from the military question,'' Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek told reporters. ``It sounds like the Germans are cutting a deal'' that would allow unification while leaving military links undecided, said one Dutch official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Washington has not reacted to Shevardnadze's suggestion.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Accident Was First Serious Navy Accident Since The Fall
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Those accidents, to CORRECT figure to 14; picks up 3rd graf, Here is
DOC.HEAD: With Ship Fire
DOC.TEXT: The fire that broke out early Tuesday aboard the guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham off North Carolina, killing one crew member and injuring at least nine others, was the first serious Navy accident since a six-week string last fall. Those accidents, which caused 14 fatalities, prompted the Navy to review safety procedures in November. Here is a rundown of recent serious Navy accidents: _Oct. 11, 1989. An officer aboard the helicopter carrier USS Iwo Jima was killed and a crewman was injured when they were struck by shrapnel from a shell fired from a nearby cargo ship during an exercise in the Atlantic Ocean. _Oct. 11. A sailor was lost overboard from the frigate USS Downes 300 miles off Tokyo. _Oct. 29. A jet fighter pilot making his first carrier landing crashed on the deck of the training aircraft carrier USS Lexington in the Gulf of Mexico, killing himself and four others. _Oct. 30. The pilot of an F-A-18 attack jet accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb on the cruiser USS Reaves in the Indian Ocean, slightly injuring five sailors. _Oct. 30. A sailor from the aircraft carrier USS Carl Vinson was lost overboard in the Pacific Ocean 620 miles from Wake Island. _Nov. 1. Three sailors and $4 million worth of aircraft missiles were swept overboard from the carrier USS Eisenhower off North Carolina. Two sailors were rescued and one was declared dead. _Nov. 1. Nine sailors were injured in a boiler fire aboard the USS Monongahela 500 miles west of Gibraltar. _Nov. 9. A Navy Reserve pilot flying an A-7E attack jet crashed into an apartment complex in Smyrna, Ga., killing two civilians. The pilot and one other person were wounded. _Nov. 11. One man was killed when the destroyer USS Kincaid collided with a freighter off the coast of Malaysia. _Nov. 14. An F-14 fighter crashed into the Gulf of Mexico 60 miles northwest of Key West, Fla. The two-man crew was not seriously injured. _Nov. 14. A fire aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Inchon at Norfolk, Va., injured 31 people, eight of them civilians. _Nov. 14. A technician at the Naval Surface Weapons Testing Center in White Oak, Md., was slightly injured in a small lab explosion. _Nov. 22. Two Marines were killed in a crash during exercises off the Iwo Jima in the western Mediterranean Sea.

DOC.HEAD: John Paul Says Church, State Relations Improving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs, pope's speech in Aguascalientes; Picks up 10th graf pvs, ``They were ...'; SUBS 4th graf from end, ``John Paul ...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II said today the church and state in Mexico are reaching a better understanding after more than a century of hostility. ``The context of the international community is initiating a new phase of its history, and that will have its repercussions here in the near future,'' John Paul said in a speech directed to the teachers of Mexico. John Paul was greeted at the airport here by a crowd of more than 50,000 people doing ``the wave.'' He delivered his speech under a hot sun for the first time on this trip, and a security guard held a white parasol over his head. Because the pope was only stopping off at the airport here on the third day of his eight-day journey, the city built replicas of important downtown colonial buildings as a backdrop. ``A new perspective of contacts between the church and the political community of this country is occurring in this day,'' the pope said. ``And in this phase of better understanding and dialogue, the church wants to offer its own support, without straying from its specific goals and abilities.'' The church is severely restricted under Mexico's constitution, although many of the restrictions are ignored. The speech was the pope's most direct public reference to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's moves toward normalization of church-state relations. The pope said teachers must strive for a ``leap in quality'' to move education beyond the basics of reading and writing. He said the church was not a brake on scientific and cultural progress, but asked teachers to ``open the world of instruction to Christ.'' The pope drew wild cheers when he spontaneously saluted the ``corazones calientes,'' or ``hot hearts,'' of Aguascalientes, which means hot waters and refers to the area's thermal springs. ``Come back, come back,'' chanted the crowd, waving thousands of white flags, pennants and hats. The pope's next stop was a shrine to the Virgin Mary at the nearby town of San Juan de Los Lagos. On Monday, in the port city of Veracruz 200 miles east of Mexico City, the pontiff had defended plans to celebrate the 500th anniversary of Christianity in the New World from critics who say the church came as an agent of conquest, repression and disease. ``The discovery, the conquest and the evangelization occupy a decisive, luminous place taken all together, even though they are not without shadows,'' John Paul told thousands of people at a waterfront prayer service. In Veracruz, the pope spoke from a raised platform along the Gulf Coast harbor where conquistadors led by Hernan Cortes first reached Mexico in 1519. They were followed five years later by the first group of missionaries. The celebrations planned for 1992, the 500th anniversary Columbus' arrival in America, have prompted a fierce debate in Latin America. Critics charge that the European conquerors destroyed native cultures, and that Roman Catholic priests were an instrument of conquest. In Mexico, Columbus Day is celebrated as ``The Day of the (Indian) Race,'' and in recent years Indian activists have attacked memorial ceremonies at the monument to Columbus in downtown Mexico City. John Paul has used the 1992 anniversary as a banner in his efforts to launch a ``re-evanglization'' or revival of Catholicism in Latin America. He plans to open a special conference of Latin American bishops in the Dominican Republic in two years to celebrate the anniversary. ``The evangelization of America, encouraged by the Lord ... encountered many limits and difficulties which even today wait to be seen in their true light through an objective study; but there were also great successes, as demonstrated by the splendid works that have served as a model and support for your people's road during these centuries,'' the pope said. John Paul cited the examples of three 16th-century priests who defended the rights of Mexican Indians. He said the church ``receives from Christ the mandate to go and preach the Gospel to all nations.' The pope then returned to Mexico City and held brief meetins with two former presidents of Mexico, Miguel de la Madrid and Luis Echevarria. The private sessions were a further sign of the warmer climate between the Vatican and Mexico, which retains some of the most restrictive religious laws outside the Communist world though they are widely ignored. John Paul also held talks Monday morning with Salinas. The president named a personal representative to the pope in February in a possible step toward re-establishment of diplomatic ties broken in 1926. Opposition politicians have criticized Salinas for what they say is a cynical attempt to shore up the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party's flagging support through rapprochement with the church. ``The whole world can see the political intentions in all this,'' leftist opposition leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas observed after Salinas changed plans at the last minute and personally greeted the pontiff when he arrived Sunday. The pontiff is making his second visit to Mexico and his 47th papal trip outside Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Endre Bohem, Writer and Producer
DOC.NOTE: eds: Endre is cq
DOC.TEXT: Endre Bohem, a producer whose credits include the movie ``The Night Has a Thousand Eyes'' and the TV series ``Rawhide,'' has died. He was 89. Bohem died Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. Bohem fled his native Hungary shortly after World War I, when he was denied a college education because he was Jewish. He became a scenarist in the United States and began producing films. Bohem's early writing credits include the 1927 film, ``Desert Night,'' starring John Gilbert. He worked for the Metro Goldwyn Mayer and Columbia studios, and at Columbia he produced short subjects. Among them was the ``Passing Parade'' series. His other producing credits include ``Alias Nick Beal,'' starring Ray Milland, ``House of a Thousand Candles,'' ``The Redhead and the Cowboy'' and ``The Night Has a Thousand Eyes,'' starring Edward G. Robinson. Bohem also produced ``Rawhide,'' the western starring Clint Eastwood as Rowdy Yates. The series ran from 1959 to 1966. Bohem's other TV series included ``Revlon Mirror'' and ``Ford Theatre.'' Bohem returned to Hungary in 1968 so that he could produce, with the national Hugarofilm company, ``The Boys of Paul Street.'' The feature was hailed as the first joint production involving companies from the United States and the Eastern bloc. An anti-war movie, it was nominated for an Academy Award as best foreign picture. Bohem is survived by his wife, Hilda; a son, a daughter, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. At his request there were no services.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Lose Effort to Forbid Politicking by IRS, CIA, FBI Agents
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with votes on amendments; picks up 3rd graf pvs: ``If we ....; deleting as redundant 10th graf pvs: They accepted...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted today to allow IRS, CIA and FBI agents to participate in political campaigns, rejecting Republican attempts to maintain the status quo established in the 51-year-old Hatch Act. On a 51-46 vote, the Senate rejected an amendment to exclude employees in the spy and tax agencies plus the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission from a Democratic bill that removes most current restrictions on political activities by civil service and postal workers. The amendment by Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas was one of three unsuccessful attempts by Republicans today to chip away at the union-sought revisions in the Hatch Act. ``Laws restricting those people and what they can do are already on the books,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, the principal author of the proposed Hatch Act revisions. ``They cannot use information gained on the job politically.'' Dole contended that the entire bill amounts to a ``pot of gold'' for the Democratic Party because unionized public employees and their political action committees overwhelmingly favor Democrats. Also defeated today were GOP amendments to maintain a ban on federal workers holding office in the two political parties and delaying any changes in the Hatch law until after a campaign finance reform bill is enacted. The first amendment by Sen. William V. Roth, R-N.H., was defeated on a 64-32 vote and the second by GOP Whip Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming was rejected 61-36. Dole hinted on Monday that Republicans might try to attach major elements of their proposed campaign finance reform bill _ such as a total abolition of PACs _ to the Hatch Act revisions later this week. The Senate already has been debating the bill for a week. ``lf we banned all PACs, there wouldn't be much demand for this bill,'' Dole said of the union-sought revisions in the Hatch Act. The Hatch law now forbids the nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal workers from participating actively in politics. The Democratic bill would lift some restrictions so that federal employees could hold party offices and solicit campaign funds from their co-workers, but not from the general public. ``The only purpose of this bill,'' Dole said, ``is to make the federal employee union PACs fatter, of which 88 percent (of their campaign donations) goes to the other party. This is a big pot of gold for the Democratic Party.'' Democrats have repeatedly denied that intent, saying the bill is intended to give federal workers the same right to freedom of expression enjoyed by other Americans. While Democrats want the Senate to complete action on the Hatch law revisions before moving to the campaign finance reform, Dole indicated that Republicans might not wait. He said the GOP campaign finance proposal with its abolition of all PACs ``could come on this measure sometime later this week.'' Democrats denied any linkage between the proposed Hatch law changes and campaign finance reform and tried to forestall a Republican effort to bring the two issues together. Despite repeated assertions that President Bush will veto any changes, Democrats so far have garnered at least a dozen votes from GOP senators on several challenges by the Republican leadership to the bill. ``It's going to pass,'' said Senate GOP Whip Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming. ``I'm sure we don't have 40 votes,'' he said, referring to the number needed to sustain a filibuster. Simpson said the major task for Republican leaders will come later when ``those of us (opposed to the changes) will have to try to sustain the veto of the president with 34 votes.'' The House approved a similar but much broader revision of the Hatch Act by an overwhelming 297-90 vote more 13 months ago. The House measure would permit federal workers to seek and hold elected public office and solicit campaign contributions from the general public. The Senate bill would retain current prohibitions against those two activities.

DOC.HEAD: National Home Sales Slip as Mortgage Rates, Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Double-digit mortgage rates and rising prices dampened existing home sales in many areas during the first three months of 1990, while boosting them in others, a real estate trade group reported Tuesday. Overall, the National Association of Realtors said sales slipped 1.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.81 million units during the January-March period, down from 3.87 million units during the fourth quarter. Sales totaled 3.90 million during the first quarter of 1989. Association president Norman D. Flynn said rising mortgage rates had the dual effect of spurring sales in moderately-priced areas while curbing them in higher-end markets. ``Buyers in affordable markets decided to buy before rates rose further, while those in high-cost areas held back,'' Flynn explained. The trade group's survey showed the median price of existing homes rose 5.2 percent to $95,900, up from $91,200 during the same period of 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. Mortgage rates also rose, starting the quarter at 9.83 percent and ending it at 10.22 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association. Rates have continued to rise, and hit 10.67 percent at the end of last week. Nevertheless, the Realtors said resales are expected to remain stable during the year as economic conditions improve. The Realtors survey covered sales of existing single-family detached homes, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives. Sales were up in 29 states, ranging from a 49.1 percent jump in South Dakota to a 0.9 percent increase in Nevada. At the same time, Vermont posted a 24.8 percent decrease, the largest decline in the nation. By region, the West saw sales rise 3 percent to an annual rate of 680,000 units, dominated by activity in California. Flynn reported some softening in high-cost coastal areas while sales in some lower-priced interior areas increased. The South had across-the-board increases, up 0.7 percent to 1.46 million units, as many oil-patch areas continued to regain strength. But the sales pace in the Northeast continued to decline, dropping 5.5 percent to 690,000 units. ``Last quarter's activity (in the Northeast) reflected high home prices and rising interest rates,'' according to John A. Tuccillo, the realtor group's chief economist. Sales in the Midwest dropped 4.9 percent to 980,000 units, due to increased interest rates and poor weather conditions, the Realtors said. Median prices rose sharpest in the West, up 7.6 percent to $143,700. Costs in the Midwest rose 6.9 percent to $74,200. Prices advanced 2 percent in the Northeast to $146,200 and 2 percent in the South to $85,800. Five Western metropolitan areas continued to have the most expensive homes, led by Honolulu with a median price of $290,400. That was followed by the San Francisco Bay area, $262,200; Orange County, Calif., $243,600; Los Angeles, $211,500, and San Diego, $182,300. San Diego was tied with Boston. The least expensive homes were found in Peoria, Ill., where the median price was $48,000; Oklahoma City, $50,600; Spokane, Wash., $52,000; Mobile, Ala., $58,700, and Louisville, Ky., $59,300.

DOC.HEAD: Government Evacuates 100,000 Families as Big Storm Approaches
DOC.TEXT: A cyclone packing winds up to 155 mph zeroed in on the south Indian coast Tuesday night, and authorites evacuated 100,000 families from a low-lying plain. Live electrical wires knocked down by winds preceeding the storm killed three people in the southern city of Madras, Indian news reports said. A building collapse injured eight others in the city, which is about 1,050 miles south of New Delhi. Waves 20 feet above normal crashed against parts of India's southeastern coast Tuesday night as the storm approached. Weather officials said the cyclone appeared to be stronger than a 1977 storm that killed thousands in southern India. Press Trust of India reported that 2,000 people had been evacuated from Madras. Weather officials said the core of the storm was 87 miles east of Madras over the Bay of Bengal and would cross into India by early Wednesday. A heavily populated, low-lying coastal plain in Andhra Pradesh state, just north of Tamil Nadu state, was expected to take the brunt of the storm. Authorities evacuated more than 100,000 families from the area and placed them in 300 camps inland, news reports said. Meteorologists said they expected ``very heavy damage to houses and installations and disruption of communications,'' Press Trust of India said. Andhra Pradesh's chief minister, M. Chenna Reddy, said army and navy helicopters and boats had been prepared for rescue operations. Heavy winds and rain were reported in several townships along the coastal plain, he said. One town, Kota, had seven inches of rain in the past 24 hours. Cyclones are the Indian Ocean's equivalent of hurricanes. They usually come in the spring just before the monsoon season begins.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Calls 250 Prospective Jurors for Selection, Press and Public Barred
DOC.TEXT: The federal judge in the trial of four men charged with the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena summoned a panel of 250 prospective jurors today. The press and public were excluded from questioning of prospective jurors before U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie for space reasons, marshals said. The four defendants are among some 20 people who have been charged in the 1985 slaying of Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, in Guadalajara, Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say New Birth Control Pills and IUDs Safer
DOC.TEXT: New birth control pills, containing one-fifth as much estrogen as the original pills, are safe for non-smoking women in their 40s and do not raise the risk for clots or cancer, researchers report. Dr. Daniel R. Mishell, chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the University of Southern California School of Medicine, and other doctors gave the update Monday on the latest safety studies of the pill and IUDs at the annual meeting of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. It also was reported that the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve, perhaps this year, surgically implanted hormone capsules that provide birth control hormones for five years. This birth control method, with the contraceptives usually placed under the skin on one arm, already is used in more than 40 countries. The implants are as effective as daily birth control pills, said Dr. Francine Sinofsky of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Because of health concerns, most American women stop using birth control pills or IUDs after their prime child bearing years. Studies show that they are used by less than 5 percent of women 35 and older, and that sterilization is now the No. 1 method of birth control among women in the age group. Mishell noted that women remain potentially fertile until nearly age 50, and said, ``It is often a real problem deciding what to do. ``It's really up to the woman, but there are many highly reliable, and generally safe, methods of contraception available.'' The original pills with strong doses of estrogen were found to increase a tendency toward blood clots. The new pills use a fifth as much estrogen and add another hormone, progestin, and studies show that they present no increased risk of cardiovascular disease or of breast cancer. The new pills have labels which say, with FDA approval, that the benefits of birth control pills may outweigh the risks. But, Mishell said, women who smoke should consider the pills dangerous because nicotine and estrogen together worsen the risk of blood clotting.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Reform Needed in Science Education
DOC.TEXT: Science teachers should stop spoon-feeding facts to students and allow them to ``discover the sheer pleasure'' of understanding science, a report said Tuesday. The American Association for the Advancement of Science called for ``vast reform in science education from preschool to university,'' but said change is most critical at the college level. Science, the report said, should be viewed as a liberal art. ``The experience of learning science as a liberal art must be extended to all young people so that they can discover the sheer pleasure and intellectual satisfaction of understanding science,'' the report said. The report, the result of a three-year study by academics in the arts and sciences, said conventional methods of teaching science should be abandoned for more student-conducted experiments, specific goal setting and group work to allow students to analyze scientific principles. Professors who simply lecture on scientific facts in conventional courses often leave students with ``underdeveloped intellectual skills and little awareness of the influences of science on their lives,'' the report said. Among the recommendations in the report, ``The Liberal Arts of Science: Agenda for Action,'' were: _Fifty percent of the instruction in a baccalaureate degree program should be devoted to liberal education; at least one quarter of that to liberal education in the natural sciences. In most institutions, that is equivalent to 15 to 16 semester hours of instruction in science for all students. _Student-student and student-faculty interaction should be increased. _There should be a major reform of national achievement and professional licensing tests. Scientific and professional societies must revise their exams to include all the goals of liberal studies in science. _Institutions must set specific targets for increasing the number of science graduates from minority and disadvantaged groups.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Caves In, Killing 60
DOC.TEXT: A tin quarry collapsed in eastern Zaire, killing 60 people, the state news agency reported today. Rescue workers who dug down nearly 70 feet have recovered 20 bodies, the agency said. The cave-in occurred Monday at Salambila, near the border with Rwanda, at a mine owned by the Kivu Mineral Society, according to the report. No other details were immediately available. Minerals, including diamonds and gold, are the main foreign exchange earners of this central African nation.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Officer Recommends 13.2 Percent Profit
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of voter-approved insurance rate rollbacks were stung by a recommendation that insurers be allowed a 13.2 percent profit for last year and up to 19 percent in the future. Proposition 103 supporters said Monday's decision by an administrative law judge could kill voter-approved rate rollbacks. ``This decision stands Proposition 103 right on its head and says, `It's business as usual,''' said Harvey Rosenfield, chief author of the November 1988 ballot initiative. In his decision, Administrative Law Judge William J. Fernandez recommended a 13.2 percent profit for the year that ended in November. The recommendation is 2 percent above the long-term industry average. The profit margin would be allowed before an insurer was required to roll back its rates for automobile, homeowners' and other lines of property and casualty insurance covered by Proposition 103. Rosenfield, a frequent foe of state Insurance Commissioner Roxani Gillespie, said: ``It's about what we expected from a judge hired by Gillespie. ... We think Gillespie ought to just stop trying to implement Proposition 103 and leave it for the next commissioner.'' Asked to respond to Rosenfield's comments, a spokeswoman for Gillespie said: ``I don't think it's important enough to.'' ``The important thing is that we have the judge's decision and the commissioner is reviewing it now,'' said the spokeswoman, Carey Fletcher. ``I really think we need to stop this Mickey Mouse politicking.'' Tom Aceituno, legal affairs counsel for the Association of California Insurance Companies, said the industry group was still analyzing the decision and would take ``a wait-and-see attitude to see what the commissioner does.'' Gillespie has 100 days to make a final decision, which could be challenged in court. Fernandez did not propose any firm limits for insurers' profits after November 1989, when the insurance commissioner took over approval of all rate increases. But he said the evidence would support a range of 11.2 to 19 percent. Fernandez rejected consumer groups' proposals to limit insurance executive salaries and subject companies to mandatory efficiency levels before calculating their allowable profit rates. ``Liberal democracy is growing in the nations of the Eastern bloc,'' he said. ``Communism with its regulatory stifling of individual initiative is being rejected. We in California should take heed of what is occurring elsewhere.'' Proposition 103 mandated insurance rates be cut 20 percent below 1987 levels and frozen for a year unless a company faced insolvency. However, the state Supreme Court ruled last year that a rollback could not be used to deny an insurer a ``fair rate of return,'' leaving it to the commissioner to set standards. Consumer groups had sought to disqualify Fernandez from the case because of alleged bias in favor of the insurance industry. They said he unfairly limited the hearing, preventing them from covering issues like ``redlining,'' where rates are pegged to geographical areas, and cross-examination of industry experts. Fernandez, whose wife is an attorney for a law firm whose clients include three insurance companies, rejected their complaint, saying he had no financial or conflict of interest.

DOC.HEAD: Charles and Di Symbolize the Trendy Rush East
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: Charles and Di wow Budapest. Rock singer Lou Reed gives a private Prague concert for President Vaclav Havel and friends. Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs fixes the Polish economy. For jet-setters, royalty, business people and tourists, the rush is on to Eastern Europe. Revolution has made a region that was firmly out of fashion during decades of Stalinist drabness the new hot ticket in travel. Travel magazines feature Eastern European locales on their covers, and Western tourists cram the streets of Prague and Budapest. For some visitors, the attraction is the money that might be made in markets untapped for more than 40 years. Mark Palmer, the former U.S. envoy to Hungary who resigned to join Estee Lauder heir Ronald S. Lauder in a new development bank for Central Europe, has likened the business people flocking to Budapest's Forum Hotel to the gold miners who rushed to the West a century ago. Others making the foray to the East seem to be searching for something more: the brave, creative spirit that powered eastern Europe's democratic revolutions and propelled philosophical intellectuals into positions of political power. As Prince Charles told a Budapest university audience Tuesday, many in the West ``have no conception of what it means to suffer invasion, persecution and loss of freedom.'' The prince, known for his diatribes against the trappings of modernity, congratulated Hungarians and all East Europeans for preserving their humanity in adversity and begged them to keep it intact. ``You can give us again a heightened sense of the classical values of the western spirit ... a new realization that democracy is not just a ballot box _ it is a wise, mature and exacting state of mind,'' the heir to the British throne stressed. From leader to laborer, East Europeans are basking in this new attention, heaping praise in return on the visitors. Frank Zappa, a 1960s counter-culture hero no longer all the rage at home, found himself feted at every turn in Prague. His zany lyrics appeal to the Czech love of the absurd. Charles and Di drew rave reviews from Hungarians accustomed to less regal visitors. ``We like what we heard, that they help ordinary people a great deal and go among ordinary people,'' said Pal Kontra, a hospital worker in his 50s waiting on a Budapest sidewalk to wave to Princess Diana. ``It's quite a change from the faces we've been accustomed to,'' said Budapest homemaker Juliana Szarka. ``For 45 years, we had to applaud somebody else,'' noted pensioner Ilona Wilnrotter as she cheered the new arrivals. At the other end of the social scale, the East's new leaders are making good use of Western good will and the revived interest of royalty and nobility in their former domains. Prince Karl Schwarzenberg, scion of a family that once owned much of Bohemia, heads a board of foreign advisers appointed by Havel to help drum up Western investment and interest in the new-look Czechoslovakia. Long barred by the Communists for championing human rights in the East from his residence in Vienna, the Czech-speaking prince now has an office in the Prague castle. Otto von Hapsburg, once Crown Prince of Hungary and fluent in its difficult language, is venturing into the eastern reaches of the empire his family lost after World War I. His latest trip was last week, to the first session of the new democratically elected parliament in Budapest. Poland's new Solidarity-led government, determined to kick the Communist habit of following economic plans devised by ill-educated former peasants and workers, enlisted Sachs, a Harvard University economist, to draw up recipes for moving swiftly to a free market economy. Dozens of constitutional lawyers and political consultnts have made the trip East in recent months, advising those unused to democracy on everything from drafting new laws to designing catchy political ads. Jane Fonda, one of many stars drawn to Havel's made-for-Hollywood ascent from political prisoner to president, perhaps provided the most unusual service to date for the fledgling East European democracies. Reportedly fired up by visits to the students who started Czechoslovakia's revolution and to the Civic Forum movement that led it, she invited a Prague activist back to California. There, she initiated him in the ultimate Western custom _ a political fundraiser that garnered Civic Forum $25,000 for its current election campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Bolivia Won't `Stand Alone' in Fighting Drugs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs with meeting ended; picks up 2nd graf pvs, At the...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today assured Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora that ``you and your countrymen will not stand alone'' in fighting cocaine and trying to improve Bolivia's ailing economy. Winding up three hours of talks at the White House, Bush promised he would seek a substantial increase in economic aid for Bolivia next year, beyond the $88 million earmarked for this year. He said Paz, in their private talks, had stressed the importance of Bolivia receiving development assistance. Paz, standing alongside Bush at a farewell ceremony on the South Lawn, pledged full cooperation in anti-drug efforts. ``We are fervent allies and we are ready to give you all of our efforts and all of our cooperation ... to everything that would be of a common interest,'' Paz said. Bush credited Paz with overseeing the destruction of more acres of coca production in the first four months of the year than was eradicated during all of 1989. Saying that Bolivia deserves U.S. help, Bush said, ``You and your countrymen will not stand alone in the fight against cocaine or in the drive for economic development. ``Because we do want what you want and that is economic benefit for your people,'' Bush said. ``And so together we're going to wage a strong fight.'' At the start of their Oval Office meeting, Bush told Paz he had ``great respect for what you have done in your country for the economy and for the fight against narcotics that means so much to us.'' Paz greeted Bush as a friend and said it was fitting they should meet in the White House, because it symbolized the ``cleanliness and the transparency of our friendship and of the relationship between our two countries.'' The visit comes as U.S. officials tout Bolivia's efforts to reduce its role as a major supplier of U.S.-bound cocaine. A U.S. official who briefed reporters on Monday said the United States plans to ``double or triple'' the number of U.S. trainers who are helping Bolivians in the war against coca leaf production. At present, the number of such trainers rotating in and out of Bolivia runs between 20 and 50. Bolivia is the world's second largest producer of coca, but lately Bolivian farmers have been eager to experiment with alternative crops. The prime reason is that the drug crackdown in Colombia, where coca leaves are processed into cocaine, has led to a drastic decline in demand for Bolivian coca. In La Paz, published reports quoted Bolivian officials as saying Paz is unhappy with U.S. aid levels and plans to ask for more during his visit. The Washington Post reported today that he would ask Bush for up to $150 million a year in new aid. The Colombian campaign began last summer with strong U.S. encouragement. Bolivia also has been carrying out what U.S. officials describe as a highly successful eradication program _ 1,000 hectares of coca destroyed in April alone. The U.S. officials, asking not to be identified, said 3,500 hectares have been eliminated thus far this year. Still, more than 50,000 hectares are being used for coca production. Bolivia has been singled out as one of the principal recipients of U.S. military aid under Bush's anti-drug program. The program totaled only $5 million in 1989 but leaped to $35 million this year and is expected to be around the same amount during the next fiscal year. The total 1991 aid package requested by the administration, including economic assistance, is $150 million. Some of the aid is earmarked for a program under which Bolivian farmers who agree to stop growing coca leaves are given a $2,000 per hectare credit for switching to an alternate crop. A hectare is about 2.5 acres. Until the mid-1980s, U.S. relations with Bolivia were not good, a reflection of American displeasure over the alleged involvement of the Bolivian military in drug trafficking during the extended periods when generals ran the country. Paz, an elected civilian, is the first Bolivian to make an official visit in a generation, the U.S. officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Attack Kills 6, Reports Radio Kabul
DOC.TEXT: Several rockets slammed into the Afghan capital of Kabul on Tuesday, killing six people and wounding 13, Radio Kabul reported. The state-run radio broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, claimed the rockets were fired by ``Pakistan-based extremists,'' an apparent reference to U.S.-armed Moslem insurgents. Afghan rebels have been fighting for 12 years to unseat Kabul's Communist-style government. Most rebel factions are based in Pakistan. Five surface-to-surface rockets battered a residential area of Kabul, the radio broadcast said, although it was not possible to independently verify the report. The reported attack was the second in as many days. One person was killed Monday when several rockets hit the city. No one claimed responsibility for either attack. Rebel fighters claim they target only military installations, although they admit their rockets misfire occasionally and hit civilian targets.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Fights to Keep Videotape of Barry Arrest as Evidence
DOC.TEXT: A videotape that federal prosecutors say shows Mayor Marion Barry smoking crack cocaine should be admitted as evidence at the mayor's June trial, the government said Tuesday. The defense wants the tape barred when Barry faces charges of drug possession and perjury. Meanwhile, sources familiar with the investigation said U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens will ask the grand jury to return as many as five additional indictments against the mayor. The new indictments would likely be misdemeanors, the sources said. The grand jury that indicted Barry on Feb. 15 met Tuesday, but adjourned without taking any action. Barry, who already faces five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use, has pleaded innocent to all charges. In papers filed in U.S. District Court, Stephens argued that the videotape of the events before Barry's Jan. 18 arrest was made with the consent of Rasheeda Moore, a government witness who cooperated with the sting operation. Prosecutors say Barry was arrested in Moore's hotel room after he bought crack from an undercover FBI agent and smoked it. Defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy has argued that the videotape should be barred because it was made before other routine methods of surveillance were tried. Stephens said the procedure was valid because Moore authorized her room to be bugged. Stephens also urged Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to deny Mundy's request that four of the misdemeanor possession charges be consolidated, saying each was ``a separate, distinct illegal drug transaction.'' Jackson has set a pre-trial hearing for May 25. Trial has been set for June 4. If Barry is convicted of any of the felony charges, he would be barred from holding office. He has not said whether he will seek a fourth term in November.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Benefits From Special Long-Lasting US Aid Provisions
DOC.TEXT: With its economy in dire straits, Israel came to the United States in 1982 for a favor: Would the U.S. pay a full year's $910 million in economic aid all at once, instead of the usual quarterly installments? The government said yes. Eight years later, the Israeli economy is in better shape, but the unique treatment for Israel's foreign aid remains a part of U.S. law. Not only does Israel still get its aid money up front each year, but since it doesn't need it immediately, it uses the money to buy U.S. Treasury bonds _ lending the United States back its own cash and earning an additional $76.7 million in interest. And to make the immediate payment to Israel each year, the United States borrows the aid funds, at an additional interest cost of up to $70 million. U.S. law is suffused with such special treatment for its Middle Eastern ally, with a value this year of $742 million _ on top of $3 billion in cash foreign aid. And the list of special provisions could grow this week when lawmakers deal with a bill containing $400 million in loan guarantees to build housing for Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel. The Senate's version of the bill would waive some $25 million in administrative fees, along with the usual requirements on eligibility for the housing and auditing of the money. A competing House version is silent on the concessions, and conferees are scheduled to meet to work out the differences. Dozens of provisions already in the law confer special status to Israel in business and financial dealings, trade, military cooperation and global politics. And like the advance aid payments, many remain in effect even though they have outlived their original justifications. In answer, supporters of Israel note its strategic position in the unstable Middle East, its valuable sharing of intelligence information about the region and about global terrorism, and shared political and religious values between the two countries. Much of the aid also is portrayed as a reward for the 1979 Camp David peace accord with Egypt, in which Israel gave up large tracts of land. But a few members of Congress are beginning to raise questions about the aid, particularly in light of new competing demands for scarce aid dollars from emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and Latin America. ``In the long run, I do not think the present high levels of aid are good for Israel or good for the United States,'' said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on the Middle East. ``It should not be looked on as an entitlement program,'' said Hamilton, who has sought to change the foreign aid law to eliminate special-interest provisions dealing not only with Israel but with other recipients as well. Aside from the issue of money availability, Israel's popularity has been strained recently. Many in the United States, including some in the Bush administration, resent what they see as harsh Israeli tactics in quelling a Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The administration is also frustrated by Israel's unwillingness to start talks on Palestinian self rule. Still, the aid to Israel seems secure. That was demonstrated by a test vote last week in the House, when a resolution affirming Jerusalem as the capital of Israel passed 378 to 34. That is the Israeli government's position, in the face of Arab criticism. ``You are not going to see anybody in Congress suggest that the Middle East get less money than the administration asked for,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee. ``Nobody is going to take onto their own shoulders the responsibility for blowing up what is already a highly volatile situation,'' he said. One of Israel's staunchest supporters, Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., said that to make any fundamental change in aid now would not only worsen Israel's internal situation, but would ``send the worst signal of all'' to neighboring Arab states that are privately beginning to accept Israel's right to exist. A spokeswoman for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, which lobbied for many of the special provisions, said continued aid is important because of instability in the region, including terrorism and the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. ``Aid helps to maintain Israel as a strong, stable, staunchly pro-U.S. democratic ally, which is fundamental to America's interests,'' said the spokeswoman, Toby Dershowitz. ``Aid signals that the U.S. is willing to invest in peace in a turbulent but vital region.'' Israel's preferred status dates to President Harry S. Truman's recognition of the newly formed state on May 14, 1948. Since then, the United States has paid out $45.8 billion in direct aid, making it the top recipient in the world. That figure does not include the hundreds of millions of dollars Israel receives in indirect help from the United States, such as the advance aid payment provision or the likely waiver of housing loan guarantee fees. The United States imposes few conditions on Israel in exchange for its aid. Economic assistance, for example, is not tied to specific development projects as it is in other recipient countries. Rather, noted a General Accounting Office report, the money ``serves a budget support and political purpose.''

DOC.HEAD: `Back to Future' Marathon Set for 19 Cities
DOC.TEXT: To commemorate the Memorial Day opening of ``Back to the Future Part III,'' Universal Pictures will present the film and its two predecessors in a special single-ticket triple bill. Universal announced Monday that 19 cities will have the special showing on May 24. ``Back to the Future,'' released in 1985, is one of the 10 most popular titles in Hollywood history. ``Back to the Future Part II'' was a hit last summer. The cities showing the ``Back to the Future'' marathon are New York, Los Angeles, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Houston, Indianapolis, Miami, New Haven, Conn., Orlando, Fla., Sacramento, Calif., San Francisco, San Jose, Calif., Seattle, St. Louis and Washington, D.C. The latest and final installment in the adventures of Michael J. Fox's Marty McFly sees McFly traveling back to the Old West to rearrange history. The film also stars Christopher Lloyd, Mary Steenburgen and Lea Thompson. All three films were co-written by Bob Gale and directed by Robert Zemeckis. ``Back to the Future Part III'' is scheduled to open in about 2,000 screens on May 25.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation into Jesuits' Murders Could Affect Continued Aid
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 9, The State Department, to CORRECT San Jose to San Salvador.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has told Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani that the investigation into the murders of six Jesuits is ``a serious matter'' that could affect U.S. attitudes on continued aid to El Salvador. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today that message was delivered by White House chief of Staff John Sununu. Cristiani and Sununu met Monday in San Jose, Costa Rica, where both were attending the presidential inauguration. Cristiani sought the meeting with Sununu, the spokesman said. Fitzwater said Sununu told Cristiani the killing of the Jesuits ``is a serious matter for the U.S. that must be properly addressed and ...that prosecution of this case would have a significant impact in America.'' Nine Salvadoran military men are accused of murdering the six Jesuit educators last November in San Salvador. Critics say the investigation has come to a virtual standstill due to footdragging on the part of the Salvadoran government. Fitzwater said Sununu told Cristiani there were anti-aid feelings in Congress because of the stalled investigation. When asked whether the adminisitration would back away from its support of new aid for El Salvador, the spokesman said, ``The administration and everyone in America is concerned about the prosecution of the murders and that obviously would have an impact on American attitudes.'' However, he said the administration stands by its request for $90 million in military aid to El Salvador for next year. ``We take him at his word that he's trying to prosecute this to the best of his ability. There are these complicating matters,'' Fitzwater said, alluding to reports that key evidence in the case is missing, including the diary of a Salvadoran commander accused in the case. The State Department said Monday that the U.S. embassy in San Salvador has been asked to confirm whether the diary is indeed missing. Loss of that evidence ``would hurt the efforts to extend the investigation and could impact on the prosecution of those already implicated,'' a State Department spokesman said. The administration has avoided directly criticizing Cristiani, but has stepped up pressure on him to get the investigation back on track.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Warn of Human Needs `Loophole'
DOC.TEXT: Democrats in Congress on Tuesday urged the Bush administration to prevent aid for the ``basic human needs'' of the Chinese people from opening resumed loans to China by the World Bank. ``It would be a very disappointing state of affairs indeed if basic human needs were used as a loophole'' to allow continued repression by the Beijing government, said Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif. Members of the House Banking subcommittee questioned the administration's policy of no longer opposing World Bank loans to China for human needs, such as a $30 million credit approved in February for earthquake reconstruction. Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary John M. Niehuss told the panel some $750 million in World Bank loans to China are still delayed as a result of Beijing's 1989 crackdown on democracy demonstrations, including about $550 million that would meet basic human needs. Niehuss said there was ``increasingly strong pressure ... from some of our major allies to resume'' lending to China, and stressed the United States does not have the voting power to block World Bank loans on its own. He declined to name the allies but reports from Beijing have told of eagerness for resumed lending by Japan and Canada, other major shareholders of the 152-nation World Bank. ``Five hundred and fifty million dollars is a great deal of money,'' said Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., a member of the subcommittee on international development. But ``if the basic human needs standard becomes too broad in interpretation, it will become a farce, a loophole. And that's what we would like to avoid.'' The World Bank executive board plans to review Chinese creditworthiness and commitment to economic reform at the end of May, Niehuss said, and the United States will ask ``whether significant lending is appropriate based on the current economic situation and policies.'' But Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass., charged that the administration was quick to block World Bank loans to smaller countries crushing human rights or resisting economic reform, ``but when they happen to be bigger countries all of a sudden we lose our will.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Suggests Soviets Join Ethiopian Food Airlift
DOC.TEXT: The United States has suggested a joint airlift with the Soviet Union to provide food for Ethiopia, where famine threatens hundreds of thousands of people, a State Department official said Tuesday. The department is awaiting a response from Moscow, said Herman J. Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for Africa. Cohen said Secretary of State James Baker III presented the idea to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at their recent meeting in Bonn, West Germany. The famine stems in part from a civil war between the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam and secessionist rebels in the northern provinces of Tigray and Eritrea. Mengistu has long received military hardware and logistical aid from the Soviet Union, but Cohen said the Soviets' direct involvement in the war appears to be tapering off. Cohen and others told a House Select Committee on Hunger that the food situation in Ethiopia is better than it was two months ago, but that the situation remains precarious. Eritrean rebels captured the strategically located port of Massawa in February and agreed to a truce that would allow the food to pass through the port. The Ethiopians have not agreed to the truce. However, Cohen said the Ethiopians may be ``slowly coming around to see that food relief is a humanitarian'' issue, not a military one. ``Three million people are still at risk,'' said Andrew Natsios of the Agency for International Development. ``Until Massawa is open, none of us can sleep comfortably at night.'' While recent efforts to deliver food through Sudan and the government-controlled port of Asseb have helped, the situation remains grim, Natsios said. ``I am very concerned that the success ... has created the impression that we have met the challenge of moving food into the north,'' he said. ``We have not.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Rejects Soviet Idea of Delaying German Military Decision
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday firmly rejected Moscow's suggestion that settling the military complexities of a united Germany could be delayed until after the countries are merged. ``It would be a fatal development if the external and internal conditions of German unity were not completely clear when the day of German unity comes,'' Kohl told reporters. The chancellor was referring to a suggestion by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that formal German unity could occur before ``external'' aspects of the merger are cleared up. Such ``external'' aspects would include those issues with international implications, such as the military stance of a united Germany. West Germany currently belongs to NATO, while East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The Soviets oppose a united Germany in NATO. During reunification talks Saturday in Bonn, Shevardnadze also suggested a ``transition period'' during which the four wartime allies would retain postwar rights, even after German unity. The United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain jointly control many matters in the former German capital of Berlin. They also have special rights outside Berlin, many involving the status of the troops they maintain in what once were their postwar military occupation zones. Shevardnadze's remarks initially triggered jubilation among some West German politicians, who sensed the pace of unification was picking up. But by Tuesday that had changed to concern about delaying settlement of important issues related to German unification. There had even been talk among some politicians of canceling West Germany's Dec. 2 national election in favor of elections for a united Germany's parliament. But Kohl said Tuesday ``without question'' the Dec. 2 elections will still occur. Vernon A. Walters, the U.S. ambassador to West Germany, said Tuesday that Washington supports a united Germany with unrestricted sovereignty and without special rights for any of the World War II allied victors. ``A united Germany should have full control over its entire state territory, without any sort of new discriminating limitations of German sovereignty,'' Walters told a Frankfurt meeting of West German newspaper and broadcast susbscribers to The Associated Press. While the United States has promised it won't stand in the way of full sovereignty for a united Germany, it has also made clear it wants a merged Germany to be part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Kohl has also vowed that a united Germany will be a NATO member. Moscow has suggested as a compromise that a united Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact until still-undefined European ``security structures'' are created. Both Washington and Bonn have said they are prepared to allow Soviet troops to remain on what is now East German territory for an interim period, but both have rejected a dual-bloc membership. East Germany also reacted negatively to Shevardnadze's weekend proposals. Government officials in East Berlin are ``skeptical'' of delaying a settlement on the international issues involved in unification, said the East German news agency ADN. Kohl said his government is hoping that the six-nation talks on unification, which began Saturday, will conclude before the end of this fall. He said the international aspects of German unification will likely be discussed at the U.S.-Soviet summit at the end of this month, and at a special NATO summit in London in July.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard University Announces 1990-91 Class of Nieman Fellows
DOC.TEXT: The 12 journalists selected as Nieman Fellows at Harvard University this fall were announced Tuesday. The fellowship was established in 1938 with a gift from Agnes Wahl Nieman and gives journalists in mid-career a chance to study at the school for one year. Foreign journalists to be named as Niemans will be announced later, the school said. The American fellows in the 53rd Nieman class are: _ Jim Amoss, 42, associate editor, The Times-Picayune in New Orleans. _ Betty Winston Baye, 44, assistant editor, Neighborhoods, The Courier-Journal, Louisville, Ky. _ John Carlson, 41, reporter-Iowa City bureau chief, The Des Moines Register, Iowa. _ Tim Giago, 55, publisher, the Lakota Times, Rapid City, S.D. _ Joel Greenberg, 34, West Bank reporter, Jerusalem Post. _ Marcia Slacum Greene, 37, reporter, The Washington Post. _ Dale Mezzacappa, 39, education writer, The Philadelphia Inquirer. _ Kevin Noblet, 37, Santiago, Chile, bureau chief, The Associated Press. _ Ana Puga, 29, Latin American correspondent, Houston Chronicle. _ Barbara Ross, 41, reporter, New York Daily News. _ Charles Shepard, 35, investigative reporter, The Charlotte Observer, North Carolina. _ Katherine Skiba, 33, reporter, The Milwaukee Journal.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller, Governor's Ex-Wife Highlight West Virginia Primary Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 7:30 p.m. EDT; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV sought nomination to a second term Tuesday, and former first lady Dee Caperton competed in a Democratic primary for state treasurer. Also on the Democratic ballot was a comeback effort by Ken Hechler, the secretary of state who sought his old congressional job back. He challenged Rep. Nick Joe Rahall. In the Senate race, Democrats Paul Nuchims and Ken Thompson were attempting to unseat Rockefeller, heir to one of America's largest fortunes. Ms. Caperton, 47, the former wife of Gov. Gaston Caperton, ran against Larrie Bailey, a former treasurer, Marie Prezioso, a Charleston investment banker and one of Bailey's former employees, and Eugene Knotts, a Wood County assessor.

Nuchims, who bills himself as a ``conceptual artist,'' spent less than $500 on his campaign. Thompson proved elusive to reporters during the campaign. The Republican Senate nominee is John Yoder, 39, a Harpers Ferry lawyer and former aide to retired Chief Supreme Court Justice Warren Berger. Ms. Caperton, a former beauty queen, said she was qualified to run the state's finances and pointed to her management of her own $5 million portfolio in addition to an estimated $11 million she reportedly received from her divorce settlement with the governor last fall. The new treasurer will finish the final two years of former Treasurer A. James Manchin's term. Manchin resigned last July to avoid a Senate trial after being impeached for his part in losses to the state investment fund. The governor appointed state Sen. Thomas Loehr as treasurer, but Loehr decided not to run for the job. The lone GOP candidate for treasurer is Elvin F. Martin, a certified public accountant. Hechler, 75, was making his third bid to recapture the U.S. House seat he gave up in 1976 after 18 years in a failed gubernatorial bid against Rockefeller.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Wilson County may not seem like the fast lane but police say it did to actress Michelle Pfeiffer. She was clocked at 90 mph Sunday afternoon on U.S. 264 _ which has a speed limit of 55 mph, said Sgt. W.M. Gay of the state Highway Patrol. The Oscar nominee, who played a sultry chanteuse in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys'' and a French temptress in ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' had to appear before a magistrate Sunday and post bail of $100. She was in Wilson for the filming of ``Love Field,'' the story of a woman's bus trip from Dallas to Washington to attend President Kennedy's funeral. It takes it name from the Dallas airport where the president landed on the morning of the assassination. Gay said Ms. Pfeiffer was driving a rented red Mitsubishi when trooper R.C. Smith turned on his blue lights. Wilson is in central North Carolina, east of Raleigh.

Actor and filmmaker Robby Benson says he'll give up his teaching job at the University of South Carolina if the community doesn't appreciate his efforts. Criticism of Benson's $63,630 annual salary and his use of USC students to film a movie surfaced about the time of reports on school President James B. Holderman's lavish spending habits during the last 1{ years at the school. ``If people think that I'm doing a disservice rather than a service here, then definitely I want to take the effort _ because it's a sincere effort _ elsewhere,'' said Benson, who has been artist-in-residence at the school's College of Humanities and Social Sciences since 1988. Benson said Monday he felt compelled to speak out since questions were raised about his filming here of the newly released movie, ``Modern Love,'' with the use of some of his students. He said he was particularly disturbed by a recent letter to a newspaper criticizing him. Eighty-nine South Carolinians were hired to work on the movie, or four of five of all those hired, Benson said. Of those jobs, 39 were given to USC students and employees, he said. Benson lives here with his wife, singer Karla DeVito, and their daughter, Lyric.

Sylvester Stallone says the characters Rocky and Rambo he has made famous are very different from his own nature. ``I am afraid of being identified with Rambo or Rocky,'' Stallone said Monday. But that's not slowing sequel production. A new installment of Rocky, the fifth, is in the works and a fourth Rambo film is planned, Stallone said. Stallone unveiled his plans while attending a television awards ceremony. Stallone said the next installment of Rambo will deal with ecology ``which is the most important problem at the moment.''

Actress Victoria Principal filed suit against CBS, claiming the network breached a contract concerning a made-for-television movie in which she starred. She alleges CBS failed to honor a promise to pay her production company $300,000 if the network decided not to make a weekly series out of the movie ``Sparks.'' ``CBS breached the `Sparks' agreement by failing and refusing to pay the liquidation fee despite its decision not to order any episodes of the series,'' according to the lawsuit filed Monday in Los Angeles Superior Court by attorney Ralph Loeb. Susan Tick, publicity chief for CBS in Los Angeles, said she was not aware of the lawsuit and could not comment about it. The TV movie, ``Sparks: The Price of Passion,'' aired on Feb. 25 and featured Miss Principal as the mayor of Albuquerque, N.M., at odds with real estate developers over growth of the city.

Actor Billy Barty was ordered to pay $428 to a television show writer who claimed he wasn't paid for creating several comedy sketches. Burbank Municipal Court Commissioner Dennis H. Shanklin on Monday granted the award to Warren Taylor for sketches he wrote for ``Short Ribbs,'' which aired last year on KDOC-TV in Anaheim and is no longer in production. Taylor already was paid $800 for his work on the show, including a satirical skit that featured Barty as a crooked judge. In a similar small claims dispute two months ago, Barty was ordered to pay $1,300 to William Winckler, another writer on the show that featured midgits and dwarfs. Taylor, Winckler and a third writer, Len Udes, told Shanklin they were guaranteed $100 for every script they wrote, even if they collaborated on sketches for the show. Barty, who has starred in such films as ``Rumpelstiltskin'' and ``Willow'' argued the writers didn't identify which scripts they authored and said it was impossible to determine who should be paid.

DOC.HEAD: Bullfighting Arenas to be Built in Oman
DOC.TEXT: A string of bullfighting arenas is being built along Oman's northern coast to encourage the traditional sport, which differs from the Western version in that bulls do all the fighting. One arena is under construction at al-Miraisi in the Barka region, about 55 miles from Muscat. Another will be at Sohar, 144 miles northwest of Muscat. Barka is famous for its desert bullfighting tradition, and hundreds of people turn out to watch the spectacle on weekends and holidays. In Omani bullfighting, there is no human participation. A referee selects a pair of animals from among the scores of bulls brought to the ring by farmers. The two bulls are pitted against each other across a sandy arena with no barriers. Fans watch the action sitting on gravel piled around the ring. In a test of strength often lasting only a few mintues, the beasts lock horns until one is forced to the ground. The victor emerges with a higher price tag. ``The bulls do not get hurt,'' said Ali Hamdan, a fan of the sport. ``The only thing damaged usually is the losing owner's pride.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Hopeful on Weapons Pact Before Summit
DOC.TEXT: The United States hopes negotiations for a chemical weapons pact with the Soviet Union can be concluded before the summit between President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev, the State Department said Tuesday. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said a range of options were being discussed, but she refused to comment on a Washington Times report that the administration has offered to halt production of chemical weapons by a specific date as part of a compromise. The negotiations are aimed at reaching a bilateral agreement to reduce chemical weapons stocks in anticipation of a global ban on the arms. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will discuss the issue next week in Moscow. The May 16-18 talks will lay the groundwork for Gorbachev's five-day visit to Washington, which begins May 30. The Washington Times said in Tuesday editions that Baker has offered to halt U.S. production of new gas weapons by a specified date. That would be a shift from the previous position of ending the manufacture only after a separate multinational treaty banning such weapons went into effect.

DOC.HEAD: Stamps by Phone, Anytime
DOC.TEXT: Americans can now order postage stamps by phone _ all day, every day. The U.S. Postal Service announced Tuesday that it has set up a nationwide stamps-by-phone system, operating 24 hours every day. Customers can buy stamps using major credit cards by calling 1-800-782-6724, (1-800-STAMP-24). The agency tested the concept between 1987 and 1989. It has now hired the Dallas-based firm, TMI Corp., to handle the operation. The system is expected to be most useful to small businesses, but can also be important to the elderly, the handicapped, and others for whom a trip to the post office can be difficult or time-consuming. Stamps will be sold at face value plus a $3 service charge, per order, and mailed to the buyer. They will be available in sheets of 50, rolls of 100 or 500 and booklets. The service also will sell postal cards and stamped envelopes.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Allegedly Tried to Remove Beaten Youths from Wife's House
DOC.TEXT: While Nelson Mandela was in prison, he sent a lawyer to his wife's house to remove three men who had been abducted there and beaten, a witness testified Tuesday in a murder trial. Mandela's wife, Winnie, has not been charged in the case, which went to trial one week ago. But two alleged victims have testified that she was the first to beat them, using her fists and a whip. Members of her bodyguard later joined in, according to testimony Monday and Tuesday. James ``Stompie'' Seipei, a 14-year-old activist, was also abducted and beaten with the men, the witnesses have said. He was found dead in a field in January 1989 with a stab wound in the neck. Jerry Richardson, one of Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards who lived at her home in the black township of Soweto, is accused of murdering Seipei. He also is charged with four counts of kidnapping, five counts of assault and one of attempted murder. One of the alleged beating victims, 20-year-old Barend Mono, testified Tuesday. He said that it was Mrs. Mandela who began the beatings after the four were abducted in December 1988 from a Methodist Church home. Mrs. Mandela said last year she was not at home when the alleged beatings took place, but she said the abductions were justified because the men were engaged in homosexual activity with a minister running the church home. The Methodist Church says it has investigated and cleared the minister of the allegations. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, has made no comment on the case since he was freed in February from his life prison term for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the white government. Mono said Mrs. Mandela's lawyer, Krish Naidoo, came to the house where the men were held one day. Richardson instructed the men to say they were not abducted but chose to leave the church home because of homosexual activity, Mono told the court. The next day, Mandela's lawyer, Ismail Ayob, visited the house and said ``he was told by Nelson Mandela to come and fetch us,'' Mono testified. He testified that eventually the three men were freed when they were taken to the medical offices of Soweto community leader Nthato Motlana. Richardson had taken the teen-ager, Seipei, away earlier, he said. Leaders of major anti-apartheid organizations and Soweto community leaders accused Mrs. Mandela early last year of ``complicity in the abductions and assault'' of the four, including Seipei. They also said her bodyguards had waged a ``reign of terror'' in Soweto, a black township outside Johannesburg. The anti-apartheid leaders called on the black community to shun Mrs. Mandela. But a few months later, she began appearing at rallies with other leaders. Since Mandela was freed, she has regularly appeared at his side during public events. On Monday, another alleged victim, Kenneth Kgase, 30, testified that Mrs. Mandela assaulted all four of the captives, punching and whipping them and pulling their hair. In addition to Richardson, eight other bodyguards for Mrs. Mandela face separate trials on lesser charges stemming from the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Watch Your Language: City Seeks Neuter Form for `Manhole'
DOC.TEXT: A manhole by any other name could be a ``person entry,'' ``exit port'' or ``personhole,'' contestants say in a tongue-in-cheek, city-sponsored bid to find the neuter form for the scruffy iron fixture. Prompted by the sensitivity of the city council's female majority to feminist issues, the Public Works Department called for suggestions to replace the familiar appellation. Responses _ much to the astonishment of city officials _ have come in from all over the world. The winning synonym for Sacramento's 26,379 circular lids is expected to be announced Wednesday night at a council meeting. ``The calls came in from everywhere,'' said Christine Olsen, a city spokeswoman. ``But it's not really a formal contest. It's just that some of our Public Works people had ideas for a change and it got blown out of proportion.'' She said she had no estimate of the number of entries. Many people are calling with ``lewd and offensive suggestions,'' and others angrily want to know about ``the women who are taking over the city council,'' said a city receptionist. An employee at the city sewer department, listed in the telephone directory under ``manhole covers,'' said the controversy ``has really had no effect here. It's all over at the council.'' Interest in the issue rose after city civil engineer Randy Witt suggested at a council meeting last month that the city hold a for-fun Manhole Terminology Change Contest to spur interest on the engineering staff. One newspaper headline said the city was ``Blowing the lid off sexist `manholes,''' while another proclaimed that a ```Tempest in a Manhole' sweeps city.'' A radio station in Hamilton, New Zealand _ Sacramento's sister city _ held a renaming contest in which ``sewer viewer'' captured the top prize. Other New Zealand nomenclature included ``peoplehole,'' ``peephole'' and ``underground service access (USA) hole.'' The nine-member city council has had a five-member female majority since last fall's elections, including Mayor Anne Rudin, who lauded the Public Works Department for ``keeping up with contemporary standards.'' But Olsen said the panel did not order any changes in the terminology used by the department. ``We're all just kind of amazed,'' Olsen said. ``We've really been getting a lot of calls, and they seem to think that the female majority on the city council ordered the change to non-sexist language. That's not true. Actually, somebody saw the term `manhole covers' in an internal report and said, `Hey, maybe it's time we made this change,' just for fun, and ask around and see if anybody has any ideas on on what to call them,'' Olsen said. For years, Olsen added, many city workers have referred to the 2-foot-diameter lids as ``utility covers.'' ``For decades, the Public Works Department employees were largely male, so the department has been making a concerted effort to have women participate in some of the non-traditional jobs,'' she said. ``It's not insignificant,'' said Deborah Franklin, a fund-raising coordinator for the California chapter of the National Organization for Women. ``We feel language is of importance. They are not holes for men, they are holes for sewers. ``But if you suggest a change, immediately there is this uproar, people saying, `Oh, those women. There they go again.' Some people are threatened in something as simple as changing the names of manhole covers.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: At 30-something, Mona doesn't want to stay in at night. She won't let just anyone do her pedicure. And since she weighs 4 to 5 tons, nobody at the El Paso Zoo will argue with her. ``When an elephant wants to go somewhere, I usually don't get in the way,'' said Lea Hutchinson, the zoo administrator and veterinarian. Mona, the zoo's senior resident, has always been headstrong. But she's become particularly obstinate in recent weeks and Hutchinson wants to bring Mona's former keeper, Rudy Romero, out of retirement to retrain her. ``He's the one she grew up with,'' Hutchinson said. ``She's had other keepers, but never developed the kind of rapport she had with him. He walks in the gate of the zoo, and she knows he's here _ it's instant recognition.'' Romero, 62, started working with Mona when she was shoulder-high in the 1950s. He stayed on with the zoo until his retirement in 1983. Romero said that when he dropped by the zoo two weeks ago, Mona became excited and began trumpeting as soon as he was on the grounds. ``She remembered me right away,'' he said. ``It's kind of embarrassing the way she acts.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Old spaghetti may sound cold and clammy, but two restaurant chains thought it was hot enough to fight over it in court. The Old Spaghetti Warehouse, based in suburban Garland, has agreed to drop the word ``old'' from its corporate moniker and will pay $400,000 to settle litigation brought by an ``older'' competitor of nearly the same name. About three years ago, the owner of a Portland, Ore.-based chain called the Old Spaghetti Factory filed two lawsuits against the Texas chain. The owner alleged that the Old Spaghetti Warehouse had stolen a recipe using mytzithra cheese _ a Greek cheese made from goat's milk _ and copied the use of trolleys as booths. On Monday, Old Spaghetti Warehouse announced it would scrap ``old'' from the signs on its stores and delete any mention of mytzithra cheese from its menu. But the company, which denies taking its competitor's sauce recipe, will continue to be able to use the special cheese. ``We are pleased that the litigation is finally behind us,'' Robert Hawke, president of the 15-store, $28 million Texas company said. ``This removes a cloud over our future and will allow us to proceed with our franchise plans.'' Old Spaghetti Warehouse opened its first restaurant in Dallas in 1972 and has since opened 14 other company-owned stores in eight states. The company went public in 1985. The Old Spaghetti Factory chain was established in 1970 and has 28 stores. The lawsuits settled Monday were filed in federal court in Atlanta, the only market in which both companies have stores.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Denies He Bowed to Pressure for Softer Terms
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh denied Tuesday that he has abandoned support for tougher penalties for white-collar criminals and promised strong recommendations on the subject after it receives more study. ``I stand second to none in pressing for nothing less than the maximum penalties that we can accommodate under the law'' for corporate offenders, Thornburgh told the Senate Judiciary Committee. He said toughened sentencing guidelines that were withdrawn recently remain under study and could be reissued later. Thornburgh has made cracking down on ``crime in the suites'' a theme of his rule at the Justice Department. But last month his aides acknowledged that he withdrew the proposed sentencing guidelines at White House request.
