The administration reportedly acted after an intense lobbying campaign by defense contractors, oil companies and others that envisioned the proposals as something resembling a ``corporate death penalty'' for a number of firms. The guidelines produced by the U.S. Sentencing Commission were revealed last fall. They would require stiff mandatory fines on companies convicted of polluting, fraud and other white-collar offenses. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said that when the guidelines were withdrawn he was ``concerned that the Department of Justice has surrendered so easily to pressure from the White House and big business to go soft on white-collar crime.'' Thornburgh said the department does ``not repudiate the proposed corporate sentencing guidelines,'' but that the recommendations had not been given adequate review. He said they are ``now being given that review'' with an eye toward eventually issuing something similar. He said there was no deadline for issuing guidelines on corporate penalties but promised that he would make his recommendations public at some point. ``I favor strong penalties against white-collar criminals,'' Thornburgh said. Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, however, complained that white-collar offenders are too often staying out of jail. ``Your prosecutors are wheeling and dealing constantly without anyone going to the slammer,'' he said. But Thornburgh said: ``I think you'd have a hard time explaining that to Woody Lemons.'' Lemons, the former chairman of a Texas savings and loan, was recently sentenced to 30 years in prison, the stiffest sentence so far in the probe of massive fraud in the thrift industry. Metzenbaum persisted, however, urging the attorney general to impress government disapproval of corporate fraud on ``the country club set.'' Thornburgh promised to get Metzenbaum a list of white-collar offenders who have been sentenced to prison. ``I will hope to disabuse you of what is obviously a mistaken view,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Narrow Field to Oppose Helms; Centenarian Makes Bid for Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 7:30 p.m. EDT: matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina Democrats on Tuesday narrowed a crowded field of candidates hoping to take on Sen. Jesse Helms, and a 100-year-old eye doctor made a bid for Congress in a Republican primary. Helms, the outspoken conservative who is seeking a fourth term, had token primary opposition from Charlotte businessman George Wimbish and retired New Bern contractor L.C. Nixon. In the six-way Democratic primary, Harvey Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, emerged as the leader in late polls but needed to win more than 40 percent of the vote to avoid a June 5 runoff. The three other top contenders were John Ingram, a former state insurance commissioner; Michael Easley, district attorney in Brunswick County; and R.P. ``Bo'' Thomas, a former state senator. In a 3rd District congressional race, Henry Merritt Stenhouse, a Goldsboro ophthalmologist who still keeps office hours three days a week, ran on a ``less government'' platform against businessman Don Davis, 60, and oil heater repairman Ken Brosman, 39.

The winner of the 3rd District primary will take on Democratic Rep. Martin Lancaster. No Republican has been elected from that district since Reconstruction. In the closing days of the Senate campaign, Gantt appealed for party unity and said a divisive primary runoff would hurt chances of unseating Helms in November. No black candidate has been nominated for the Senate in North Carolina since 1914, when popular election of senators began in the state. Easley and Thomas sniped at each other in television ads and in public, each demanding apologies for what they said was distortion of their records. Thomas was under fire from Easley and other Democrats for vulgar remarks made about women and past state leaders. Thomas said Easley plea-bargained drug cases instead of prosecuting them.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Abandoned Son at Rest Stop Sentenced to 40 Years for Assault
DOC.TEXT: A man who abandoned his emaciated, battered 7-year-old son at a freeway rest stop has been sentenced to 40 years in prison for four counts of second-degree assault involving the boy. Sadism ``fits more aptly than any other term I can think of'' to describe the behavior of Edward Donald Tuinman, 30, said Yakima County Superior Court Judge Bruce Hanson. The judge reserved judgment Monday on whether the sentence would run concurrently with a 10-year term for abandonment in Idaho. The earlier sentence stemmed from the discovery of Ed ``Little Eddy'' Tuinman, emaciated, battered and burned by cigarettes, at a rest stop on Interstate 84 near Boise on Jan. 4, 1989. Authorities said the boy, who is mute and retarded, was abandoned while Tuinman, his wife and their other children were moving from Washington state to Arizona. Tuinman's wife, Deborah, was not charged because authorities said she also had been abused by him. Defense lawyer Rick Hoffman said the exceptional sentence, 10 years on each count to run consecutively, would be appealed. The standard sentencing range for each assault count is 43 to 53 months, Hoffman said. Deputy prosecutor Steve Keller recommended the 40-year sentence for charges covering four types of abuse _ shooting the boy with BBs from an air gun, holding a hunting knife to the boy and poking the tip into his feet and legs, choking and hitting the boy, and burning him with cigarettes. Tuinman pleaded guilty and asked to be forgiven by the court, his family and Eddy. ``It hurts down inside me,'' he sobbed. ``I can't believe it happened.'' He hung his head while the judge viewed a videotape of a cabin the Tuinmans occupied in nearby Buena. The tape showed blood stains, dents where the child was thrown against plasterboard, BBs embedded in the wall and cords used to tie the boy to his bed at night. ``We don't often see cases where children are repeatedly and consistently and ... sadistically abused in the manner Ed Junior was,'' said sheriff's detective Rose Roberson. ``Our outlook of the human race has been jaded just a bit by what we've seen.'' Other children in the family were forced to join in beating their brother, Roberson said. The elder Tuinman was abused as a child and may have suffered brain damage from three head injuries, so he ``did not have all things working properly for him,'' Hoffman said. Since being placed with a family in the Boise area, the little boy has gained weight and is walking and feeding himself, Roberson said.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Finances Improve, But Deficit Still Expected
DOC.TEXT: Postal service finances have perked up a bit, but an official said Tuesday that a loss of up to $1.5 billion is likely by the end of the fiscal year. The U.S. Postal Service said it had net income of $370 million in the first half of fiscal 1990, which began Sept. 1. That's $289 million better than had been expected for the period. Postmaster General Anthony Frank told the agency's board of governors that an increase in the productivity of postal workers and lower than expected transportation costs led to the savings. Mail volume also increased slightly, bringing in more money. Senior Assistant Postmaster General Comer S. Coppie said a cost-of-living increase for postal workers was due this month and that other costs were rising. Overall, Coppie said, the agency is likely to finish the fiscal year with a loss of between $1.3 billion and $1.5 billion. The postal service already has filed for a rate increase, including a boost to 30 cents for first-class stamps. If approved, that's likely to take effect early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Musawi Expresses Fears For Hostages If Missing Iranians Are Dead
With AM-Britain-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The reputed mentor of a group holding two U.S. hostages said Tuesday he fears that a Western captive could be executed if rumors are true that four long-missing Iranians are dead. ``If the death of the four Iranians is ascertained, that will definitely affect the hostage issue,'' said Hussein Musawi, a Shiite Moslem fundamentalist. ``One of the kidnap groups might react by murdering a hostage.'' ``I don't have any concrete information on that,'' Musawi said by telephone from his headquarters in the east Lebanon city of Baalbek. ``But they have done it before. What's there to stop them from doing it again?'' The four Iranians were seized by right-wing Lebanese Forces militiamen north of Beirut in July 1982. They are widely believed to have been killed either in civil-war shelling or by their captors. In a separate interview with the Communist-run Voice of the People radio station, Musawi did not specifically rule out further releases. But he said he did not expect the hostage issue to be settled this year because the United States has made no conciliatory gesture following the release of two Americans last month. ``This issue has turned into a very complicated one because of the negative U.S. stand ... The hostage issue will be frozen for a certain period of time,'' he added. Musawi heads Islamic Amal, a pro-Syrian faction in the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for Shiite extremists holding most of the 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. The hostages include six Americans. The captive held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Musawi also is the reputed mentor of the pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the group that freed U.S. educator Robert Polhill on April 22 after 39 months in captivity. The move was followed by the Organization of Islamic Dawn's April 30 release of another American, Frank Reed, after 43 months as a hostage. The kidnappers and Iranian officials have asked that the fate of the four Iranians be determined. President Bush has said the United States could try to help account for them, and he publicy thanked Iran and Syria for helping secure the freedom of Polhill and Reed. Musawi said those who wield influence over the hostage-holders, especially Iran, will resume their efforts when ``positive indications appear from the West.'' But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated Monday that the United States will make no deals for the release of the hostages. ``You cannot let terrorists think they can steal American citizens and beat them up and just steal more and more and more and more,'' he said. Musawi told the AP he believes no more hostages will be freed before Israel and its militia allies in Lebanon free some 400 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners, another key demand made by the kidnappers and Tehran. ``And I think they won't,'' he said. ``If the Americans want to solve the hostage issue, they should solve the problem of the Moslems and oppressed held by Israel and its surrogates.'' There has been growing pressure on Israel to free its Arab detainees to help win freedom for the hostages. Israel says it is not opposed to a swap in principle, but that such an exchange should include three Israeli servicemen captured in Lebanon in 1986 and believed held by radical Shiites linked to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia. Gen. Antoine Lahad, commander of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army, said Monday he will not release any of the 300 Shiite prisoners his group holds unless efforts are made to free militiamen and Israeli soldiers held by Shiite groups.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Tehran World's Most Expensive City
DOC.TEXT: Tehran is the world's most expensive city in dollar terms, costing nearly twice as much as it does to live in New York, according to a survey of 83 cities published Tuesday. Despite high levels of inflation, the continual decline of many currencies in Latin American countries has ensured they remain financially attractive to expatriates. Quito, the capital of Ecuador, ranks as the cheapest city, according to the survey published by a private Geneva-based research and consultancy organization, Corporate Resources Group. Taking New York as the base of 100 and using the dollar exchange rate of April 9, the survey showed Tehran has a cost-of-living index of 192. It said an overvalued currency was the main reason the Iranian capital proved so expensive. By contrast, the steady decline of the Japanese yen since the middle of last year helped bring down the costs of living in Japan in comparison with other countries, the survey said. It said Tokyo, frequently the most expensive city in previous international surveys, was the second-most-expensive city with a cost-of-living index of 150. Osaka stands at 133. The Gabon capital, Libreville in West Africa, has an index of 143, it said. The Norwegian capital Oslo, with an index of 135, ranks top of the European league and fifth overall. Helsinki, in Finland, is rated at 130, it said. It said the world's ``bargain locations'' were in North and South America. Only Toronto, with an index of 101, is more expensive in dollar terms than New York. Other ratings included Chicago at 96; Washington, D.C., 95; Los Angeles, 94; San Francisco and Boston, 93; Houston and Miami, 92; and Cleveland, 88. It said Quito had an index of 40, the lowest of the cities surveyed. The study was based on a basket of 151 products including food consumed at home, alcohol, tobacco, clothing, transport, sports and leisure, but not housing. It is aimed at helping international companies determine cost-of-living differentials for their expatriate employees.

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Band on Peace Mission to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: After performing ``God Bless America'' before enthusiastic Muscovites outside a hotel near the Kremlin, members of an American Legion band were looking forward Tuesday to marching through Red Square itself. But Dorothy Hill, 74, the leader of the band from Waltham, Mass., said the musicians have already accomplished their main mission _ promoting peace, understanding and togetherness between the Soviet and American people. Mrs. Hill single-handedly spent three years working her way through the Soviet bureaucracy to bring the 70-member, all-male band to Moscow as a ``peace move'' between the superpowers. On Wednesday, the Joseph P. Hill American Legion Band, named after Mrs. Hill's late husband, will become the first American band to march in Moscow's annual Victory Day parade, commemorating the defeat of Nazi Germany. The band's members range in age from 17 to 82, and include veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam. The band began its 10-day trip on Saturday, and already there have been some emotional moments, particularly two impromptu concerts Sunday and Monday outside the Hotel Rossiya across from the Kremlin. The band played ``God Bless America,'' the U.S. and Soviet national anthems, and other patriotic tunes. And soon, curious Soviets _ including some bemedaled World War II veterans _ were clapping, dancing and singing along. ``It was one of the most emotional times of my life,'' said Mrs. Hill, speaking in her thick Boston accent. ``The people there watching and listening were shedding tears, we were shedding tears. ``It proved my point right there _ that reaction of your people and our people _ that peace is possible,'' Mrs. Hill told a news conference at the headquarters of the Soviet Peace Committee. ``People. Togetherness. And we've seen it the last couple of nights.'' Mrs. Hill, a World War II Coast Guard veteran, began planning the trip after having a dream ``that we should never see another war.'' With no Soviet contacts, she used charm and persistence, staying up through the night to dial telephone operators in Moscow to find someone to contact. Finally, one operator put her in touch with the Soviet Peace Committee, ``and once we got them, the show was on the road,'' she said. At a ceremony Tuesday, Soviet Peace Committee Chairman Genrik Borovik praised Mrs. Hill as a ``remarkable, wonderful woman.'' ``I'm happy that she broke American bureaucracy and Soviet bureaucracy,'' said Borovik, who as a television commentator often criticized U.S. foreign policy before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power. Borovik called the band's presence unusual, because of the American Legion's reputation as a right-wing organization, ``which was always, let me say, not the best friend of the Soviet Union.'' John ``Jake'' Comer of Quincy, Mass., a past American Legion national commander, said the tears ``just came out of my eyes'' as the band played ``God Bless America'' and he held the Soviet and American flags during the impromptu concerts. ``I've been to 18 countries ..., had an audience with the pope, visited the Oval Office with Presidents Reagan, Bush,'' he said. ``I've done everything, but nothing as moving as that.'' Mrs. Hill said she didn't always have warm feelings toward the Soviet Union, recalling the Cold War. ``I was as bad as everbody was in those days. `The Communists _ what are they doing to us?' and so forth,'' she said. Now, however, ``We love 'em. We love 'em. We had the opportunity as people to prove it.''

DOC.HEAD: Lottery Looking into Sales of Tickets in Third-World Countries
DOC.TEXT: The Florida Lottery wants to be the nation's first to market its games overseas by selling tickets in the Caribbean and Central and South America. Officials from the Caribbean, Central America and South America have asked Florida to open ticket outlets in their countries and let them keep some of the profits. Lottery officials declined to identify the nations involved. Those foreign officials also hope to stop ticket bootlegging that makes money for foreign scalpers but nothing for the governments. In exchange, Florida would get an enormous base of new lottery players, bigger jackpots and ultimately more money for its public schools. On Monday, state lawmakers OK'd the lottery's study of proposed international sales. Federal law bars selling lottery tickets by mail or importing tickets from other countries, but is vague on selling U.S. tickets overseas and doesn't address Florida's ticket-selling over telephone lines through computers. New Hampshire also is negotiating with an unidentified country in the Far East for lottery sales, said that state's lottery director, James Wimpsatt.

DOC.HEAD: More New Mothers Getting Paid Leave; Fewer Quitting Jobs
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The share of first-time mothers receiving paid maternity leave has nearly tripled in recent years, while only half as many have quit their jobs, the Census Bureau said Tuesday. More than 60 percent of new mothers quit working from 1961 through 1965, while only 28 percent did so from 1981 through 1985. On the other hand, almost half received paid maternity leave in the second survey period, up from 16 percent in the first. While the study, ``Work and Family Patterns of American Women,'' includes data only through 1985, it does show historical trends starting in the 1960s. The report was released as Congress is considering a bill that would require employers with 50 or more workers to offer unpaid time off, with job and benefit protection, for the care of newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children, as well as to deal with personal health problems or ill spouses or parents. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush urges companies to provide paid parental leaves voluntarily but is unwilling to force them to do it. The report comes just a day after the National Center for Health Statistics reported that the increase in births in recent years continued into 1989 with 4,021,000 births, up from 3,913,000 a year earlier. Births have risen steadily in recent years as the giant Baby Boom generation passed through its prime childbearing years. Although this has resulted in an increase in the actual number of births, birth rates remain well below those of the Baby Boom era of the 1950s and early 1960s. The Census report found that younger women are more likely to quit their jobs or to be fired when they become pregnant than are older mothers. From the ages of 18 to 22, 43 percent of new mothers left work, while only 20 percent of those having a first child at age 25 and over left their jobs. Overall, 63 percent of women having their first children from 1961 to 1965 did not return to work, the study said. That fell to 51 percent in the 1971-75 period and 28 percent from 1981 through 1985. Those receiving paid maternity or sick leave when having their first baby totaled only 16 percent in the early 1960s. By the first half of the 1970s, it was 23 percent and, in the first half of the 1980s, 47 percent. The share of women receiving unpaid leave _ meaning they were promised a job on their return from maternity leave _ rose from 14 percent in the early 1060s to 21 percent in the 1970s, then slipped to 20 percent in the 1980s. The share fired from their jobs was nearly constant, 5.0 percent in the early 1960s and 4.6 percent in the later periods. In the early 1960s, 2.7 percent of first-time mothers said they never stopped working. That dipped to 1.7 percent in the early 1970s but rose to 2.8 percent in the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Won't Charge Actor, File Against Friend Instead
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have refused to charge Todd Bridges with possession of drugs and decided instead to file felony drug charges against a friend who was arrested with the star of ``Diff'rent Strokes.'' Bridges, 24, who has had numerous run-ins with the law, and Steve Mallen, 36, were arrested early Saturday after police allegedly found 2 ounces of cocaine in their car. ``We are rejecting the case against (Bridges) because, after evaluation, it's rather clear there is insufficient evidence to show he had any control of the substance,'' Deputy District Attorney Norm Shapiro said Tuesday. Mallen was charged with possession of cocaine for sale. Bridges was jailed until Tuesday in lieu of $25,000 bail. Bridges faces retrial July 30 on a charge stemming from the February 1989 wounding of Kenneth ``Tex'' Clay, who was shot eight times at a crack house. A jury last year acquitted Bridges of attempted murder and attempted involuntary manslaughter in the case. Jurors deadlocked on assault with a deadly weapon and the charge was refiled. Bridges has pleaded innocent. A conviction could bring six years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Heir Who Wanted to Give Money to LaRouche Says He's Competent
DOC.TEXT: A du Pont family heir who has been declared incompetent to handle his financial affairs testified Tuesday his family has ``used the court to control me'' because of his donations to Lyndon LaRouche. Lewis du Pont Smith, 33, is trying to overturn a court order that limits his spending from a $10 million trust set up by his grandfather to $15,000 a month. He said the order ``offends my dignity.'' Smith, an independent candidate for Congress from suburban Philadelphia running on the extremist political platform of LaRouche, testified he is ``very upset, even angry, that my family has continued this action for so long.'' Smith's parents went to court at the end of 1985 after their son gave LaRouche $212,000. Since then, LaRouche has been convicted of conspiracy, mail fraud and income tax charges and is serving a 15-year federal prison sentence. ``I don't think my family has respected my right to disagree with them,'' Smith said. Chester County Common Pleas Judge Lawrence Wood, in declaring Smith incompetent, relied on psychiatrists' opinions. More psychiatric testimony is expected during the hearing. ``Foolishness is not mental illness,'' said Dr. Richard Lonsdorf, a psychiatrist brought in by Smith's attorney. If a person has a minimal capacity to understand what he is doing, he shouldn't be declared incompetent, he said. Smith testified he bought a house in Leesburg, Va., and sold it for a $40,000 profit. He also said he bought a $15,000 Cadillac and leased a home in New Hampshire where two years ago he ran unsuccessfully for Congress. He said he has worked closely with the Wilmington (Del.) Trust Co., trustee for his estate, and persuaded it to make changes in the investments. He said he has never been influenced by LaRouche, that LaRouche has never asked him for money, and that he works for organizations connected with LaRouche because he believes in what he is doing.

DOC.HEAD: Soggy Fields Hurt Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Rain and sodden fields are hampering many farmers as they try to plant corn and other crops this spring, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. Nationally, corn planting was reported 50 percent complete, trailing normal progress by three percentage points. Cotton planting was 39 percent completed, down five points from the usual pace for this time. But corn producers in Iowa, Nebraska and Ohio were able to make up for earlier delays, planting about one-third of their acreage during the week of April 30-May 6. ``Rain slowed planting in Kentucky and Missouri,'' the report said. ``Planting lagged 41 points behind the 76 percent average in Missouri. Plant ing also lagged behind normal in Illinois and Colorado.'' Cotton farmers were held up by rain and wet fields in Arkansas, Missouri, Tennessee and Texas. However, cotton planting ``progressed rapidly'' in Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi and the Carolinas, and was nearly finished in Arizona and California, the report said. Winter wheat was generally in ``good to fair'' condition, with 23 percent of the crop inn place, six percentage points behind the five-year average. Planting of spring wheat for this year's harvest was 75 percent completed, 10 points ahead of the normal pace, the report said. Seeding was complete in South Dakota and almost finished in Idaho. Planting was 62 percent completed in North Dakota, three percentage points ahead of normal.

DOC.HEAD: Moammar Gadhafi Says He Considered Missile Attack on U.S. Base
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi said he considered attacking a U.S. military base on the Greek island of Crete with missiles if American planes had resumed bombing Libya in 1986, a newspaper said. The idea was dropped because of close Libyan-Greek relations and the danger to civilians, Gadhafi was quoted as telling an international peace conference Saturday. Gadhafi gave a ``fiery'' 35-minute speech via satellite to the International Conference for Peace in the Mediterranean in Ierapetra on Crete last weekend, the newspaper Eleftherotypia said Monday. The United States maintains two bases on the Mediterranean island _ an air force communications station near Iraklion, eastern Crete, and a supply depot for the 6th Fleet at Suda Bay. The Navy base on the western tip of Crete, about 500 miles from the Libyan capital of Tripoli, is within range of Libyan missiles, military analysts said. Former socialist Premier Andreas Papandreou, who governed Greece from 1981-89, maintained close ties with Third World leaders and had praised Gadhafi for his anti-American rhetoric. In his speech, Gadhafi said U.S. intentions to close the naval communications station near the Greek capital were a welcome move. ``The fact that the (U.S.) base at Nea Makri is closing gladdens us especially and we hope the same will happen with the U.S. base at Lampedusa in Italy,'' he said. Lampedusa, which houses a U.S. Coast Guard base, came under Libyan rocket attack in April 1986 after U.S. planes bombed Tripoli, but the rockets fell into the sea far short of their mark. As part of a worldwide austerity plan, the United States has announced it will close the U.S. Air Force base adjacent to Athens International Airport. The closing of the two bases will leave the two on Crete and 20 small units in various parts of Greece. The three-day conference was attended mostly by leftist-oriented participants who called for a denuclearized Mediterranean and an end to foreign bases and fleets in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo to Mate Again Rare Tiger That Strangled Cub
DOC.TEXT: Zoo officials say they will again mate a rare Sumatran tiger that apparently accidentally strangled her 2-month-old cub while zoo visitors watched in horror. ``It even occurs in the wild. The mother doesn't usually kill the cub intentionally _ just through accident or neglect,'' said Ronald Tilson, the Minnesota Zoo's director of conservation, who studies Asian tigers. The cub, named Shere-Kahn, died Sunday at the Lowry Park Zoo after the mother, Tuka, apparently picked him up wrong. Her jaws nearly surrounded the cub's neck, cutting off his air supply. An autopsy showed the cub died because his windpipe was blocked, said David Thompson, zoo director. Shere-Kahn was Tuka's first offspring and zoo personnel attributed the death to her lack of experience as a mother. Shere-Kahn was the first Sumatran tiger born in captivity in the United States this year. Now, 32 of the rare orange and black striped animals live in captivity in this country. An estimated 600 to 800 exist in the wild, only on the Indonesian island of Sumatra. Zoo officials said they would breed the 11-year-old Tuka again, but they're considering hand-raising the next litter. Witnesses told curator Lex Salibsury that Tuka and Shere-Kahn were frolicking in a moat when the 150-pound adult cat grabbed her 16-pound cub by the throat, then dragged it through the water. Zoo keepers lured Tuka into a cage and grabbed the unconscious cub, and tried unsuccessfully to revive it with mouth-to-mouth resusciation. ``It was very sad. People were just sobbing,'' said Michael Hoad, who was visiting the park when it happened. The incident prompted zoo keepers to start monitoring another new mother, Kariz, a Persian leopard who gave birth to three cubs on March 6.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnap, Shooting in $1 Robbery
DOC.TEXT: The assistant manager of a movie complex was kidnapped and shot in the throat, leaving him paralyzed from the chest down, in a robbery that police said netted $1. Oscar Zarruck, 19, of San Francisco, was left to die on the shore of the Oakland Estuary about five miles from the movie complex, where he was discovered Saturday afternoon by the Coast Guard. Police said Charles Bell, 19, of Oakland, was arrested the next day, driving Zarruck's car and wearing a movie promotion button taken from Zarruck's shirt. Police Sgt. Bill Gillespie said Bell plotted the robbery for weeks, anticipating a large haul. He spent Friday night in the theater and surprised Zarruck when he arrived for work Saturday morning, ordering him to open the safe, Gillespie said. Zarruck stalled until other employees arrived, but Bell forced him, with a hidden gun, to get into his own car and drive around Oakland, the sergeant said. The other employees did not know what was happening. Bell shot Zarruck and took his wallet, which contained $1, Gillespie said.

DOC.HEAD: `Garfield' Creator Wins Cartoonist of the Year Award
DOC.TEXT: Jim Davis, creator of fat cat ``Garfield,'' has been named Cartoonist of the Year for 1990 by the National Cartoonists Society. After six years as a nominee, Davis, of Albany, Ind., won the ``Reuben'' _ the cartoon world's equivalent of the Oscar _ for the cynical, overfed Garfield, featured on television specials and many novelty items as well as newspaper cartoons. The award was presented aboard the MS Sunward II in the Caribbean during the weekend, said Selma Gore, spokeswoman for Norwegian Cruise Lines. The award, a 16-inch bronze statue designed by the late cartoonist Rube Goldberg, founder of the 44-year-old society, shows eight people tangled together around an inkstand. Awards for excellence also were given in five categories. Johnny Hart of Endicott, N.Y., who draws ``B.C.'' and ``Wizard of Id,'' was honored for best newspaper strips and panels. The newspaper editorial and sports award went to Pat Oliphant of Falls Church, Va. ``Mad Magazine'' cartoonist Sergio Aragones, of Ojai, Calif., won the society's magazine and book award. Chuck Jones of Laguna Beach, Calif., won the electronic media award for his work on Bugs Bunny and other animated cartoons, and Roy Doty of New York City was honored in the commercial category for his advertisements. Mell Lazarus, creator of the nationally syndicated ``Miss Peach'' and ``Momma'' comic strips, is president of the 450-member organization.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Removes Welcome Mat for Goddess of Democracy Radio Ship
DOC.TEXT: The government pulled up the welcome mat Tuesday for the Goddess of Democracy radio ship, saying it would not be allowed to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China from Taiwanese waters. Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming urged the radio ship to observe international laws that ban unauthorized broadcasts. ``The government has not and will not become involved in the operation'' of the radio ship, Shaw said. Shaw made his remarks after top government officials met to discuss how to handle the touchy problems raised by the radio ship. The Chinese government has warned that any help provided by Taiwan for the ship would be considered ``an open provocation.'' The ship's presence could jeopardize a recent thaw in the historically chilly relations between Taipei and the Communist government in Beijing. Tensions across the 100-mile Taiwan Strait have eased, marked by increased trade and travel between the two countries in recent years. The ship's spokesman, Xu Tianfang, said the Goddess of Democracy was scheduled to arrive in the northern Taiwanese port of Keelung on Friday to refuel and take on provisions before heading to international waters to begin broadcasts. Xu, deputy secretary of the Paris-based Boat for China Foundation, the ship's main organizer, said the ship's agent would apply for a port entry permit. The government has not received any applications from the ship, Shaw said. ``If that happens, we will make proper decisions based on humanitarianism, international practices and domestic laws,'' he said, without specifying whether the ship would be allowed into Keelung. The Communications Ministry has said the ship would be allowed to dock in Keelung unless the government issues instructions to the contrary. Wang Shih-hsiung, an independent legislator, said he has organized a flotilla of Taiwanese fishing boats to form a ``boat wall'' to escort the radio ship into Keelung. Xu said the ship's sponsors have dropped plans to have leading exiled Chinese dissidents board the ship in Keelung to make the broadcasts. But he would not rule out the possibility that at least one prominent dissident, Yan Jiaqi, might join in the broadcasts if he chooses to do so. Yan, chairman of the Federation for a Democratic China, a Paris-based Chinese dissident organization, arrived in Taipei Monday for a weeklong visit. Yan, a professor and former member of China's top think tank, fled China last June following the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The 1,200-ton Goddess of Democracy sailed from France March 17 for international waters off the Chinese coast, from where it plans to broadcast music, news and pro-democracy messages to the mainland. The Chinese government has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the planned broadcasts. The Goddess of Democracy took on provisions last week in Singapore, but Hong Kong refused to allow the ship to enter its waters. Officials in the British crown colony are sensitive about relations with China, which is scheduled to take over Hong Kong in 1997. The ship is sponsored by a coalition of press organizations headed by the French news magazine Actuel, with the cooperation of the Federation for a Democratic China. The Goddess of Democracy is named after the statue erected by pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square last May. It was destroyed during the June 4 military crackdown that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of demonstrators dead. The Nationalist Chinese government fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces in mainland China.

DOC.HEAD: Press Institute to Urge Stepped-Up Efforts to Free Newsmen
With AM-Britain-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said Tuesday it would ask the United States, Britain and U.N. organizations to step up efforts to get journalists held hostage in Lebanon freed. Institute director Peter Gallinor noted in a speech that five years had elapsed since the kidnapping of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, and British journalist John McCarthy. ``We will send messages from this assembly to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, UNESCO and the governments of the United States and Britain asking them to increase their efforts in getting (the hostages) released,'' Gallinor said. He said there was hope U.N. organizations might achieve what others have not been able to do. Two American hostages were recently set free, but six other Americans are still in captivity along with 10 other Westerners. The hostage held longest is Anderson, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Who Scrawled `Hitler is Back' Sentenced to Learn About Holocaust
DOC.TEXT: Three young men who spray-painted ``Hitler is Back'' on a high school wall were ordered Tuesday to learn about the Holocaust by a judge who noted it was the anniversary of V-E Day. Westchester County Judge John Carey ordered the men to return to court June 25 for a quiz on their history lesson. He also sentenced them to weekly tours at a hospice for the terminally ill. ``I don't wish to punish any of you,'' Carey said. ``I wish to educate you.'' Michael Morano, 18, Michael Venturino, 18, and Neville Anthony Mason, 20, all of Ardsley, were charged with spray-painting swastikas and writing the words ``Jew,'' and ``Hitler is Back'' on the walls of Ardsley High School on June 20, 1989. Morano, who pleaded guilty to a felony criminal mischief charge, admitted doing the actual spray-painting. A high school dropout, he told the judge he learned about Hitler and the war from television and movies. Venturino, who drove the three to the school, and Mason, who provided the paint, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor criminal mischief charges. Before sentencing the young men, Carey told them that Tuesday was the 45th anniversary of V-E Day, the day World War II ended in Europe, saying the sentencing occurs ``in an historical context.'' He then read about the treatment of Jews by Adolf Hitler _ from William Shirer's ``The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich,'' James Michener's ``Poland,'' and a pamphlet about a concentration camp in southern Poland the judge visited five years ago. ``I wish as part of your sentence, I could sentence you to go to the Majdanek concentration camp,'' the judge said. ``It's a terrible place.'' As he went through the pamphlet, discussing the horrors of the gas chambers and brutal experiments on small children, he added several times, ``This is what your Hitler did.'' Carey, whose brother was killed in the war, read in the Michener book that in one day alone, 18,000 Jews were killed at a single concentration camp. ``That's more than the population of Ardsley killed in one day,'' Carey said of the New York City suburb. ``What had they done? What were they guilty of?'' If the three fail to pass the quiz, the judge could give them the exam again later or consider it a violation of probation and resentence them. Dr. Evan Bellin of the American Jewish Congress' committee on anti-Semitism for Westchester County, said ``Justice was served'' by the judge's sensitivity.

DOC.HEAD: Top Soviet Official Presses Call for Naval Arms Talks
LaserPhotos WX11, WX12
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's chief arms control adviser said Tuesday that continued U.S. opposition to naval arms talks could damage superpower ties. ``We think that this policy is unjust and aimed at undermining security and gaining military superiority over the Soviet Union,'' Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev said of the American refusal to negotiate over a ban on short-range nuclear weapons in the superpower navies. Akhromeyev made the comments in his first appearance before a Senate Armed Services subcommittee and his second trip before a congressional panel in less than a year. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's principal arms control adviser and a member of the Supreme Soviet, Akhromeyev said U.S. opposition to naval arms talks could jeopardize significant cuts in armed forces and weapons down the road. ``We consider that sooner or later if we do not want to stop the negotiations on reduction of nuclear and conventional arms, naval forces cuts negotiations are unavoidable,'' said Akhromeyev. He also said the issue of whether the Soviets should give up their SS-24 nuclear missile if the United States gives up the multiple-warhead MX missile on railroad cars should be addressed in talks once a treaty to reduce strategic weapons by 50 percent is signed. ``It would be good if experts of our countries in this issue ... really studied this prior to getting into those future negotiations. That issue is already on the agenda of the day,'' Akhromeyev said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the projection forces and regional defense subcommittee, invited Akhromeyev to appear before the panel to discuss naval arms reductions. In a new wrinkle to U.S.-Soviet relations, Akhromeyev said his country would be willing to include land-based Soviet aircraft used to protect its naval forces in talks on banning the navies' short-range nuclear weapons. ``We think that nuclear weapons of all kinds of systems at sea should be the subject of negotiations,'' Akhromeyev said. ``In other words, the nuclear systems which are deployed on aircraft carriers, on submarines and on aviation.'' At the Malta summit last December, Gorbachev pressed President Bush on such talks and on limiting submarine-launched cruised missiles. Bush rejected Gorbachev's call for naval arms talks, arguing that the United States is a naval power. And members of the Senate subcommittee raised serious doubts about imposing limitations on U.S. naval forces. ``I am opposed to limiting the qualitative or quantitative naval forces,'' said Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the committee and a former secretary of the Navy. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said any reduction in the United States' access to sea lanes is ``tantamount to losing oxygen to our lungs,'' and added the arms control agenda is already overloaded. On another issue, Akhromeyev said the Soviet Union did not violate the U.S.-Soviet agreement in December 1987 to eliminate short-range nuclear weapons even though some SS-23s have been found in East Germany, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. Akhromeyev said the weapons, without nuclear warheads, were sold to those nations prior to the treaty and so they do not violate the pact.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Baltics Bjt
Lithuania Cuts Meat Shipments to Soviets; Will Try Trading Instead
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania is cutting meat shipments to Soviet ministries by 10 percent in hopes of using the scarce food to barter with Soviet factories for oil and other supplies, a government spokesman said Tuesday. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has cut off oil and most natural gas shipments to Lithuania in an attempt to force it to rescind laws backing its March 11 declaration of independence. The breakaway republic, which expects to run out of oil by next week, already has laid off 12,500 people for lack of fuel. Lithuania will sell some of the meat to its own people and use the rest for barter trade, said Aidas Palubinskas of the government press office. Meat is in extremely short supply in the Soviet Union, making it a valuable item for trade to workers in factories that produce items Lithuania needs. The Soviet government newspaper Izvestia promptly accused Lithuania of cutting milk and meat supplies to strike back against the Soviet sanctions. ``Lithuania has decided to retaliate,'' Izvestia said. ``It has nothing to lose. Meat shops in Vilnius now are selling only cow's hoofs and pig's heads.'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis denied that vengeance played any part in the decision. He cited the Soviet failure to ship feed grain to the republic. Lithuania's anti-blockade committee on Tuesday ordered preparation of a list of other strategic goods that may be pulled from export in the future, the press office said. The Soviet Union has virtually halted shipments of wood and certain plastics since the blockade began last month, the press office said. Metal supplies have been cut by half, paper shipments by 25 percent. At a news conference Tuesday evening, Landsbergis also advised Lithuanians not to be bothered by Soviet soldiers marching through the city in Wednesday's parade to mark the end of World War II. ``The best way to react is to completely ignore the parade, shut your windows and even shut the shutters,'' he said, according to Rita Dapkus of the government's press office. Landsbergis added that World War II is continuing in a sense because the Soviet Union is refusing to give up the territory it occupied then. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are all trying to regain the independence they had until Soviet troops occupied their lands. They were forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Heir to Submachine-Gun Fortune Accused of Having Contact with Kids
DOC.TEXT: A convicted child molester and heir to the Thompson submachine-gun fortune was charged with violating probation for allegedly offering a child a $100 to go with him, police said. Russell Ambler Maguire, 65, whose fortune was once estimated at $100 million, was held without bond at the Pinellas County Jail since his arrest Friday, following an investigation. The probe began when a woman summoned police and said she overheard Maguire talking to three children in a grocery store parking lot. ``She recognized him and heard him offer one of them $100 to go with him,'' said Pinellas Sheriff's Sgt. Greg Tita. ``She also heard him say, `You're a real good-looking boy.''' The children, girls 4 and 12 and an 11-year-old boy, had no physical contact with Maguire in the April 25 incident, Tita said. It was the second time Maguire was charged with probation violation since his conviction in 1986 for fondling an 8-year-old girl at his Clearwater Beach condominium. After the first conviction, Maguire was sentenced to 10 years probation with psychiatric counseling. He was prohibited from having unsupervised contact with children as part of his probation, court records show. The first probation violation, for leaving the county and state several times, brought him a 15-year prison sentence. The judge ordered him to serve 30 months and to remain on probation for 12{ years.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Nobel Peace Prize Winner Elie Wiesel's Tribute at Holocaust Site
With AM-Jewish Congress, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is the full English text of a tribute by Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel to Holocaust victims that was read Tuesday at a ceremony at the site in Berlin where Nazi leaders planned the ``Final Solution.'' Wiesel's statement was read in Hebrew, English and German. The English version was read by Heather Harris, 23, of San Francisco who now lives in Jerusalem, where she heads the World Union of Jewish Students. Wiesel, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp, did not attend the ceremony.

Wannsee _ a warning, Wannsee _ the end _ the final solution. The target: Jews, all Jews, everywhere. Only Jews. What does a Jew today feel in this place, marked by evil and malediction? Fear and trembling, anger _ incommensurate anger, helplessness and grief _ infinite grief. Cry? One must not cry here! If you begin, you will not stop. How many tears does one shed for thousands of communities? How long does one lament the death of tens of thousands, of hundreds of thousands of inoccent, abandoned, forsaken victims? If only the walls could speak, If only the trees and clouds could testify. We need to hear them, for most German men and women, in the past, refused to speak, refuse to remember. It is here that, in a businesslike atmosphere of banality and efficiency, twelve German high government officials, in the name of their criminal leadership on behalf of their nation, condemned the entire Jewish people to death and oblivion: teachers and their pupils, brides and grooms, intellectuals and workers, rabbis and their disciples, young revolutionaries and old dreamers of Zion. All were doomed. Simply, solely as Jews. At that time, children were still playing in the streets of Sighet and Saloniki. Others were still begging for bread in the ghettos of Warsaw and Bialystok. Still others were praying for the coming of the Messiah in the hidden bunkers and attics of Vilna and Lublin. Here they were already dead and they did not know it. It is Jewish history that the Germans tried to annihilate here. It is Jewish memory that Germany tried to eradicate here, forever. That is what a Jew remembers in Wannsee. But Wannsee also means for us Jews that memory is stronger than its enemies. It means that Jewish hope has vanquished fear. It means that when we Jews visit and listen to the somber and dark echoes at Wannsee, we aim at preventing future generations from inheriting our past as their future.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Prices for Less Milk in 1989, Says Government
DOC.TEXT: Milk production dropped last year but higher prices boosted sales receipts of dairy farmers to a record level, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Overall milk output in 1989 declined 1 percent to about 144.3 billion pounds from a record of 145.2 billion pounds in 1988, the report said. But cash receipts from milk sales rose 10 percent to $19.4 billion, eclipsing the old record of $18.5 billion set in 1983. Milk production has been rising this year in response to higher prices and may edge up by 1 percent to 3 percent in 1990, possibly to another record level, according to USDA forecasters. The annual report showed that actual marketings of milk in 1989 totaled about 142.1 billion pounds, down from 142.9 billion in 1988. About 2.1 billion pounds were used on farms where produced, including milk fed to calves and used by dairy producer families. About 141.1 billion pounds of the milk marketed was sold to plants and dealers for more than $19.1 billion, an average of $13.56 per 100 pounds, the report said. More than 497 million quarts (about two pounds each) were sold directly to consumers for an average of 53.9 cents per quart. Those receipts totaled $267.9 million. The average number of milk cows in 1989 was reported at 10,127,000 head, down from 10,262,000 the year before. But average milk production rose to 14,244 pounds per cow last year from 14,145 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Hussein: Iraq Can Make Devices British Seized as Nuclear Triggers
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein displayed several locally-made electric devices Tuesday, which he said were similar to components seized by British customs agents who claimed they were triggers for nuclear weapons. Saddam held up the devices before about 2,000 Arabs attending a Baghdad rally, as he accused the West of trying to hinder Iraq's technical development. He refuted charges by Britain and the United States that Iraq was trying to obtain electric triggering devices for use in a nuclear weapons program. The devices seized by customs officers in March at London's Heathrow Airport had been manufactured in the United States. He also held up what he described as a U.S.-made condenser, similar to those seized in Britain. He said Iraq had earlier been able to import some of the same devices produced by an American company. ``The ones they seized were not all what crossed,'' he said without further elaboration. Saddam reiterated Iraq's denial that the devices were nuclear triggers. He said they were electrical condensers intended for use by the University of Technology. At the rally, Saddam held up two electric devices, which he said were made by Iraqi technicians at the Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization. ``Only five days after the Americans said they (seized them) our young men in the military industry managed to produce two condensers,'' Saddam told the rally, called to express solidarity with Iraq. ``If the British or the Americans want to import some of these devices which are labeled `Made in Iraq' they can negotiate a deal with the Ministry of Industry and Military Industrialization,'' he said to cheers from the Arab delegates. Saddam said the technicians, without being asked, produced two samples in two different government enterprises. The Iraqi leader also accused the West of conducting a campaign to hinder what he described as Iraq's technical and scientific advancement. He said the West ``chases Iraq wherever it purchased equipment in order to prevent it, and consequently the Arab nation, from looking to the future.'' Saddam said Iraq will not abandon its technical research despite pressure from the West. ``Technical and scientific advancement is the new title of patriotism. So how can an honest and patriotic man retract from such a course?'' he said. Saddam said the campaign against Iraq started in March after his government hanged a London-based Iranian journalist, Farzod Bazoft, accused of spying for Israel and Britain. He accused the West of threatening Iraq because of its support for Arab nationalism. Iraq has denied any intention of developing nuclear weapons, but Saddam created a furor by saying Iraq would unleash its chemical arsenal against Israel in case of an Israeli attack. At the time of the joint U.S.-British customs sting operation in March, Iraq said the devices described by U.S. prosecutors as nuclear warhead detonation capacitors allegedly being smuggled to Baghdad were intended for a non-nuclear university laser project. The 40 capacitors seized in March were labeled as air conditioning units in an effort to get around U.S. bans on export of militarily sensitive technology, U.S. officials said. Three people were arrested in England in connection with the case after an 18-month investigation by U.S. and British customs officials. Capacitors can be used to create the first electrical spark in the chain reaction that leads to a nuclear explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Developments at a Glance
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW _ Here is a look at developments Tuesday in the Baltic republics.

ESTONIA _ Estonian lawmakers dropped the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from their republic's name to make it simply ``The Republic of Estonia'' and adopted Estonia's old national flag in place of the red banner of socialism. Without formally declaring independence, the Parliament reinstituted several paragraphs from its 1938 constitution, including a passage saying Estonia is ``an independent republic, with the supreme state power vested in the people.'' The parliament said the steps were intended as a show of solidarity with Lithuania and Latvia. It also adopted a resolution proclaiming Baltic solidarity and congratulating Latvia on declaring independence.

LATVIA _ A group of legislators who oppose independence asked Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev not to impose sanctions on Latvia, saying this would hurt the large number of Latvian citizens loyal to the Kremlin. The group called for a referendum on independence. A labor group threatened a protest strike to support the anti-independence drive.

LITHUANIA _ The government of the breakaway republic announced it was cutting meat shipments to Soviet ministries by 10 percent in hopes of using the scarce food to barter with Soviet factories for oil and other supplies. Gorbachev cut off oil and most natural gas shipments to Lithuania in an attempt to force it to rescind laws backing its March 11 declaration of independence. The Soviet government newspaper Izvestia accused Lithuania of cutting milk and meat supplies to strike back against the Soviet sanctions, but Lithuanian government leaders denied the move was retaliatory.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out Aboard Oil Tanker, 1 Killed, 6 Injured
DOC.TEXT: One man was killed and two others were reported missing after fire broke out aboard an oil tanker as it was unloading fuel, officials said Tuesday. Another six people were injured as an explosion ripped through the crew quarters the Filipino-registered Annette II Monday evening, starting the blaze, local fire officials said. They said the vessel was carrying 83,000 barrels of jet fuel, gasoline, diesel fuel and kerosene with a total value of more than $2 million. The cargo was being unloaded at the Esso installation at the Montego Freeport pier. There was no immediate word on any fuel spill into the Caribbean coastal waters. Montego Bay, on Jamaica's northern shore, is in the heart of the island's main tourist zone. Three fireboats, including two from the U.S. Coast Guard, were battling the blaze. The ship was towed out to sea. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known. The dead man was identified as a Jamaican stevedore, Herman Stephenson.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Worried at High-Tech Weapons in Terrorist Hands
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement officials worry about high-tech weapons falling into terrorist hands, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Tuesday. Thornburg hailed the weekend arrest in Florida of two Colombians charged with trying to send Stinger ground-to-air missiles to drug lord Pablo Escobar, but said the ``success of efforts to frustrate the use of this technology is ... frightening in itself.'' The Stinger incident underscored the interest of terrorists in the use of highly sophisticated weaponry, he said. ``This raises the level of concern in law enforcement at all levels,'' Thornburgh told a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. ``We hope to be able to frustrate these events before some catastrophe takes place.'' On another matter, Thornburgh told the committee that the government is providing around-the-clock protection for 11th Circuit judges as a result of the Dec. 16 package-bomb slaying of federal Judge Robert S. Vance. Thornburgh said $7.5 million was made available in a recently approved spending bill to provide U.S. marshal to protect the judges. The circuit includes Florida, Georgia and Alabama. Two days after Vance was killed in his home outside Birmingham, Ala., a similar bomb killed Robert Robinson, a Savannah, Ga., city councilman and civil rights lawyer. Thornburgh said ``substantial progress'' was being made on the investigation into Vance's death.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Spanish Defense Officials Meet
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Spanish Defense Minister Rafael de la Cruz met with his American counterpart Tuesday in what a Pentagon spokesman described as a cordial discussion of arms cooperation. Spokesman Bob Hall said de la Cruz had previously met with Deputy Secretary of Defense Donald J. Atwood during a visit by Atwood to Spain. Hall described the meeting with Atwood here as ``very cordial, friendly'' and said the Spaniard was also meeting with officials of the armed services. He said de la Cruz and Atwood ``went through a variety of subjects about arms cooperation, the situation in Europe and changing defense outlooks.'' Spain, the United States and Italy are joining to develop an updated version of the AV-8 Navy Harrier plane to be known as the Harrier II Plus. The program, said to be budgeted at an estimated $485 million, will develop the next generation of the famed vertical-lifting jets for use by the navies of the three countries. Spain has 11 older models and will purchase 18 new ones; the U.S. Navy expects to acquire 33 new Harriers; Italy, 17. The identically equipped new Navy jets, Spanish Defense Ministry sources said, will provide the three navies with greater compatibility in Mediterranean maneuvers and defense.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Criticize Bush For Ignoring Hiking Trail Needs
DOC.TEXT: More than $100 million President Bush wants for building logging roads in national forests should be spent on trails and recreational facilities that deteriorated in the 1980s, environmentalists said on Monday. ``The U.S. Forest Service wants to spend 10 times as much money on logging roads as it does on trails. That's an unacceptable imbalance that reflects the misplaced priorities of an agency with a `timber-first' approach to forest management,'' said Jay Watson, The Wilderness Society's forest specialist. ``This fundamental imbalance has resulted in a logging road network that would go around the world more than eight times while at the same time our trail system has been allowed to fall into a state of disrepair,'' he said. The National Wildlife Federation, Sierra Club National Audubon Society and Amercian Hiking Society joined in the call to redirect road contstruction funds into trail maintenance and construction, wildlife management and recreation programs. Susan Henley, executive director of the American Hiking Society, said trail usage has doubled since 1970. ``There's an increased recognition by the American public that trails are are good, healthfull recreation. The demand is exceeding the supply,'' she said. Fran Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation said the Forest Service estimates a benefit-to-cost ratio of nearly $10 for every $1 spent on fish and wildlife management, while the ratio for logging and roads is less than 2-to-1. ``If you want to increase the economic values, you would increase fish and wildlife spending, not logging and roading,'' she said. Hunt said the roads the Forest Service builds to help harvest timber would also displace wildlife, degrade habitats and cause erosion that results in tremendous loss of fishing resources. ``In some areas, the damage to the fisheries exceeds the value of the timber harvested,'' she said. Watson said Bush's budget proposals represent cuts from levels Congress approved last year of 17 percent for trail construction and 55 percent for maintenance of recreation facilities, including campgrounds, boat ramps and visitor centers. The coaltion said Bush should be held accountable for the spending blueprint even though much of the deterioration occured over the past 10 years under the Reagan administration. Watson said 360,000 miles of logging roads currently cover the national forest system's 156 units and another 33,000 miles are planned in the next decade. About 100,000 miles of trails cover the same area, but there is nearly a $200 million backlog of trail reconstruction and maintenance in national forests, he said. The environmental groups said if $100 million were diverted from the roads fund toward other programs there still would be $200 million left for logging road construction, enough to build and reconstruct more than 5,700 miles of roads on national forests.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Letter Carriers Honored
DOC.TEXT: A New York mail carrier who went into a burning building and helped save four people was honored for heroism Tuesday. James P. Kinney of New Rochelle was named national hero of the year by the National Association of Letter Carriers. Kinney, 34, helped an infant, the child's grandmother and two disabled people escape the building, the union said. After the fire was brought under control, Kinney resumed delivering mail on his route. Ernest Smith of Edison, N.J., was named the group's humanitarian of the year for volunteering time to encourage education and offer guidance to young people. In addition to the national honors, the union cited: _Robert D. Pope of Statesville, N.C., for coming to the aid of a truck accident victim who had been thrown from his vehicle and onto a power line. _John D. Mockenstrum of Toledo, Ohio, who rescued two young children from a locked car that was on fire. _Lawrence J. Gerigk of San Francisco, who intervened in an assault, capturing the suspect and holding him for authorities.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Ticket Tax Increase Not Needed
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration can modernize the air traffic control system without raising ticket taxes to pay for it, the congressional audit agency said Tuesday. ``Increased modernization costs and expanded use of the (aviation) trust fund to pay for operations expenses ... do not necessarily require an immediate increase in user fees,'' John W. Hill Jr. of the General Accounting Office told a House panel. The Bush administration has proposed raising ticket taxes from 8 percent to 10 percent to finance the modernization. The administration has also proposed that the Aviation Trust Fund pay a greater share of the operating costs of the Federal Aviation Administration. The trust fund was set up in 1970 to pay for the equipment costs of maintaining safety in the skies. The fund is financed chiefly through ticket taxes, but also through fees on cargo and aviation fuel. Despite its name, it is a bookkeeping account which must be spent according to annual congressional directives. Hill testified before the Public Works and Transportation investigations subcommittee. The subcommittee is trying to determine if excess balances are building up and if so why Congress is not spending them. Since 1971, the Aviation Trust Fund account has been used for a share of FAA personnel and administrative costs. The administration has proposed raising the share from the current 58 percent to 85 percent, arguing that private commercial and general aviation account for 85 percent of the FAA's costs. Hill said the FAA could afford to use the trust fund to cover 75 percent of operating costs, plus pay for modernization, with no increase in fees. Hill referred to the National Airspace System Plan, which was initiated in 1981 to replace computer, radar and communication equipment. Major delays and add-ons have caused the estimated cost to rise from $12 billion to $16 billion. ``FAA now acknowledges that modernization will need continuous funding and not end in 1991 as its preliminary cost-benefit analysis for the NAS Plan indicated,'' Hill said. By being used to purchase government bonds that are not counted in the deficit, the Aviation and Highway trust funds just mask the true size of the deficit instead of being spent to clear congested airways and repair highways, critics say. Critics also say other similar trust funds elsewhere in the government are similarly used. The Transportation Department projects a cash balance for the aviation fund of close to $15 billion by the end of September. It was expected to take in $5.1 billion during the current fiscal year, about two-thirds of which is revenue from the ticket tax and a quarter is interest earnings, but pay out only $3.5 billion. Similarly, the department projects a cash balance of $18 billion in the highway fund by the end of September this year, of which $7 billion is in a mass transportation account. Hill said a real surplus of $3.4 billion will exist for new highway spending when the five-year spending authority for the highway fund ends in 1991. The highway fund is financed through a 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax and 15-cent-a-gallon diesel tax was well as other fees. The highway money goes to states, which administer projects. Hill said states can afford much more highway spending than Congress now allows with its spending ceilings. He pointed out that in 1989, Congress set a ceiling of $12 billion even though $22 billion was available. Kate L. Moore, assistant transportation secretary for budget and programs, said the highway fund is highly leveraged, with the $11 billion balance supporting $33 in spending commitments through the addition of state funds. She said much of the balance in the funds represents accumulated interest owed by the Treasury, since the surplus is invested in government securities. Spending down too much money would add to the deficit, she said.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Investigators Point Finger Of Blame At Congress
DOC.TEXT: Two veteran HUD investigators told Congress Tuesday that it ignored warnings and must bear part of the blame for scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Paul A. Adams, inspector general at HUD, and his retired predecessor, Charles L. Dempsey, told a Senate panel examining the HUD scandals that they repeatedly pointed to program abuses in semi-annual reports that went unnoticed by Congress. ``I never received so much as a phone call,'' said Dempsey, who retired as inspector general in 1984. ``The information was there _ nobody was reading the reports,'' Dempsey said. ``Frankly, I thought no one up here gave a darn.'' Adams said he received no reaction to his semi-annual reports to Congress over five years, until the one last spring that drew attention to HUD and began unraveling broader scandals of influence-peddling, fraud and political favoritism at the department. Potential fraud and management problems in some of those programs were pointed out in previous reports that went unnoticed, he said. ``I believe this inaction allowed HUD's problems to perpetuate and grow to the point of scandal, as we all have seen,'' Adams said in his prepared testimony. Both Adams and Dempsey spoke to the Senate Banking Committee's subcommittee on the HUD scandals, which has been holding hearings on ways to improve congressional oversight and HUD management. The panel's hearings have gone largely unnoticed while a House subcommittee drew attention for its investigation into the HUD scandals. Under questioning, Adams said he found ``startling revelations'' in the testimony last week before the House panel by former HUD deputy assistant secretary DuBois L. Gilliam, who gave detailed accusations that politics dominated decisions about who got federal housing grants under former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Adams said his office is consulting with Justice Department officials to ensure all Gilliam's allegations are investigated. In an interview later, Adams said he would be consulting also with the court-appointed special prosecutor investigating Pierce. Gilliam testified under a grant of immunity from further prosecution. He pleaded guilty to charges of accepting gratuities and abuse of HUD programs last year, after his activities were uncovered by Adams' office. Adams declined to say which of Gilliam's allegations over three days of testimony came as a surprise to him or merited further investigation. HUD Secretary Jack Kemp referred angrily to Gilliam's charges in a separate appearance before a Senate appropriations subcommittee. ``I am outraged that a former HUD official would suggest to a committee of the Congress _ as DuBois Gilliam did last week _ that Congress had better watch HUD becaause it's an election year,'' Kemp said. ``There is no room for politicking and profiteering at HUD,'' Kemp said.

DOC.HEAD: List of World's Most Expensive Cities
With AM-Expensive Cities

DOC.HEAD: Moore Pleads Guilty to Five Felony Counts
DOC.TEXT: Arch Moore, the maverick Republican who became West Virginia's only three-term governor this century, pleaded guilty Tuesday to five counts of political corruption. Moore, 67, faces up to 36 years in prison and $1.2 million in fines. He was released on a $10,000 personal recognizance bond pending his scheduled sentencing July 10. U.S. Attorney Michael Carey said the government will make no sentencing recommendation as part of its agreement with Moore. The former governor agreed April 12 to plead guilty to the indictment accusing him of crimes involving his 1984 campaign and his 1985-89 term. Moore also served as governor in 1969-1977. As other West Virginians went to the polls in the state's primary election, Moore entered guilty pleas before U.S. District Court Judge Walter Hoffman to two counts of tax fraud and one count each of extortion, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. ``This is a very serious crime. Any time the franchise of the voters is taken away from them is a serious offense,'' Carey said. Moore, accompanied by his wife, Shelley, answered to each charge in a firm, strong voice, but he seemed overcome when Hoffman asked him if he was ``induced'' to plead guilty. Moore paused for several seconds, his head down, before answering in a strained voice, ``No.'' He then left the courtroom through a side door to be fingerprinted and photographed by federal marshals. Hoffman, who also has sentenced former Vice President Spiro Agnew on tax charges and former Charleston Mayor Mike Roark on cocaine charges, was called in from Norfolk, Va., after West Virginia's federal judges recused themselves. The indictment said Moore defrauded the state of his salary and benefits by funneling $100,000 into his 1984 campaign fund; extorted $573,000 from a coal operator in 1985; filed false income tax returns in 1984 and 1985; and tried to block the federal grand jury investigation of him. Moore agreed to plead guilty after prosecutors told him they secretly tape-recorded a meeting during which he admitted receiving illegal cash donations in the 1988 campaign and discussed plans to hide information from investigators. ``Mr. Moore used large sums outside the election process. It was a scheme to run the election outside the limit of the law,'' said John Campbell, an assistant U.S. attorney from the Justice Department's public integrity section. Moore is the second West Virginia governor to be convicted of federal charges. W.W. ``Wally'' Barron, a Democrat who served from 1961 to 1965, was acquitted of bribery conspiracy charges in 1968 but went to prison for bribing the foreman of the jury that acquitted him. It also was the second time Moore was indicted. In 1975, he was charged with extorting $25,000 from a financial holding company trying to get a state bank charter. He was acquitted in 1976. Moore's political craftiness and flexibility allowed him to survive four decades in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans 2-to-1. He was elected governor in 1968 and four years later held off a challenge by Democratic Secretary of State Jay Rockefeller, who later became governor and U.S. senator. Moore could not succeed himself after his second term, and he lost a 1978 bid for the U.S. Senate. In 1984, he staged a comeback and won a third four-year term as governor. The state's only other three-term governor was Arthur Ingram Borman, who served from 1863 to 1868. Moore could not repeat the success of his 1969-77 terms, however, and in 1988 was defeated by political novice Gaston Caperton, a Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Gives Soviets Permission to Buy More Grain
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has been given another go-ahead to buy more grain from the United States, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said Moscow now has permission to buy up to 22 million metric tons of U.S. grain without further consultations, an increase of two million tons. A long-term grain agreement between the two countries specified initially that Moscow could buy up to 12 million tons of grain a year without further U.S. approval. That limit was raised to 16 million tons last October and to 20 million tons in December. The new limit of 22 million tons applies to the 12-month period that began Oct. 1. The agreement itself runs through Dec. 31. Officials said the increase resulted from talks with the Soviets in recent days and takes into consideration recent large purchases of corn by Moscow. In all, since Oct. 1, the Soviet Union has bought about 18.9 million tons of corn and wheat for delivery in 1989 and 1990. Those orders include more than 15.6 million tons of corn and 3.3 million tons of wheat. Purchases also include 342,300 tons of soybeans, 1.2 million tons of soybean meal and 7,300 tons of barley. In 1988-89, sales were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.4 bushels of corn or 36.7 bushels of wheat or soybeans.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Diet Study Challenges Way Americans Eat
DOC.TEXT: A major dietary study suggests that humans are a vegetarian species whose risk of disease is increased by eating meat and animal products, says a Cornell University researcher. A plant-based diet is more likely to promote good health and reduce the risks of heart problems, cancer, diabetes, osteoporosis and other diseases, according to the preliminary findings of the continuing study in China. ``People who eat mostly plant foods and a generous variety of plant foods ... that is the kind of diet that is most likely to be associated with reduced risk of the kinds of disease that tend to kill us in this country,'' said T. Colin Campbell, a nutritional biochemist who directed the continuing study. Other dietary studies reached similar conclusions focusing on one aspect of a specific disease or on individual foods or nutrients, but none has taken such an extensive look at ``the total dietary pattern effect,'' said Campbell. ``Animal foods, in general, are not really helpful and we need to get away from eating them,'' he said. Only in the last few thousand years have meat and animal products become staples of our diet. ``That's not nearly enough time to evolve new mechanisms to give us protection from those kinds of foods,'' said Campbell, who is writing a book on the reasons humans have turned into carnivores. The study began in 1983 to explore dietary causes of cancer but was expanded to include heart and metabolic diseases and a variety of infectious diseases. Aiding Cornell in the study are scientists from the Chinese Academies of Preventive Medicine and of Medical Sciences and the University of Oxford. Scientists surveyed 6,500 Chinese, each of whom contributed 367 facts about their diet. The preliminary findings will be reported in a 900-page monograph to be published next month by Cornell University Press. Campbell said there were several provocative findings regarding proteins, fat and cholesterol among the roughly 8,000 correlations that were found statistically and biologically significant in the study. The study found that the Chinese consume one-third less protein than Americans and that only 7 percent of their protein comes from animal sources, compared with 70 percent for Americans. ``The dietary guidelines that have been formulated in the West rather incorrectly protect our intake of animal protein. Consumption of animal protein itself also raises the risk of cancer and heart disease,'' he said. Previous studies have urged reducing dietary fat to less than 30 percent of an individual's daily caloric intake to curb the risk of heart disease and cancer. But the Chinese study suggests that fat should account for a maximum of 20 percent _ and preferably only 10 to 15 percent _ of calories. Campbell said the Chinese consume 20 percent more calories than Americans do, but Americans are 25 percent fatter. That's because Chinese eat about a third of the fat that Americans do and twice as much starch. The study also found that the Chinese had a lower cholesterol level than Americans, who consume more animal foods and dairy products. Cholesterol levels in China ranged from 88 to 165 milligrams per 100 milliliters of blood plasma, while the U.S. range extended from 155 to 274 milligrams. In addition to reducing the risk of heart disease, low cholesterol also protects against colon cancer, the most common life-threatening cancer among Americans, Campbell said. The Chinese diet contains three times more dietary fiber than Americans', yet the study found no evidence that the high fiber level interfered with the absorption of essential minerals, such as iron. Campbell said the study showed that Americans don't have to eat meat to prevent iron-deficiency anemia. The average Chinese adult consumes twice as much iron as an American adult. People also don't need animal products to prevent osteoporosis, a bone disease resulting from a lack of calcium.
