Campbell said the study showed that people need less calcium than previously thought and that the Chinese received enough from vegetables. The findings are only the beginning of the study's benefits, said Campbell. The second phase of the research involves resurveying the original participants and including people from 12 counties in Taiwan, which Campbell said is a dietary intermediate between China and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Agree to Cut Prices on Some S&L Properties
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators agreed Tuesday to cut prices on hard-to-sell real estate the government is inheriting from bankrupt savings and loans. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration endorsed stepping up sales, but withheld comment on the specifics of the plan. The Resolution Trust Corp. voted unamiously to permit regulators to cut a property's price by 15 percent if it had not sold in six months _ four months for a single-family home. A further reduction of 5 percent is allowed after an additional three months. The RTC adopted a second policy authorizing auction sales, allowing no more than a 30 percent discount from appraised value. Meanwhile, the Joint Economic Committee said Tuesday that the 1990 budget deficit will swell to $185 billion, up from $152 billion last year, and that thrift-related spending could total $45 billion this year. The new sales policy is stirring concern among real estate professionals who fear that too many cut-rate sales could hurt already depressed markets in some areas of the country. ``It's a fine line that has to be walked. They (the RTC) are not oblivious to this,'' Fitzwater said. ``We are concerned about getting rid of the properties in a way that helps reduce the burden on the taxpayer,'' he said. ``We obviously don't want to wreck the economy.'' Regulators said holding a backlog of real estate off the market, with the hope that prices will rise, can be just as harmful. ``We've become convinced that holding on to property is too costly both for us and the taxpayer and what we're adopting is designed to move properties without disrupting markets,'' said RTC Chairman L. William Seidman. The proposal originally came before the RTC board two weeks ago. The board delayed action at the urging of Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, who regulates nationally chartered banks. Clarke said he feared faster sales could hurt still-solvent banks and S&Ls struggling with deteriorating real estate portfolios. However, Clarke said an analysis by the RTC staff convinced him the new policy would have little effect on solvent institutions. ``We've satisfied ourselves that as far as we can tell, and you can never tell for sure, adoption of this policy would not have an adverse effect on any of the institutions not in receivership,'' he said. At the end of February, the last month for which firm figures were available, the RTC owned $16.4 billion in real estate after having sold $2.1 billion. It expects its portfolio to swell as it repossesses property posted as collateral for now-delinquent loans. A Treasury-led panel overseeing the RTC's work for the Bush administration encouraged the agency to offer greater price cuts sooner than permitted in the new policy. In a related development, the RTC said it had hired a Miami company, Auction Co. of America, to hold an unprecedented auction of $200 million to $300 million worth of commercial properties. Regulators anticipate holding the auction in late summer.

DOC.HEAD: Savings Bonds Sales Up
DOC.TEXT: Sales of U.S. savings bonds jumped 11 percent in April over the same month last year, boosting the total value of bonds held by Americans to a record $120.49 billion, the Treasury Department reported Tuesday. The Treasury said sales last month totaled $703 million, up from $634 million sold in April 1989. April's report brought the total of bonds sold through the first seven months of fiscal year 1990 to $4.63 billion, down slightly from the $4.65 billion sold during the same period last year. Savings bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 7.01 percent when held five years or longer.

DOC.HEAD: Government Uses Flow Chart to Explain Marcos Building Purchase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Marcos taken ill, details from cross-exam; picks up 2nd graf pvs: `They said ...
DOC.TEXT: The federal fraud and embezzlement trial of Imelda Marcos recessed abruptly Tuesday for the second time in two weeks when her blood pressure soared during testimony about her family. Mrs. Marcos, 60, former first lady of the Philippines, began sobbing when defense lawyer Gerry Spence cross-examined FBI agent James Trimbach on his testimony about the Marcoses' using allegedly stolen money for their own ends. Spence, apparently referring to the Marcoses' daughter Imee, asked whether there was ``anything wrong with paying for your children's education?'' Mrs. Marcos began to sob, and friends said later that she was upset by the allusion to her older daughter, whom she has not seen in four years. Imee lives in Morocco and is not allowed to travel on a Philippine passport, they said. After the judge declared a recess, she was taken to a nurse's station. Aides to Mrs. Marcos quoted her physician, Dr. Rafael Zagala, as saying her blood pressure had jumped. She later left the courthouse, quietly crying, on the arm of a marshal and climbed into her black van to return to her midtown apartment. Spence said he hoped Mrs. Marcos could return to court on Wednesday. Earlier, prosecutors used a giant flow chart and Trimbach to explain how Mrs. Marcos and her late husband allegedly used stolen money to secretly buy a New York office building. They said that through money transfers involving 14 banks in New York, California, the Bahamas and the Philippines, the Marcoses paid $51 million for the Crown Building, a gilded tower across Fifth Avenue from Tiffany's. It was the first of four buildings the prosecution says were bought by the Marcoses with some of the $220 million allegedly plundered from their country's treasury during former President Ferdinand Marcos' 20 years in power. Mrs. Marcos is on trial in federal court for fraud and embezzlement, along with Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, who is accused of helping the Marcoses conceal their purchases. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii in September. Assistant U.S. Attorney Debra Livingston used the board covered with boxes and arrows to show jurors how money moved from accounts held by the Marcoses and their allies to other accounts and eventually to the Crown purchase. Many witnesses, including several former bank officials, have testified that Marcos used Philippine banks and government-owned companies controlled by cronies to launder and conceal money allegedly drained from the country's dollar reserves or skimmed from government contracts. The chart purported to show that in September 1981, funds held in five different banks were channeled through intermediate accounts in six separate transactions, and eventually to the Crown Building purchase. Most of the money, including $30 million from the Traders Royal Bank of Manila, converged in a $43,128,239.25 deposit to the New York branch of Banque Paribas of Geneva. Prosecutors say that the Banque Paribas account was managed by Stephane Cattuai, whom they have described as the Marcoses' personal Swiss banker, and that the money represented the bulk of the payment for the Crown Building. Among the banks listed on the chart was the California Overseas Bank, which on Monday was ordered by Judge John F. Keenan to be turned over to the Philippine government as part of a plea bargain by its former owner, Robert S. Benedicto. Benedicto, a Marcos friend, originally was indicted as a co-conspirator but fled to Spain and then Venezuela. He gave up ownership of the bank and pleaded guilty to wire fraud in exchange for being dropped from the case. His lawyer, Wayne W. Smith, said the bank was worth between $20 million and $30 million. In a related development, the Los Angeles Times said the Marcoses doled out about $8.5 million to politicians, reporters and others in the final days of Marcos' regime in a desperate bid to retain power. The ledger was among documents found at Malacanang Palace after Marcos fled a popular revolt on Feb. 25, 1986, and Corazon Aquino, who had defeated Marcos in an election days earlier, was installed as president. It showed that Mrs. Marcos gave watches and envelopes of cash to members of the national press corps during the campaign, and that as votes were being counted she handed out money gifts at a dinner for members of a government agency assigned to investigate election fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, GOP Discuss Tax Increases, Hear Sour Economy Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Darman, Foley, Panetta comment, inserting 8 grafs after 3rd graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush discussed potential tax increases with Republican lawmakers Tuesday as Budget Director Richard Darman suggested deficit-fighting actions totaling as much as $100 billion may be needed this year. A range of suggestions for raising revenues _ including a national lottery, a one-cent federal sales tax and higher taxes on alcohol and tobacco _ are ``part of the mix,'' said Assistant Senate Republican Leader Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo. Darman's figures _ he gave a range of $60 billion to $100 billion _ were two to three times the size of the savings that Bush said would be needed when he proposed his fiscal 1991 budget in January. The $100 billion figure is an outside possibility but ``I was citing an extreme case,'' Darman said later in an interview. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he and other Democratic leaders would meet Wednesday morning with Bush on the budget. He commented after a meeting in which many House Democrats insisted that Bush be forced to specify the economic conditions that make major budget cuts necessary. ``If this summit is going to come up with very strong proposals on deficit reduction, we're going to have to lay some groundwork with the country why it's necessary,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. He suggested major deficit-cutting action would ``face a very tough time in the House and Senate on both sides of the aisle'' in this election year. Darman said the scope of the action required depends on the eventual cost of the saving and loan bailout ``and that's impossible to estimate reliably at this point.'' In any event, he said automatic spending cuts of over 20 percent throughout government loom this fall if Congress and the White House are unable to agree on a series of major deficit-cutting steps. On whether Bush will support higher taxes as part of a budget compromise, Darman said: ``He's prepared to talk without any preconditions.'' ``There are some ideas we're not prepared to put on the table,'' he added without elaboration. Although he won office on a ``no new taxes'' pledge, Bush made it clear Tuesday he was willing to discuss some form of tax increase as part of an overall budget compromise, GOP lawmakers said. Simpson, speaking to reporters outside the White House, suggested Bush had ruled out higher income taxes as part of any budget compromise. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater wouldn't even go that far. Instead, he repeated his day-earlier phrase that Bush had set ``no preconditions'' on budget talks _ not even to rule out raising income taxes or reductions in Social Security cost-of-living increases. ``We start these negotiations from scratch,'' Fitzwater said. He said any tax increases that might emerge from a White House-Congress budget summit were ``up to the negotiators.'' Bush's opening of the door to tax increases for the first time in his presidency carried the risk of political repercussions to Republicans. And Republican lawmakers were clearly uncomfortable with the phrase ``tax increase.'' House Assistant Republican Leader Newt Gingrich of Georgia said Republicans would not agree to any plan that would hurt them politically in an election year. ``We're not going to agree to stupid deals,'' Gingrich said. Asked what kind of taxes might be raised, Gingrich said: ``I don't know. We'll have to wait and see what the Democrats want to discuss.'' Participants at the White House session said Budget Director Darman, at Bush's behest, delivered an unusually pessimistic review of the economy. Darman later told GOP senators at a lunch in the Capitol that it appeared the $64 billion fiscal 1991 deficit target under the Gramm-Rudman law would be missed by at least $60 billion, said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. The budget official reportedly told both the White House and Capitol sessions that rising interest rates as well as higher estimates of the S&L bailout have swollen the predicted federal deficit. The Gramm-Rudman law requires the deficit to be lowered to $100 billion this year and to $64 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Mandatory spending cuts in both defense and most domestic programs are triggered if the deficit levels aren't reached. Democratic senators, meanwhile, also met Tuesday to discuss Bush's overture for a no-proposals-barred budget summit. Participants said there was general agreement that Bush should be forced to show his hand on what measures he would support to cut the deficit. ``There was some talk that taxes may have to be raised, but Democrats won't be the ones'' initiating tax hikes, said Sen. Dennis De Concini, D-Ariz. After the White House session, Simpson said that spending cuts of the magnitude described by Darman, which could slash 20 percent or more from each program's budget, ``would be totally unacceptable to the American people and totally unacceptable to the Congress.'' Bush ``talked about the absolute necessity of no preconditions and putting everything on the table,'' Simpson said. ``Value-added taxes, taxes on booze and cigarettes, a national lottery, a one-cent national sales tax, all sorts of things like that are in the mix,'' Simpson said, while adding: ``Nobody's talking about raising income tax rates.'' ``The president is fully aware that he's got a country to run and he's got to do that in a responsible way because lots of figures have changed,'' Simpson said.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Drops Soviet Symbols to Show Baltic Solidarity
DOC.TEXT: Estonia dropped the trappings of Soviet power on Tuesday, changing its name and its flag, and proclaimed solidarity with Latvia and Lithuania in the three Baltic republics' drive toward independence. Without formally declaring independence, Estonia's Parliament reinstituted some paragraphs from its 1938 constitution, including one proclaiming Estonia ``an independent republic, with the supreme state power vested in the people.'' It dropped ``Soviet Socialist'' to become simply ``The Republic of Estonia.'' And it adopted its old tricolor national flag in place of the hammer-and-sickle banner of socialism. Parliament said the steps were meant to show solidarity with sister republics Lithuania and Latvia, which have issued declarations of independence. All three states were independent until forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The deputies also adopted a resolution proclaiming Baltic solidarity and congratulating Latvia on declaring independence. ``The path to our own statehood is not easy, but we are convinced that here in the Baltics, we three _ acting together _ will arrive at a restoration of our independent states more fruitfully than if each were to struggle on its own,'' said the statement, broadcast on Radio Estonia and monitored in Britain. Lithuania's 3.8 million people are under an economic blockade imposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an attempt to force Lithuania to rescind several laws passed since it declared immediate independence March 11. Estonia and Latvia set unspecified transition periods for secession from the Soviet Union. On Monday, Lithuania's Council of Ministers decided to cut meat shipments to Soviet ministries by 10 percent in hopes of bartering scarce meat directly with Soviet factories for oil and other supplies, said Aidas Palubinskas, of the Supreme Council legislature's information bueau. The Soviet government newspaper Izvestia accused Lithuania Tuesday of reducing meat and milk shipments to the Soviet Union in retaliation for Moscow's economic sanctions. In Latvia, legislators who oppose independence asked Gorbachev not to impose sanctions on Latvia, saying that would hurt many citizens loyal to the Soviet Union. The group called for a referendum on independence. Activists say the recent parliamentary elections constituted a referendum on independence. Advocates of separation won more than two-thirds of the seats in the parliaments of all three Baltic republics. Latvia issued a declaration of independence on May 4 but did not ask for an immediate break with Moscow or suspend the Soviet constitution. It is waiting to hear if Gorbachev will impose sanctions similar to those on Lithuania. Latvians make up 53 percent of the 2.6 million people in their native land, and many Russian and other non-Latvian residents oppose independence. In Estonia, Parliament approved the constitutional changes and the traditional symbols of state by a vote of 73-14. Eighteen deputies did not vote or did not attend the session. Minutes later, a small crowd gathered on the cobblestone square outside the ancient parliament building and watched as the red flag was lowered. It was replaced by the blue-black-and-white striped flag used by Estonia when it was independent between the two world wars. Matt Laar, a deputy from Tallinn, the Estonian capital, said the republic already is feeling the effects of the Soviet oil and natural gas embargo against Lithuania because a Lithuanian refinery processes half of Estonia's gasoline. Estonians have tried to start talks with the Kremlin about eventual independence, but Moscow has refused. The Estonian Independent, an English-language weekly in Tallinn, reported that Gorbachev adviser Alexander Yakovlev told Estonian Supreme Soviet chairman Arnold Ruutel negotiations could not start until Parliament suspended its March 30 decision to cancel the Soviet constitution on Estonian territory. Laar said Tuesday's action followed two days of negotiations among groups in the legislature, including the Popular Front, the Communist Party and representatives of the ethnic Russian minority that makes up 30 percent of the 1.5 million population. Ethnic Estonians comprise 64 percent of the population. In Latvia, the United Council of Work Collectives, which claims 140,000 mostly non-ethnic Latvian members, called for a strike to protest the declaration of independence. It gave no strike date, but leaders previously mentioned May 15. A front-page appeal in Latvia's Communist Party newspaper said pro-independence leaders ``did not consider it necessary to ask the people: Do they want a return to unemployment, lawlessness and oppression? Do they want hunger, cold and bankruptcy as in neighboring Lithuania?'' It called the declaration of independence ``an anti-Soviet and anti-constitutional state coup.'' Anatoly Alexeyev, head of the Interfront Movement that unites thousand of non-Latvians, said he expected a major anti-independence demonstration on Wednesday during Victory Day celebrations marking the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. The West has responded cautiously to the independence movements, fearing they could weaken Gorbachev's attempts at reform. President Bush has been reluctant to do anything that might affect his May 30 summit with Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, West German Finance Minister Confer
DOC.TEXT: West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel conferred with President Bush on Tuesday and said afterwards that there is ``no risk of inflation'' from the union of the two Germanys. Waigel said Bush expressed keen interest in hearing the latest developments, from the negotiations on a common currency to the number of East Germans who have resettled in the West. Waigel said Bush and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady were ``especially impressed by the fact that the federal central bank, the Bundesbank, will have sovereignty over all monetary political matters in the entire German economic zone. ``So there will be no risk of inflation due to unification and monetary and economic union,'' Waigel told reporters on the White House driveway. He spoke in German, with an interpreter translating the remarks. Waigel said the meetings of Western finance ministers here this week had confirmed again ``that the monetary union and the economic community between East and West Germany will make a contribution to growth and will even reduce imbalances.'' He said East Germany is undertaking ``radical steps'' toward a market economy. ``The reform there is more radical than anything that's going on in any other Eastern and Central European nation,'' he said. Waigel is also chairman of the Christian Social Union, one of the parties in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government. The finance minister said he thanked Bush for U.S. support for German unity. ``These are very difficult but very interesting times, and the Americans have clearly been on our side,'' Waigel said. Kohl will visit the White House on May 17.

DOC.HEAD: Rain In The South-Central States, Snow In West
DOC.TEXT: Rain spread across the south-central section of the nation Tuesday, while record cold hit the Northwest and snow fell west of the Rockies. Showers and thunderstorms associated with an upper level disturbance crossing Texas extended from the central and western Gulf Coast to southern Missouri, with thunderstorms along the Gulf Coast. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.57 inches at Galveston, Texas, 1.37 inches at Lake Charles, La., and 1.36 inches at Port Arthur, Texas. Record lows were reported at Astoria, Ore., at 34; Medford, Ore., 31; Olympia, Wash., 30; Pendleton, Ore., 35; and Spokane, Wash., 31. Snow fell across parts of Idaho, Wyoming and Colorado, with up to 8 inches of snow reported in the Big Horn mountains of north-central Wyoming. Up to 6 inches of snow was possible in the northern and central mountains of Colorado by Wednesday morning. A freeze warning was posted for the Cache Valley and Wasatch Front of northern Utah, and a frost warning was issued for the lower agricultural areas of southern Idaho. Strong northwesterly wind ushered cold air into the north-central states. Strong southerly wind prevailed from the southern high Plains to the lower Ohio Valley and the upper Great Lakes, with wind blowing stronger than 35 mph in the Chicago area. Strong southerly wind in the Southwest helped keep temperatures unseasonably mild in some areas. Morning lows of 51 at Flagstaff, Ariz., and 73 at Las Vegas, Nev., were records for the date. Elsewhere, a few showers were scattered across the northern Atlantic Coast region. Flooding continued in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Texas. The Arkansas River crested at Little Rock, and Lake Texoma on the Texas-Oklahoma line was finally receding from its record flood of more than 27 feet above normal. In Dallas' Rochester Park neighborhood, Red Cross officials said at least two-thirds of the 174 homes affected by flooding from the Trinity River since early last week were still inundated. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 at Big Piney, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Admiral Urges Gorbachev to Maintain Law and Order
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet admiral urged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Tuesday to invoke ``strict law and order'' against draft evasion, desertion and Baltic insults against World War II veterans. The remarks by Adm. Vasily Grishanov, at a rally in the Bolshoi Theater marking the defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945, drew prolonged applause from a crowd of veterans, many of them decorated generals and admirals from the Second World War. Gorbachev, addressing the same meeting on the eve of a Victory Day military parade in Red Square, received tepid applause for a speech that lauded veterans, but dwelt largely on disarmament and Josef Stalin's purge of the officer corps on the eve of World War II. Grishanov, a little known three-star admiral, did not directly criticize Gorbachev or the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia for seeking to secede from the Soviet Union _ the first of the 15 Soviet republics to take such a step. But his speech was one of the clearest public expressions yet of dissatisfaction among officers of Kremlin tolerance toward the separatist movements in the Baltic republics. ``The heart aches,'' Grishanov said. ``Unfortunately, in recent years, certain political forces have been persistently forming a negative attitude toward the Soviet Armed Forces. They are trying to break down the notion of the motherland for the young people.'' ``As a result, there is a phenomenon of pacifism, evasion of military service, and unfortunately even acts of desertion,'' he said. ``We veterans are calling upon the young men to be real men. Prepare to fulfill your constitutional duty of defending the motherland!'' he said. ``The whole society must take real care of its defenders. In general, there must be a strict civil law and order in the state,'' he said. The veterans nodded their heads repeatedly during the speech, and burst into spontaneous applause at the mention of law and order. The admiral appeared to be in his 70's, but was not introduced as ``retired,'' as is customary for officers no longer on active duty. ``The way they treat war veterans in the Baltic republics is a tragedy,'' Grishanov said, alluding to assertions by Baltic residents that the Soviet soldiers occupied rather than liberated their nations during World War II. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940 as part of a pact with Nazi Germany. The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow passed a resolution saying that the Nazi-Soviet Pact was invalid, but maintains that the annexation was voluntary. Many Russians, particularly in the military, have been critical of Gorbachev for allowing what they view as the dissolution of the Soviet Union and its alliance in Eastern Europe, much of which was consolidated under arms during World War II and its aftermath. Gorbachev reiterated his view that the reunification of Germany would be welcome as long as the security of the Soviet Union and other countries was ensured. He warned that any effort to change post-war borders would be a ``great, fatal mistake.'' The Soviet Union along with wartime allies the United States, Britain, and France is now meeting with representatives of the two German states to try to work out the formula for reunification. A major sticking point is the West's demand that a united Germany be a part of NATO. Gorbachev rejects that demand, but did not directly address the issue in his speech. He sharply criticized Stalin's repression of the Soviet officer corps in the late 1930s, and the dictator's unwillingness to believe that Germany was planning an attack. Gorbachev credited Stalin with managing the system that turned the Soviet Union's war fortunes around. But he said the system only worked because during a war Stalin had to leave many decisions to the intelligence and initiative of subordinates in the field rather than managing the war from the capital. He sat quietly through Grishanov's speech, twiddling his fingers on the green baize-covered table in front of him, as he often does when listening to speeches critical of his policies. Soviet authorities were planning a military parade in Red Square on Wednesday to mark the 45th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Deadly Kentucky Blast Blamed on Ventilation Violations
DOC.TEXT: Six alleged violations of federal mine ventilation rules contributed to a methane explosion that killed 10 Kentucky miners last year, the government said Tuesday. A federal investigation into the blast found that some Pyro Mining Co. managers knew that explosive methane gas was accumulating in the mine four days before the explosion, but they did not maintain required records that would have alerted others. A report by the Labor Department's Mine Safety and Health Administration also said that autopsies found traces of marijuana in one victim and marijuana and cocaine in another, but there was no evidence that linked the drug use to the Sept. 13 explosion in Wheatcroft, Ky. James Greenlee, executive vice president of Costain Coal, Inc., which owns Pyro, said the company had not reviewed the report and would not discuss its findings yet. The company allowed six violations of federal ventilation requirements to occur in the days and hours before the accident, said William Tattersall, assistant labor secretary for mine safety and health. ``The combination of violations set the stage for the explosion,'' Tattersall said. The mine safety and health agency does not immediately propose fines against companies for allegedly violating safety regulations, but eventually, the company could face up to $100,000 in fines, an agency official said. The report alleged that managers failed to make required checks for the deadly gas in the hours before the explosion, failed to keep enough clean air in the mine to sweep out methane and made a series of changes in air pathways that caused a methane buildup the day of the disaster. The report said mining equipment that did not meet federal requirements was operated in the mine. Federal investigators were unable to determine exactly what triggered the explosion, although they identified five possibilities _ a cutting torch, a sccop tractor with multiple electrical safety deficiencies, detonation of a blasting cap, a spark generated by falling roof rock or snapping of a steel wire under tension.

DOC.BYLINE: Federal Agency Puts $582 Million Water Project in Limbo ^By STEVEN K. PAULSON
DOC.TEXT: The federal Fish and Wildlife Service has recommended a seven-year study of the environmental impact of a proposed $582 million Colorado water project that would kill the project, a congressman said Tuesday. The agency determined that the Animas-La Plata water project in southwestern Colorado would have adverse effects on so many other water projects in New Mexico and Colorado that further investigation is required, Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell said. Campbell, a Democrat, said contracts with the Southern Ute and Ute Mountain Ute Indian tribes, which have senior water rights in the region, require that the project be completed in 10 years. ``This would postpone it so much that it destroys the agreement,'' he said. The project would irrigate 68,000 acres of farmland, settle a lengthy government water rights dispute with the two tribes and provide drinking water for Durango residents. The project would include two reservoirs, three major pumping plants and a 157-mile network of pipes and canals. Supporters say the project would assure water for the future in southwestern Colorado and northwestern New Mexico. Critics claim the project would ruin the Animas River and provide water that would be too expensive for farmers, and that Indian water claims could be satisfied by a cheaper project. A spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service declined to comment on the ruling, saying the Colorado and New Mexico congressional delegations had to be briefed first. Groundbreaking had been delayed until June so federal biologists could complete an endangered species study on possible effects on squawfish and razorback suckers. Campbell said the ruling doesn't make sense because the federal government previously imposed a program to eliminate the fish it is now trying to protect. Campbell was referring to earlier efforts by state and federal agencies to eliminate trash fish from rivers in the area in an effort to make a better environment for trout. According to biologists, Animas-La Plata would deplete up to 18 percent of the flows downstream into the San Juan River now relied upon by rare fish. The San Juan, as it now flows through New Mexico and Utah, is one of only five rivers believed to be supporting wild populations of the squawfish. In the last three years biologists have discovered 27 squawfish and 13 razorback suckers in stretches of the San Juan River 90 miles downstream of Animas-La Plata. The Colorado squawfish, a silvery migratory fish that grows up to 5 feet long, was placed on the federal list of endangered species in 1967. The razorback sucker, a humped fish that grows up to 30 inches lnog, was proposed for protection on the list last year.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHINGTON: said Kuykendall.
DOC.TEXT: Fighting the bout with cancer, from which his brother had died two years ago, Channell ``was in tough shape,'' Kuykendall said. ``But until he got hit, his spirit was remarkable.'' Services for Channell were being held in his home state of West Virginia. Channell was sentenced to two years' probation in July 1989 for using his tax-exempt foundation to funnel millions of dollars to the rebels. He was accused of soliciting wealthy conservatives for sums of more than $1 million in some cases. Working with then-White House aide Oliver North, Channell routed the money to help the Contras during the time when Congress had banned formal U.S. assistance. Channell was the first person in the Iran-Contra affair to admit he violated the law. He pleaded guilty in April 1987 to one count of conspiring to defraud the Treasury of tax revenue. He admitted falsely advising wealthy contributors that their donations to the Contras were tax deductible. He subsequently assisted prosecutors in the investigation of the sale of American arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Contras.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Wants NATO's Nuclear First-Strike Policy Retained
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Tuesday he wants NATO to maintain the policy that allows for a first-strike use of nuclear weapons in the event of a Warsaw Pact invasion of Europe. Cheney, en route to a NATO session reviewing nuclear strategy, told reporters that the alliance's defense ministers will lay the groundwork for a lengthy review of NATO strategy involving the use of conventional and nuclear systems. President Bush called for the review last Thursday in light of the political and military changes that have swept Europe the past year. The president's request came as he announced he had scrapped plans to replace short-range nuclear missiles in Europe with an updated version and put aside plans as well to upgrade the nuclear artillery shells in NATO's arsenal. Cheney was to be joined by the defense ministers of 14 other NATO nations for the first of four sessions leading up to a summit in London in July of all NATO leaders. Cheney said he intended to brief the allies on Bush's initiative, which comes as the member nations reassess NATO's political and military significance amid the crumbling of its longtime foe, the Warsaw Pact. Bush's decision on short-range weapons does not signal the beginning of the removal of U.S. nuclear weapons from Europe, Cheney stressed. ``That does not mean that you want to walk away from the role of nuclear weapons in the overall defense of Europe,'' Cheney said. ``We think U.S. nuclear capability, both theater and strategic, will continue to be an important part of our overall alliance strategy.'' Cheney said the ``flexible response'' doctrine, allowing for the first use of nuclear weapons, has provided security for the alliance for decades ``and I'm not eager to remove one part of it.'' ``I would not give that up,'' he said at another point. Cheney was asked whether the debate will now switch from the hotly contested issue of the Lance missile to alliance plans to modernize air-launched nuclear missiles known as TASMs (Tactical Air to Surface Missile). The secretary said he didn't see ``any reason'' for the defense ministers to discuss the issue. ``There's nothing that's happened within the last few weeks that ... in any way changes our approach to TASM,'' Cheney said. NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner, who accompanied Cheney on the flight, said Monday he expected the defense ministers to formally issue a statement supporting Bush's initiative on short-range weapons. He said he also expected them to direct the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, U.S. Gen. John Galvin, to undertake a comprehensive study of the alliance need for its nuclear weaponry. Cheney said he expected the meeting scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday to focus on ``both conventional and nuclear forces and where we will go with respect to arms control.'' The meeting is with members of the Nuclear Planning Group, which is composed of the defense ministers of the 16 NATO nations, except France and Iceland. The secretary said it was a ``reasonable guess'' that the NATO review process may last into next year, given ongoing East-West talks on reducing conventional forces, but that he wouldn't put a timetable on the study.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Allow Political Activity for IRS, CIA, FBI Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Tuesday to allow law enforcement, intelligence and tax agents to spend their off time soliciting campaign contributions from colleagues and taking other active roles in partisan politics. On a 51-46 vote, Senate Democrats rejected a Republican attempt to exclude employees of the FBI, the CIA, the Internal Revenue Service, the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission from a proposal to relax rules on political activities by government workers. ``The FBI, CIA and Justice Department are still in a special category,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``I do not believe we want to politicize those agencies.'' Democrats denied trying to politicize those workers or any of 2.9 million civil service and postal employees they claim would benefit from their proposed relaxation of the Hatch Act. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said his bill overhauling the 51-year-old law was intended to clarify conflicting rulings on what political activities federal workers can participate in while totally forbidding such activities on the job. The Hatch Act now forbids the nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal workers from participating actively in politics off the job but allows them to wear campaign buttons while at work. Glenn's bill would outlaw the buttons but lift most restrictions on off-the-job activities so that federal employees could hold party offices and solicit campaign funds from their co-workers, but not from the general public. Dole's amendment to maintain the prohibitions on campaign activities by IRS, FBI, CIA and FEC workers and career federal prosecutors was one of several unsuccessful GOP attempts Tuesday to chip away at Glenn's bill. ``Laws restricting those people and what they can do are already on the books,'' Glenn said. ``They cannot use information gained on the job politically.'' Also defeated were GOP amendments to maintain a ban on federal workers holding office in the two political parties and delaying any changes in the Hatch law until after a campaign finance reform bill is enacted. The first amendment, by Sen. William V. Roth, R-N.H., was defeated on a 64-32 vote and the second, by GOP Whip Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, was rejected 61-36. Republicans have contended the entire bill amounts to a ``pot of gold'' for the Democratic Party because unionized public employees and their political action committees overwhelmingly favor Democrats. ``lf we banned all PACs, there wouldn't be much demand for this bill,'' said Dole, holding open a threat that Republicans later this week might try to attach to the measure their proposed package of campaign finance reforms. ``The only purpose of this bill is to make the federal employee union PACs fatter, of which 88 percent (of their campaign donations) goes to the other party,'' he said. Despite repeated assertions that President Bush will veto any changes in the Hatch law, Democrats so far have garnered several votes from Republicans on each challenge by the GOP leadership to the bill. The House approved a much broader revision of the Hatch Act by an overwhelming 297-90 vote more than a year ago. But the House bill also would permit federal workers to run for public office solicit campaign contributions from the public. The Senate bill would retain current prohibitions against those two activities.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Candidates Angered by New Tax Talk
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 9th graf pvs, ``I think, with 3 grafs of Rollins' comment
DOC.TEXT: Election year discomfort among Republicans was obvious Tuesday after President Bush's lips moved and taxes suddenly appeared on the budget negotiating table. ``I'm opposed to having taxes be on the table, period,'' said Rep. Bill Schuette of Michigan, one of the Republican congressmen challenging a Democratic senator. Schuette's comment was typical of GOP candidates who have made opposition to tax increases a centerpiece of their campaigns. As one Republican operative put it, ``There is a clear anxiety among Republican candidates.'' Speaking on the condition he not be named, the source said that candidates and activists ``feel there has been a clear distinction between the parties on the tax issue. They feel the negotiation would be used by the Democrats to muddle the distinction.'' Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, the Democrat who lost to Bush in the 1988 presidential election, called Bush's ``no new taxes'' pledge ``a fraud on the American public.'' ``I know it was effective and the election is over,'' Dukakis said. ``But to make that kind of commitment given the size of the federal deficit, this (savings and loan) disaster, which is going to cost the people of this country hundreds and hundreds of billions, was irresponsible.'' Republicans feared the public also would remember the Bush pledge. ``I'm not going to vote for anything which causes us to lose politically,'' said House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia after a White House meeting with the president. The initial reaction of Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the House Republican campaign committee, was that injecting the possibility of a tax increase this election year was ``a disaster.'' ``There is something of an anti-tax movement around this country ... and certainly Republicans are on the right side of that at this stage of the game,'' said Rollins, who added that ``the most significant contrast between Democrats and Republicans is on the tax issue. The public feels that the Republicans ... are the party that's fighting against raising their taxes.'' A shift in that perception, he said, would ``certainly affect our candidates who are challenging Democratic incumbents to take the tax pledge. Since 1980, the Republicans have portrayed Democrats as the ``tax and spend'' party. ``Read my lips, no new taxes,'' was Bush's most memorable line from the 1988 presidential campaign. When he stood before the 1988 Republican convention to accept its presidential nomination, Bush predicted this day would come. ``And the Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again,'' declared the presidential nominee. ``And I'll say to them: Read my lips. No new taxes.'' The Democratic-controlled Congress refused to push. The word on taxes sent to the White House from the start of the Bush administration was ``After you, Mr. President.'' Then, at a Sunday night summit with congressional leaders in the White House living quarters, the president agreed that everything _ including taxes _ would be on the negotiating table in the effort to come up with a way to cut the federal deficit. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Tex., chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, called it ``a question of walking that plank together.'' But the 1990 campaign trail is clogged with Republicans who adopted Bush's ``read my lips'' stance. For Schuette, taxes is ``a defining issue. It separates Bill Schuette from (Democratic Sen.) Carl Levin. And I think it separates many Republicans from many Democrats.'' But does Schuette suddenly find himself separated from Bush? The congressman hopes not. ``Do I think he will in the end agree to something that raises taxes?'' he replied. ``No, I don't think he will.'' Kelly Mitchell, press secretary for Rep. Robert Smith, R-N.H., who is running for the Senate seat being vacate by GOP Sen. Gordon Humphrey, said Smith ``does not support tax increases. He plans to maintain that position.'' Other hard-line anti-taxers were Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., challenging Democratic Sen. Paul Simon and Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, challenging Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin. ``I am apoplectic,'' said a Republican political operative, who insisted on anonymity. ``This comes out just in enough time so the Democrats have a shield around them for the rest of the campaign.'' Republicans were quick to insist that an increase in income taxes was not being discussed. ``Value-added taxes, taxes on booze and cigarettes, a national lottery, a one-cent national sales tax, all sorts of things like that are in the mix,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate Republican Whip. Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, the third-ranking Senate Republican, complained the media were getting the emphasis wrong. ``Bush thinks news people are making a great mistake to center it around taxes,'' said the Rhode Island senator. ``I don't want him to raise taxes,'' said Bruce Benson, the Colorado Republican Party chairman. ``I still want him to cut government. ... I also know we've got a government that if the Democrats won't work with you without some kind of a switch sometimes you have to bend and let the Democrats push you into something.'' Anticipating the Republican argument that Bush was being dragged ``kicking and screaming'' to consideration of a tax increase, House Democratic leaders were quick to say they weren't putting pressure on the president. ``Democrats are disinclined to drag them kicking and screaming anyplace,'' said Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., chairman of the House Democratic Caucus. ``They called us,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., vice chairman of the caucus.

DOC.HEAD: Go-Go Dancing Outlawed as `Lewd and Lascivious'
DOC.TEXT: The tales of bikini-clad table-dancers flashing their breasts at patrons of the Country Cafe and Lounge were finally too much for the residents, who got the village fathers to ban go-go girls. ``There were a lot more activities going on inside that bar than just dancing,'' resident Lori Burden said Tuesday, after residents of this central Illinois community of 440 petitioned the village board Monday night. The petition was signed by 111 of the town's 201 registered voters. About 75 people packed the tiny Village Hall as the board voted 4-2 to declare the go-go girls ``lewd and lascivious.'' The ban takes effect in 10 days. Charles Muehlebach, who owns the Country Cafe and Lounge, two bars and a liquor store in neighboring Decatur, said the girls had been dancing here since 1983. ``They don't strip or dance naked. They just flash. This place is like a Sunday school compared to places in the cities,'' Muehlebach said. ``I don't know what started this. We've never had any trouble before this. I don't understand it.'' Muehlebach said he's considering legal action against the village to compensate for lost revenue. ``This is a town of 400 and all it's got is a laundromat, a grain elevator and a couple of bars. The other bar owner is thinking about closing because business is so bad. Now they want to shut me down.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Leaves for Europe Meetings, Call for End to Isolation
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk left Tuesday on a major European tour aimed at convincing Western leaders that South Africa has changed enough to justify an end to international efforts to isolate it. ``It is wonderful to go to Europe with the knowledge that South Africa is busy taking its rightful place in the international community,'' the South African leader said at an airport news conference before his departure. The first stop on the nine-country, 18-day tour is France, where President Francois Mitterrand has shunned previous South African leaders in protest against the system of white minority rule. Although apartheid still exists, de Klerk's historic talks last week to settle differences with the African National Congress have led the French leader and others to agree to give de Klerk a hearing. In recent months, de Klerk also freed political prisoners including African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and had taken other steps toward reform. The evening news on South Africa's government-run television said a senior government source described the tour as ``a concerted effort to pull South Africa from the morass the country has found itself in.'' ``The visit is not only going to be demanding of the state president but also of the utmost importance to South Africa,'' the television said. After France, de Klerk will visit Belgium, Italy, West Germany, Britain, Spain, Switzerland, Greece and Portugal. His exact itinerary is being kept secret for security reasons, but he is to meet the heads of government in every country. Among his hosts will be British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, King Juan Carlos of Spain and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``I welcome the opportunity for re-evaluating what is happening in South Africa to the heads of state and heads of government I will be visiting,'' de Klerk said at his news conference. Many Western countries have imposed economic and trading sanctions against South Africa and cut athletic, entertainment and scientific exchanges because of apartheid, under which the black majority of 28 million in this nation of 37 million residents has no vote in national affairs. But de Klerk has pledged to end white rule and share power with the black majority. In the government's first-ever talks with the African National Congress, the country's most powerful black political organization, the two sides agreed to work together to end political violence and clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution. Two months ago, Mandela had been calling for increased sanctions and complete diplomatic isolation of South Africa. But after last week's talks he said the ANC would not seek new sanctions. Government television reported that Spain is considering ending its entertainment and sports boycott of South Africa in response to de Klerk's visit and the talks with the ANC. The South African foreign ministry described it as the most extensive foreign trip by any South African head of government since the ruling National Party came to power in 1948. ``There will be no slipping in by the back door,'' government television assured viewers. In the past, South African leaders have visited foreign countries as tourists. De Klerk will also be looking for support for his political plans. Western European nations have been an important source of aid and support for the ANC and de Klerk hopes they will help to control more radical black elements that oppose any peaceful solution with the white government. De Klerk said he was visiting European leaders to tell them that instead of pressure, South Africa needs encouragement. ``This does not mean interference,'' he added. De Klerk is accompanied by Foreign Minister Pik Botha and other officials. ``We have such a good case to present at the moment that I'm not worried about the outcome of the tour,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Commends Mandela, de Klerk on Their Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent messages congratulating Nelson Mandela and South African President F.W. de Klerk on their historic first round of talks, the White House said Tuesday. Bush has invited both men to visit the White House. An informed administration source said Tuesday those visits will probably take place in the latter part of June. The source spoke only on the condition of anonymity. The White House did not release the texts of the messages, but a deputy spokesman, Roman Popadiuk, said Bush characterized the three days of talks as ``very positive.'' Earlier, in Johannesburg, the African National Congress released the contents of Bush's letter to Mandela. De Klerk's office confirmed he had received a letter from Bush but did not divulge the contents. ``Your brave struggle against apartheid and your commitment to peace and a political solution to South Africa's great problems have stirred the hopes of many,'' Bush wrote Mandela, the deputy president of the ANC. ``The American people respect this commitment and support your efforts to achieve a non-racial and democratic South Africa with equal opportunity for all,'' Bush said. The letter said the great energy shown by Mandela since de Klerk freed him from a life prison sentence in February had helped the country move closer to achieving those objectives. ``The joint commitment to a peaceful process of negotiations and efforts to resolve the existing climate of violence agreed to by the African National Congress and the government is a great step forward to this end,'' Bush said, adding that he looked forward to discussing those issues with Mandela when they meet later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Magazine Defamed Tennis Star, But Ruling Not Binding
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Tuesday found a Swedish magazine guilty of defaming former tennis star Bjorn Borg by printing allegations he used drugs, but the verdict was not binding. A formal ruling was expected in the case next week. Borg, a five-time Wimbledon champion, sued the weekly magazine Z for $58,000 after it quoted his former girlfriend Jannicke Bjorling as saying he used drugs. Z's chief editor, Jorgen Widsell, told the court Tuesday he had three sources who said Borg had used cocaine. A day earlier, Borg denied in court that he ever used drugs. His lawyer argued that the magazine knew Ms. Bjorling was in the midst of a bitter child-custody dispute with Borg at the time of her comments. The two, who were not married, have a son. Before Tuesday's verdict by the nine-member jury, Borg stormed out of the courthouse after the judge denied his attorney's request to call an additional witness. ``This is enough for me. I'm leaving,'' Borg said. He told pursuing reporters: ``I do not care what you write.'' Three judges were to deliver a formal verdict in the case Monday.

DOC.HEAD: East German Parliament Remembers World War II Victims
With AM-Jewish Congress, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's first democratically elected Parliament on Tuesday eulogized the millions of people who died at the hands of Adolf Hitler's Nazi regime. Recalling the horrors of the Nazis and the deaths of six million Jews, in addition to millions of Russians, Poles and others, Parliament President Sabine Bergmann-Pohl said ``the insane path of German history found its end on May 8, 1945.'' Referring to last fall's peaceful revolution that brought down East Germany's hard-line Communist leadership and opened the way for the reunification of East Germany and West Germany, Mrs. Bergmann-Pohl said: ``Today we have the hope that May 8 does not remain as the last mutually binding date for German history.'' ``But it will always be closely tied to whatever happens along our way into the future,'' she added. Also on Tuesday, a special ceremony dedicated to the thousands of Soviet soldiers killed by Nazi troops in battles to capture Berlin, was held at East Berlin's Treptow Park, the site of a war memorial to the Soviets. Officials say about 5,000 Soviet soldiers died fighting the Germans in the last few days of the war in Europe and the battle for Berlin. The parliamentary ceremonies coincided with a meeting in East Berlin's Palast Hotel between World Jewish Congress leader Edgar M. Bronfman and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Bronfman said at the meeting that a memorial should be erected at the site of the Berlin Wall that was opened last Nov. 9, because the date had ``dual importance.'' On Nov. 9, 1938, Nazis killed dozens of Jews and ransacked Jewish homes and stores in what became known as Kristallnacht, or crystal night, because of the broken glass that littered the streets afterward. ``Let me suggest that the date Nov. 9 is a really important date in black distress and golden hope,'' Bronfman said. Prior to the meeting, leaders of the Jewish Congress held a memorial ceremony at the Wannsee Villa in Berlin, where German leaders met in 1942 to map out their so-called ``Final Solution'' that led to the death of 6 million Jews.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Figure Channell Dies
DOC.NOTE: EDs: COMBINES pvs and edits thruout to ADD hospital, police comment, other background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Carl ``Spitz'' Channell, the first person to plead guilty to illegal activities in the Iran-Contra case, has died of pneumonia while recovering from a car accident, associates said Tuesday. The conservative fund-raiser, who was 44, died Monday at George Washington University Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Terry Abdoo. Channell pleaded guilty in April 1987 to conspiring to defraud the government by using his tax-exempt foundation to raise money for the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. The plea marked the first break for special prosecutors in their investigation of the Iran-Contra case. He later assisted prosecutors in the investigation of the sale of American arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Contras. Former Rep. Dan Kuykendall, a friend of Channell, said Channell had been undergoing chemotherapy for lung cancer and had recovered enough to engage in consulting work. But he was struck by an automobile March 15 near his office in Southeast Washington, according to Kuykendall, who is now a Capitol Hill lobbyist. District of Columbia police spokeswoman Shannon Cockett said the driver of the car, Donald Parker Jr., had lost control of his vehicle. Parker, a Washington resident was given a ticket for failure to pay full time and attention, a moving violation, she said. Because the accident resulted in a death, the case will be referred to the U.S. attorney for further investigation, Cockett said. Abdoo said Channell had been admitted to the hospital April 17 and associates said he was being treated for complications from the car accident and the cancer. Channell ``struggled and struggled,'' to recover from massive injuries that included several broken bones and a crushed pelvis, said Kuykendall. Fighting cancer, from which his brother had died two years ago, Channell ``was in tough shape,'' Kuykendall said. ``But until he got hit, his spirit was remarkable.'' Services for Channell will be held Saturday in Elkins, W.Va., followed by burial in Huttonsville, W.Va., said Eleanor McManus, who is Channell's aunt. Channell was sentenced to two years' probation in July 1989. He was accused of soliciting wealthy conservatives for sums of more than $1 million in some cases. Working with then-White House aide Oliver North, Channell routed the money to help the Contras during the time when Congress had banned U.S. government assistance. He admitted in pleading guilty to falsely advising wealthy contributors that their donations to the Contras were tax deductible.

DOC.HEAD: Papal Visit to Mexico Draws Ire of Some Critics
With AM-Pope, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``John Paul II, the whole world loves you,'' goes the chant heard in the streets during the pope's visit to overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Mexico. But a few dissenting voices can also be heard. Critics are asking whether the papal visit is a means for the ruling party to win political mileage. They question church policy. They complain about the exclusivity of one papal Mass, and skewer the commercial hoopla surrounding the pontiff's eight-day visit. As always in Mexico, some of the most biting commentary has come from editorial cartoonists. The pro-government newspaper Excelsior ran a cartoon about church opposition to birth control, which showed the pontiff's jet approaching Mexico amid a huge flock of storks. Political analyst Adolfo Gilly, in the daily newspaper La Jornada, criticized the pope for preaching ``submission theology'' as opposed to ``liberation theology,'' a doctrine that holds the church must actively involve itself in the fight for social justice. The pope has also drawn complaints over his support of celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Christianity in the Americas, set for 1992. Indian activists say the church served as an agent of the Conquest, which decimated their population and shredded their culture. El Financiero, Mexico's business daily, noted that only the well-connected and the affluent got tickets to the pope's Sunday Mass at the Basilica of Guadalupe. The shrine was a sea of lace, pearls, richly jeweled rosaries, silk ties and soft wool suits. Thousands of others, patient in their humble clothes, had to stand behind police barricades outside in the rain. ``Do you know what happened in those streets you toured in your covered car?'' La Jornada rhetorically asked the pontiff. Even the government daily, El Nacional, took note of the plight of the masses. ``Hours of waiting? Was it worth it to see the pope for less than a minute?'' ran one of its headlines Monday. The pope and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari have been sharply criticized for striking what some see as a rather unholy alliance. The cartoonist Helguera, for instance, drew a crassly grinning pontiff holding a crucifix superimposed over the flag of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which has ruled Mexico for 61 years. The PRI clearly hopes to make political points with the papal visit and the prospect of establishing formal relations with the Vatican. The church, which supported conservatives and opposed social reform, lost its property and many of its rights between 1859 and 1926. Church officials have said they would welcome amendments to a constitution that now forbids the church to own property, bans religious education, outlaws clerical garb in public and bars priests from voting. Most of those restrictions are ignored in practice nowadays, but opposition politicians have criticized the PRI for what they say is a cynical attempt to shore up flagging support by engineering a formal rapprochement with the church. There is still enough opposition in Congress to make Salinas reluctant to try to ram through constitutional changes, but normalizing relations with the Vatican would not require that.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Nears For MOVE Charges
DOC.TEXT: Four days before the deadline for filing civil rights charges, a top Justice Department official said Tuesday no new evidence has been found to justify re-opening the case of the bloody confrontation between Philadelphia police and the radical group MOVE. But John Dunne, chief of the department's Civil Rights Division told reporters, ``The case will have my full attention for the next 72 hours. I am hopeful that we will able to find any new information.'' Eleven people died, including five children, when police bombed a fortified row house occupied by MOVE on May 13, 1985. A fire that began when the bomb was dropped destroyed 61 homes. A group of Philadelphia ministers, lawyers and community activists is still hoping a federal grand jury could be presented with evidence and issue indictments before the weekend. But after meeting with the group for an hour, Dunne said he could offer no assurances. ``The federal statutes are very strict,'' Dunne said. ``There must be hard evidence to prove guilt beyond a resonable doubt that a party or parties intended to deny people within our community their civil rights which are protected by the federal law.'' ``To date, it is our conclusion that there is not sufficent evidence,'' he said. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., who organized the meeting, said the case could be presented to a grand jury in ``a half a day.'' Specter has badgered the Justice Department for two years to take another look at the MOVE evidence. He won a promise at Dunne's Senate confirmation hearing that the department would keep that possibility alive. A Philadelphia grand jury and a federal investigation previously have concluded that the evidence would not support indictments.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Mourn At Funeral Of Baseball Tragedy Child
DOC.TEXT: One week before 8-year-old Holly Rizzi was killed by a car that careened through a park in this Chicago suburb, she walked up the aisle of St. Mary's Catholic Church to receive her First Communion. On Tuesday, her funeral was held there. About 300 friends, relatives and classmates from St. Mary's Catholic School attended the service for Holly, one of three children killed Saturday when the car plowed through the park and a game of Little League T-ball. Six other children and three adults, including the car's driver, were injured. ``If before we took them for granted,'' Associate Pastor Robert Burnell said of Riverside's children, ``we will no longer do so.'' Despite the tragedy, Burnell told the mourners, Holly's friends and schoolmates would be able to cope with the loss. ``Children, too, know about the mysterious, the inexplicable. They know about death,'' he said. ``Many a child has seen a black casket lowered into a grave and known that grandmother was no longer cooking in the kitchen.'' Holly's parents, Michael and Julia Rizzi, sat silently with her brothers, Peter and Nicholas, during the hour-long service. The parents appeared upset but did not cry when the small white-veiled casket, surrounded by pink and white flowers, was carried into the church. Later, outside, children wept as the seven-car procession left for a private burial. The funeral for another victim, 8-year-old Ryan Womack, was set for Wednesday. Rites for 7-year-old Colin Anderson were to be held Thursday in the chapel of a hospital where his father, Bruce, 43, remained in fair condition, recuperating from a leg injury suffered in the crash. A Cook County grand jury has issued at least a dozen subpoenas in its investigation into how James J. Harasek's Cadillac came to plow through the park Saturday afternoon, just as the game was beginning. T-ball is a kind of Little League baseball for young children in which the ball is set up on a tee, rather than pitched. Harasek, 59, was hospitalized in fair condition with a fractured elbow. He has refused to answer investigators' questions on the advice of his attorney, Charles G. Levy. Levy said tests taken when Harasek was admitted to the hospital showed no alcohol in his blood. Police are seeking medical records and testimony from Harasek, a retired tavern owner who, state records show, was ticketed five times for traffic violations over the last 24 years. Investigators said they also want Harasek's relatives and friends to testify about his condition and whereabouts before the crash. On Tuesday, 8-year-old Jacqueline Tuglis remained hospitalized in critical condition, 7-year-old Kevin Rose was in serious condition, and 7-year-old Justin Glaredon was in fair condition, said Michael Maggio, a spokesman for Loyola University Medical Center. Three children and one adult were released from the hospital after treatment for their injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Passed to Carry Out 1972 Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The House approved legislation Tuesday to put into effect a 1972 treaty against biological weapons. By a vote of 408-0, the House approved a bill which makes it illegal to develop and possess biological weapons. The bill goes to the White House, where President Bush is expected to sign it into law. Under the legislation, any individual, corporation or government is prohibited from developing or possessing any biological weapons, and prohibited from assisting a foreign state or organization from doing so. Biological weapons are harmful forms of bacteria, viruses, fungi or naturally occuring toxins that could be directed at an enemy. A biological weapon could be unleashed on an unsuspecting public by using it in a liquid to contaminate water or in an aerosol that is dropped by bomb. In 1925, the Geneva Protocol banned the first use in war of biological and chemical weapons, but did not address the development, production, possession or transfer of the weapons. Forty-four years later, President Nixon ordered the Defense Department to destory its arsenal of biological weapons. The United States then spearheaded the fight for an international ban on production and possession of them. On April 10, 1972, in Washington, Moscow and London, 111 countries signed the Biological Weapons Convention, which prohibits production and possession of the weapons. The Senate ratified the treaty two years later. According to the pact, each nation must take ``any necessary measures'' to prohibit biological weapons at home. Legislation was introduced in Congress over the years to include the prohibition in U.S. law, but the measures never got far, largely because no administration or powerful congressional group pushed for passage.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militias Ignore Cease-fire, 19 Injured in Shelling
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces ignored a call for a Tuesday cease-fire and pounded each other with artillery and rocket barrages, devastating residential areas and severely damaging two hosptitals. Nineteen people were injured Tuesday, raising the toll to 19 dead and 46 wounded since fighting was renewed Monday between renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's army and Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. According to a police count, 941 people have been killed and 2,502 wounded since the fight began Jan. 30. In south Lebanon, meanwhile, four people were killed and six wounded in artillery duels between the Iranian-backed, fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and their Shiite rivals, the Syrian-supported Amal militia, police said. The two militias have been battling on and off for two years for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiite community, the country's largest sect. In another incident, Israeli soldiers killed two Arab guerrillas Tuesday in a clash near the border, the Israeli army said. The Israeli military said the guerrillas' identity was unknown. On Monday, Israeli troops shot and killed a guerrilla belonging to a pro-Syrian organization and captured another in a shootout six miles north of the border. In Beirut's Christian sector, a three-man mediation committee called for a cease-fire Tuesday evening, but the call went unheeded as the two rival factions bombarded residential areas at the rate of 20 shells and rockets a minute. Nasrallah Sfeir, patriarch of the Maronite Catholic Church, was one of the leaders appealing for the cease-fire. Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Christian community that has dominated politics in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. ``Our bible does not permit such practices. Enough destruction. Enough war,'' Nasrallah said. ``This shelling only leads to more destruction. ... It doesn't lead to any outcome. Only the poor population is the victim,'' Sfeir said in his appeal broadcast by all radio stations in Lebanon. On Monday, thunderous shelling raged through the night, setting hospitals and apartment blocks on fire. Huge tongues of flame licked into the night sky amid the flashes of exploding shells and rockets. The fighting in the Ashrafiyeh, Karantina, Badaro and Furn el-Shubbak neighborhoods of Christian east Beirut eased off around daybreak into mortar and machine gun clashes. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said Aoun's military hospital in Badaro was severely damaged by salvoes of 122mm rockets fired by Geagea's gunners. He said Aoun's 130mm howitzer batteries hammered the Hospital de Notre Dame du Liban in Jounieh, a Geagea-controlled port 12{ miles north of Beirut. One hospital patient was interviewed on Geagea's Lebanese Broadcasting Corp. television station. ``Despite my wound, I left the bed and hid in the closet. I stayed there until nurses came into the room and took me to the shelter on a stretcher,'' he said. A carpet of debris and broken glass covered the corridors of the seven story hospital and its owner, Dr. Fawzi Azaimi, appealed to both sides to stop shelling medical centers. ``This is a crime,'' said Azaimi, who heads the syndicate of private-sector hospitals. ``Private hospitals can hardly cope with the difficulties they're facing. We cannot afford reconstruction costs. I plead with the government for urgent financial assistance,'' he added. The Christian confrontation has caused damage estimated at $1 billion and forced 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million population to seek refuge in safer parts of Lebanon or flee abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Protesters Fill Square after Talks Break Down
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: Talks broke down within minutes Tuesday between protesters and government, and about 8,000 enraged anti-Communists crowded into central University Square demanding that interim President Ion Iliescu resign. Another demand is the exclusion of former Communists from politics. The crowd swelled from about 1,000 at noon as protesters streamed to the square following the talks breakdown. The square is the site of an anti-government rally that began 17 days ago. Demonstrators promise to continue their protest until May 20, when Romania holds its first free national elections in more than 50 years. Iliescu and other former Communist officials within his National Salvation Front, which dominates the provisonal government, broke with their Marxist past after the December revolution here and embraced democratic ideals. But their critics accuse them of clinging to Communist ideals and of desiring to reimpose totalitarian rule if the Front wins the elections. Recent polls indicate Iliescu and the Front are well ahead. Four protest leaders went to government headquarters at 10:30 a.m. for talks with Iliescu and other leaders of the provisional Parliament, but stormed out after Iliescu and Vice President Ion Caramitru kept them from videotaping the proceedings. A government offer of a stenographer to record the minutes was refused. It was not clear whether a dialogue would be resumed. Protest groups coordinating the rally said they want a dialogue, but they want it recorded. Iliescu spokesman Paul Financu told a news conference ``a dialogue is still possible if (protest leaders) clarify their own position.'' He said their demand to film the talks ``showed they were interested in publicity and not substance.'' Iliescu reversed his earlier position and agreed Friday to hold a dialogue with a delegation from the demonstrators, but then ruled out any discussion of their demands to change the electoral law and delay the balloting. The protest delegation Tuesday included Stelian Tanase of the intellectual Group for Social Dialogue and leading former dissident Doina Cornea. Iliescu, a former Communist Party functionary, fell out of favor with dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in the early 1970s and was relegated to lesser posts. He rose to prominence after the December revolution that led to Ceausescu's ouster and execution. A government statement Tuesday deplored the ``reprehensible'' attack on presidential candidate Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party during a campaign stop Saturday in Braila, 180 miles northeast of Bucharest. Liberal Party officials said Campeanu suffered a cut face. The statement directed police to ``do their duty to ensure order and peace at electoral meetings and protect candidates from any violent acts.'' It expressed ``confidence no political parties are behind the violence.'' But Liberal Party and National Peasant Party officials blamed National Salvation Front supporters for attacks on their candidates for Parliament and the presidency, and threatened to boycott the elections if political violence continues. A mile from the rally in University Square, visiting Mother Teresa, the 79-year old missionary and Nobel Peace laureate, met students and implored them to ``prayer, love and peace.'' She is in Romania with four other nuns to set up a permanent mission in Chitila, eight miles northwest of Bucharest. Mother Teresa, who leaves Wednesday, has visited orphanages and a hospital for AIDS-infected children.

DOC.HEAD: Company Meets Union Anyway
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound meeting with union officials only hours after the bus line declared victory in the drivers' strike shows the company still needs the union's help to rebuild its struggling company, a union official said Tuesday. Union President Edward M. Strait said he met with Greyhound chairman Fred Currey Monday afternoon, just a few hours after Currey held a news conference to declare the strike over. ``If they continue to hire drivers who don't know where they are going, the traveling public is the one that suffers,'' Strait said of the company's pledge to hire non-union replacements for rebuilding the bus line, which lost $56 million in the first quarter. Greyhound Vice President Anthony Lannie said bus company officials met with union officials Monday, despite their declaration of victory in the 2-month-old strike, because they'd rather give 1,300 remaining jobs to union drivers than spend $5,000 to train each new driver. Officials on both sides kept the Monday afternoon meeting under wraps until Tuesday. In a letter Tuesday to local Greyhound union presidents, Strait described the meeting as ``less than cordial'' and said it produced ``absolutely nothing.'' ``My only hope at this juncture is that his creditors will take the initiative to tell Fred Currey'' to get back to the bargaining table, Strait's letter said. Currey's victory declaration is ``merely another smoke screen to avoid the real issue _ a fair and equitable contract for the professional employees who built the company,'' Strait's letter said. Over the weekend, the two sides held their first bargaining talks since mid-March, but the talks quickly broke down after the company offered a four-year wage freeze and proposed an elimination of 4,500 union jobs. The union called the offer an insult. The union represents 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers who walked off the job March 2. As of Monday, the company said 548 union drivers had crossed picket lines. It also had hired 2,888 new drivers and had 501 others in school, which would give it 3,937 available drivers by May 16. Greyhound, which is in the midst of scaling backs its services, has said before it could operate a full system with about 3,200 drivers, although more are needed for the busy summer travel season. It told the union over the weekend it had immediate openings for about 600 union drivers and could probably make way for another 700 within a few months.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON
Former French Resistance Fighters Salute Quayle at Paris Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Paris ceremony, angered motorists. Picks up 6th graf, `He said' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Former Resistance fighters saluted Vice President Dan Quayle at a World War II victory ceremony Tuesday as angry motorists blared car horns because Quayle's motorcade was blocking traffic around the Arc de Triomphe. Quayle stopped at the Arc to celebrate the 45th anniversary of victory over Nazi Germany after flying into Paris from London, where he pledged that NATO will adjust to the changes of a free and united Europe. ``There is no substitute for NATO,'' he said in London. Quayle joined British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher there at a ceremony marking the 100th birthday of Dwight D. Eisenhower, the wartime Allied commander who helped create NATO's military force and later became president.
