In Paris, a score of former Resistance fighters stood in formation underneath a huge tricolor by the eternal flame burning at the monument in honor of France's unknown soldier. The vice president and his wife, Marilyn, shook hands with each veteran to the cheers of onlookers out for a late evening stroll under balmy spring skies. Motorists leaned on their horns meanwhile because of the snarled traffic around the Arc, the capital's busiest intersection. Part of the motorcade carrying news photographers became lost in the holiday-weekend traffic. The Quayles landed at Orly Airport in Paris aboard Air Force Two. They were spending the night with U.S. Ambassador Walter J. Curley. Quayle holds talks Wednesday with President Francois Mitterrand, Premier Michel Rocard and European Space Agency officials before returning home. He will also address a delegation headed by Mayor Jacques Chaban-Delmas of Bordeaux, a former Resistance leader and chief of the French committee honoring Eisenhower's 100th birthday. The vice president said in London that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will work with other institutions to ensure European security as the Cold War comes to an end. Both Quayle and Thatcher paid tribute to Eisenhower's postwar vision of a free and united Europe. ``He foresaw the unification of Germany and foresaw that we should come to a stage when a divided Europe would be a thing of the past,'' Mrs. Thatcher said of Eisenhower. ``That is what we're working for now.'' Attending the ceremony was Eisenhower's granddaughter, Susan Eisenhower, and her Russian husband, Roald Sagdeev, former head of the Space Research Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. On the future of the 16-nation Alliance following the downfall of communist governments in Eastern Europe and the reforms in the Soviet Union, Quayle said, ``NATO will accommodate itself to the changes.'' He said the Western military alliance would work with the 12-member European Community, the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and other institutions ``to provide for European security and also to look to trade opportunities.'' The vice president and Mrs. Thatcher discussed East-West relations, the Soviet Union, Lithuania, and hostages at a dinner Monday night at Chequers, her country residence. At a meeting Tuesday with Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, both Quayle and Hurd ruled out any deals to free the 16 Western hostages being held in Lebanon. ``Negotiations were conducted in the past ... and you can see where we are today. Hostages are still being held,'' Quayle said in a British Broadcasting Corp. television interview. ``President Bush is adamant about this. The prime minister is adamant about this. We do not negotiate with terrorists. Hostages should be released.'' Six Americans are among those held in Lebanon. Held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Quayle arrived Monday night from Rome on a European tour commemorating Eisenhower. As Mrs. Thatcher was waiting to greet Quayle at her 10 Downing St. residence on Tuesday, her husband Denis Thatcher, who had been on a golfing vacation in Florida, returned home after an overnight flight. ``I am waiting for the vice president. Would you like to meet him?'' Mrs. Thatcher asked her husband. Reporters and photographers were standing by. ``I need a shave,'' Thatcher said and disappeared.

DOC.HEAD: States Battle Federal Agency Over Control of Missouri River
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for three drought-plagued western states asked a federal judge Tuesday to order the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to maintain water levels in a crucial reservoir along the Missouri River. But lawyers for the corps, which wants to lower the river's reservoirs to support shipping downstream, contended a federal judge has no authority to dictate how the corps should manage its system of six Missouri River dams. Former South Dakota Gov. William Janklow, who is representing the three states, said lowering the level of Lake Oahe would destroy this year's hatch of millions of walleye eggs. That would deal a $20 million blow to North Dakota and South Dakota's tourism industries, he said. Both North Dakota and South Dakota rely on fishing and attendant tourism to boost their economies, Janklow told U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy. ``We don't live in wealthy states ... We have very limited economic opportunities available to us,'' he said. South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana are suing the corps in an effort to block the agency's plans to allow the water level of Lake Oahe to fall 3 feet before June 1. The lake stretches from south-central North Dakota into South Dakota. The three states are seeking a preliminary injunction to force the corps to maintain the lake at its current depth until June 1. On Tuesday, the lake was measured at 1,588.4 feet above sea level. The judge said he would rule by noon Wednesday on the request. The lawsuit was filed Friday, and Tuesday was the only day of arguments. But Charles Findlay, a Justice Department attorney representing the corps, said Conmy had no authority to intervene in the agency's management of the river reservoirs. A judge may step in only if the corps acted in bad faith, and the agency has consulted the affected states extensively in making its management decisions, Findlay said. The three states' request would block shipping in the Missouri's navigation channel, which stretches from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis, Findlay argued. Keeping the river's level low also could disrupt the nesting of two federally protected rare birds, the piping plover and interior least tern, he said. Janklow countered that the birds would not be affected, and any harm to the shipping industry was exaggerated. Shipping contributes only $14 million in benefits to the system, compared to $67 million in benefits from fishing and recreation, Janklow said. South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson and North Dakota Gov. George Sinner attended Tuesday's hearing, as did attorneys representing Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas and Missouri. Officials of the three states said the lawsuit reflects growing anger at the corps' management of the entire Missouri system in a lingering drought, now entering its third year in the Dakotas.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Camarena Trial Will Be Most Interesting
DOC.TEXT: The trial of four Mexican men charged in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena may be ``one of the most interesting cases'' a jury could address, a judge told prospective jurors Tuesday. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie urged the panelists to ``search your hearts and minds'' before asking to be excused from the case because of hardship. The trial, focusing on the internationally sensitive 1985 slaying of the Drug Enforcement Administration agent, is expected to last about two months. More than half of the 250 possible jurors said it would cause financial or other hardships to be away from their jobs for so long, but 118 prospects said they could serve and were given a 37-page questionnaire to fill out before actual questioning begins in court Wednesday. The questionnaire asked how much jurors had read or heard about the highly publicized Camarena investigation. They were asked to disclose whether they had read about 150 people, including Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro-Quintero and an array of alleged participants in Camarena's torture murder. The list also included the name of Elaine Shannon, author of a book on the case, which was turned into a TV movie. ``This case will perhaps be one of the most interesting cases on which you will have the opportunity to serve,'' the judge told jury candidates. Camarena, 31, was kidnapped off a Guadalajara, Mexico, street in February 1985. Testimony at the trial of three other men convicted in 1988 showed he was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before he was killed along with his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles outside Gudalajara. The killings were said to be in retribution for DEA seizures of 10,000 tons of marijuana. The four men on trial are Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a convicted Honduran drug kingpin; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer and Javier Vasquez Velasco, who is accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the Camarena slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country and more than 20 were convicted in Mexico. Jurors were also asked whether they had read about Antonio Garate Bustamante, a former Mexican police officer who said he arranged the abduction of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, another defendant in the Camarena killing. The alleged kidnapping strained U.S. relations with Mexico, where President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has called the action a violation of Mexican sovereignty. Rafeedie, presiding over separate proceedings in the doctor's case, has demanded to know how Alvarez was brought here from Mexico and has set a May 25 hearing on the matter. Alvarez's trial has been indefinitely delayed pending that hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Cardinal Tomas O'Fiaich, Irish Nationalist, Dead at 66
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with new attribution, quotes, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Cardinal Tomas O'Fiaich, the primate of all Ireland and an ardent Irish nationalist, died Tuesday after falling ill on a pilgrimage to Lourdes, France, the church announced. He was 66. The cardinal, who was head of the church in both the Republic of Ireland and Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, died of cardiac arrest in a hospital at Toulouse, 95 miles from Lourdes, officials said. An announcement of the death, issued by the church's press office in both Belfast and Dublin, said O'Fiaich had appeared unwell to doctors accompanying the group of 600 pilgrims from his seat at Armagh in Northern Ireland. Lourdes is a Catholic shrine where a peasant girl reported a vision of the Virgin Mary in 1858. Miraculous cures have been reported there. The cardinal was admitted first to hospital in Lourdes, then flown by helicopter to Toulouse. Philippe Giovanni, director of the Rangueil Hospital there, said O'Fiaich died of a ``brutal cardiac arrest'' soon after being admitted. While calling for a unified Ireland and criticizing British policy in Northern Ireland, O'Fiaich, whose name was pronounced O'Fee, also castigated the violence of the Irish Republican Army. The predominantly Catholic outlawed guerrilla army seeks to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite it with the Irish Republic. ``You can't unite people with bombs and bullets,'' the cardinal once said. He was appointed spiritual leader of Ireland's 4 million Catholics in in 1977. Two years later Pope John Paul II made O'Fiaich one of the first cardinals of his papacy. Tributes to O'Fiaich poured in from some both sides of the Irish border. In Dublin, Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said he was ``devastated, ... deeply grieved.'' Britain's top official in Northern Ireland also expressed sadness. ``We did not always agree about everything, but he treated me with the greatest possible courtesy, friendliness and warmth,'' said Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke. However, the Rev. Martin Smyth, a legislator in the British Parliament for the Ulster Unionists, said his party hoped O'Fiaich's death will give Catholics ``a more positive spritual leadership and a less Republican stance.'' In Belfast, Ulster Television suspended scheduled programs for an hour and aired a religious program and a news program about the cardinal. O'Fiaich was born Thomas Fee in Cullyhanna, in south Armagh, within sight of the border with the Irish Republic. He changed his name to the Gaelic form as his love of the Irish language and nationalist sentiments developed. O'Fiaich retained close ties to Armagh, which has been dubbed ``bandit country'' because of the IRA activity. From the time he became primate, he spoke publicly of his wishes for a united Ireland. He visited IRA guerrillas in jail, called the British Army's fatal shooting of an Irish civilian murder, and said the border dividing Ireland was ``unnatural.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans Reported Arrested in Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans, one of them a Hong Kong-based publisher, have been arrested by Vietnamese authorities and are being held in Ho Chi Minh City, friends said Tuesday. Friends of publisher Michael Morrow, who said they have been in touch with Vietnamese authorities, said the two were being held on unspecified charges. Morrow's colleagues spoke on condition of anonymity. Official media in Vietnam have made no mention of the arrests. State Department spokesman Martin Judge said Tuesday in Washington that the department had been informed through unofficial channels of one American being arrested in Vietnam on April 20. He said he did not have that person's name, and knew nothing of other arrests. The embassy in Bangkok has applied to visit the arrested American, but Judge knows of no reply yet. ``We have had a travel advisory against travel to Vietnam since May 1988 because we cannot offer consular services and no third country represents U.S. interests in Vietnam,'' Judge noted. Friends of Morrow said he and an unidentified American were on trip to look into possible investments in Vietnam when they were arrested. A third person, French businessman Terry Rodzynk, was also arrested but subsequently released and allowed to leave the country, they said. The group was seized in the central Vietnam city of Danang and taken to Ho Chi Minh City, Morrow's friends said. Morrow has an association with Vietnam dating to the war, when he started a private news service in the country. He was captured by Communist forces during the war but was released after a short captivity. A longtime resident of Hong Kong, Morrow is the publisher of Petroleum News, an industry journal focused on Asia's energy sector. He also heads Asia 2000 Ltd., a publishing house, and a trading company in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Seventeen Share Home in Flooded Neighborhood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `The company ...' to CORRECT that neighbor's family has eight, sted seven.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR8; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The rain-swollen Arkansas River on Tuesday reached a record level, forcing residents into unusual living arrangements, such as the 17 people from four families sharing Sandy Pratt's house. ``I'm just glad they all have a place to go,'' said Mrs. Pratt, whose 13 neighbors moved in last week after the Arkansas River flooded. ``As long as we're dry on this hill, they have a place to eat and sleep and get clean.'' That means eating in shifts, stepping over sleeping bodies, standing in line for the bathroom and hearing the unending whirr of washer and dryer. The river reached a record 27.6 feet at Little Rock, 4 feet above flood stage, forcing an estimated 325 families from their homes. In Texas, the Trinity River caused the region's worst flooding in 80 years, with more than 1,600 people seeking shelter. Tuesday afternoon, Gov. Bill Clements authorized the Texas National Guard to send 50 soldiers to shore up a levee on the Red River near Texarkana that was weakening. Oklahoma's Lake Texoma, which crested 27 feet above normal, has forced hundreds of people to evacuate. In the past two weeks, floods contributed to the deaths of 13 people in Texas and one in Oklahoma. Officials said the flooding along the Arkansas River was the worst since a 1927 rampage that prompted construction of many of the levees along the river. Mrs. Pratt, who grew up in the neighborhood where she now lives with her husband and two children, said she was going grocery shopping Friday night when she learned relatives and others down the street were being told to leave. ``I told my mother, `Well, I guess I'd better go (to the grocery store) because it looks like I'm going to have company.''' The company included her parents, her sister's family of three and another neighbor's family of eight. The Wombles, the Irvings and the Carrolls spent the night packing their belongings into rented trucks. On Saturday morning, when the trucks were parked on higher ground, they moved in with the Pratts. ``You can imagine trying to cook for 17 people,'' said Mrs. Pratt. ``We eat in shifts.'' Her sister, Vicki Carroll, added: ``We all kind of line up around the coffee pot and at the refrigerator.'' Many of their meals have been provided by the Salvation Army, which has a vendor's truck set up at the end of the block. ``As soon as they see us up, they come down with sausage and biscuits and coffee,'' Mrs. Pratt said. Sleeping bags, the couch and a pop-up camper in the back yard have been used for bed space. ``There were bodies everywhere,'' said Eunice Womble, Mrs. Pratt's mother. Getting into the bathroom also has been difficult. ``It's almost time to go to bed by the time we all get clean,'' she said. ``We have two bathrooms, so that helped.'' The biggest problem has been laundry, she said. ``My washer and dryer ... go constantly.'' The experience has not been unpleasant, they said. ``We had a cookout,'' said Mrs. Pratt. ``We had a big kickball game in the back yard,'' said Mrs. Womble. ``And my flower bed,'' Mrs. Pratt said with a laugh. ``They used my flower bed as a base.'' Officials say it could be Thursday before evacuated families are allowed to return home. ``We were in the midst of remodeling,'' said Mrs. Carroll. ``My husband took a two-week vacation, and this is what he got.'' Her husband, Steve, and father, Forrest Womble, helped National Guardsmen, city crews and other volunteers who worked through the night Monday to reinforce levees. Mrs. Carroll said she recorded it all on videotape. ``My husband said we can look back on it and laugh,'' she said. ``I didn't think it was too funny at the time, but maybe later.''

DOC.HEAD: PLO Application to Join World Health Organization On Hold
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen European and moderate Arab countries on Tuesday urged that the PLO's bid to make its self-declared State of Palestine a full voting member of the World Health Organization be put on hold indefinitely. In a draft resolution to the U.N. agency's annual assembly, the countries, including Egypt and Morocco, called on WHO's director-general, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, to continue studying the issue and report back ``at an appropriate time.'' But Iraq indicated it would try to force a vote on the issue. The move followed renewed U.S. threats to cut off all funding to WHO if its 167-nation assembly approved the application by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Such a move would boost the PLO's campaign for international recognition of its state. The State Department maintains the PLO is not entitled to full membership in any U.N. organization because it does not meet internationally recognized criteria of statehood, including control of territory. ``We should use political means to attain health objectives, but not health issues to serve political ends,'' Nakajima told delegates attending the two-week meeting that opened Monday. Although the assembly is due to discuss issues such as nutrition, poverty and health risks from hazardous wastes, the PLO application topped the agenda. It was scheduled for consideration Thursday. Nakajima has warned that WHO would have to slash all its important programs if the United States withdrew its funding, including the fight against tropical diseases, AIDS, and child vaccination programs. The United States is pledged to contribute $78 million to WHO this year, or 25 percent of the agency's regular budget. Washington also provides much of the funding for programs outside the regular budget, such as the campaign against AIDS. A U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said funds would stop immediately if the PLO were admitted. The draft resolution was sponsored by Austria, Denmark, Egypt, Finland, France, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Morocco, New Zealand, Oman, Pakistan, Portugal, Senegal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. More than 100 countries, many in the Third World, have recognized the independent Palestinian state declared by the movement's parliament-in-exile, the Palestine National Council, in November 1988. The Palestinian state roughly encompasses the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip though no boundaries have been declared. In a letter to Nakajima last month, the PLO warned the assembly against yielding to ``pressure and political blackmail by the United States and Israel.'' The PLO currently has non-voting observer status with WHO.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Vow To Continue Protests, Disgusted Students Look To Summer
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: Blacks who paralyzed Selma's school system after a white-dominated vote to fire the city's first black superintendant promised Tuesday to keep the protest going, despite his decision to quit for $150,000. Schools Superintendant Norward Roussell, 55, announced his resignation Monday after accepting $150,000 to drop a $10 million lawsuit against the white-majority school board contesting his dismissal as racial discrimation. ``This issue in Selma is larger than Dr. Roussell,'' said Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, a black protest leader who on Sunday completed a five-day jail term for contempt of court. ``We don't see this as a sell-out,'' he said of the settlement in this focal point of the civil rights movement. ``It's a victory for us.'' In December, the board voted 6-5, along racial lines, not to renew Roussell's contract when it expires June 30, the end of his third year. Roussell's supporters contend he was fired because of his race. His critics cite an evaluation that said he lacked managerial skills. Roussell said the evaluation was unsubstantiated. The months since the board's vote have been marked by marches, picketing, sit-ins and school boycotts by black adults and students who said Roussell's firing was racist. All schools in the 6,000-student public system were closed for about a week in February. Dozens of people have been arrested for violating court orders limiting the protests. But daily the demonstrators have returned to City Hall. Varner said he and others would continue to push for an elected school board to preside over a public school system that now is 80 percent black. The system has shrunk to about 5,700 students after some 300, mostly white, pulled out amid the racial turmoil. The school board currently is appointed by the City Council, which also has a white majority. This city of 25,000 is about half white, half black. ``The majority of the people here are good people who want the best for themselves and want the best for their children,'' Roussell said in an interview prior to his resignation. ``But like any town, you've got politics and racism. Racism feeds the politics, and politics feeds the racism.'' Conflict-weary students hoped to be free of both during the upcoming summer vacation. ``It used to be perfect,'' said Carlos Browning, a black, 17-year-old, Selma High School junior. ``Now it seems like white kids are afraid to talk to blacks.'' The three-month vacation, which begins June 1, ``will give everyone time to cool down so things can get back to normal next year,'' Browning said. Jim Walker, a white senior who transferred from Selma High School to Central High School in Tuscaloosa, said blacks and whites ``got along great'' until the protests. ``I had to get away from all this mess,'' said Walker. ``This was supposed to be my best year and it's been my worst.'' Roussell's departure left at least one school board member wondering if anyone can handle the racial conflicts and please the whole community. ``I would be afraid to apply for this job,'' said Sheila Okoye, a black board member who had opposed Roussell's firing. ``Whoever gets the job is going to be in hot water. ... If a black one comes in and all the white people like him, the black people are going to wonder what he's selling,'' she said. ``If he's a white one, black people are going to feel that he's getting the job because he'll do what the white community wants him to do.'' A white board member, Dick Bean, said he feels the board can now ``move forward in a positive manner.'' He said an interim superintendent would be chosen and a search begun for a permanent one.

DOC.HEAD: Families of Hostages Pressuring Rushdie in Hopes of Winning Releases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 5 grafs SUB for 11th graf, `Mann, who' to UPDATE with possible Runcie-Moslem meeting, Mrs. Mann's comment. Picks up 12th graf, `Peter Temple-Morris ...' with editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Hopes raised by the release of two American hostages in Lebanon have turned to frustration for families of British captives, and some are demanding a conciliatory gesture from author Salman Rushdie. David Waite, the brother of hostage Terry Waite, has said Rushdie should apologize for his book, ``The Satanic Verses,'' which many Moslems consider blasphemous to Islam. The father of hostage John McCarthy was quoted as saying ``The Satanic Verses'' should never have been published. Rushdie's defenders say it is unfair to blame the British author for the plight of the hostages. Most of them were kidnapped before the publication of the book in September 1988 and the subsequent decree issued against the author by Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The religious decree, or ``fatwa,'' called for Rushdie's death on grounds the book blasphemed Islam. Despite this, a Gallup poll published Tuesday in The Daily Telegraph found broad public support for some sort of gesture from Rushdie. Of the people queried, 58 percent said Rushdie should apologize to Moslems, and 36 percent thought he should withdraw the book. Rushdie has been in hiding since Khomeini's decree was issued in February 1989. In an interview from hiding last month with BBC radio, he said it was not his reponsibility to end the controversy over the book. ``The people who are attacking me have the business of solving the problem,'' he said. He also told the interviewer the question was ``unfair,'' sounding exasperated. Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain after Khomeini's decree. Syria was a broker in gaining the release of the two Americans last month _ Robert Polhill and Frank Reed. However, Britain broke relations with Syria in 1986 over the Syrian Embassy's alleged role in attempting to bomb an Israeli airliner in London. The lack of diplomatic ties with Iran and Syria has been cited as a key obstacle to the release of Waite, the archbishop of Canterbury's special envoy; journalist John McCarthy; retired pilot Jack Mann; and teacher Brian Keenan,who has dual Irish and British citizenship. Paul Handley, Archbishop Robert Runcie's press secretary, said Tuesday night the Anglican leader is considering meeting Sayed Quddus, a leading British Moslem, who says Waite is alive and well. Quddus, president of a Moslem group in Bradford, northern England, requested the meeting. He said he was told in Iran recently that while Waite was well and in good spirits, he would be freed only in exchange for Rushdie. Mann, who disappeared May 12, 1989, is the only British hostage to disappear since the Rushdie controversy erupted. Mann's wife, Sunnie, 78, flew to London Tuesday and said she thought the British government could be doing more to help the missing Britons. ``I think they could be doing a bit more to help the hostages, but I am not in politics _ it is not my line,'' she said at London's Heathrow airport. Peter Temple-Morris, a Conservative Party lawmaker who chairs the Anglo-Iranian Parliamentary group, said last week that Rushdie should consider ``the effect he is having on British-Iranian relations and also the effect he is having on the British hostages.'' He urged Rushdie not to further postpone a decision about publishing a paperback edition of ``The Satanic Verses'' _ either publish and get it over with, or cancel it, Temple-Morris said. George Foulkes, the opposition Labor Party's foreign affairs spokesman, said if Rushdie scrapped the paperback and apologized, it would help the hostages. Rushdie has said he wants a paperback, but publisher Viking Penguin has not announced a decision. Frances D'Souza, who chairs the International Committee for the Defense of Salman Rushdie and His Publishers, said the hostages' families have been frustrated by the government's lack of a ``strong, energetic, forceful policy.'' She said she understood the families' ``tremendous frustrations'' but warned that giving in to Iran's demands on Rushdie ``would set a dangerous precedent. What will they ask next, that we extradite Mr. Rushdie?'' An editorial Tuesday in The Independent newspaper said Rushdie has already apologized for the ``shock and pain'' caused by his novel. This was a reference to an essay Rushdie wrote in which he expressed regret for the tensions the book had caused. In the essay that appeared in the Independent on Sunday weekly newspaper, Rushdie said he never intended to blaspheme Islam but recognized that many Moslems were shocked and pained by his book. Among the scenes Moslems found offensive were one in which prostitutes are given the names of the wives of the prophet Mohammed. The book also implies that Mohammed wrote the Koran, the Moslem holy book, instead of it being dictated by Allah.

DOC.HEAD: Abuses Continue in Turkey, Amnesty International Says
DOC.TEXT: Widespread torture and other abuses continue unabated in Turkey six months after the government proposed new human rights safeguards, according to a report by Amnesty International. ``In early 1990, thousands of people remained imprisoned for political reasons, including hundreds of prisoners of conscience convicted for their non-violent political or religious activities,'' the international human rights organization said in a report being released Wednesday. ``Among them are members of political organizations, trade unions and Kurdish groups as well as journalists and religious activists. The use of torture continues to be widespread and systematic, in some cases resulting in death.'' Turkey ratified the United Nations Convention against Torture in 1988, the report said. In September and November last year, the government announced proposals governing length of detention, access to lawyers and protection for prisoners of conscience. None of those proposals has been enacted. Under the government proposal, the maximum detention period under police custody would be reduced from 15 days to four to 10 days, though longer detention would be permitted under emergency legislation. The government also proposed abolishing the death penalty for 13 categories of offenses, but not for murder and political offenses that produce the most death sentences, the report said. ``While these draft amendments, if passed, would represent a step in the right direction, they nevertheless would fall short of international standards in important respects,'' Amnesty International said. The report included testimony from several prisoners who said they were tortured with beatings on the soles of their feet, electric shocks, showers of ice cold water and being hung by their arms. ``Torture is still routine even among those detained for only a few days,'' Amnesty reported. The testimony of prisoners shows ``anyone is at risk from torture in Turkey, particularly if held on political grounds,'' the report said. ``Many prisoners sign confessions under torture which are then used as evidence against them, in violation of international standards,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: `Hamlet,' Starring Kevin Kline, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: There wasn't much doubt that Kevin Kline could play Hamlet. He did it four years ago at the New York Shakespeare Festival in an odd, uneven production directed by Liviu Ciulei. Its biggest plus was Kline, who offered a thoughtful, clear-spoken but low-keyed portrait of the Danish prince. Now ``Hamlet'' and Kline are together again for a second time as part of the festival's six-year marathon of all of Shakespeare's plays. In addition to playing the title character, Kline now has taken on the task of directing the play himself. Kline the director may not yet be the equal of Kline the actor, but he has done a respectable job. This is a no-nonsense, cleanly performed ``Hamlet,'' done with a minimum of production clutter. In this version, the text is all, and no one speaks it better than Kline. Kline the actor has improved since his last outing. He's more relaxed, freer and a little looser with the play's tragedy _ and moments of comedy _ than he was in 1986. Yet he doesn't neglect the poetry that is such an important part of the role. This Hamlet has more passion than Kline's previous incarnation. He grieves openly for his dead father. His outrage at his mother's marriage to his uncle is fiercer. His relentless humiliation of Ophelia is more unnerving, almost sadistic. His wit and bitter sense of humor is more sharply defined, particularly in the gravedigger's scene when he ruminates on the nature of life and death. And his realization of what he must do to avenge his father's death is more carefully plotted out. It builds appropriately to a bloody climax that seems inevitable from what has gone before. Kline has staged the play simply with few props and the barest of stage sets, just a burgundy curtain hanging on a back wall. The costumes are modern dress. When Hamlet first appears _ wearing a buttoned-up white shirt with a high collar and a black suit _ he looks like a refugee from one of New York's downtown rock clubs. Claudius, done up in red sash and a blue military uniform, resembles an admiral in dry dock. And Gertrude wears a ballgown that would be just as appropriate at the Plaza as at Elsinore. There are a few awkward touches. The play-within-a-play is oddly staged with Claudius and Gertrude on the platform with the actors who are reenacting Claudius' crime. And the duel at the end of the evening seems cramped on the Anspacher Theater's small playing area. The fight almost careens into the audience. For the most part, the play has been cast with remarkable care. Brian Murray is an unctuous Claudius, who nevertheless manages to generate some sympathy for his nasty predictament. Dana Ivey _ in the play's most thankless role _ is a regal, unyielding Gertrude, while Diane Venora is a vulnerable Ophelia able to make the character's famous mad scene shattering rather than silly. Best of all is Joseph Sommer's Polonius, priggish without being petulant and whose death can be seen as a loss even by Hamlet. Kline is a generous actor-director, allowing each performer, down to the smallest role, a chance to shine. But what makes this an enriching ``Hamlet'' is Kline's fidelity to the play itself as an actor and now as a director.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Murder Suspect A `Jerk,' Not a Killer, Lawyer Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with two grafs to UPDATE with juries retiring for night; SUBS last graf to CORRECT that Mondello charged with riot sted aggravated harassment, detail counts.
DOC.TEXT: A white teen-aged murder defendant was a ``jerk'' to pick up a bat and go after four young blacks to protect his neighborhood, but it was not his fault one of the blacks was shot to death, his lawyer said Tuesday. Prosecutors, however, said the defendant, Keith Mondello, was accountable because he organized the white mob that surrounded and trapped Yusuf Hawkins, 16, in the moments before Hawkins was shot Aug. 23 in Brooklyn. After final arguments Tuesday, the jury was charged by Justice Thaddeus Owens of Brooklyn's state Supreme Court. Jurors began deliberating at 5:30 p.m. A second panel already was weighing the case against Joseph Fama, the accused gunman in the Hawkins killing. The cases were tried in the same courtroom but heard by separate juries. Both juries retired for the night at about 7 p.m. Fama and Mondello, both 19, would face 25 years to life in prison if convicted of murder. Outside the courthouse Tuesday, about a dozen protesters chanting ``Justice for Yusuf'' were arrested for disorderly conduct. In his closing argument, Mondello's lawyer Stephen Murphy said the incident was not motivated by race and sought to place the blame on a local young woman, Gina Feliciano, for inviting black and Hispanic ``drug-dealer'' friends to a party in the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood. He said Mondello believed the blacks were coming to attack the local whites. ``Everyone's going to say Gina's not the cause of this. That's garbage,'' Murphy said. ``She put the wheels in motion.'' But Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns said it was preposterous for Mondello and the gang he assembled ``to believe they had the right to arm themselves and go out on a public street'' to protect their neighborhood. Burns said the bat-wielding white mob stalked and surrounded Hawkins and his three black friends, and pushed Hawkins into a doorway. After one of the whites, allegedly Fama, pulled an automatic pistol and fired four shots, the white mob scattered without pausing to help their fatally wounded victim, Burns said. ``Like a mob they came, like a mob they left. Group courage masking individual cowardice,'' he said. Burns charged that Mondello organized, armed and set in motion the actions of the mob. ``That's depraved indifference to human life,'' he said, urging a murder conviction for Mondello. ``He's responsible under the law.'' Murphy called Hawkins' shooting ``a horrible thing,'' but argued that Mondello, who admitted he was at the scene with a baseball bat, had nothing to do with it. ``As they were walking away, some lunatic comes out and shoots him,'' Murphy said. He said Mondello was foolish to believe Miss Feliciano's threat and foolish to sign a police statement confessing to his role in the attack. ``He is a jerk,'' Murphy said. ``He let her make a jerk out of him. He let the cops make a jerk out of him. But it's no crime to be a jerk.'' Mondello is charged with two counts of murder, two counts of manslaughter, three counts of unlawful imprisonment, three counts of menacing, one count of riot, four counts of discrimination and one count of weapon possession.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Semitism Seen Rising in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf: ``The likely,'' with margin of error
DOC.TEXT: Anti-Semitism is rising in the Soviet Union in the age of glasnost, according to two surveys released to Congress on Tuesday. In one survey, 77 percent of the people polled in Moscow said they thought most of their countrymen were anti-Jewish and 60 percent believed some Soviets harbored such feelings. The survey, released by the American Jewish Committee, found 48 percent of the respondents believe anti-Jewish sentiment is increasing in the Soviet Union, while 44 percent said such feelings were unchanged. Five percent said anti-Semitism was declining. The poll, of 506 randomly chosen Moscow adults, found 91 percent of the respondents thought Jews should be alllowed to decide for themselves whether to emigrate. The American Jewish Committee, along with the National Science Foundation, the University of Houston and the Soviet Academy of Sciences, paid for the poll. The likely uncertainty in a sample of 506 people would be more than four percentage points either way, according to a standard statistical calculation. Another survey, conducted by the Jewish Research Center of the Soviet Sociological Association in Moscow, focused on about 500 Soviet Jewish leaders. About 73 percent said they had experienced or witnessed an act of anti-Semitism in the last six months of 1989. The polls were released at a hearing of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus. Richard Schifter, the assistant secretary of state, said official anti-Semitism has declined since Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev instituted reforms in 1986. At the same time, liberalization inside the Soviet Union has allowed ``groups pressing the anti-Semitic case'' to become more visible. The number of Jews leaving the Soviet Union has increased dramatically, with thousands leaving the country each month. In 1989, 71,000 Jews emigrated, up from 914 in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, Irish Nationalist, Dead at 66
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs, `However, the' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Paisley comment. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `In Belfast...'. CORRECTS style throughout on O Fiaich, no apostrophe
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, the primate of all Ireland and an ardent Irish nationalist, died Tuesday after falling ill on a pilgrimage to Lourdes, France, the church announced. He was 66. The cardinal, who was head of the church in both the Republic of Ireland and Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, died of cardiac arrest in a hospital at Toulouse, 95 miles from Lourdes, officials said. An announcement of the death, issued by the church's press office in both Belfast and Dublin, said O Fiaich had appeared unwell to doctors accompanying the group of 600 pilgrims from his seat at Armagh in Northern Ireland. Lourdes is a Catholic shrine where a peasant girl reported a vision of the Virgin Mary in 1858. Miraculous cures have been reported there. The cardinal was admitted first to hospital in Lourdes, then flown by helicopter to Toulouse. Philippe Giovanni, director of the Rangueil Hospital there, said O Fiaich died of a ``brutal cardiac arrest'' soon after being admitted. While calling for a unified Ireland and criticizing British policy in Northern Ireland, O Fiaich, whose name was pronounced O'Fee, also castigated the violence of the Irish Republican Army. The predominantly Catholic outlawed guerrilla army seeks to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite it with the Irish Republic. ``You can't unite people with bombs and bullets,'' the cardinal once said. He was appointed spiritual leader of Ireland's 4 million Catholics in in 1977. Two years later Pope John Paul II made O Fiaich one of the first cardinals of his papacy. Tributes to O Fiaich poured in from some both sides of the Irish border. In Dublin, Irish Prime inister Charles Haughey said he was ``devastated, ... deeply grieved.'' Britain's top official in Northern Ireland also expressed sadness. ``We did not always agree about everything, but he treated me with the greatest possible courtesy, friendliness and warmth,'' said Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke. But hardline Protestant leader Ian Paisley of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, said O Fiaich was ``the mallet of Rome against the Protestants of Northern Ireland.'' He claimed O Fiaich had ``made an outrageous statement that the majority of bigotry in Ulster stemmed from the Protestant section of the community'' and added: ``He did not seem to realize that the IRA, which is carrying out the most atrocious of outrages ... were the people who needed to be indicted with bigotry.'' In Belfast, Ulster Television suspended scheduled programs for an hour and aired a religious program and a news program about the cardinal. O Fiaich was born Thomas Fee in Cullyhanna, in south Armagh, within sight of the border with the Irish Republic. He changed his name to the Gaelic form as his love of the Irish language and nationalist sentiments developed. O Fiaich retained close ties to Armagh, which has been dubbed ``bandit country'' because of the IRA activity. From the time he became primate, he spoke publicly of his wishes for a united Ireland. He visited IRA guerrillas in jail, called the British Army's fatal shooting of an Irish civilian murder, and said the border dividing Ireland was ``unnatural.''

DOC.HEAD: Frito-Lay Must Pay Singer Tom Waits $2.5 Million for Imitating Him
DOC.TEXT: Frito-Lay inc. must pay singer Tom Waits almost $2.5 million for imitating his gravelly style in a radio commercial hawking corn chips, a federal court jury decided Tuesday. ``Now I have a fence and a gate around my voice,'' Waits said following the verdict. The jury deliberated abut eight hours over two days before deciding Waits should receive $2,475,000. The entertainer's lawyer had asked for $1.5 million. ``This was a humiliation to Mr. Waits. They picked on the wrong guy,'' said Waits attorney Howard King. Waits, 40, was portrayed as a street poet with a loyal following who had refused all offers to do commercials, turning down such corporations as Honda, Kraft and Burger King. Many of his songs are paeans to gritty life at the margin, describing nighthawks at the diner, truck drivers, hard drinkers and prostitutes in dingy worlds filled with cigarette smoke. Frito-Lay attorney Anthony Liebig argued Waits wasn't well-known enough to be imitated. ``There is no question he is widely known to extreme insiders in the rock industry but that has nothing to do with being known by the broader segment of the population,'' Liebig said. Waits sued Frito-Lay and ad agency Tracy-Locke Inc., which hired Dallas singer Stephen Carter to launch ads for its Salsa Rio Doitos in September 1988. He sued in U.S. District Court under federal trademark laws and under a California common law, established in a case involving Bette Midler, that outlaws imitating a professional singer's distinctive voice for commercial use. ``I was shocked,'' Waits testified during the trial when asked his reaction to hearing the corn chip commercial for the first time. ``I think he studied me closely. I heard things I do with my voice that I've never heard anyone else do, a certain intimacy.'' Waits said Carter copied ``my phrasing, my timbre, my voice, my approach.'' ``It embarrassed me,'' he testified. ``I had to call my friends and tell them, `If you hear this thing, please be informed it's not me.' I was on the phone for days. And people kept calling me.'' Waits has been featured on such albums as ``Franks Wild Years,'' ``Rain Dogs,'' ``Swordfish Trombones'' and ``Closing Time.'' He has also been an opening performer for such acts as Frank Zappa. The singer-composer also contributed to the motion picture score of ``One From the Heart,'' and he appeared in the films ``Rumble Fish'' and ``Cotton Club.''

DOC.HEAD: Problems with Cooling System Could Delay Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 6 grafs after final graf to UPDATE with simulated shuttle accident.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's scheduled launch next week with the $100 million Astro observatory could be delayed days or even weeks because of a problem with the shuttle's cooling system, NASA said Tuesday. Engineers ``need time to assess the situation,'' said NASA administrator Richard Truly. ``I don't see it to be an earth-shattering problem.'' The launch had been scheduled for May 16 or May 17. If a valve that doesn't seem to be working properly has to be changed, NASA would prefer doing that at the launch pad, Truly said. The procedure has never been performed there, however, and officials are uncertain how many days that might take. Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of prelaunch operations for Columbia, estimated it would be a ``10-day to two-week hit.'' ``It's a big job,'' Murrah said. ``You would have to drain the system (of coolant) and clean it.'' Rolling the shuttle back to its hangar to change the valve or another part of the cooling system, such as a filter, would mean an even longer delay, Truly said. Two shuttles already are in the hangar _ Atlantis and the newly returned Discovery _ and work on them would be disrupted, he said. ``It's hard for me to speculate because I don't know if we have to change anything,'' Truly said. But, he added, ``We'll think a long time before we decide not to fix it on the pad.'' The valve in question, in one of Columbia's two Freon cooling loops, controls the proportion and rate of Freon distributed between the crew cabin heat exchanger and the cooling system for payloads. Engineers on Sunday saw an unexplained change in the flow of coolant, NASA said. ``The system is still operating with a reduced flow, and engineers are reviewing data on the system and conducting trouble-shooting activities,'' the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in a statement. ``In parallel with trouble-shooting, managers are also assessing what would be required to change the valve and where that activity would be performed,'' the agency said. NASA managers are reviewing the situation at the two-day Flight Readiness Review meeting, which began Tuesday. The agency had hoped to confirm a launch date by the end of the meeting Wednesday. Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the first Spacelab mission since 1985. Four astronomers who are part of the seven-man crew will operate the on-board observatory, which will probe sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. Up to 100 mission managers and other officials, meanwhile, went through a simulated shuttle accident Tuesday to test emergency procedures and better prepare for a real-life disaster. ``It worked better than we thought it would,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. ``There were very few lessons.'' During the 1{-hour exercise at Kennedy Space Center, television monitors showed a shuttle returning to the launch site shortly after liftoff. The shuttle in the video veered off the runway, injuring two of five astronauts. The simulated problems included main engine shutdown less than two minutes into the flight, a leaking power unit, inability to purge the shuttle's hydrogen lines and excessive winds. Such failures, when combined, are ``extremely unlikely,'' Lenoir said. Truly said a series of simulated shuttle accidents are planned ``to make sure the communications loops are in place.'' An accident on board an orbiting shuttle will be simulated at Johnson Space Center in Houston around late June, followed by a mock crash landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., in August.

DOC.HEAD: 80 Contras Turn in Weapons on First Day of Demobilization
DOC.TEXT: Eighty Contra rebels turned in their weapons Tuesday to U.N. peacekeeping troops on the first day of their demobilization after nearly a decade of battle. A rebel leader said glumly: ``We did not have the ending we all wanted.'' The disarming was the first under an accord reached last week between the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and the leadership of the Nicaraguan Resistance, the Contra umbrella organization. Many of the weapons turned in Tuesday were old and rusty, and some of the fighters were pre-adolescent boys in olive-green uniforms several sizes too big. ``All beginnings are difficult,'' said Jose Pallais, vice minister of security forces in the new government. The U.S.-backed Contras had waged a nine-year insurgency against the leftist Sandinista government, defeated in elections by Mrs. Chamorro's coalition. She took office April 25. The disarmament process is to continue until June 10. Armando Orozco Guzman, 28, was the first Contra to formally disarm. He turned in a battered AK-47 assault rifle that he claimed he had used during his five years with the rebels. Orozco was photographed for a temporary identification card to use until he receives permanent identity papers from the Nicaraguan government. An Organization of American States representative registered his name and identification number. He picked up new, civilian clothes _ blue denim pants, a cotton short-sleeved shirt, underwear, socks and boots _ and turned in his uniform, which OAS representatives burned. Then he stood in line, waiting for a truck to take him home. U.N. officials said there are about 13,800 rebels in seven security zones that were set up throughout the country for the demobilization. El Almendro, a dozen wooden homes on the banks of a small river, is the assembly point in Security Zone 5, which straddles Rio San Juan province, 180 miles southeast of Managua. U.N. officials said there were about 1,600 Contras in Zone 5 but that more were coming in from the surrounding countryside. ``We did not have the ending we all wanted _ to do away with the uncertainty that remains in all the nation,'' Israel Galeano, the top Contra commander, told troops standing at attention under a broiling noon sun. ``But we will be strong as long as we remain united,'' he added. Galeano and other Contra leaders had objected strongly to Mrs. Chamorro's temporary retention of Gen. Humberto Ortega, brother of Sandinista former president Daniel Ortega, as commander-in-chief of Nicaragua's armed forces. The Contras had demanded Gen. Ortega and all other Sandinistas be removed from the military before they disarmed. That demand was not mentioned in the two-page accord signed Friday. ``Today, those who deposit their weapons should not be afraid _ you are not alone,'' Galeano told the troops. ``We are not doing it in exchange for a ration or a pair of shoes. We are doing it to help the nation.'' After fighting the Sandinistas since 1981, the Contras have agreed to return to civilian life while the Sandinistas remain in control of the army. Galeano told his soldiers those wanting to disarm voluntarily should step aside and do so. Only 80 of the assembled troops did. The OAS will provide non-lethal aid to the Contras after they hand their rifles over to the U.N. peacekeepers. Most of the weapons turned in were Soviet-made AK-47 rifles. In a warehouse, the rifles were being split into two or three pieces. Mines and grenades were to be destroyed elsewhere. On hand for the disarming were Gen. Agustin Quesada of Spain, who heads of U.N. peacekeeping troops, and representatives of Mrs. Chamorro and Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo.

DOC.HEAD: North Diaries Raise New Questions of Bush-Contra Links
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 12: ``The notebooks,'' with two grafs of background on what happened that day
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North met with then-Vice President George Bush a few hours after lying to the House intelligence committee about assisting the Nicaraguan Contras, an entry in North's White House diaries suggests. Portions of the diaries, released Tuesday, renew questions about whether Bush was more deeply involved in assisting the Contras than he has acknowledged. The 1,400 pages of notebook entries were obtained by a private group, the National Security Archive, as the result of a lawsuit filed against the government. U.S. intelligence agencies still are reviewing the remaining 1,200 pages of North's diaries. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The vice president's role in the Iran-Contra affair was completely examined in the congressional inquiry and we have nothing to add.'' Among the disclosures in the newly released material: _On Dec. 20, 1985, North laid out a ``3rd Country Solicitation Plan'' in support of the Contras that included trips by Bush to Honduras for an inauguration there. The plan also called for President Reagan to meet with Ecuador's president. Bush went to Honduras in January 1986 for the inauguration of President Jose Azcona Hoyo and Reagan met in Washington that month with Ecuadoran President Leon Febres Cordero. There was an elaborate plan in the Reagan administration to induce third countries to support the Contras, according to evidence introduced at North's trial last year. Bush has denied being involved in any ``quid pro quo'' arrangements providing additional economic and military aid to Honduras in exchange for allowing the Contras to use base camps there. _North's notes refer to a noon ``meeting w V.P.'' on Aug. 6, 1986. That would have been just 3{ hours after North lied to the House intelligence committee by denying he was supplying military advice to the Contras. North admitted he had lied when he took the witness stand at his own trial last year and when he testified in the recent trial of former National Security Adviser John Poindexter. Shortly before meeting with Bush, according to North's diaries, the White House aide had a ``meeting w Don Gregg,'' Bush's top national security aide. Gregg, now the U.S. ambassador to South Korea, has said he found out about North's involvement with the then-secret Contra resupply network on Aug. 8, 1986. Gregg asserts he didn't tell Bush about North's involvement until four months later, after the Iran-Contra affair became public. The notebooks provide offer no elaboration on the Aug. 6 meeting entries. But earlier that day, the diaries show, North got a call relating to problems in the Contra resupply operation. The call was about Felix Rodriguez, a former CIA operative sent to El Salvador with the blessing of Gregg. Rodriguez wound up working in North's Contra resupply network, but had a falling out with him. Rodriguez complained to Gregg on Aug. 8, 1986 that private operators were getting rich off of North's network. U.S. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said he didn't believe Congress had seen the page referring to Bush and Gregg and Aug. 6 meetings. ``It clearly at the very least would raise questions which ought to have been put at the time to appropriate witnesses,'' Hamilton said of the Aug. 6 entries. ``I would have if I had seen them.'' The former House Iran-Contra committee chairman suggested that a congressional investigation might be in order. ``If there is evidence relevant diaries were withheld, redacted or blacked out then I would want'' the House intelligence or judiciary committees to ``conduct an investigation,'' said Hamilton. ``I would expect the same of the independent counsel,'' he added, referring to the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office. _North and others in the U.S. government who aren't identified by name in his notes met with Panamanian Gen. Manuel Noriega in March 1984, where the discussion focused on the role of Costa Rica as a ``buffer'' between Nicaragua and Panama. _A March 6, 1984, entry focused on the ``vulnerabilities'' of Roberto D'Aubuisson, referring to his ``inability to deliver U.S. aid,'' saying he was a ``poor military officer'' and alleging he ``bumped off best friend.'' D'Aubuisson is the founder of Arena, now the ruling party in El Salvador. ``What were the quids and the quos with all these countries?'' Tom Blanton, deputy director of the archive, asked at a news conference. ``What did the vice president know and when did he know it? How much did Don Gregg know?'' The Justice Department released the new material from North's notebooks in response to a lawsuit filed by the group and by Public Citizen, a group founded by Ralph Nader. North still has the notebooks, but he supplied copies of 900 pages in 1987 to the Iran-Contra congressional committees. His lawyers heavily censored the portions they turned over to Congress. Asked whether North attorney Brendan Sullivan had withheld relevant material from the Iran-Contra congressional committees, Blanton said, ``You bet.'' Blanton cited a Jan. 5, 1984, entry stating, ``Costa Rica project approved,'' a reference to planned military exercises and other steps designed to counter the threat posed by Nicaragua. One entry said that then-Costa Rican President Alberto Monge ``needs to be stroked.'' Reached by telephone at his office, Sullivan said that he has not commented in the past on the Iran-Contra affair and would not do so now. ``This material should never have been withheld from Congress in the first place,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., whose Senate subcommittee investigated allegations of narcotics trafficking in connection with the Contras. Kerry said the executive branch should produce the remainder of the material ``without further delay.'' North turned over copies of all 2,600 pages of his notebooks to the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office at his trial last year. Prosecutors did not object to the turning over of the new batch of material to the private group.

DOC.HEAD: Indicted Mayor Wins Berth in Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with results, quotes from Usry; no pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Indicted Mayor James L. Usry won a runoff spot against City Councilman Jim Whelan in Tuesday's non-partisan mayoral election, setting up a June 12 runoff in this casino city. In final unofficial returns, Whelan had 3,481 votes, or 35 percent, to Usry's 2,906 votes, or 29 percent. Five other candidates split the rest. Since no candidate received more than 50 percent of the vote, the issue will be decided in a runoff. There are 35,400 year-round residents of the city. Usry, the 68-year-old president of the National Conference of Black Mayors, ran a low-budget campaign that sought to draw on his longtime strength in the black community. He was indicted Jan. 3 on charges he illegally accepted $6,500 in an alleged scheme to bring rolling chairs to the Boardwalk. He pleaded innocent and countered that the charges were trumped-up, in part because he is black. Usry said he was not disappointed at finishing second. He said the election proved he could overcome the ``taint and clouds'' of his indictment, and he predicted victory next month. Speaking of the alleged crimes, he said: ``The people know that did not happen. ... They also know we have a program to revitalize the city.'' Whelan, 41, a swimming instructor in a predominantly black school, came out attacking early in the campaign. He challenged Usry's record after a six-year tenure, and the was generally considered a front-runner throughout the race. Among the other candidates, Councilman Seth Grossman had 1,546 votes, former City Council President Hank Tyner had 1,105 votes and Assemblywoman Delores Cooper had 726 votes. Local activists Joseph Polillo got 172 and John McQueen Jr. had 67. Usry first took office in 1984 after defeating then-Mayor Michael Matthews in a recall election. Matthews later pleaded guilty to extorting $10,000 from an undercover FBI agent. Usry defeated Ms. Cooper in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's Environment Chief Vows to Develop the Amazon `Humanely'
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's environment czar vowed Tuesday to curb the destruction of the Amazon rain forest and to develop the biologically sensitive area in a ``rational, humane and ecological'' manner. ``We can't stop development and growth, but yes, we can make human occupation compatible with the survival of the planet,'' said National Environment Secretary Jose Lutzenberger. Lutzenberger, 64, outlined a plan for encouraging development and farming while preserving the unique ecological balance of the 2-million square mile rain forest. A world-renown ecologist, he said the government will introduce a program to revitalize the forest's soil through organic agricultural methods and to reduce the traditional style of slash-and-burn farming that has destroyed 200,000 square miles of the region. He said the Collor de Mello administration, which first took office in March, will also quadruple its fire-fighting efforts. ``In this way we will stop small farmers, impoverished by soil that only gives two or three harvests, from burning other tracts of the jungle,'' said Lutzenberger. He said the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank had expressed interest in financing the program but gave no details. Slash-and-burn farmers clear large tracts of unused land by setting fires and then plant crops until the soil is exhausted. They then move on to fresh land. Lutzenberger said the burnings are now monitored by satellites that can detect even small brush fires. He said forest rangers in helicopters are used to catch and fine violators. He said Brazil will also explore alternative energy sources such as solar, wind and biomass energy instead of building the huge hydroelectric dams that were popular in recent decades. Environmentalists have opposed the dams saying they flood huge tracts of Amazon land, killing trees and animals while providing few benefits for the thousands of Indians and Brazilian farmers living in the area. He specifically singled out the Itaipu dam, built by Brazil and Paraguay on the Parana River dividing the countries and the Tucurui project in the Amazon jungle. ``Itaipu only produces at 60 percent of its capacity and we don't even know what to do with so much energy,'' Lutzenberger said. ``Tucurui generates electricity for large aluminum factories that export minerals at low cost and the Amazon natives don't see any benefit.'' Lutzenberger said Brazil should scrap plans for large dams in the rain forest and concentrate instead on promoting small generators and floating river turbines financed and run by local municipalities and private businessmen. The appointment of Lutzenberger, an agronomist educated in the United States, was seen as a victory for conservationists, who claim Brazil has traditionally done little to preserve the Amazon. ``There are many people who would like to see the jungle disappear to raise cattle, but they won't do it with my approval,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Prize for Indian, Australian at Buckingham Palace
By GRAHAM HEATHCOTE
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, one of the richest prizes in the world, was presented Tuesday by Prince Philip to Indian lawyer Baba Amte and Australian biologist Charles Birch. Amte, 75, a Hindu whose work for the sick crosses India's religious divisions, and Birch, 72, a retired Sydney professor who has explored links between science and religious faith, shared the 410,000 pounds ($684,000). Amte founded hospitals and centers for lepers, blind children, the deaf and other handicapped of all India's religions. He also founded centers for Untouchables, the lowest Hindu caste called Harijans. Birch, a member of the Uniting Church of Australia composed of Methodists, Presbyterians and Congregationalists, was at Buckingham Palace for the brief private ceremony. He was accompanied by Sir John M. Templeton, the U.S.-born investment counselor who founded and funds the annual prize. It was first awarded in 1973 to Mother Teresa of Calcutta. The Templeton prize money is adjusted every year to keep it ahead of the Nobel prize, worth 200,000 pounds ($334,000), said the Rev. Wilbert Forker, Templeton's press spokesman. Amte was unable to travel and Philip handed the check to his son, Dr. Vikas Amte, a leprologist. The son said Amte has not decided what he will do with the prize but in the past has given about $100,000 in money from prizes ``to causes for saving the environment.'' Vikas Amte said his father was not religious, but he believed in God and saw God in human beings. ``He has often said it isn't hard to establish a relationship with God who is invisible and unknown but it's often very difficult to establish a relationship with your neighbor,'' the son said. The prize citation for Birch called him an ``original thinker (who) uses modern discoveries in natural science to expand man's understanding of God as designer and creator of the universe and its creatures.'' Birch said he will use his prize partly to fund an annual lecture at the University of Sydney on human aspects of science and technology; will help a program on science and faith at the School of Theology in Claremont, Calif., and a Christian social ethics project in Geneva. Templeton, 77, a Presbyterian elder from Nashville, Tenn., is a British citizen living in Nassau, Bahamas. He started the prize because the Nobel prizes neglected religion. The Templeton Prize has been awarded to 16 Christians, two Hindus, a Buddhist and a Moslem. Templeton told a news conference the prize was ``not for saintliness nor good works ... but is limited to people who have done something of an original nature that led to a great increase in man's love of God or men's understanding of God.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Summons Witnesses in Salvadoran Massacre of Priests
DOC.TEXT: A judge said Tuesday he again summoned two cadets who may have crucial knowledge involving the massacre of six Jesuit priests to testify in the trial of nine military men accused of the murders. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday the Bush administration has told President Alfredo Cristiani the murder investigation is ``a serious matter'' that could affect U.S. attitudes on continued aid to El Salvador. Up to now, the only evidence against the accused is testimony by other suspects in the case. Under Salvadoran law, such testimony is not considered valid. A squad of uniformed soldiers roused the victims _ the six priests as well as their housekeeper and her daughter _ from their home at the Central American University campus on the night of Nov. 16. The eight were shot to death. The crimes were committed during a monthlong offensive by leftist guerrillas, in a military-held area which was under a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Col. Guillermo Benavides, commander of the Military School at the time, and three lieutenants and five soldiers were charged with the murders. Pretrial evidence purported to show the death squad left from the school. Four cadets were on guard duty at the school that night and may be able to shed light on who left and who entered the building then. But when Judge Ricardo Zamora of the 4th Criminal Court asked them to appear as witnesses, the army told him they had been sent out of the country on a study mission. Cadets Jose Wilfredo Aguilar Alvarado, Cesar Moises Rivera Perez and Raul Galan Hernandez are at Fort Benning, Ga., and Erick Othmaro Granados is at a military school in Panama. Zamora said Tuesday he again summoned Aguilar Alvarado and Granados to testify. A court source told The Associated Press Monday that the military reported as ``disappeared'' a guard logbook at the school that the court wanted as evidence, and Benavides denied having a personal diary he was supposed to have kept. The source insisted on anonymity. Zamora said Tuesday that two officers summoned to testify have not appeared, adding that it has become virtually impossible for the case ``to be presented to the jury, because of lack of evidence.'' At least one retired officer said publicly that Benavides acted under orders from higher ups to assassinate the Jesuits, whom the pro-government press had been attacking as leftist sympathizers for weeks before the murders. More than 72,000 people have been killed since guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, launched a war for power a decade ago. Most victims were civilians suspected of being leftist sympathizers, slain by rightist death squads with links to the military. The FMLN announced Tuesday it will continue attacking military targets until an accord is reached with Cristiani's rightist government to end the war. A rebel news release said the FMLN recently presented U.N. official Alvaro de Soto, who is acting as a go-between with the Cristiani government, an outline of their demands for ending the war. In the document, rebel leaders reiterated earlier demands for political reforms and that the size of the military be reduced and its command structure purged of rightist officers.

DOC.HEAD: Separatist Party Declares Victory After Preliminary Count
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a separatist party declared victory Tuesday after preliminary results showed his Croatian Democratic Union had won at least 158 seats in the 356-seat state legislature. The final round of parliamentary elections, held Sunday and Monday, was Croatia's first free vote in 50 years. With about 70 percent of the 2 million votes counted, the Party for Democratic Reform, which ruled the republic as the Croatian Communist Party before the elections, had 42 seats. A centrist coalition of independents and other smaller parties won six seats, with distribution of the rest still uncertain. Democratic Union leader Franjo Tudjman said his party's first task would be ``to prepare a new Western-style constitution for Croatia and to discuss Yugoslavia's future'' with the other five republics in the Yugoslav federation. Tudjman's center-right party advocates Croatia's independence from the rest of Yugoslavia. Its apparent victory is likely to exacerbate political and ethnic tensions with other republics, particularly Serbia, which remains under orthodox Communist rule. The 66-year-old Tudjman, who was once the Yugoslav army's youngest general, spent almost five years in jail in the 1970s for Croatian nationalism and ``hostile activities'' against the state. He said he was once a ``true Communist believer, but now I'm glad that Croatia is free of Marxist one-party hell.'' Tudjman's campaign was based largely on nationalist sentiment and the appeal for independence. Under his formula, Yugoslavia's six republics would become independent states under a loose confederation and would maintain relations only in areas of common interest. Croatia followed the neighboring republic of Slovenia in holding multiparty elections after more than four decades of one-party rule. Macedonia and Bosnia-Hercegovina are planning free elections later this year. Communist-ruled Montenegro and Serbia have not yet legalized opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Asks for More Freedom for Catholic Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6 pvs, `The pope's talks...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with pope meeting with diplomats. Pick up 7th pvs, `In Aguascalientes...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XAGS1
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II said Tuesday the church and state in Mexico are reaching a better understanding and issued a veiled appeal for a repeal of the decades-old constitutional ban on Catholic schools. ``Open the world of teaching to Christ!'' the pope cried in a speech to a crowd that included many schoolteachers. Later, before the biggest throng of the trip, John Paul called on young Mexicans not to lose hope in the face of injustice and poverty and to seize faith in Christ as a weapon against despair. Many of today's young are ``wounded by despair,'' the pope said, citing ``evasion, abandon, hedonism, discotheques, drugs, indifference, pessimism, the artificial paradises in which so many find refuge.'' Thousands of youths waved white, yellow and green handkerchiefs, pennants and caps as the pope spoke to more than 200,000 people gathered on the slopes of a bowl in the hills at San Juan de Los Lagos, about 50 miles south of Aguascalientes. The pope's talks to the youth of Mexico and their teachers came on the third day of his second trip to Mexico. On Tuesday night, back in Mexico City, the pope met with the foreign diplomatic corps and urged a more moral approach to the problems of refugees and the foreign debt. ``I feel the obligation to underline ... the ethical dimension of this imprisoning crisis,'' the pontiff said, speaking about the foreign debt. Mexico has a $93 billion foreign debt, second highest in the developing world after Brazil. In Aguascalientes, 275 miles northwest of Mexico City, the pope stopped off at the airport before flying on to San Juan. Because the pope did not enter the city, replicas of downtown colonial buildings were installed as a backdrop to his speech to teachers. John Paul, speaking under a white parasol to ward off the blazing sun, noted recent increased contacts between the Vatican and Mexico, whose constitution has harsh restrictions on religious activity. ``A new perspective of contacts between the church and the political community of this country is occurring in this day,'' the pope said. ``And in this phase of better understanding and dialogue, the church wants to offer its own support, without straying from its specific goals and abilities.'' It was the pope's most direct public comment on the gradual relaxation of the church-state relationship in Mexico that was symbolized when President Carlos Salinas de Gortari met John Paul at the Mexico City airport on Sunday. The 1917 constitution says all schools must be government-run, with a curriculum set by federal authorities. In practice, however, Catholic schools and universities have long existed and are growing in number. In one of the paradoxes that characterizes church-state relations, many government leaders send their children to Catholic schools, which are generally considered of higher quality. The pontiff said he hoped that Mexicans would overcome the idea raised by critics that the church had obstructed cultural and scientific progress. ``It is enough to remember the secular educative efforts of the religious and ecclesiastical institutions, from the first evangelization until the present day,'' he said. The church lost the right to religious schools because its liberal opponents during the late 19th and early 20th centuries believed it was a regressive force in Mexico that retarded social progress. The pope drew wild cheers when he spontaneously saluted the ``corazones calientes,'' or ``hot hearts,'' of Aguascalientes, which means hot waters and refers to the area's thermal springs. The throng did ``the wave'' and also waved white handkerchiefs and flags bearing the image of the pope. John Paul then traveled to the nearby shrine of the Virgin of San Juan de los Lagos. The 18th-century sanctuary, in a pink stone basilica, contains an image of the Virgin made of corn husks. Millions of pilgrims annually pay homage to the statue, which was credited with resurrecting a dead little girl in 1623. I the afternoon Mass for youth, the pontiff's homily was interrupted for minutes at a time by cheers and chants. When the pope asked if those present would allow themselves to be tricked by drugs, hedonism or false ideologies, they roared ``No.'' ``Young people, don't lose hope, you are pilgrims of hope,'' the pontiff said. John Paul called the Mass for youth ``the moment of my trip to Mexico that I have most looked forward to.'' The pope has a special affection for the young, and in Mexico, about 65 percent of the population is under 29. John Paul appeared sunburned after a day in the sun even though he spoke from the protection of a canopy. Priests on the temporary altar at San Juan wore yellow baseball caps to shield themselves. John Paul's eight-day visit is his 47th trip outside Italy as pope and his 10th journey to Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Homosexual Cadet Won't Have To Repay Tuition
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has reversed its ruling that an ROTC cadet discharged for homosexuality will have to repay the government $38,612 in scholarship tuition, the cadet learned Tuesday. Rob Bettiker, a chemistry major at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, received a letter from the Navy saying the military would drop its bid to force him to reimburse the government for the tuition. Bettiker, who had been fighting the Navy over the issue, said he thought the turnaround was ``great.'' ``I was really surprised. I thought the best case that would ever happen to me is that the secretary of the navy would just consider my case indefinitely,'' he said. Bettiker said he hoped the Navy's decision would have implications for other Reserve Officer Training Corps cadets discharged for their sexual preference. ``The way it's worded, they tried to make it as particular to me as possible _ but I feel its a precedent,'' he said. The Navy quit paying Bettiker's tuition after the fall semester. Bettiker was discharged Jan. 31. The 22-year-old Ohio native had planned to enter the Navy's prestigious Nuclear Propulsion Program after graduation next month but will now be working in a cancer research laboratory at the University of California at Berkeley. David Carney, a second homosexual cadet, has reportedly also been exempted from the Navy's demand that ousted homosexual cadets repay the government for tuition. Carney, a Harvard University graduate, is studying in Britain and could not be contacted for comment. In an interview earlier, Carney said, ``In my view, the U.S. Navy broke its contract with me, not vice versa.''
