A Navy spokesman said the two cases were ``reviewed on their merits, and the decision was made not to seek recoupment,'' but that there had been no changes in the Defense Department's policy barring homosexuals from the armed forces, The New York Times reported in Wednesday's editions.

NATO is at a critical phase as it struggles to adapt to change in Europe and tries to make ``a partner in security'' out of the Soviet Union, the alliance's secretary general says. ``We are looking at this alliance not as an instrument of confrontation, but as an element of cooperation in a new security structure,'' Manfred Woerner said Monday. Speaking on the eve of the opening of a new round of NATO meetings, Woerner also dismissed Soviet suggestions that a unified Germany become neutral or hold dual membership in both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. ``Neutrality is no alternative. And to be a member of both pacts is just neutrality without a word,'' the former West German defense minister said.

Terry Anderson, the longest held of the 16 Western hostages, helped fellow prisoners make Scrabble and Monopoly games to amuse themselves, according to a newly freed captive. His guards are giving him and other hostages plenty of diversions, according to an account given by former hostage Frank Reed to Anderson's sister, Peggy Say. ``They have a lot of things which was encouraging to me; at least they did at the time Frank was there,'' Mrs. Say said Monday. These included boxes of books, writing materials and dominoes. Although Anderson, 42, is in good physical condition from plenty of exercise, he is tired and needs dental care, Mrs. Say said. She said the hostages are blindfolded and chained in line with their preference.

If he quits his job, Rep. Stephen Solarz could become an instant millionaire. So could Rep. Dan Rostenkowski. Democrats Solarz and Rostenkowski are the two could-be millionaires among 184 House ``grandfathers'' who can put their campaign cash to personal use if they retire from the House by January 1993. Put more simply, they can take the money and not run. Congress last year voted to close the loophole that allows certain House members to take their campaign funds with them when they retire, but the new restrictions did not take effect immediately.

The charred remnants of America's two worst space tragedies, the 1967 Apollo fire and the 1986 Challenger explosion, will soon be united in an abandoned missile silo miles from any plaque or memorial. The Apollo capsule will be moved from NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., where it has been in a shipping container for 23 years, and buried atop the remains of the shuttle. No ceremony is scheduled when the capsule, its heat shield and 31 cartons of hardware and investigative material arrive on a flatbed truck around May 20. No marker is planned. ``It's not as if by putting this in the silo we have forgotten the contribution these guys have made to the program. There are memorials'' elsewhere, said NASA spokesman Mark Hess. ``We didn't think it was really appropriate that we do anything special or make some kind of a public event out of this.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Congressional Republicans on Budget Summit Proposal
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts lead; picks up 2nd graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with Republican leaders today to push his idea for a ``no preconditions'' budget summit designed to reduce the deficit. Democrats were holding separate meetings to map strategy for their participation in what could be the first formal tax-increase discussions of Bush's presidency. GOP leaders have hailed Bush's ice-breaking overtures on the budget. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said on Monday he believed Democrats would join in the process. ``I believe the answer will be in the affirmative,'' said Dole. ``We need to do it.'' Democratic leaders of the House and Senate, meantime, were meeting with rank-and-file members to gauge their feelings about budget bargaining in an election year. Sixteen top Democrats met for an hour Monday in a closed-door session. ``We've had different views expressed,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said afterward. Pressure has been building for action on the budget because of the slowing economy and the increasing cost projections of the federal bailout of the savings and loan industry. The weaker the economy, the less revenue the government can expect to collect and the greater the federal deficit. As a result, the amount of budget cuts the administration says will be er taxes and cuts in benefit programs. ``You sure aren't going to get that without starting this process and having the right people there arguing all of it on the table,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there would be ``no preconditions'' to holding the negotiations. Republicans denied that such a statement is inconsistent with Bush's campaign pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``There isn't any president who hasn't tried to make good on his promises. There's no president who hasn't lived through times that change, and maybe outdate some promises,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, top Republican on the House Budget Committee. Frenzel said he favors a package paring next year's deficit by $55 billion, including some form of new taxes would be ``the only way (Bush) can do the job,'' Frenzel said. Domenici said he would want to reduce the shortfall by between $42 billion and $50 billion. Higher taxes should be open to negotiations, he said. Last week, the House passed a Democratic-written spending plan that includes $36 billion in deficit reduction. The Senate Budget Committee approved another Democratic plan containing $43 billion in savings. Both proposals would give the military nearly $10 billion less next year than Bush wants. Bush proposed a budget in January that claims to shrink the shortfall by $36 billion to just under $64 billion. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law requires that next year's budget gap not exceed $64 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Out There Is an Economic Boom
DOC.TEXT: Somewhere out there is an economic boom _ in the Pacific Rim, in Eastern Europe, in Western Europe's unified market of 1992, in Latin America, even in the United States. You can feel it and read about it in daily newspaper reports, in the economic analyses of brokerage houses, in academic writings. The world's politics and markets are being restructured. Opportunity is out there. Seizing it, however, may be another matter, akin to reaching for a rainbow or grasping for a dream or walking into a mirage. Or, as it has been put, like trying to spend the so-called peace dividend. A decade or more ago the boom was to be in Latin America, with U.S. banks financing the way toward swift industrial development. Somehow it didn't work out that way; now, some of those nations can't afford to repay the loans. The Pacific Rim was the rage a few years ago. Economies on the Asian shore of the Pacific Ocean were exporting huge amounts of products and rapidly raising their living standards. Moreover, there was China, an awakening giant. But the United States got tired of importing so much and began insisting on freer trade. China lost a great deal of enthusiasm for Western-style development. The future of Hong Kong once more was thrown into question. The European Economic Community's barrier-free market, scheduled for 1992, became an outlet for the emotions of economic boomers. The United States of Europe, that's what it would be. What a market, declared the boomers. Europe will produce more efficiently what they make best, and the United States will do what it does best, and the two massive entities will trade themselves into greater wealth. It might come true, but experience flashes caution. It could mean more competition than cooperation. Trade relations always are touchy; each side feels it gives too much, neither side believes it receives reciprocity. Thank goodness for the East European option, said American business people. The sudden development of free markets in the socialist states will provide an enormous opportunity for industrial and consumer goods, they said. Questions: Will people accustomed to governmental paternalism adjust to the uncertainies, the risks of competition? Who will pay the bills for cleaning up the polluted environment? What goods can these nations offer in trade? Where will the boom occur? How? Perhaps, some say, right here in the United States, with the peace dividend being the lever. That thought had currency for awhile, but the thesis slammed into reality. It probably is true that money will be saved on military defense, but everyone knows that dozens of new ways to spend already are waiting for sponsorship, and that every one of them will be deemed urgent by somebody. To date, the peace dividend has been layoffs, not just from cuts in government spending but from efforts by companies to lessen their dependency on government contracts. Why, taxes might even be raised, not lowered. The lack of success in finding an economic boom, or the potential for one, is not discouraging the seekers. Brokerage houses aren't just looking one year ahead, difficult as that is to do, but an entire decade _ into a new century. The forecasts are laden with terminology such as new era, decade of globalization, era of change, new world, gay nineties (all over again), the century of space. Most have a world view, or even a spatial perspective. But when the future becomes history, it might be seen all over again that the greatest boom of all was created right in the homes, in the insatiable appetite of human beings for new consumer products, services and dreams.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Military Questioned for Retaining Pro-Noriega Elements
DOC.TEXT: People don't fear the military as they did when Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was in power, but deciding on its role and personnel is a problem for the new government. The new Public Forces include officers who were loyal to Noriega. Many Panamanians question whether high-ranking officials of the old regime have a place in the new order. ``Panamanians won't accept that officers of the old Defense Forces could be those who, in a democracy, control the police,'' the newspaper Panama-America said. ``To think about putting into uniform and arming those who for many years oppressed, punished and tortured is not an easy task.'' The military's makeup should be submitted to a referendum, said Alberto Conte, leader of the Civic Crusade, a business and professional organizaion that led the opposition to Noriega. Keeping Noriega's old officers ``doesn't offer any guarantee that the new Public Forces will be efficient, respectful and demilitarized,'' he said. Eusebio Marchosky, in charge of an effort to recover state property stolen by Noriega and his cronies, said officers who had served the dictator were hindering his work and retaining them ``is against the national will.'' Ricardo Arias Calderon, who is second vice president, interior minister and justice minister, has said Panama's leaders chose to keep Noriega's officers after the U.S. invasion in December because ``to exclude them would be to judge them categorically, and not as individuals.'' Officials of the civilian government have accused members of the new Public Forces of crimes. Special prosecutor Rodrigo Miranda charged Capt. Leslie Loaiza, head of the Judicial Police Academy, with involvement in the kidnap-killing of Marcos Rodriguez Justines, 3-year-old nephew of former Col. Marcos Justines, who was Noriega's second in command and now is in jail. Officials say the apparent reason for the abduction was to force Justines, jailed on charges of helping steal $47 million in a bank scandal, to share the money. Why the child was killed is uncertain. Forty-seven other other Noriega officers are jailed on charges ranging from misdemeanors to murder. Noriega took refuge in the Vatican Embassy, but surrendered to U.S. forces Jan. 3 and now awaits trial on drug charges in Miami. Arias said many Panamanians had suggested ``firing everyone and recruiting from zero.'' On the second day of the invasion, he said, the leadership had to decide between that and issuing ``a call to service on new terms.'' Forming an entirely new military and police force would have meant asking U.S. soldiers to remain three to five years while it was done, Arias said. Mario Rognoni, a legislator from Noriega's Democratic Revolutionary Party, said: ``the idea of demilitarizing the country is an error because a modern state must have the necessary elements of security.'' He said Panama is made vulnerable by its location and the fact that it will assume control of the Panama Canal at the end of the century. For more than two decades, the Panama Defense Forces were responsible for all military and police functions, which now are under civilian control This year's military budget is $80 million, about $70 million less than under Noriega and only 3.5 percent of the total national budget. Several specialized battalions Noriega controlled have been disbanded, along with six schools or bases generally used for military instruction. A civilian police academy is in the planning stages. Panama's air force is run by the National Air Service and 12 of its more costly planes are assigned to the Treasury Ministry. The navy and marines no longer exist. ``There will be nobody in uniform in charge of all services,'' a role reserved for the civilian president, Arias said. He said a commission concluded the ratio of security forces to citizens should be 4 to 1,000, meaning 8,000 officers, but that Panama needed 12,000 because of its forests and special maritime needs. The commission was made up of security officials from Spain, Argentina and Costa Rica, which disbanded its army more than 40 years ago. Noriega's Defense Forces numbered about 15,000.

DOC.HEAD: ROMANCING THE SOUNDS: The Record Industry
Columbia Records' Chief Has an Ear Open for Alternative Music
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The youngest president of the one of the world's largest record companies has an itchy ear for alternative music and is pushing those bands harder than such superstar staples as Michael Jackson and Bruce Springsteen. Don Ienner, 36, became president of Columbia Records a year ago, after being lured from Arista Records, where he was executive vice president and general manager. While at Arista, he helped launch singer Whitney Houston into pop-stardom. But within just 48 hours at Columbia, Ienner seized upon the sound of Poi Dog Pondering, an eclectic folk-ethnic-rock band from Hawaii and Texas who had two EPs out on the tiny label of Texas Hotel Records. The idea, Ienner said in an interview, was to get alternative bands and work with them over the years to create a mainstream following. ``We had Bruce Springsteen covered,'' Ienner said. ``The previous regime had no idea what we were doing with alternative music. They didn't break the Psychedelic Furs, they didn't break so many great bands. ... Nothing, nobody. The philosophy before was, if you can't sell 2 million albums don't work it.'' CBS Records, which owns Columbia Records, in the past rode high with mainstream successes such as Jackson's ``Thriller,'' and mega-hits from Springsteen, George Michael, Barbra Streisand, Billy Joel, Neil Diamond and James Taylor. But Columbia Records was in a slump after Sony Corp. bought the parent company in 1988. ``We needed to change direction,'' Ienner said. ``There was nothing, just retreading the superstars, just one after another after another. That's why we were losing market share; that's why we were losing people; that's why we weren't getting any new bands.'' Ienner speaks in a booming staccato about his professional passion: music. ``I'm not a Harvard MBA,'' he said. ``I'm not the accountant and I never even finished high school. Music has been my life and that's the thing I love the most.'' He started his career as a teen-ager working in the Capitol Records mailroom in 1969. From 1972-77, he was in partnership with his brother, Jimmy Ienner, in a publishing, management and production company. He went to Arista from Millennium Records, a label he co-founded in 1977. Besides Poi Dog Pondering, the first band he signed as president after a heated battle with almost every other major record label, he picked a young band called Toad the Wet Sprocket from Santa Barbara, Calif. Poi Dog has befuddled music critics trying to describe its peculiar sound. The ensemble plays everything from the standard guitar, bass, drums to the not-so-standard accordian, flugelhorn, tin whistle, wood block, congas, banjo and somebody's used frying pan. Among other things, the ensuing musical mesh has been called ``hillbilly-luau-Earth Mother rock,'' a ``wild stew of global folk styles'' and a ``blissful aural buzz.'' Toad the Wet Sprocket relies heavily on an accoustic guitar, has a sound in the vein of the Smiths and fuzzy, resonant vocals similar to R.E.M.'s Michael Stipe. ``It was important that we get and use Poi Dog Pondering as our signature band,'' Ienner said. Poi Dog and Toad would ``show our musical sensitivity.'' It would also help Columbia cater to a huge audience carved out in large part by college radio stations looking for an alternative to Top 40 music. The hope is also that the smaller, dormant bands will blossom into big hits further down the line, similar to the success of bands and artists such as R.E.M., the Replacements, the B-52s, the Violent Femmes, New Order, Lou Reed and Elvis Costello, all on the Warner Bros. label. ``If you work the baby bands as hard as you work the big bands or maybe work the baby bands more than you work the big bands ... you'll have something that you'll be proud of in the next five years,'' said Ienner.

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Continues as Park Celebrates Centennial
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't long after the first tourists appeared in the valley carved amid granite peaks that conservationists mourned the impact of humans here. Frederick Law Olmsted, a member of the first Yosemite Commission, wrote in 1865 of ``picturesque rocks stenciled over with advertisements of patent medicines.'' Naturalist John Muir complained the ``valley looked like a frowsy, backwoods pasture'' after a visit in 1889, the year before Yosemite became a national park. Yosemite National Park turns 100 this year. So do its problems. In Muir's day, no more than a couple of thousand hardy folk each year trekked through the wilderness to refresh themselves in the mists of Yosemite Falls and marvel at the park's granite monolith, El Capitan. Last year, 3.4 million people came through the valley, bringing with them some of the very problems they were trying to escape in the city. Park officials are struggling with the best way to deal with the crowding, pollution, development and traffic that threaten its natural beauty and serenity. ``Yosemite, for a number of reasons, really just ranks very highly in people's level of care,'' said Allan Bedwell, National Park Service spokesman. ``It goes back to Yosemite playing a major role in this country as a symbol of wilderness or nature or primeval heritage. ``I think a lot of it has to do with the fact that it's accessible to people. Those cliffs, those waterfalls, represent wilderness _ even though you have to view that wilderness in a fairly urban setting.'' Visitors can order anything from pizza to prime rib in Yosemite's snack bars and restaurants, or buy T-shirts, tennis balls and mugs in park gift shops, then get extra cash from an automatic teller machine. A beauty shop and video rental cater to park service and concession employees who live in the valley. Law enforcement officers booked 500 people into the jail last year. It was anticipated a decade ago that Yosemite's 100th birthday on Oct. 1, 1990, also would be a celebration of the ambitious 1980 general management plan that promised to balance convenience with conservation. But 10 years proved too short a time to meet such grandiose goals as eliminating cars from the valley and removing nonessential businesses, offices and personnel to locations outside the park boundaries. The park service has acknowledged the failure to fully implement the plan and is cataloging nearly 4,500 letters of comment from park enthusiasts as it decides how to plan realistically for Yosemite's next 100 years. ``The plan was formulated at a time when there was a different administration and different political climate,'' Park Superintendent Michael Finley said. Its implementation was hindered, in part, by a lack of money and, in some instances, by proposals that proved unrealistic, Finley said. For example, a landscape architect has found there is not enough suitable land to expand employee housing in the community of El Portal outside the park, as the plan proposes, Finley said. The park service did succeed in eliminating 650 parking spaces as planned, but a parking garage that was supposed to replace some of the lost spaces never materialized. Pressure to remove facilities from the park has remained constant from environmentalists, who complain many of the services interfere with the mandate to preserve Yosemite. ``We want to make it accessible to people. But do you need to be able to buy mugs and T-shirts and a badminton racquet in order to enjoy Yosemite National Park?'' asked Patricia Schifferle, regional director of the Wilderness Society. Superintendent Finley argues that visitors who soothe their muscles in a swimming pool after hiking to the top of Yosemite Falls or spend a night in a $180 room at the Ahwahnee Hotel also gain an appreciation of the park. ``If you look at it one way, you could be shocked and say, `In John Muir's holy temple there are swimming pools,''' Finley said. ``But if John Muir could keep 200,000 people from churning up the Merced River, would he do it by putting in three swimming pools?'' At the heart of the controversy over what services are appropriate for a national park is the Yosemite Park and Curry Co., a subsidiary of MCA, which provides guest services in the park. Critics argue that Curry wields too much influence over the park. Schifferle cites Curry's proposal to remove some existing employee housing and replace it with dormitories near Yosemite Lodge. Schifferle says the plan is contrary to the goal of removing unnecessary employee housing from the valley. ``A lot of what's been said critical of the Curry Company is flat erroneous. They've said we want to build more facilities here. Not true,'' said Curry spokesman John Poimiroo. He defended the dormitory plan, saying it would decrease traffic between El Portal, where it was proposed employees would be moved, and the valley floor. Critics also say the company profits from a 30-year contract that requires it to pay the government only .75 percent of its annual sales while not contributing to the goals of the general management plan. The National Park Service revealed that in 1989 Curry paid $635,000 to provide, without competition, most guest services. Poimiroo admits the fee is low. He points out, however, that Curry's financial commitment to the park does not end with the concessions fee. Curry also has invested $100 million in the park since 1973, when MCA bought the concessionaire, in maintenance and capital improvements, which included $8 million to repair and restore the Ahwahnee Hotel, Poimiroo said. But claims that the money represents an investment in the park are met with skepticism by environmentalists, who say Curry ultimately makes money on that type of spending. ``Are they spending money on the park, or are they spending money to do business in the park?'' Schifferle said. ``That's why I find the $100 million is probably more PR hype than reality as far as actual benefit to the park. It's probably benefiting Curry Company enormously.'' Attempts to renegotiate the concessions fee before the contract expires in 1993 have failed, but many expect the new contract to include clauses requiring Curry to invest some profits in specific programs. Finley points out that even successfully raising the fee would not necessarily mean more money for Yosemite itself. The concessions fee is deposited in the U.S. Treasury where it is re-appropriated by Congress, leaving the park service to compete with other interests, Finley said. The lively debate on how to protect Yosemite's natural beauty inevitably leads to the park service's conflicting missions: preserving the park while making it accessible to the public. ``Yosemite always has been on the political hot seat because, probably more than any other park, it mirrors that tension every day of every year,'' said Jim Snyder, park historian. ``The issues have become national because they symbolize what could happen to the national parks.''

DOC.HEAD: The Dump Quayle Rumor: No One Believes It But Still It Lives
DOC.TEXT: The odd thing about the Dan Quayle rumor is how few people believe it. Yet it refuses to die. Three years in advance of Election Day 1992, President Bush told The Dallas Morning News that Quayle ``absolutely'' would be his running mate again. ``He's doing a very good job, an outstanding job,'' said the president. Then why is Washington awash in a new flurry of ``dump Quayle'' rumors? The poll numbers certainly have a lot to do with it. Bush enjoys approval ratings of close to 80 percent, while fewer than half the people questioned give Quayle passing grades. In a recent Gallup poll, 54 percent described Quayle as unqualified to be president. It all has to do with the news business, said Walter F. Mondale, who spent four years as vice president without anyone suggesting he was about to be dumped by Jimmy Carter. ``On every national political news reporter's calendar, oh, about October of the first term of a president, he always writes the vice presidential failure story,'' said Mondale. ``The reason I never had one is we would usually get a hint the story was coming and Carter would call the reporter personally. He'd say `I want you to know Mondale is the best vice president anybody ever had and I'm very happy with him.''' But Mondale was the exception. Conservatives wanted to dump George Bush. Liberals wanted to dump Lyndon Johnson. Moderates wanted to dump Richard Nixon. Conservatives wanted to dump Nelson Rockefeller. In restrospect, it seems like lots of people wanted to dump Spiro Agnew. It's part of the job description for vice presidents: Preside over the Senate, attend funerals, and be the target of rumors the president wishes he'd picked someone else for his running mate. But switches are rare. Gerald Ford dumped Rockefeller in 1976 in favor of Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas, who campaigned at a low growl and shocked viewers of his debate with Mondale when he blamed Democrats for all the wars of the 20th Century. Dole has quipped that in the 1976 campaign he went for the jugular and got his own. Richard Viguerie, a conservative activist, recalled the ``save Agnew'' effort mounted by the political right in 1971 when there was talk that Nixon might dump the former Maryland governor from the ticket in 1972. ``Conservatives made a big effort to make sure Agnew stayed on the ticket,'' he said. They needn't have bothered. Soulmate Pat Buchanan later said that Nixon had ``no thoughts or intentions of dumping Agnew.'' Viguerie and his ideological comrades would have liked someone other than Bush as Ronald Reagan's running mate in 1984. But, said Viguerie, ``Conservatives never thought there was any hope of dumping Bush.'' One near-unanimous view in assessing the Quayle rumor is that Bush has a highly developed sense of loyalty and would not dump the man he picked to run with him in 1988. ``If anybody really knows George Bush they know he is long on loyalty,'' said Tom Griscom, who served as White House communications director during the Reagan presidency. ``George Bush is about as intensely loyal a person as you'll ever find in politics,'' said Viguerie. And yet, the rumor continues to have currency. A recent version noted that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had bought a ranch in Wyoming _ and that's a fact. Baker's real estate deal prompted speculation that he would change his voting residence to Wyoming so that he could run in 1992 on a ticket headed by fellow Texan George Bush. The Constitution bars presidential electors from casting their votes for two candidates from their own state. Thus if two Texans were paired on the national ticket, only one of them could receive that state's electoral votes. ``Absolutely, positively, he has no plan to change his voting residence,'' said Margaret Tutwiler, a longtime Baker aide who now is chief State Department spokesman. Washington loves a good rumor and even many of those who shrugged off the Quayle speculation did so in a way that somehow kept it alive. ``The problem with this is the timing is all wrong,'' said a political consultant who insisted on anonymity. As quickly as he dismissed a Baker-for-Quayle trade as improbable, the consultant went on to speculate that Quayle's standing in the polls ``will never improve. In this age of mass media, once the public has decided something there's just no way to reverse it.'' Another consultant pointed to a magazine article about columnist George Will, who happens to be one of Bush's least favorite people. Take note, said the consultant, who insisted on being nameless, that the article was written by Bush friend Vic Gold. Further, said he, it points out that Will and Quayle have been lunching together _ a sure sign to the devious of mind that the president is peeved with his veep. Mondale offered a little sympathy. ``You can always find someone in any administration who thinks the vice president should go and usually you can find quite a chorus if you put in an hour or two,'' said the former vice president. But Mondale also said that Quayle's problem appears ``different in depth and scope.'' Quayle, he said, ``is a troubled occupant of that position.''

DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. shareholders showed support for management's fight against Carl Icahn's proposal to spin off the conglomerate's steel business, and the takeover strategist conceded his plan might face defeat. Icahn himself indicated Monday he might not have the votes necessary for approval of his plan, which he says would boost USX's share value, but said there still was a significant amount of support among major shareholders for his efforts. No vote totals from the shareholders' meeting were announced.

President Bush will veto any bill requiring employers to give time off to workers with new babies or family illness, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told business leaders. Sununu threatened any version of the pending ``family leave'' bill that would mandate such an employee benefit, according to business group lobbyists who attended a White House meeting with him on Monday. Alixe Glen, deputy White House spokeswoman, later confirmed he had made such remarks.

The chairman and chief executive of Circle K Corp. resigned after presiding over a drastic expansion that left the convenience store chain searching for ways to meet interest payments on $1.3 billion debt. No replacement was named for Karl Eller, 61, but the company said president Robert A. Dearth Jr., 45, would manage Circle K's operations. Spokesman Ray Cox said Monday that Eller resigned to pursue personal business opportunities.

Playboy Enterprises Inc. unveiled a recapitalization plan aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of founder Hugh Hefner. The recapitalization, subject to shareholder approval, would establish two classes of common stock, including a new class of non-voting stock. It would increase the number of outstanding Playboy shares from 15 million to 37.5 million, including 30 million shares of non-voting stock, the company said Monday.

Eastern Airlines announced a money-back guarantee to business travelers and sharply reduced fares for children on some flights, in the latest bid to attract passengers to the rebuilding carrier. Martin Shugrue, the court-appointed trustee running Eastern, said Monday that travelers buying certain tickets could get their money back if they are for any reason unhappy with the flight. He also said summer fares for children to nine Florida cities would be $39 on peak days and $29 on other days.

Greyhound Lines' chairman said the 2-month-old strike by bus drivers was ``irrelevant'' and effectively over, but strikers scoffed at the claim, and one compared it to Napoleon declaring victory at Waterloo. ``The strike is in effect concluded from the point of view of day-to-day operations,'' Greyhound Lines Inc. Chairman Fred G. Currey told reporters Monday. But some union officials claimed Currey's statement was a publicity stunt to scare striking drivers back to work at the nation's only intercity bus company.

American workers' productivity continued to lag in the first three months of 1990, posting its worst performance in a year, the government said. The governmnet said Monday that non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ declined by 1 percent, the biggest drop since productivity fell by an annual rate of 1.3 percent for the January-March period last year. During all of last year, productivity rose just 0.9 percent, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession.

MCI Communications Corp., the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company, will pay its first-ever dividend on common stock _ 5 cents per share _ starting next month, MCI Chairman William G. McGowan says. McGowan told shareholders on Monday at their annual meeting that MCI plans to pay a twice-annual dividend of 5 cents and ``that is going to be an MCI policy. He said the dividend would be payable June 11 to shareholders of record as of May 21.

NBC, which once tried to buy 51 percent of Cable News Network, is planning its own 24-hour news service for its affiliates, NBC News president Michael Gartner says. The affiliates could use the service as part of their own broadcasts or when NBC is ``dark'' and not broadcasting. The plan likely will be presented to affiliates at their annual convention, June 3-6 in Washington, D.C.

The stock market forged ahead Monday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.26 to 2,721.62. Bond prices edged lower on profit-taking and anticipation of the $30.5 billion auction of new Treasury notes and bonds this week. The dollar fell against most major currencies. Grain, soybean, energy, precious metals, livestock and pork futures prices all closed higher while copper futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Great Excitement Over Rather Little
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department issued a report Friday that created quite a shock. Hardly anybody concerned with the future of the economy failed to react to it within minutes. Many economists were unnerved. After reading the report, they wondered what had gone wrong with their interpretation of the data, and why they had not foreseen what occurred. Some viewed the new report as indicative of an economy even weaker than realized. Some saw it as a sign the bottom had been reached, and that the economy would begin strengthening. The stock market suddenly came alive. Whatever they made of the numbers, hardly an economist who wants to remain in the public eye failed to offer an explanation, interpretation or forecast. Most significant of all the reactions was the widespread view _ it seemed to sweep through the investment community in minutes _ that the numbers would force the Federal Reserve to reconsider lifting interest rates. What caused this commotion? The April jobless rate and numbers that created it, that's what. What did the rate do? It rose to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March. Or, if you include military, to 5.3 percent from 5.1 percent. You might wonder how little numbers like that can cause big reactions like those that occurred, and your wonderment is justified. After a weekend of reflection, you may be sure that many people are less excited than before. That short period of reflection, for example, might have caused some of them to realize that the change in the numbers might be a matter of methodology rather than reality. And that the numbers might yet be revised. Revisions are common, and they include the March numbers. After studying their data, for example, Labor Department analysts raised by 103,000 their estimate of payroll increases in that month. The earlier figure was 26,000. A single month's data has always been suspect, simply because it could be an isolated event. That event could be a real one, an actual occurrence, but it also could be due to faulty counting or to seasonal adjusting. While realizing this, the economic fraternity nevertheless reacted as if to a major event, and one conceivable explanation might be boredom. A look at the statistics over the past year or so provides the basis for that theory. Since last April, that is, the most inclusive monthly unemployment rate, one that includes military, has varied from 5.3 percent only once. That was last May, when it dipped to 5.2 percent of the labor force. In short, the jobless rate has provided little if any clue to the economy's direction in that time, a time in which the economic fraternity was looking far, wide and everywhere for any little indication of direction. Placed in that perspective, therefore, the April jobless rate represented a big change. And, to be sure, some other elements in the report were significant, such as a continued decline of manufacturing employment. But even Janet Norwood, commissioner of labor statistics, thought the report wasn't really of major significance, and she so informed Congress. She told them that: ``... Thus far we can discern no meaningful changes in the measures that might signal a deteriorating unemployment situation.'' In particular, Mrs. Norwood said, ``neither the number of newly unemployed _ those jobless less than than five weeks _ nor the number of job losers has started to climb.''

DOC.HEAD: Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell at the latest auction to their lowest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department on Monday sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.79 percent, down from 7.91 percent last week. Another $8.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.84 percent, down from 8.03 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.78 percent on April 23, and six-month bills averaged 7.75 percent on April 16. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.06 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,803.10 and 8.29 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,603.60. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.56 percent last week, down from 8.57 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Cash, Not Service, Important Question For Greyhound
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. has resumed most of its operations, but some analysts question whether the company has enough cash to avoid bankruptcy as it tries to recover from a 9-week walkout by bus drivers. Chairman Fred G. Currey said Monday the strike was ``in effect concluded from the point of view of day-to-day operations.'' He said Greyhound is serving areas which brought in 98 percent of its revenue last year, and will be running at 90 percent of scheduled pre-strike miles by June 19. Union officials challenged the claim, pointing to the company's recent announcement of a $55.8 million first-quarter loss. They said Curry was trying to scare striking drivers back to work. In addition to the loss, Greyhound has said it would not make a $9.75 million interest payment due May 15. The company also did not pay about $5 million in lease payments due at the end of April. Some analysts have questioned whether the Dallas-based company will be able to pay bills to operate even if creditors don't call in their loans and force the company into bankruptcy _ a possibility because of the missed payments. Greyhound had amassed a strike fund of more than $50 million but has said the frequently violent walkout, in which some buses have been hit by gunfire, has cost more than anticipated. In documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Greyhound said it had spent $20 million on beefed up security, legal fees and extra driver training. ``I'm surprised at how much cash they're burning,'' said Leigh Walzer, an analyst with R.D. Smith & Co. in New York. ``Cash could become a real bind.'' Walzer gave the company only a 20 percent chance of surviving the strike without having to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors. Currey would not disclose Greyhound's cash resources in an interview Monday, but he said money that would have been used to cover interest and lease costs is being used to help operate the company. Nevertheless, Currey said creditors recognize Greyhound can be rebuilt and ``we expect and we've received cooperation.'' Currey said ridership increased last week to its highest levels since the strike began, although it remains between 65 percent and 75 percent of year-ago levels. Revenue is running at about the same level, he said, and remains less than expenses, although the carrier is near break-even. He suggested revenues would be 85 percent to 90 percent of last year's levels by mid- to late summer. Curry also said the company could post a profit by next year. Union officials have challenged the company's claims of restored service and said Currey's victory cry was a publicity stunt. ``It's a common ploy to try to scare a few more strikers into scabbing by announcing that there's no hope,'' said AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty. ``Mr. Currey's claim that the Greyhound strike is over is like Napoleon claiming victory at Waterloo _ its' both ridiculous and false,'' said Jim La Sala, international president of the Amalgamated Transit Union, the umbrella organization for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. The company proposed a contract offer Saturday that would have eliminated 4,500 union jobs, changed from per-mile wage rates to hourly wage rates and imposed a four-year wage freeze. Union officials called the proposal an ``insult'' and refused to put it to a vote. No further talks were scheduled. Currey did not rule out resuming negotiations with the union, noting it remains the licensed bargaining agent for the drivers. He said the company would continue to need drivers as it expands. The union, which represents 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers, walked off the job March 2. As of Monday, the company said 548 union drivers had crossed picket lines. It also had hired 2,888 new drivers and had 501 others in school, which would give it 3,937 available drivers by May 16. Greyhound has said before it could operate a full system with about 3,200 drivers, although more are needed for the busy summer travel season. The company also said it would reduce its charter operation sharply _ from 197 cities to 19 cities _ and cut unprofitable miles. Company officials could not provide the number of destinations that will lose service, but Currey said, ``Local carriers already have moved on to many of those routes, and Greyhound is trying to locate new carriers for the others.'' ``It would appear that the company needed this strike to justify abandoning bus service to rural communities across the country,'' said the ATU's La Sala.

DOC.HEAD: MCI To Pay Its First Dividend
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. Chairman William G. McGowan has a surprise for shareholders of the phone company's common stock: the first-ever dividend. MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, will pay a twice-a-year dividend of 5 cents, McGowan told applauding shareholders at the company's 18th annual meeting Monday. He said the dividend would be payable June 11 to shareholders of record as of May 21. ``That is going to be an MCI policy,'' said McGowan, adding, ``Hopefully, we'll even increase it someday.'' ``We didn't want to borrow to pay a dividend and we didn't go cash-positive until the third quarter of 1988,'' said Daniel F. Akerson, MCI's chief financial officer. He said that for nearly two years, MCI paid its bills as well as financed expansion through internally generated funds. That practice was broken last month when MCI said it would borrow money from banks to buy Telecom USA Inc. of Atlanta, the No. 4 long-distance company, for $1.25 billion. ``We didn't want to send the wrong message'' to investors, Akerson said, adding, ``that's why it's a modest dividend. We still feel investors that invest in MCI are primarilly interested in growth.'' Still, he said the company decided to start paying a dividend in part to attract institutional investors such as pension funds, many of which are barred by their own rules from investing in companies that do not pay dividends. McGowan, who ran the 90-minute meeting at the Kennedy Center's concert hall, appeared in good spirits despite having undergone chest surgery in April. McGowan, who underwent a heart transplant in 1987, was released April 16 from a Pittsburgh hospital. The most recent surgery was described as unrelated to the transplant. McGowan said the board of directors approved the dividend despite having second thoughts about committing the Washington-based company to the expense while acquiring Telecom USA. The acquisition, announced April 9, awaits approval by Telecom's shareholders and several government agenies. MCI earned $156 million in the first quarter on revenue of $1.8 billion. For all of 1989, the company's profit rose 58 percent to $529 million on revenue of $6.47 billion. MCI stock was the third-most-active issue Monday in the national over-the-counter market, gaining 37{ cents to $38.25.

DOC.HEAD: Another Round Opens in Regulatory Turf Battle
DOC.TEXT: The jurisdictional turf battle between the federal agencies regulating securities and futures markets moves to the Senate panel that oversees one of the rivals, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The CFTC has been locked in a war of words with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the stock market regulator, over which should oversee financial products that have elements of both a security and a futures contract. So-called hybrid products include stock index futures. The Senate Agriculture Committee was scheduled to hear this afternoon from top officials of the four agencies that make up the White House Working Group on Financial Markets _ the Federal Reserve Board, the SEC, CFTC and the Treasury Department. The group was set up in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash to handle intermarket issues. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan, SEC Chairman Richard Breeden, CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm and Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber were scheduled to appear at the hearing. The four already have aired their views before congressional panels and in numerous speeches and interviews. Breeden and Glauber are on one side. Gramm on the other with Greenspan somewhere in between. Breeden and Glauber think, at the very least, the SEC should be given control of stock index futures. These products _ now controlled by the futures exchanges with CFTC oversight _ allow investors to speculate on the stock market without buying the underlying stocks. A federal appeals court last year ruled that such hybrid products come under the purview of the CFTC if they have the slightest similarity to a futures contract. Breeden has complained that the court ruling discourages financial innovation and drives new products to foreign markets. Greenspan says he is ``slightly in favor'' of giving the SEC control of stock index futures. But he is against merging the SEC and CFTC, which has been proposed in legislation introduced in the House last month. Greenspan also says one agency should be responsible for setting margin limits _ but he doesn't know which one. Margins are the down payments investors must make to buy securities or futures contracts on credit. Margins for the securities markets, usually 50 percent of the total price, are set by the Fed. Margins for futures contracts are set by the exchanges with limited input by the CFTC, and typically are much lower. Critics claim that the disparity in margins limits leads to a trading strategy known as index arbitrage in which speculators, trying to take advantage of brief price differences between the two markets, move huge blocks of stock back and forth. That, say critics, leads to wild price swings that frightens small investors from the stock market. But Gramm disagrees with those criticisms. In a speech to a futures industry conference last week, she said the attempt to grab CFTC authority over stock index futures is driven by ``jealousy'' on Wall Street and ``regulatory imperialism'' at the SEC. In an informal session with reporters last Friday, Breeden said his bid to acquire control of stock index futures was for the good of the economy. ``This is a policy dispute,'' he said. ``This isn't a question of turf.''

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Senses Imminent Defeat But Expects Eventual Victory
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn virtually conceded defeat in his latest battle with USX Corp., but he remains convinced he will ultimately win his crusade to boost the price of the steel-energy conglomerate's stock. Icahn told shareholders at the USX annual meeting Monday he might not have the crucial support of several big institutional investors. He said his plan to break up USX and spin off its U.S. Steel subsidiary apparently would fail. But the takeover strategist, who is USX's largest stockholder with a 13.3 percent stake, told reporters he found ``a strong nucleus of shareholders'' who believe management should do more to improve the company's stock price. Icahn said he would keep talking to these shareholders, and he predicted, ``I think there will definitely be some changes.'' ``I think we made a statement,'' Icahn said of his non-binding proposal, which would have separated the lackluster U.S. Steel from the more robust Marathon Oil Co. Icahn may have been undaunted because he knows how to win this game _ he's done it before. In 1988, Icahn lost a fight to unseat Texaco Inc.'s board of directors at the oil giant's 1988 annual meeting. But several months later, Texaco management decided to undertake a restructuring _ including the sales of billions of dollars worth of assets _ that Icahn had campaigned for as a means of boosting share values. ``We were right at Texaco,'' Icahn told reporters Monday. ``We'll stick around to see that (stock) value appreciate,'' he said of USX. Icahn made a hostile takeover bid for USX in the mid-1980s, but he said another buyout offer is unlikely because the company's ``poison pill'' defense limits the number of shares he could buy. Before the meeting, observers said Icahn eventually could force management to restructure aggressively even if his proposal failed. The company has said it will continue its 10-year-old restructuring, but management wants to accomplish it on its own terms. There was no surge of support for Icahn apparent at Monday's gathering. He received polite applause for his comments, but shareholders who spoke in favor of management and against breaking up the company got a slightly more enthusiastic response. The 3{-hour meeting was attended by some 600 shareholders, most of them individual stockholders and retirees of USX subsidiaries. The meeting largely was uneventful _ the company's biggest shareholders, the institutional investors, did not speak, and many already had submitted their proxies. Results of the vote were not expected for at least a week. Icahn got the most support from the crowd when he complained about the USX stock price, which he contended would improve if his plan were carried out and shareholders were issued separate stock for U.S. Steel and for Marathon. The outcome of Monday's vote was being watched as an indicator of how much strength takeover strategists have in the 1990s, now that the debt-financed takeover boom has ended. In March, takeover strategist Harold Simmons lost a proxy fight that sought to remove the board of directors at Lockheed Corp. The biggest winners in that battle were institutional investors who extracted concessions from Lockheed management.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Takes Proposal to USX Shareholders
With PM-USX, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. may have won its latest battle with Carl Icahn, but the level of support for the takeover strategist's break-up plan should keep pressure on management to bolster the company's stock price. ``This is a corporation that has changed and will continue to change. That is inevitable,'' USX Chairman Charles A. Corry said at the company's annual meeting Monday. Most of the shareholders in attendance showed support for management's fight against Icahn's proposal. It called for the company to spin off its U.S. Steel subsidiary to shareholders, leaving USX as an energy company with its Marathon Oil Co. unit, which is based in Findlay. Icahn conceded his plan was likely to be defeated, but he said he found a significant amount of support among major shareholders. Shareholder Bruce Schoenberger, a Toledo attorney, said he favored Icahn's proposal because it would force management to consider taking some kind of action to boost the stock's value. ``It requires them to at least look at some alternatives,'' he said. About 600 people, mostly small shareholders and retirees, attended the meeting in the auditorium of a junior high school. Institutional investors, the company's major shareholders, did not speak and many already had submitted their proxies. It will take a week or longer to count the votes, said USX spokesman William Keslar. Icahn contends the relatively weak steel business is hampering USX's stock price and is a potential drag on the company if there is an economic downturn. He said he was certain he had the support of the holders of about 80 million shares, nearly one-third of the company's outstanding common stock. But he said several key institutional investors had not told him whether they would support his plan, which Icahn said indicated they might have been leaning towards management. He conceded he may lose the vote but was confident he had succeeded in forcing management to make future changes to enhance shareholder value. ``If we lose we still have an excellent mandate,'' Icahn said. ``Several of the large investors have said, `We agree with you,' he said. ``They agree conceptually something has got to be done.'' Most of the shareholders who spoke at the meeting supported management, saying U.S. Steel needs the capital provided by the oil business. They expressed fear the company could become a takeover target if it sheds the steel business. ``I agree wholeheartedly there will be great need for capital both in the oil and steel business,'' Icahn said in response to one shareholder. ``But why should USX jeopardize the future of the oil business, which is a jewel, and use that capital for steel?'' Icahn received the most applause when he said USX stock is greatly undervalued. The financier has argued that stock in separate steel and energy companies would be worth a total of $48 a share. USX closed down 50 cents at $33.50 a share Monday on the New York Stock Exchange. Peter Rosko, a shareholder and finance professor at the University of Minnesota, said it was uncertain whether the stock would appreciate that much, but he still favored Icahn's proposal. ``Neither division should subsidize the other. Neither should cover the sins of the other,'' he said. In response to Corry's upbeat assessment of the company's 1989 results, Rosko asked, ``Why hasn't the stock moved?'' The audience clapped when Rosko asked Corry to predict what USX stock will be worth in 1992. Corry declined to answer, but said Icahn's analysis of past growth could be misleading because it is based on certain narrow periods. ``The stock price is what it is,'' Corry said. ``The real question before stockholders doesn't deal with that. ``The question before stockholders is: Does this idea make sense? Is it likely to improve things?''

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Brags It Beat Honda
LaserPhoto DT4 of May 7
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. today begins tooting its own horn in advertisements that say two pairs of its cars beat two Hondas in consumer testing. The campaign is the latest effort by the company to shore up its declining sales by attacking Japanese competition head on. ``We're attacking the myth of complete infallibility of the Japanese carmakers,'' Chrysler marketing Vice President John Damoose said Monday at a media briefing on the new television, radio and print advertising campaign. The company's campaign began in March with a television ad showing Chairman Lee Iacocca pacing around a table of company executives and saying the No. 3 U.S. automaker's cars are just as good as their Japanese rivals _ but that no one knows it. The campaign also has included a six-city road show that winds up later this month in Los Angeles with Iacocca reiterating that theme. The automaker also has a safety campaign aiming at Japanese automakers, which supply far fewer cars with air bags than Chrysler does. Late last week, General Motors Corp. began a campaign enlisting all of its active and retired employees and dealers to tell friends, neighbors and acquaintances that the quality of GM cars has improved during the last five years. Ford Motor Co.'s latest automobile advertisements make no quality comparisons with Japanese products. It began its ``Quality is Job One'' theme nine years ago and has no plans to change it. In its new ads, Chrysler will cite a study it commissioned involving 200 Southern California owners of GM or Ford cars who called themselves likely import-car buyers. The study had consumers compare the Honda Accord with the Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim, and the Honda Civic with the Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance. The Spirit and Acclaim are essentially the same car, as are the Shadow and the Sundance. The researchers from U.S. Testing Co. Market Research Inc. of Wheeling, Ill., found that after quizzing the consumers on 33 facets of the cars' operations, 83 percent preferred the Spirit-Acclaim over the Accord and 76 percent preferred the Sundance-Shadow over the Civic. Those results certainly are at odds with recent sales figures. The Accord was the best selling car in the United States last year, with 362,707 driven off dealer lots. The best-selling Chrysler car was the Dodge Dynasty, far down the list with 109,250 sold. Dennis Hill, president of the research company, said he didn't know how many of the survey's participants actually bought one car or the other. Chrysler spokesman A.C. Liebler and Hill declined to say how much the study cost or how much the automaker was spending on advertising. The ad campaign comes at a time when Chrysler's U.S. car sales need a boost. Sales of Chrysler's cars slipped 21.8 percent through the first four months of this year compared with last year. At the end of April, the company's cars held 8.7 percent of the total car market compared with 10.7 percent at the same time last year. Meantime, sales of Honda's cars have risen 4.4 percent, and market share rose to 8.3 percent from 7.4 percent last year. Part of the slide in Chrysler's market share was due to scaling back its presence in the fleet market, which Chrysler said was too costly, and the absence of a subcompact car, a lack caused when the company shut down a Detroit assembly plant in February. ``We knew this would happen,'' Liebler said of the market share decline. Damoose and Liebler declined to say when the effects of the advertising campaign should begin showing up in sales figures, but both were confident that the ads would make a difference.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarket Executives Go on Shopping Excursion
DOC.TEXT: At the supermarket industry's international trade show, executives are finding out what it's like on the other side of the cash register. They're taking a four-day shopping excursion, and the emphasis along the aisles of the marathon McCormick Place convention center is on the healthy, convenient and environmentally friendly. ``In past years, the ... convention has served as a springboard for virtually all of the industry's significant innovations _ from scanning to microwaveable foods,'' said Michael Muldoon, an official of the show's sponsor, the Food Marketing Institute. ``In 1990, the convention will continue to play a vital industry role, taking a hard look at the issues likely to dominate the business in years to come _ especially food safety, health and nutrition, environmental concerns and human resources,'' Muldoon added in a statement. The trade show spanning 25 acres is billed as the largest annual exhibition of its kind and is complete with pyramids of shiny red apples and the aroma of buttery garlic bread samples. An estimated 35,000 visitors are expected to view the stocked displays featured by about 1,000 companies during the show, which ends Wednesday. Grocers of the 1990s are becoming increasingly concerned about health, convenience and environmentally sensitive packaging as they restock their supermarket shelves, said Timothy M. Hammonds, the institute's senior vice president. ``It's happening largely because the baby-boom generation that built the fast-food industry now have families and don't have time,'' Hammonds said. At the same time, the industry is ``using more recyclable material and paying more attention to solid waste,'' he said. Jerry Greenfield, co-creator of Ben & Jerry's ice cream, typified the marketers' increased consumer awareness. On Monday, for example, Greenfield was busy scooping samples of the company's new reduced-cholesterol Ben & Jerry's Light, an ice milk that the Waterbury, Vt., company introduced early this year. ``You won't get skinny eating Ben & Jerry's Light, but you will get one-third less fat and 40 percent less cholesterol,'' the company's promotional material says. Like many other Americans, Greenfield said, ``I'm getting concerned with my fat intake.'' Among the executives sampling the ice milk was Richard Turici, a general manager for Entenmann's Inc. The baked-goods company, based on New York's Long Island, is removing the fat from its products. Turici said a new line of about 12 cholesterol-free, fat-free cakes and cookies has pushed Entenmann's sales up 40 percent. Healthier food is ``what's hot'' among today's consumers, Turici said Kellogg Co. of Battle Creek, Mich., is promoting its health-conscious image by offering to measure cholesterol levels in a booth displaying packaging of two new cereals the company will be marketing. ``It supports our image. Our products have no cholesterol,'' said Bud W. Morgan, vice president of the company's central zone. Cereal, he said, also fulfills customers' need for convenience. The new cereals are Bigg Mixx and Kenmei Rice Bran. Bigg Mixx is a combination of wheat, oat, corn and rice. Aimed at youngsters, the cereal is packaged in a box featuring an animal that's a curiously humorous combination of a chicken, a pig, a wolf and a moose. Kenmei Rice Bran is a rice flake that Kellogg's hopes will catch on the way oat bran cereals have. Responding to increased environmental awareness, several companies exhibited recyclable grocery bags. Continental Extrusion Corp. of Garden City, N.Y., for example, is marketing a re-usable bag with handles of recyclable polyethylene resin. The customer buys a bag for 50 cents and gets 5 cents back each time he or she brings it to the market. The bag should easily last the 10 trips it takes to recoup the cost, said Robert Pachelbel, a sales executive. ``The crux of the matter is ... you're reducing the amount of waste being put out in landfills,'' said Pachelbel. The Washington-based Food Marketing Institute is a non-profit international association with 1,600 members operating about 17,000 retail food stores.

DOC.HEAD: CEO Resigns at Troubled Convenience-Store Chain
DOC.TEXT: Karl Eller, an expansion-minded leader whose name was synonymous with Circle K Corp. for seven years, has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the debt-ridden convenience store chain. Eller, 61, presided over an expansion that saw Circle K grow from 1,200 stores in 1983 to the nation's second-largest convenience chain with 4,685 in 33 states last November. In the process, it rang up debts of $1.3 billion. No replacement was named Monday, but the company said president Robert A. Dearth Jr., 45, would manage operations, with oversight from the board of directors. Spokesman Ray Cox said Eller resigned to pursue personal business opportunities. Cox said Eller and Circle K executives agreed not to comment beyond a statement announcing the resignation. Eller said in the statement that with the company in the process of restructuring, it was time for him to step aside and give the directors the latitude to establish new objectives. Circle K last month halted interest payments to bondholders under a plan designed to restructure its debt load. The agreement with its senior creditors and its largest shareholder, American Financial Corp., gave it a seven-month moratorium on debt and interest payments. Circle K had threatened to file for reorganization under Chapter 11 of U.S. bankruptcy laws if it was denied a reprieve on its debts. The agreement gave bank lenders that have extended nearly $800 million in senior debt to Circle K the right to determine whether the company can pay interest on subordinated debt. Officials have said the restructuring could include exchanging some outstanding subordinated debt securities for new bonds, stock or cash. Circle K is the nation's second-largest convenience store chain behind Southland Corp., owner of 7-Eleven. Circle K has announced plans to sell 350 stores in the Pacific Northwest and another 25 in Hawaii, but Cox said neither sale had closed. Eller, a Circle K director since 1972, became chairman and chief executive in June 1983. The growth in the number of U.S. stores _ in addition to 1,400 licensed or joint ventures overseas _ cost Circle K $850 million, much of it raised through risky high-yield junk bonds issued by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. In addition to rising interest payments, company officials have blamed Circle K's problems on intense competition in the industry, including the spread of convenience stores run by oil companies able to sell gasoline more cheaply. Circle K in March announced a $40 million operating loss for the quarter ended Jan. 31. Analysts said Eller, who in late 1988 told stockholders expansion was the key to the company's survival, failed to provide for stability after growth. ``He built the empire, but it's clear there wasn't anybody beneath him. He didn't build the infrastructure to operate it,'' said Dennis Telzrow, an analyst with the Dallas brokerage Eppler, Guerin & Turner. Telzrow said Eller's departure was expected after Circle K hired Dearth away from United Brands Co. in January. Sheryl Gillett Caudana, granddaughter of Circle K founder Fred Hervey, also criticized Eller's management. ``I felt that he was making some decisions that were not in the interests of either the long-term survival of the company or the stockholders,'' she said. Eller in 1968 founded Combined Communications Corp. and in the next decade built the company into one of the nation's largest mass-media enterprises. He sold the company in 1979 to Gannett Co. and spent the next four years as director of the communications division of Columbia Pictures Industries and as a financial consultant in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Bancorp To Tighten Management Practices
DOC.TEXT: Washington Bancorporation, the second largest banking concern in the nation's capital, has agreed to tighten management practices and procedures after defaulting on about $26 million in short-term debt. The agreement with federal regulators includes a special review of the company's real estate loans, the bank said in a statement Monday. Washington Bancorp's commercial loan portfoilio is heavily concentrated in real estate, a market that has gone into a slump in recent months. Washington Bancorp, the parent of National Bank of Washington, reported a $5.7 million loss for the first quarter of 1990 and a sharp jump in its portfolio of nonperforming loans. The default on $26 million in debt occurred when unrelated banks that had provided backup lines of credit withdrew those assurances, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Signs Trade Pacts With East Germany, Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The European Community signed accords Tuesday with East Germany and Bulgaria, virtually completing the first stage of a bid to boost trade and economic links across a once-divided continent. The EC already signed trade and economic cooperation pacts with the Soviet Union, Hungary and Poland, and on Monday it finalized an agreement with Czechoslovakia. Romania remains the only East European nation changing to democracy and free enterprise with which the EC has no such accord. Negotiations to replace a 1980 pact are expected to open soon. The 10-year accords with Eastern Europe provide for economic cooperation in many sectors, including farming, the environment and easing curbs on imports of East European goods. Currently, trade between Eastern Europe and the European Community totals $50 billion a year, half of which involves the Soviet Union. On April 28, the EC said it was ready to start a second stage of economic relations with Eastern Europe: talks for association accords that also cover political consultations. Yet some East Europeans are eager to become EC members quickly. Czechoslovakia wants to join by 1999. But the EC, citing dramatic differences in economic development, has ruled out full membership for the time being for any East European nation. One exception is East Germany, which will join after merging with West Germany. The 10-year EC-East German accord on trade and economic cooperation signed on Tuesday is a formality. It will be changed once the two Germanys create an economic and monetary union and will disappear with formal unification. Until then, Irish Foreign Minister Gerard Collins said, ``This trade and economic cooperation agreement will help to bring the two parties closer together.'' Collins, whose country holds the EC's rotating presidency, signed the East German and Bulgarian accords on behalf of the EC at two separate ceremonies. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl signed for East Germany and Bulgarian Prime Minister Andrey Loukanov signed for his country. Pohl said East Germany hoped to boost exports of machine tools, textiles, chemicals and electronic products and looked forward to foreign investments from the EC nations. ``Via technology transfer we will be able to get support for our industries,'' he said. The EC-Bulgaria accord provides for ``improved market access (for Bulgarian products) and commercial cooperation, which is an important step towards Bulgarian membership of the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade,'' Collins said.

The stock market was mixed in early trading today as Wall Street awaited the first phase of the government's record quarterly refunding auction. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose a scant .45 to 2,722.07 in the first half hour of trading. Advancing issues were nearly matched by declining ones in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 497 up, 426 down and 535 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.66 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Market analysts said stock prices could be affected by concern about the Treasury's three-day refunding auction this week. The first phase of the auction was scheduled for later today, when the government planned to sell $10.5 billion worth of three-year notes. Lack of strong demand for the government securities over the three days could send interest rates higher, hurting stock prices. That could end the market's six straight days of gains, its longest unbroken winning streak since October. But concern about interest rates was eased by Friday's unemployment report for April, which said the jobless rate rose to its highest level in over a year. That makes it less likely the Federal Reserve would move to raise rates. Among blue-chip stocks in early trading, IBM rose ] to 110~, Exxon was up [ to 46, General Electric rose \ to 66 and Philip Morris was unchanged at 43]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .03 to 186.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained .32 to 347.65. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.26 to 2,721.62. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 947 up, 553 down and 492 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 132.76 million shares, against 140.55 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Say Star Signs Deal To Do Reebok Commercials
DOC.TEXT: Singer and actress Madonna reportedly has signed a deal to do commercials for Reebok shoes. The deal with the leading athletic shoe manufacturer is for at least two commercials, the Boston Herald reported in Tuesday editions, quoting a source it didn't identify. Neither Reebok nor its advertising agency, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, would confirm the deal. ``The association with Reebok and Madonna is a rumor. We have a policy that we don't comment on rumors,'' said Bernadette Mansur, a Reebok vice president in charge of marketing and communications. ``As a general matter, we don't talk about advertising until such time as it is produced or aired,'' said Scott Cheyne of the advertising agency. The star is beginning the United States part of her ``Blonde Ambition'' world tour. The Dick Tracy movie in which she stars with Warren Beatty is due out next month. Reebok and Madonna have been involved in separate, controversial advertisements. Madonna made a commerical for Pepsi Cola last year that was shown once and pulled because of viewer's confused it with a separate music video the Madonna released at about the same time that mixed sexual and religious imagery. The one wearing Reeboks bounces back on a bungee cord, but the other apparently doesn't make it, because the cord comes back without the jumper.

DOC.HEAD: Settle Battle Over Names, Cheese
DOC.TEXT: Old spaghetti may sound cold and clammy, but two restaurant chains thought it was hot enough to fight over in court. The Old Spaghetti Warehouse, based in suburban Garland, has agreed to drop the word ``old'' from its corporate moniker and will pay $400,000 to settle litigation brought by an ``older'' competitor of nearly the same name. About three years ago, the owner of a Portland, Ore.-based chain called the Old Spaghetti Factory filed two lawsuits against the Texas chain. The owner alleged that the Old Spaghetti Warehouse had stolen a recipe using mytzithra cheese _ a Greek cheese made from goat's milk _ and copied the use of trolleys as booths. On Monday, Old Spaghetti Warehouse announced it would scrap ``old'' from the signs on its stores and delete any mention of mytzithra cheese from its menu. But the Garland company, which denies taking its competitor's sauce recipe, will continue to be able to use the special cheese. ``We are pleased that the litigation is finally behind us,'' Robert Hawke, president of the 15-store, $28 million Texas company said. ``This removes a cloud over our future and will allow us to proceed with our franchise plans.'' Old Spaghetti Warehouse opened its first restaurant in Dallas' West End in 1972 and has since opened 14 other company-owned stores in eight states. The company went public in 1985. The Old Spaghetti Factory chain was established in 1970 and has 28 stores. The lawsuits settled Monday were filed in federal court in Atlanta, the only market in which both companies have stores.

The Soviets today were reported in the market for 550-thousand metric tons of wheat. On Monday, the U.S. Agriculture Department announced the Soviets purchased 1.75 million metric tons of corn.
