Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were higher, bolstered by firm cash prices, while feeder cattle prices were hurt by profit-taking. Pork futures were boosted by higher cash prices and light movement of hogs from the farm to processors. Live cattle were .02 cent to .15 cent higher with June at 75.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to unchanged with May at 84.50 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent to .28 cent higheer with June at 65.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent to .60 cent higher with May at 70.90 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled higher in Monday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Munro Steps Down from Top Time Warner Posts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 10 new grafs to reflect Munro announcement, get shareholders meeting underway. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The Delaware ... May stand.
DOC.TEXT: J. Richard Munro, who led publishing giant Time Inc. into a combination with entertainment powerhouse Warner Communications Inc., said today he is stepping down as co-chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner Inc. The announcement, which came at the annual shareholders' meeting of the world's biggest media and entertainment concern, came as no surprise. When Time and Warner announced last year they planned to merge, Munro said he planned to stay on for only a short time to share the chairman and chief executive posts with Warner boss Steven J. Ross. As part of his employment contract, Munro also had a powerful incentive to step down. He is eligible for deferred compensation of nearly $4.3 million if he retires on or before May 31. His departure, effective Wednesday, automatically elevates Nicholas J. Nicholas, the president of Time Warner, into the post of co-chief executive with Ross. Nicholas, 50, is expected to become the sole chief executive on Ross's retirement from that post in July 1994. Munro, 59, joined the company in 1957 and became president and chief executive in 1980. He has been chairman and chief executive since Sept. 1, 1986, sharing those posts with Ross since Time acquired a majority of Warner's stock last summer. The buyout was completed earlier this year. Some Time Warner shareholders are unhappy that they were not allowed to vote on a $200 a share takeover offer from Paramount Communications Inc. that Time spurned in favor of its $14 billion deal with Warner. Time's stock rose as high as $182.75 a share during last summer's three-way takeover fight, but the stock of its successor company, Time Warner, closed Monday at $94.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Munro, Ross, and Nicholas have argued that their plans to combine Time and Warner was a better deal for shareholders in the long run than Paramount's $12.2 billion offer for Time would have been. The Delaware Chancery Court backed them up, ruling in favor of management's right to follow its own ``business judgment'' that a combination of Time and Warner was the better course despite what shareholders might have wanted. That comes as little comfort to some shareholders and their advisors who note the company's stock is trading for less than half of what Paramount offered and near its 52-week low of $87.50 a share. ``Why should shareholders risk their money in American companies when they are treated this way,'' William Steiner, a Time Warner shareholder from Great Neck, N.Y., asked on the eve of the annual meeting. Institutional Shareholder Services Inc., a Washington, D.C.-based consulting firm that advises big shareholders, recommended withholding votes for four former Time Inc. directors up for election at today's meeting. ``Time management was faced here with a choice between a deal carefully crafted to protect its own managers and one that was not, but offered a substantial premium to shareholders,'' the consulting firm said. The deal was completed earlier this year. The combined company is a leader in magazines, film production, recorded music, pay television services and cable TV systems operations. Despite a big debt load stemming from the merger, Time Warner has launched a new weekly magazine, Entertainment Weekly; bought the West Coast magazine and book concern Lane Publishing, and acquired a 19.5 percent stake in the theme parks operator Six Flags Corp. It sold the textbook publisher Scott Foresman and Co. The company recently reported a $187 million loss in the first quarter compared with a loss of $217 million a year earlier. The losses reflected the costs of the buyout of Warner. But it also noted that operating income for the quarter _ excluding interest, taxes and costs of the merger _ was up 16 percent at $536 million, while revenue rose to $2.74 billion from $2.55 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Chairman of Hershey Foods Dies
DOC.TEXT: William E. Schiller, retired chairman of the board of Hershey Foods Corp., has died. He was 81. Schiller had retired from the company in March 1974. He died May 2 at Hershey Medical Center from heart disease, spokeswoman Deborah Saline said Tuesday. He joined Hershey Foods in 1947 as a comptroller and the next year was named treasurer and elected to the board of directors. He became vice president and treasurer in 1956 and chairman of the board and treasurer in 1965. He was a certified public accountant in the Chicago and New York offices of Arthur Andersen and Co. for 14 years before joining Hershey. He was a director of the Hershey Trust Co., Milton Hershey School, M.S. Hershey Foundation and The Hershey Bank. He was a former chairman of the Pennsylvania Chamber of Commerce. He was born in Sydney Mines, Nova Scotia, and received bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Michigan. He is survived by his wife, Mary; two daughters, Kathryn S. MacCarthy of Upland, Calif., and Eileen of Seattle; a son, Carl F. of Aspen, Colo,; two stepdaughters; nine grandchildren; and five great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Say Bush Willing to Discuss Possible Tax Increases
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush likely will rule out raising income taxes but is willing to discuss other tax increases, ranging from a national sales tax to higher levies on alcohol and cigarettes, Republican lawmakers said today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, however, said that the White House would withhold comment on any specific tax _ including income taxes _ in an effort to get unbiased deficit-cut talks launched. ``We start these negotiations from scratch,'' Fitzwater said. He said the type of tax increases that might emerge from a White House-Congress budget summit were ``up to the negotiators.'' ``We aren't specifying what's under consideration. There are no preconditions,'' Fitzwater said. Bush, having abandoned his ``no-new-taxes'' pronouncements, discussed taxes with congressional GOP leaders after Budget Director Richard Darman delivered a gloomy assessment of the economy, said participants at a White House meeting. Darman told the GOP lawmakers that automatic budget cuts in the range of $45 billion to $55 billion _ and possibly even more _ could take place next fall in the absence of major additional deficit-cutting steps, according to both GOP lawmakers and Fitzwater. Republicans said that a range of possible taxes and new ways of ranging revenue were discussed at today's White House meeting. ``Value-added taxes, taxes on booze and cigarettes, a national lottery, a one-cent national sales tax, all sorts of things like that are in the mix,'' said Assistant Senate Republican Leader Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming. However, he added, ``Nobody's talking about raising income tax rates.'' At the hour-long White House session, participants said, Darman told the lawmakers that an automatic budget cut in excess of $55 billion was likely this fall in the absence of major new deficit-cutting steps. That could chop about 20 percent across the board in defense and most domestic programs. Despite the president's earlier pledge against new taxes, Simpson said, Bush ``is fully aware that he's got a country to run. And he's got to do that in a responsible way because lots of figures have changed.'' Simpson, speaking to reporters in the driveway outside the White House, said Darman had spelled out spending cuts so massive that they would be ``totally unacceptable to the American people.'' Participants said Bush listened as GOP lawmakers discussed a variety of tax options, but that he did not voice his own opinion on any particular tax. However, the president reiterated his position that there be no ``preconditions.'' ``We're going to see the economic jitters set in unless somebody assumes some responsibility for the budget,'' said Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss. ``The president is trying to do this. And I applaud him for it.'' House Assistant Republican Leader Newt Gingrich of Georgia said Republicans would not agree to any plan that would hurt them in an election year. ``I'm not going to vote for anything which causes us to lose politically...and we're not going to agree to stupid deals,'' Gingrich said. Asked what kind of taxes might be raised, Gingrich said: ``I don't know. We'll have to wait and see what the Democrats want to discuss.'' GOP leaders have hailed Bush's ice-breaking overtures on the budget. Democratic leaders of the House and Senate, meantime, were meeting with rank-and-file members to gauge their feelings about budget bargaining in an election year. Sixteen top Democrats met for an hour Monday in a closed-door session. ``We've had different views expressed,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said afterward. Pressure has been building for action on the budget because of the slowing economy and the increasing cost projections of the federal bailout of the savings and loan industry. The weaker the economy, the less revenue the government can expect to collect and the greater the federal deficit. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said erlier there would be ``no preconditions'' for budget negotiations. Republicans denied that such a statement is inconsistent with Bush's campaign pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``There isn't any president who hasn't tried to make good on his promises. There's no president who hasn't lived through times that change, and maybe outdate some promises,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, top Republican on the House Budget Committee. Last week, the House passed a Democratic-written spending plan that includes $36 billion in deficit reduction. The Senate Budget Committee approved another Democratic plan containing $43 billion in savings. Both proposals would give the military nearly $10 billion less next year than Bush wants. Bush proposed a budget in January claiming to shrink the shortfall by $36 billion to just under $64 billion. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law requires that next year's budget gap not exceed $64 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower

DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies today in moderate European trading. Gold prices fell. Dealers said trading was affected by uncertainty over the outcome of this week's U.S. Treasury refunding auction, the results of which could influence interest rates and therefore the dollar's value. Higher U.S. interest rates would make the dollar worth more; lower rates would make the dollar weaken. Some dealers also expressed reluctance to trade dollars too heavily ahead of the Friday release of the April U.S. retail sales figures and producer prices, which could provide more insight into the U.S. economy and also influence the dollar's value. The dollar appears to be in a narrow range for the time being, said Jens-Uwe Fischer, a senior dealer at Manufacturers Hanover in Frankfurt, but other dealers said there was room for further declines. DOC.HEAD: Supplying Struts to Toyota
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp.'s Delco Products Division later this year will begin exporting suspension struts to Toyota Motor Corp. in Japan, the U.S. automaker said Tuesday. GM said it expected to supply about 500,000 of the parts a year from its factory in Kettering, Ohio, for use in Toyota Corollas built in Takaoka, Japan. Delco's Kettering plant currently supplies suspension struts to the New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. plant in Fremont, Calif., a joint venture between GM and Toyota; and Toyota's Cambridge, Ontario, plant, both of which make Corollas. Struts also are shipped to Toyota's assembly factory in Georgetown, Ky., where Camrys are made. Delco's plant in Rochester, N.Y., currently supplies windshield washer systems and parts to NUMMI and Toyota plants in Japan and Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: White House Defends Veto Threat
Eds. LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with White House defending veto threat; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `White House...; Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The White House today defended its threat to veto a bill guaranteeing unpaid leave for workers with family emergencies, saying that requiring the benefits could drive up unemployment. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush urges companies to provide paid parental leaves voluntarily, but he is unwilling to force them to do it. Fitzwater defended the adminstration's stance amid criticism from the measure's sponsor that it is a rebuff to working families. ``It would be most unfortunate if my party, which so strongly supports family values, were to turn its back on working families, women, children, grandma and grandpa,'' said Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J. At one point in his daily news briefing Fitzwater suggested that workers ``look for other jobs'' if they or their unions could not negotiate parental leave with their employer. He later backed off that suggestion, saying, ``The high priority is to make work and family complementary. ... We urge all employers to find sensitive and flexible leave policies, but the government should not dictate it.'' ``These are the kinds of rigidity that cause companies to not be able to hire people, and cause greater levels of unemployment,'' Fitzwater said. ``It's at the point at which it becomes mandatory that we say the negative risks outweigh the benefits,'' he said. White House chief of staff John Sununu assured business leaders in a private meeting Monday that Bush would veto the family and medical leave bill scheduled for House action Wednesday. His threat was recounted by business lobbyists who attended the session and was confirmed by a Sununu aide who asked not to be identified by name. The bill has bipartisan support but is opposed by business groups. It requires employers with 50 or more workers to offer unpaid time off with job and benefit protection for the care of newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children, as well as to deal with personal health problems or ill spouses or parents. Roukema, the chief Republican sponsor, called the veto threat ``a complete surprise.'' She earlier had urged the White House to avoid veto threats or ``rash statements.'' ``It's a job security issue for working families,'' Roukema said. The bill's Democratic sponsors denounced the veto threat and said the move would be at odds with Bush's 1988 campaign support for family values. ``I can't believe the kinder, gentler president is going to veto it,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. She said Sununu took leave from his job as a professor at Tufts University while he served as governor of New Hampshire _ and kept job benefits from the university. ``Sununu took family leave himself, and I think he has a lot of nerve,'' Mrs. Schroeder said. Mary Tavenner, a lobbyist for the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, said businesses opposed the measure because of its cost and contended that many employers already offer better benefits. ``There's only so many things an employer can offer,'' she said. Tavenner and Christine Russell, lobbyist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, were among the business representatives invited to the White House meeting. Although there have been proposals to change the length of guaranteed leave, they quoted Sununu as saying Bush would veto any period that was required by law. ``He basically said the president would veto anything that is a mandated benefit,'' Tavenner said. Under the House bill, employers would have to offer up to 10 weeks of unpaid family leave over a two-year period, and up to 15 weeks in one year for a sick worker. An employee returning from leave must be restored to his or her previous job or an equivalent position, and employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave. Federal workers would have the same guarantees with a longer unpaid leave: 18 weeks for family leave over two years and 27 weeks a year for medical leave.

DOC.HEAD: Management Change at Leading Sweetener Company
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Tate & Lyle PLC, one of the world's leading sweetener companies, announced a top-level management change Tuesday at the New York-based Amstar Sugar Corp. subsidiary acquired two years ago. Tate & Lyle said William Shanley, Amstar's president and chief executive officer, will step down Oct. 1 to become president of another Tate & Lyle subsidiary, Tate & Lyle Inc. Shanley will be responsible for U.S. government and legislative liaisons on issues affecting the sugar industry, as well as relations with the American investment community, the company said. His replacement at Amstar will be Jack F. Lay, presently senior vice president. Tate & Lyle, headquartered in London, is a major producer of sweeteners and starches, with operations in Europe, Africa and the Americas. Besides Amstar, purchased in 1988, the company's U.S. holdings include A.E. Staley Manufacturing Co., Western Sugar Co., and Pacific Molasses Co.

DOC.HEAD: EC Opens Dumping Inquiry on South Korean Car Radios
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive commission Tuesday opened an anti-dumping inquiry into car radio imports from South Korea after receiving a complaint from an industry group. The anti-dumping complaint was brought by the Association for Legal-Auto Radio Measures, comprised of major European manufacturers Philips NV, Grundig AG, and Blaupunkt-Werke GmbH. The group, which makes more than 70 percent of EC-made car radios, said that by forcing EC car radio prices down, the South Korean exporters had caused considerable profit cuts and job cuts among EC manufacturers. According to the complaint, 5.8 million South Korean car radios were sold in the 12-nation trade bloc in 1988, up from 1.7 million in 1985, raising South Korea's market share to 32 percent from 14 percent. The EC manufacturers' share in their own market fell during the same period to 33 percent from 49 percent. If the South Korean companies are found to have been dumping car radios on the European market at prices lower than at home, the EC can impose retaliatory duties on their car radio exports. In a statement, the commission said a comparison between internal South Korean prices for car radios and prices charged for comparable exports to the EC showed that ``the alleged dumping margins are important.'' The South Korean concerns named in the complaint are Sinbang Electronics Co.; Korea Electronics Co.; Osio Electronics Co.; Carspec Electronics Co.; Sunkyong Limited; Woojin Electric Co.; Tongkook Electronics Co.; Hyundai Electronics Co.; Daewoo Corporation; Haitai International Inc.; Sherwood (Inkel), Dongwon Electronics Co.; Samsung Electronics Co.; and Shindong Electronics Co.

DOC.HEAD: Commodities Scandal Trial Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with beginning of jury selection, ruling to allow defense to present evidence of clients' lawful behavior. Picks up 5th graf pvs, ``Also stung ...
DOC.TEXT: Fewer dollars may be involved, but prosecutors say the trial of three futures traders concerns offenses no less serious than those committed by Wall Street felons Ivan Boesky and Michael Milken. ``Cheating is cheating,'' said U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson. Jury selection began today in the U.S. District Court trial of Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz, three traders of Swiss franc futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. They are accused of swindling customers. They represent one of four groups of Chicago futures traders _ 47 in all _ who were indicted last year after an unprecedented sting. FBI agents posing as corrupt traders secretly tape recorded conversations that the government contends reveal organized fraud among traders at the Merc and the rival Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest futures exchanges. U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams decided Monday and today to allow defense lawyers to introduce evidence of their clients' lawful behavior to show that the difference between legal and illegal trading is unclear. Also stung by the investigation was a clerk who has pleaded guilty, along with 15 of the traders, to reduced charges in exchange for cooperation with prosecutors. None has been sentenced. Prosecutors have not revealed how much money they believe was stolen by traders, saying only that the alleged schemes involved hundreds of investors and thousands of trades. The scandal dealt a black eye to the reputation of the futures markets, which already were perceived as freewheeling, in much the same way the insider trading cases of the 1980s tarnished the image of the stock market. The Chicago exchanges and their federal regulators responded with tougher anti-fraud measures, and Congress is considering proposals to strengthen the integrity of the markets. New York commodities lawyer Thomas Russo said the scandal probably involves less money and public harm than the Wall Street insider trading cases, in which Boesky and Milken paid fines and restitution totaling $700 million to settle criminal charges. But Russo said: ``I think the amount of money is not the material issue in these cases. It goes beyond dollars to the integrity of the markets.'' Mosky, Scheck and Zatz are charged with multiple counts of mail or wire fraud and violations of the federal Commodity Exchange Act. Each count carries up to five years in prison. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy, for which he could be sent to prison for 20 years and be forced to forfeit personal assets including exchange membership. In court documents, the government has portrayed Mosky as a ringleader who persuaded Scheck and Zatz to accept the responsibility and costs of trading errors he made while executing customer orders in the Swiss franc trading pit. The government contends Mosky later repaid Scheck and Zatz by manipulating customer orders, sometimes via trades conducted illegally outside the pit. The government's evidence includes the FBI tapes, mountains of trading records and the expected testimony of two other Swiss franc traders, each of whom pleaded guilty in August.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Chief Praises Strike Bill
DOC.TEXT: Teamsters General President William McCarthy has warned Congress that the 1.8 million-member union will not contribute to any political candidates who do not support a bill that protects strikers' jobs. Union officials attending a convention of about 800 union members that began Monday voiced praise for the bill sponsored by U.S. Rep. William Clay. McCarthy said the bill was critical to the survival of the labor movement. The bill would bar companies from permanently replacing striking workers with new employees. Clay, D-St. Louis, is one of labor's strongest allies in Washington. In a statement recalling Clay's criticism of former President Ronald Reagan's firing of striking air-traffic controllers in the early 1980s, Clay said his bill would ``stop this insanity ... and save the labor movement from annihilation.'' Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-St. Louis, told the Teamsters that such a law was needed because most U.S. companies had adopted an attitude that ``greed is good.'' ``The majority feel that the way to compete is to beat it out of your workers ... break them if you can,'' Gephardt said. Daniel Ligurotis, chairman of the Central Conference of Teamsters, said the right to strike was being abridged by the hiring of replacement workers. ``This repulsive practice, which in the past was done only by the most vicious employers, is now the rule rather than the exception,'' he said. The Teamsters union contains five conferences: Central, South, East, West and Canadian. The Central is the largest, with 491,000 members in 13 Midwestern states, including Missouri and Illinois. Missouri has 50,000 Teamsters. The Central Conference meets every four years. This year's convention is being held at the St. Louis Sheraton Hotel and runs through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders sold to take profits despite reports the Soviet Union was in the market for a major wheat purchase. At the opening, wheat prices gained support from reports the Soviets were buying 550,000 metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program. But technical selling set in with the lack of follow-through buying by traders. DOC.HEAD: International Paper Company Elects Directors, Hears Labor Complaints
DOC.TEXT: International Paper Co.'s shareholders overwhelmingly re-elected six directors to the board Tuesday despite calls from a union representative to bring ``new blood'' into the company. Although most of the proxy ballots were submitted before the morning meeting, a union representative criticized the board's selection and urged shareholders to withhold their votes. ``There's no new blood, no new ideas,'' said Ed Garvey, an attorney for the United Paperworkers International Union, which has members who work in International Paper's mills. The company, which reported a 19.3 percent drop in its first quarter earnings, is engaged in a labor dispute involving union members at several U.S. mills where employees have been working with a contract, said Garvey. The paperworkers union, which represents about 28,000 of the company's 30,000 hourly workers, is not threatening to strike because several strikes in recent years at individual mills were unsuccessful, Garvey said. Striking workers were replaced, he said. During the meeting, Garvey said many workers perceive John A. Georges, International Paper's chairman and chief executive, as the ``Frank Lorenzo of the paper industry.'' Lorenzo, chairman of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., has been involved in bitter labor disputes and strikes with that company's Eastern and Continental Airlines subsidiaries. About 250 people attended the 1{-hour meeting during which several people urged management to negotiate with union locals. The six directors were re-elected to the 14-member board by more than 99 percent of the vote. They were Georges; Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of General Motors Corp.; Willard C. Butcher, chairman and chief executive of Chase Manhattan Corp.; Thomas C. Graham, president of the USS division of USX Corp.; Donald F. McHenry, a Georgetown University professor; and Edmund T. Pratt, chairman and chief executive of Pfizer Co. Purchase, N.Y.-based International Paper is the world's largest producer of such products as packaging papers, business communications papers, commercial and magazine printing papers, corrugated containers, photographic papers and films, lumber and wood products. International Paper also is involved in oil and gas exploration and drilling and real estate. The company's 1989 sales totaled $11.4 billion. For the 1990 first quarter, International Paper's earnings declined to $180 million from $223 million for the same period in 1989. First quarter sales were $3.2 billion this year and $2.6 billion a year ago. Georges told shareholders that although 1989 was a ``great year,'' growth was expected to slow. ``Our view of the (domestic) economy in 1990 anticipates GNP growth in the area of 1.5 to 2.0 percent. If this holds true, operating rates of most of our major businesses should hold up reasonably well although these rates will be lower than in 1989,'' he said. ``Prices in some product lines have declined, and they remain under pressure.'' But Georges also said that recent European acquisitions ``put us in a very good position to participate in the continent's economic growth.'' Shareholders also rejected proposals to divest the company's investments in South Africa and adopt a confidential voting procedure. The South Africa proposal has been rejected at past meetings. The board opposed it, saying that Masonite Ltd., a producer of wood and other fibers, has a ``distinguished record in race relations,'' Georges said. In addition, about 92 percent of the workforce is non-white, he said. The facility is integrated and provides equal pay for equal work, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Weather Hampers Pipeline Repair
DOC.TEXT: Texaco Inc. said Tuesday that bad weather in the Gulf of Mexico prevented divers from investigating and repairing a broken pipeline that has leaked about 37,000 gallons of oil. Texaco spokesman Max Hebert said the leak in the 20-inch pipeline apparently had stopped and oil was breaking up in rough seas. The largest slick is about a mile long and 400 yards wide, though still far from shore, he said. The leak from the Texaco-operated Eugene Island pipeline occurred about 100 miles off the Louisiana coast. Winds of 25 miles per hour and four-foot to six-foot seas prevented Texaco's three skimmers from removing any oil from the water. More bad weather was forecast for Thursday. The 112-mile-long pipeline, which serves 36 drilling platforms, is operated by Texaco and owned by Texaco, Marathon Oil Co., Exxon Corp., Mobil Corp., Chevron Corp. and Conoco Inc. The system, in which oil from offshore wells is piped to shore, was shut down early Monday. The pipeline normally handles about 95,000 barrels a day. Texaco Chairman Alfred DeCrane mentioned the spill at the company's annual meeting Tuesday and said Texaco was committed to the environment and had has practiced ways to deal with spills. Separately, Texaco President and Chief Executive James Kinnear said the company plans to invest in new technology to increase reserves from existing fields by 14,000 barrels a day in 1990 and 1991. In addition, a total of $365 million will be invested in refineries to allow production of an additional 85,000 barrels a day in the United States and 39,000 abroad, he said.

DOC.SECOND: Prepares 14 Million Tax Returns in Fiscal 1990
DOC.TEXT: H&R Block Inc. said Tuesday it prepared 14 million tax returns in its fiscal year ended April 30, a 7.1 percent rise over the previous year. H&R Block, which won't report 1990 corporate earnings until June, said the number of returns prepared by its company-owned and franchised offices worldwide was up from 13.1 million returns in fiscal 1989. The figures do not include refunds prepared elsewhere but brought to H&R Block to be filed with the IRS electronically. A total of 2.9 million returns were filed electronically under the company's Rapid Refund program, up from 825,279 the previous fiscal year. Rapid Refund was in operation in virtually all U.S. offices during the 1990 tax filing season, compared to only one-third of company-owned and two-thirds of franchised offices during the 1989 tax filing season, H&R Block said.

DOC.HEAD: Fined $58,900 for Safety Violations at Two Jeep Plants
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. was fined $58,900 for dozens of safety violations at its two Jeep plants in Toldeo, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration said Tuesday. OSHA area director Arnis Andersons said Chrysler was cited for 68 violations, including a lack of machinery and equipment guards, improperly stored flammable material, inadequate wiring and employees without protective eyewear. The inspection from November through February was initiated after a Jeep employee complained in October about several alleged safety problems, Andersons said. The plants employ 5,300 people and produce Jeep Cherokee and Grand Wagoneer models. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said that the company had not reviewed the report, but the company would correct any problems ``that our safety and health people agree need to be corrected.'' Despite the fines, Andersons said the plants, built at the turn of the century, did well considering their age and size. ``There has been remarkable, remarkable improvement from what we saw from a safety point of view,'' he said. ``They are really striving to improve the workplace conditions.'' Andersons said OSHA the Toledo plants had not been examined in seven years and had a high employee accident rate in the past.

DOC.HEAD: One-Stop Shopping, More Low-Fat Foods Predicted for Future Supermarkets
DOC.TEXT: Supermarkets will have to offer more low-fat products, environmentally conscious policies and one-stop shopping conveniences like banking to compete in the 1990s, industry leaders said Tuesday. The ``mom and pop'' grocery may be taking a step into the past at the Food Marketing Institute's trade show, which covers more than 1 million square feet of space and involves more than 1,000 companies, chiefly food retailers. Topics of discussion include new-age trends such as ``micromarketing'' to target individual tastes of shoppers and hiring more minorities to help erase an image of a white-male dominated business. ``The supermarket truly is the microcosm of the lifestyle of America,'' and must reflect the changes in lifestyle to survive, said Timothy Hammonds, senior vice president of the Food Marketing Institute. The Washington-based group, whose 1,600 members operate about 19,000 retail food stores nationwide, said a survey of 1,005 shoppers found that fat content beat cholesterol and salt as the biggest nutrition concern for consumers. The nationwide survey, based on telephone interviews, was conducted in January and released Tuesday, the third day of the four-day meeting. Two years ago cholesterol was the biggest concern, Hammonds said. Shoppers surveyed this year said they are buying more fruits and vegetables, more chicken and fish, and less meat and fatty products. Store managers are responding to these changes by stocking their shelves accordingly, Hammonds said. An increasing number of supermarkets are addressing the nation's solid-waste crisis by recycling, said Patrick Collins, president of Ralphs Grocery Co., a supermarket chain based in the Los Angeles area. Collins said 87 percent of wholesalers and retailers pick up recyclable waste products from their stores for consolidation at distribution centers. Another trend is one-stop shopping, which has turned the neighborhood grocery store into a self-contained mini-mall offering services ranging from in-store restaurants to banking. ``All supermarkets will be doing that'' to meet the needs and time pressures of two-income families, Hammonds said. ``It doesn't mean the small store or convenience store is going to go away, but they'll have to specialize'' to stay afloat, he said. As more women and minorities enter the work force, supermarkets must make an effort to hire them, and not just for entry-level positions, said Henry Hailstock, manager of minority affairs for Giant Food, Inc., a Washington-based supermarket chain. Giant has worked with local college placement directors to recruit minority students, and has established internships designed to provide on-the-job training for minorities. The effort is aimed in part at promoting the retail industry as a career, and not just as a part-time job, Hailstock said.

DOC.HEAD: MIT Not Only Responsible For New England Growth, But California Too
DOC.TEXT: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which took credit last year for the explosive growth of the New England economy in the 1980s, now can point to a new study that says its graduates have built up Silicon Valley too. But the report's author and officials at other schools caution against reading too much into the work. MIT alumni have started some 176 companies in northern California, accounting for about $22 billion in sales and more than 90,000 jobs, according to a report conducted by Chase Manhattan Bank for the research university. About 90 of the companies are in Silicon Valley, the region south of San Francisco named for its concentration of high-tech businesses. ``It shows there's been a remarkable concentration of MIT alumni who have contributed to the formation and growth of Silicon Valley,'' said John Larson, an MIT fundraiser. But the report's author said the findings did not necessarily point to a single-school domination of the region. ``If you added up for all the schools (in the nation) the list of the companies they considered to be related to the school, the sum of all those on the list would exceed the population of companies in this country by a wide margin,'' said Richard Aspinwall, the Chase Manhattan vice president and economist who conducted the study. Also, many companies have several founders, not all of whom went to the same school, and many founders may have been educated at more than one institution. For example, a company might have been founded by three people who are graduates of MIT, Harvard and Stanford, Aspinwall said. Officials at other schools also discouraged drawing too many conclusions from the study. ``We have an awful lot of graduates too that are walking around Silicon Valley,'' said a professor of electrical engineering and computer science at the University of California at Berkeley. ``It's very difficult to get in to MIT, students have to be very bright and ambitious, but exactly the same is true for Stanford, exactly the same is true for us,'' said the professor, who declined to be identified. ``The tie (in Silicon Valley) to Stanford is much stronger than to MIT,'' said Karen Bartholomew, a Stanford spokeswoman. Jim Aisner, a spokesman for Harvard Business School, echoed: ``I'm sure a lot of Harvard Business grads have founded lots of firms. A good number of our grads go on to be entrepreneurs.'' Still, he said, ``there are an awful lot of good schools. This makes perfect sense that a lot of those firms were founded by MIT graduates.'' The Chase report is not the first such study for MIT. Last year, the Bank of Boston did a study of the companies begun by MIT graduates in the Massachusetts area. That report, released in June, said 636 businesses started by MIT graduates in Massachusetts accounted for more than 300,000 jobs in the state and about $10 billion in annual income for state residents. Although the Massachusetts economy has hit hard times, and growth in California has slowed as well, MIT can point to its graduates as a driving force in Silicon Valley, Aspinwall said. ``The companies started by MIT graduates in Silicon Valley have been sources of strength,'' Aspinwall said. ``The companies have grown more rapidly than their industry as a whole, and they've grown more rapidly than companies in Silicon Valley as a whole.'' Abe Lederman, who graduated from MIT in 1981 with a master's degree in computer science, was one of five MIT alumni who founded Verity Inc., a computer software manufacturer based in Mountain View, Calif. ``MIT prepared you to work really hard and (taught) the entrepreneurial ethic and stuff. At MIT people are pretty smart and all that,'' said Lederman, 32. ``What helps being at MIT is having all these really bright people that work really hard.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed mixed in U.S. foreign exchange trading Tuesday after strengthening slightly in Europe, but money brokers said the underlying direction of the American currency remained unclear. Gold prices fell. Republic National Bank in New York quoted bullion at $369.90 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, down $1.80 from late Monday. Currency strategists said a few outside influences were affecting the dollar Tuesday, notably pent-up appetite for dollars in London after a three-day holiday weekend there and a surprisingly good sale of new U.S. debt securities at a quarterly Treasury refunding auction in Washington. The dollar demand helped strengthen the currency, but the Treasury auction discouraged dollar buying because it suggested U.S. interest rates won't rise significantly, some traders said. That could make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors relative to other key currencies. Despite the Treasury auction's immediate effect, Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, suggestedthe long-term trend for dollars would remain strong. But Scott Greene, chief dealer for the New York branch of Switzerland's Banco Julius Baer & Co., suggested that the currency of choice increasingly looked like the West German mark, reflecting the optimism about the economic dynamism expected from a reunited Germany. ``The vulnerable side is the down side for the dollar,'' Greene said. ``All we need is a slight push there.'' Others expressed reluctance to trade dollars, preferring to await the final outcome of the Treasury auction, which goes through Thursday, as well as any economic insight derived from statistics on April U.S. retail sales and inflation, due to be released Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 158.13 Japanese yen from 157.80 yen Monday. Later in London it fell to 157.92 yen. By the time trading closed in New York the dollar fetched 157.63 yen, down from 158.15 yen Monday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6697 from $1.6710 late Monday on European markets. London markets were closed Monday for a national bank holiday. By the time trading closed in New York the pound fetched $1.6705, worth more than its $1.6685 value late Monday. Other late-dollar rates in New York compared with late-Monday levels: 1.6575 West German marks, up from 1.6556; 1.4310 Swiss francs, unchanged; 1.1639 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633; 5.5685 French francs, up from 5.5615; 1,216.00 Italian lire, up from 1,214.50. In gold trading, bullion for immediate delivery on the New York Commodity Exchange fell $1.90 a troy ounce to $370.00. Earlier in London, gold fell $369.75, down from $371.45 bid Friday. The London market was closed Monday. In Zurich, gold fell $1.70 an ounce to $369.00, and in Hong Kong gold rose 32 cents to $373.42. Silver for immediate delivery fell 2.7 cents an ounce to $4.989 on the New York Commodity Exchange. Earlier in London silver fell 4 cents an ounce to $5.01.

DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris Moving 500 Jobs Out of New York City
DOC.TEXT: Philip Morris Cos. said Tuesday it will move 500 jobs, almost one third of its Manhattan work force, to a half-empty building it owns north of New York City. The company said its Manhattan offices have become overcrowded and its lease on additional rented office space in the city expires in September 1991. Moving are Philip Morris International, the company's overseas tobacco arm, and Philip Morris Capital Corp., a financial services company. The relocation to the former General Foods Corp. headquarters in Rye Brook in Westchester County will begin this year and should take about a year, spokeswoman Alice T. McGillion said. Philip Morris acquired the building when it bought General Foods in 1985. Many of the employees there moved to Glenview, Ill., after Philip Morris bought Kraft in 1988 and formed Kraft General Foods. Philip Morris currently employs 1,700 people in New York City. No jobs will be eliminated as a result of the move, McGillion said.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices jumped Tuesday in the final minutes of trading as the market cheered the outcome of the first phase of a record-sized auction of government debt securities. The gain extended the market's winning streak to seven trading days in a row, its longest unbroken rally since last July. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 11.94 to 2,733.56. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 813 up, 650 down and 518 unchanged. The Treasury's quarterly refunding auction consists of $30.5 billion in notes and bonds sold over three days. At the first part of the auction Tuesday, the government sold $10.5 billion worth of three-year notes at an average yield of 8.74 percent. The sale was considered a success, said Dudley Eppel, managing director of equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Some market watchers had feared the interest rate on the notes would go even higher to attract buyers; higher interest rates tend to depress stock prices. But results of the auction weren't released until a few minutes before the market closed, keeping stock prices in a narrow range most of the day. The Dow average was up 1.13 points on the day as of 3:45 p.m. EDT. But minutes later the auction results were released, sending prices climbing. By the closing bell at 4 p.m., the Dow had shot up more than 10 points, ending 11.94 higher for the day. Eppel said the market's real concern over the refunding auction will come Thursday, when the Treasury plans to sell $10 billion of 30-year bonds. These bonds are considered a bellwether for long-term interest rates. In between, on Wednesday, the agency will sell $10 billion of 10-year notes. ``We still have another couple of days,'' Eppel said. ``But it looks like so far, so good.'' Among most-active blue-chip stocks, IBM rose \ to 110} and Philip Morris rose \ to 43|. Among other blue chips, American Telephone & Telegraph was up \ to 40|, General Motors rose { to 46} and Union Carbide gained ] to 19~. The Dow Jones Professional Investor Report said Nippon Life Insurance and Chubb might bid for the insurance company, which has put itself up for sale. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market grew $11.197 billion, or 0.34 percent, in value. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose .61 to 431.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose .25 to 347.58.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasts of Rain Push Cocoa Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices declined sharply Tuesday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange as rain forecasts improved crop prospects in Africa and South America. On other markets, frozen orange juice futures surged, livestock and pork futures declined, grain and soybean prices retreated, energy futures were mixed, and precious metals declined. Cocoa futures settled $55 to $68 lower with the contract for delivery in May at $1,215 a ton. Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merril Lynch & Co. in New York, said cocoa prices in recent weeks had been supported by reports of dry weather in West Africa and Brazil. Weather forecasts call for the end of the dry pattern and the start of a rainy period. Contributing to the drop in cocoa prices was the triggering of sell stops as futures broke through the $1,250-a-ton support level. Frozen orange juice prices surged on New York's Cotton Exchange as the market reacted to continued tight supplies. The U.S. Department of Agriculture crop report due out Thursday is expected to increase the orange juice crop estimate, Ganes said. She said the estimate could be revised upward by 2 million to 3 million boxes, but the increase will not make much difference in the supply and demand balance. Frozen orange juice was 2.5 cents to 4.6 cents higher with May at $1.968 a pound. Grain and soybean futures prices were lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders sold to take profits despite reports the Soviet Union was in the market for a major wheat purchase. At the opening, wheat prices gained support from reports the Soviets bid for 550,000 metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program. But technical selling set in with the lack of follow-through buying by traders. Corn was performing well through most of the day as the market reacted to Monday's announcement that the Soviets purchased 1.75 million metric tons of corn, but sold off towards the end of trading. William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc., said many traders concluded there will be no further purchases by the Soviets. But after the close of trading, the USDA announced it has raised the amount of grain the Soviets can purchase in 1989-1990 to 22 million metric tons from 20 million metric tons. Soybean prices drifted lower due to low buyer interest at current prices, Biedermann said. Wheat was 3} cents to 6{ cents lower with May at $3.78 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1} cents lower with May at $2.89 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents lower with May at $1.66 a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents lower to a { cent higher with May at $6.33{ a bushel. Precious metals prices declined on New York's Commodity Exchange as the Soviets and other countries sold gold and other metals to finance their grain purchases, said Richard Levine, an analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York. Gold was $1.90 to $2 lower with May at $370 a troy ounce; silver was 2.7 cents to 3 cents lwoer with May at $4.989 a troy ounce. Livestock and pork futures dropped sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with the onset of profit-taking, with frozen pork bellies down the daily limit. Live cattle were .45 cent to 1.28 cents lower with June at 73.92 a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .83 cent lower with May at 84.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .60 cent to 1.50 cents lower with June at 63.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.35 cents to 2 cents lower with May at 68.30 cents a pound. Energy prices were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the market shrugged off reports of a fire at Chevron's El Segundo, Calif., refinery and a leak in a Texaco pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was. 25 cent lower to 3 cents higher with June at $18.28 a barrel; heating oil was .32 cent lower to .90 cent higher with June at 51.34 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .01 cent to .62 cent higher with June at 62.48 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: End Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose Tuesday, strengthened by European demand and fears of supply disruptions from a Gulf of Mexico pipeline shutdown, but traders said a late bout of selling left the market only slightly higher. ``We basically finished not far from where we started,'' said James R. Fiedler, an energy futures broker at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the June-delivery price of West Texas Intermediate, a key grade of high-quality crude, rose 1 cent per barrel to $18.28, after trading as high as $18.58 earlier in the day. Later-month contracts, however, were mostly lower. Among refined products traded on the exchange, June-delivery wholesale home-heating oil rose .9 cent a gallon to 51.34 cents. Later-month contracts were mixed. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for June delivery rose .62 cent a gallon to 62.48 cents, and later month prices strengthened as well. Natural gas for June delivery strengthened to $1.583 per 1,000 cubic feet, vs. $1.580 Monday. Subsequent month contracts were little changed to slightly higher. Energy futures brokers said the main influences in the market were pent-up demand in Europe, where the London market was closed Monday as part of a three-day holiday. They also said an apparently broken pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico, which serves 36 six drilling platforms and handles 95,000 barrels a day, might cause supply disruptions to refineries just as they are preparing to process large quantities of crude for the summer driving season. Texaco Inc., which runs the Eugene Island pipeline system, said Tuesday that bad weather had prevented divers from determining the exact cause of the problem. The pipeline was shut down on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Founder of Atari To Join Commodore
DOC.TEXT: Commodore International Ltd. said Tuesday that Nolan K. Bushnell, the founder of Atari Inc. and the developer of the first video game system, will head a team at the computer maker to develop consumer products. Bushnell, 47, will coordinate and market consumer-interactive products for Commodore based on its Amiga line of personal computers. ``I think we are creating something really special for the marketplace,'' Bushnell said, declining to elaborate. ``I think you'll be quite excited with what's going on.'' He said the new products would be introduced at a consumer electronics trade show in June. Commodore manufactures and markets personal computers for home, education, business and professional users. Its recent emphasis has been in multimedia computers, which combine video, text, graphics and sound on the same screen.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Plans To Cut Oil Exports
DOC.TEXT: Mexico is considering a cut in oil exports in order to take care of domestic industrial needs, the government said in a five-year energy plan. The cut in exports would be to 1 million barrels a day from a current 1.23 million barrels. Almost all of the exported oil would go to the United States, Japan and Spain, the plan by the Secretary of Energy, Mines and Industry said. The report said production levels likely will remain at the current level of about 2.5 million barrels a day through 1994. The static production along with domestic needs for refined petroleum and the existing refining capacity means ``the volume of crude destined for export necessarily will see a gradual drop,'' the report said. The plan, released last week, calls for a more efficient use of energy and increased energy prices within Mexico. It said Mexico would save its resources and put money it might have spent on the oil infrastructure into other areas. Mexico said oil prices were not expected to increase significantly soon and likely would not reach record levels set in 1980-81 before the end of the century. Mexico, which is not a member of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, gets 33 percent of its export revenue from oil and lists itself as sixth in the world in oil production.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Execs Got $4 Million in Bonuses as Thrift Lost $590 Million
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Savings & Loan Association's top executives got $4 million in bonuses in 1989, even as the S&L's vast junk bond holdings led to a $591.1 million loss for the year. The thrift's proxy statement, mailed Monday in advance of the company's June 5 annual meeting, shows that 17 current or former Columbia executives received a total $9.5 million in compensation last year, including the bonuses. The statement also shows that government regulators were so unhappy with the extraordinarily high pay of former Columbia chief Thomas Spiegel that they forced him to return or forgo at least $1.1 million in compensation. Columbia said Friday it lost $293.3 million during its first quarter due to continued losses on its $3 billion portfolio of junk bonds, the biggest collection of the high-yield, high-risk securities assembled by any S&L. Spiegel, who stepped down as chairman and chief executive at the end of last year, is trying to find a buyer for the bonds. Spiegel was a close associate of convicted Drexel Burnham Lambert financier Michael Milken, whose network of junk bond buyers included many thrifts. Spiegel, a former Wall Street bond trader whose father founded Columbia, once was the highest paid thrift executive, earning $9 million in cash and bonuses in 1985. He earned $898,922 in salary and other compensation last year. In November 1989, under pressure from federal regulators, he repaid $600,000 he received as part of a $4.1 million pay package in 1988, the proxy showed. The proxy also reveals that Spiegel was to have received $500,000 per year in return for his efforts to sell the junk bond portfolio, which were announced when he stepped down at the end of 1989. Due to objections from the Office of Thrift Supervision, however, that amount was reduced to a nominal $1 per year, the proxy shows. Spiegel continues to receive a benefits package and an administrative budget of $17,400 per month to cover an office, an assistant, a secretary and other costs. Columbia, once one of the nation's strongest thrifts, now has a negative net worth of $215.6 million and is in danger of being seized by federal regulators. It is $338.3 million short of the capital it is required to maintain under the standards adopted last year when the government bailed out the federal insurance fund for thrifts. Besides Spiegel, many of the other executives who received large 1989 bonuses have since left the company. The largest amount went to Christopher S. Moore, an executive vice president in corporate finance who received $1.35 million in 1989, including a $1.15 million bonus. He resigned two months ago. Lawrence K. Fish, who resigned as president in August, received $1.32 million in compensation last year, including a $820,000 payment when he left. Edward G. Harshfield, hired to replace Spiegel, is guaranteed a $500,000 yearly salary but has performance-linked bonus provisions in his contract that could bring his total pay to as much as $3 million. Harshfield also is permitted to continue as a general partner of a Merrill Lynch-sponsored investment fund he had headed before joining Columbia in March. The fund was established to bail out struggling savings and loans. It had hoped to raise $100 million, but managed to find investors willing to put up only about $30 million.

DOC.HEAD: USX To Sell Energy Properties for $193 Million
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. said Tuesday it will sell $193 million worth of oil and gas wells to two companies. The exploration division of Sonat Inc. will purchase $140 million worth of wells and other facilities from USX, said Thomas Barker, finance vice president for Birmingham, Ala.-based Sonat. Most of the assets are in Arkansas, he said. Atlantic Richfield Co. will buy 175 working natural gas wells in southwestern Oklahoma, said Earl Sims, a spokesman for Atlantic Richfield's energy division. Atlantic Richfield said the wells produce 14 million cubic feet of natural gas daily. Sims wouldn't disclose what Atlantic Richfield would pay for the wells, but the difference between USX's total sale price and what Sonat said it would pay is $53 million. Officials at both Sonat and Atlantic Richfield said they would not operate the USX properties as joint ventures. Pittsburgh-based USX said it expects to complete the sale in from two to three months. Texas Oil & Gas Co., the USX division that owns the properties, accounted for about 5.5 percent of the company's 1989 sales. USX's sale announcement comes a day after shareholders voted on New York financier Carl C. Icahn's proposed splitting of the corporation's steel division and energy holdings, including Texas Oil & Gas.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Washington Real Estate Magnate Accused of Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: The son of a Washington real estate magnate was accused Tuesday of illegally passing confidential information about one of his father's deals to a friend who allegedly traded on the inside information. In a civil complaint filed at federal court in Chicago, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused B. Francis Saul III of violating the Insider Trading Act of 1984. The SEC also charged Saul's friend, Peter David Garvy. Both men are 28 and Chicago residents. In 1988, the SEC alleged, Saul, son of B. Francis Saul II of Chevy Chase, Md., told Garvy, a former school roomate, about a proposed tender offer one his father's companies, Westminster Investing Corp., had made for another Saul concern, the B.F. Saul Real Estate Investment Trust. According to the complaint, Garvy bought 5,500 shares in the investment trust before the tender offer was made public. The complaint also charged that Garvy told his father, Eugene, 70, of Hinsdale, Ill., and a friend, Betsy Perk, 29, of Chicago, about the pending deal and they purchased shares in the Saul trust. The complaint does not accuse the elder Saul, Garvy's father or Ms. Perk of any wrongdoing. ``This kid is totally innocent. He's taken a lie detector test and passed it 100 percent,'' said Saul's attorney, George Rogers. ``We intend to fight it immediately as soon as we can get to trial and we expect to win.'' Rogers said he was surprised the SEC was bringing the case despite a federal appeals court decision in New York last week that overturned an insider trading case in which a broker received merger information from a client whose family owned the company in question. ``Sometimes people have to be told twice. No one's ever accused the government of being smart,'' said Robert Stephenson, Garvy's attorney in Chicago, adding that his client also denied the charges and would seek a quick trial. The SEC charged that Garvy, his father and Ms. Perk made a total of $61,000 in profits using the information supplied by the younger Saul. The SEC is seeking from both Garvy and the younger Saul, who was not accused of trading for himself, a total of three times the total illegal profits, or $183,000, in penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Plan Would Give SEC Control Over Stock-Index Futures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `The committee ...' to UPDATE with comments from Chicago Board of Trade; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Glauber said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Tuesday it will introduce legislation this week stripping the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of control over stock-index futures. The announcement marks a victory for the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates the nation's stock markets, in a turf battle with the rival CFTC, which oversees U.S. futures markets. Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber told a Senate panel the administration wants the SEC to have authority over all stock-related financial products, including stock-index futures and stock-index options. The committee chairman, Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, D-Vt., after complaining that the proposal would further delay futures market reform legislation, said he would ask Senate leaders to bring it to the floor for action. In Chicago, Thomas R. Donovan, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, complained that the proposal ``would solve a perceived problem only to create a very real one by placing futures markets under two regulators.'' Such a transfer of authority ``is clearly just the first step of creeping regulatory imperialism,'' he added in a lengthy statement released by the CBOT. Glauber said the administration believes that one market regulator should control all aspects of the financial community, but that creating a new agency or merging the SEC and CFTC could take too much time. ``Instead, the administration supports a less sweeping approach that would only unify regulation of the `one market' of stocks, stock options and stock-index futures under the SEC,'' he said. Glauber described the SEC as ``the agency with the greatest expertise in the combination of these products.'' While the CFTC and SEC ``are doing a good job under difficult circumstances,'' Glauber said the answer to the jurisdictional dispute was to simplify ``regulatory fragmentation.'' The administration plan also calls for giving the SEC control of setting margins, the down payment investors must make when buying stocks or futures contracts on credit. Glauber announced the administration plan in testimony before the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees the CFTC. The dispute centers on which agency should oversee financial products that have elements of both a security and a futures contract. These so-called hybrid products include stock-index futures. Leahy complained the dispute has held up passage of a bill that adds several market reform measures to the CFTC's reauthorization. ``Congress remains blocked from enacting the tough reforms we all agreed are needed,'' he said. Leahy also said the committee ``should consider responsible, appropriate solutions _ possibly even the ultimate merger of the SEC and CFTC if this is shown to be justified and feasible.'' John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association, who sat in on the hearing, said: ``There'll be no jurisdictional change this year. But it sure mucks up the reauthorization scene, which I think everybody will agree is unfortunate.'' The Senate hearing began as the first trial stemming from a massive fraud investigation into the Chicago futures exchanges got under way with jury selection Tuesday. Last year, 47 traders and one clerk were indicted on various fraud charges following an FBI undercover probe at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest futures exchanges. In the wake of that scandal, the CFTC was criticized roundly by several members of the Senate Agriculture Committee last fall for being too lax a watchdog. The committee was scheduled to hear from representatives of the four agencies of the White House Working Group on Financial Markets, which was set up in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash to handle intermarket issues. In addition to the Treasury's Glauber, other witnesses testifying were Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan, SEC Chairman Richard Breeden and CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm. The four already have aired their views before congressional panels and in numerous speeches and interviews. Breeden and Glauber are on one side, Gramm on the other with Greenspan somewhere in between. Breeden and Glauber have said the SEC should be given control of stock-index futures, which now are controlled by the futures exchanges with CFTC oversight. The products allow investors to speculate on the stock market without buying the underlying stocks. Gramm has said the attempt to grab CFTC authority over stock-index futures is driven by ``jealousy'' on Wall Street and ``regulatory imperialism'' at the SEC. Previously Greenspan has said he is ``slightly in favor'' of giving the SEC control of stock index futures. But he is against merging the SEC and CFTC, which was proposed in legislation introduced in the House last month.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Office Supply Company Proprietor Gets Award
DOC.TEXT: President Bush honored the proprietor of a Storm Lake, Iowa, office supply company as National Small Business Person of the Year. ``Small business is the backbone of the U.S. economy,'' creating two out of every three new jobs, Bush told 175 people at a White House ceremony Tuesday where the Small Business Administration awards were presented. Roberts' Iowa Office Supply, Inc., has grown from a small retail outlet to a company with $8.5 million in annual sales and 55 employees. Also honored were: Phyllis Apelbaum, president of Arrow Messenger Service, Inc., of Chicago, the first runner-up, and two second-runners up, G. David Mathews, president of Ozark Mountain Enterprises, Mountain View, Ark., and Joseph and Helen Massimino of Oatmeal Studios, Rochester, Vt. Ozark Mountain Enterprises makes hand-forged iron products. Oatmeal Studios designs greeting cards and other novelty items.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Says Times Herald Not Harmed By Comics Switch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to RESTORE dropped word `unfairly' in lead, CORRECT triple damages explanation; picks up 4th graf pvs, `We feel ...'
DOC.TEXT: By MICHAEL GRACZYK=

A jury on Tuesday said the Dallas Times Herald was not harmed unfairly by the loss of 26 comics and features last fall to its larger rival, The Dallas Morning News. The jury voted 10-2 in declining to award damages to the Times Herald, which contended that the Morning News and its parent, A.H. Belo Corp., violated anti-trust laws by taking over the features in a move to drive the Times Herald out of business. The Times Herald had asked for $33 million in actual damages and what its attorneys termed significant punitive damages. The $33 million, under Texas antitrust and conspiracy laws, would have been tripled if the Times Herald lawsuit had been successful. ``We feel strongly we have been vindicated,'' said Robert Decherd, Belo chairman. ``The law and the facts of this case have been with us all along. We never doubted the outcome. If you apply the law to this case, there was no case.'' Times Herald Publisher John Buzzetta said, ``I'm disappointed,'' then hurriedly left the courtroom with his attorneys. ``We'll keep on fighting,'' said Times Herald attorney Wayne Fisher. The Times Herald released a statement later saying, ``We disagree that the conduct of our competitor was legal or proper in any way. In fact, it was wrong in many ways _ wrong morally, wrong ethically, wrong for the profession of journalism and wrong for Dallas and its people.'' The lawsuit challenged a Belo joint venture with Universal Press Syndicate that stripped the Times Herald of features including Doonesbury, Dear Abby, The Far Side and Erma Bombeck. Jurors deliberated five days before reaching the verdict Tuesday afternoon. The jurors were asked: ``Did A.H. Belo Corp. or The Dallas Morning News Co. willfully attempt to achieve monopoly power in a relevant market or markets?'' Jurors earlier asked about the definition of ``willfully'' and whether the relevant market in the case was the newspapers or the features. State District Judge David West accepted a response proposed by Belo and Morning News attorneys and over the objections of Times Herald lawyers. The Times Herald had contended the features transfer violated antitrust laws, was intended to strengthen Belo and Morning News market dominance in Dallas and drive the Times Herald out of business. The suit also alleged that Morning News and Belo officials conspired to get the features and interfered in the Times Herald's contract with Kansas City-based Universal Press Syndicate. Belo and The Morning News defended the deal as a good business decision. It will use syndicate comics characters in television programs and commercials to encourage newspper readership. A syndicate requirement of the venture mandated that all Universal Press features in the Times Herald be moved to The Morning News. The Times Herald said the five-year deal and The Morning News' right of first refusal for any new syndicate features amounted to a restraint of trade. The Times Herald estimated the features loss cost it a permanent circulation drop of 10,800, which their experts calculated was worth the $33 million. Morning News attorneys repeatedly referred to circulation figures that showed the Times Herald is in better shape now than it was before the features were moved. Times Herald officials, however, testified that in order to stop the circulation slide, they began a $1 million reader lottery promotion to boost circulation. Times Herald witnesses termed the lottery a short-term and temporary solution. The Morning News' daily circulation was an estimated 355,000 and the Times Herald's 225,000, according to the 1989 Editor & Publisher Yearbook.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Readies Heavy Resources to Help Eastern Europe, Third World
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-11: ``On another,'' statement on environmental program; pvs graf 6, now graf 12: ``Bargaining over,'' edited for transition; DELETES grafs 13-15 pvs bgng: ``The finance,'' outdated by new material. Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: International Monetary Fund officials approved a record $60 billion increase in resources Tuesday to meet growing demands for assistance from emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and debt-strapped nations in Latin America. The authorization from the IMF's policy-setting interim committee came after the panel adopted a U.S.-backed proposal to crack down on countries that are delinquent in repaying their IMF loans. The 50 percent increase, which still must be approved by the voting membership of the 152-nation fund, would boost IMF lending resources to $180 billion. Third World countries had fought to double IMF resources, contending $240 billion is needed to ensure that economic assistance to Eastern Europe does not crowd out support for Latin America and Africa. B.T.G. Chidzero, finance minister for Zimbabwe, said greater support from the IMF and its sister lending organization, the World Bank, was critical to avert ``falling into a crisis of international development finance in the present decade.'' On another matter, the finance officials stopped short of endorsing a proposal to create an environmental fund in the World Bank to supply $1.3 billion in low-interest loans over three years. The money would be used to address cross-border environmental problems such as global warming, the growth of deserts, river system pollution and destruction of the ozone layer. France is backing the new fund, but the United States and several other countries are opposed. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, in remarks prepared for Tuesday's closed-door sessions of the Development Committee, called the environmental issue ``of great importance'' to the United States. But he said approval of the new fund should be delayed until questions concerning current World Bank environmental programs were addressed. In a statement, the Development Committee said that it had agreed that ``further work was necessary'' on the proposal and that in the meantime the World Bank should ``take steps to reinforce its existing environmental programs.'' French Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy had pleaded with other countries to approve the program now and warned, ``time is passing.'' Bargaining over the increase in IMF resources at times became intense, according to participants in the meetings. Arguing for the U.S. position, Brady noted the administration must win suport for the proposal from a Democratic-controlled Congress. Canadian Finance Minister Michael Wilson, head of the interim committee, said that to get the final agreement, ``each country had to put a little water in its wine'' and accept compromises. The United States, which had wanted to delay the next round of funding negotiations until 1995, agreed to a 1993 date. In return, the United States achieved a key demand for tougher procedures for poor countries that owe $4 billion in back payments to the IMF. Delinquent countries who adopt economic reforms would be eligible for money from a special IMF fund. However, nations behind in their payments could lose their voting rights. Also, the agency could sell gold roughly equivalent to the members' original contributions to meet the obligations of defaulting debtors. The 11 nations behind in their payments are the Sudan, Zambia, Peru, Costa Rica, Honduras, Guyana, Somalia, Sierra Leone, Cambodia, Vietnam and Panama. The IMF increase was also tied up with a diplomatic question of the rankings of the biggest economic powers in the fund. The rankings govern how much voting power the nations have. America's No. 1 ranking and voting strength was left unchanged at 19 percent. However, Japan vaulted from No. 5 to No. 2, tied with West Germany. Britain, previously ranked No. 2, dropped into a tie for fourth place with France. On another matter, Polish Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz told reporters he had held discussions during the two-day meetings on Poland's efforts to reduce its $41 billion foreign debt. Balcerowicz reported progress in negotiations with commercial banks using debt-reduction guidelines called for by Brady. But he indicated less success in the effort to cut Poland's debt owed to other governments. Reducing the debt burden is critical for Poland to keep political support for its crash program to replace four decades of communism with a free-market economy, he said.
